heading: Kidnapping from lawful guardianship
HeadNote.description:
Kidnapping from lawful guardianship - Authority of lawful guardian - His authority would be valid against everybody except the natural guardian or other lawful guardian - He cannot initiate criminal proceedings u/s.361 of I.P.C. against natural guardian of the child.

Section 6 of the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act provides that natural guardian of a Hindu minor in the case of a boy or an unmarried girl is father and after him the mother. However, it provides that custody of a minor who has not completed the age of 5 years shall ordinarily be with the mother. Difference between the natural guardianship and custody is well understood. Father of a Hindu minor is guardian though, mother may be in custody or she may be entitled to custody upto certain age. In the present case Vikas was aged about 12 years when the alleged incident occurred. Therefore, he was minor and as such in view of the provisions of Section 6 of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, the petitioner, being father, was natural guardian of the boy. He was the lawful guardian of the child and he continued to be lawful guardian even when the boy was removed from Z. P. Primary School, Pargaon by taking transfer certificate by his mother. Explanation to Section 361, I.P.C. provides that the lawful guardian in the said Section includes any person lawfully entrusted with the care or custody of such minor. It may be said that when Vikas was admitted in S.O.S. Bal-Gram hostel, he was for the time being in custody of the Director of that Bal-gram hostel and in view of the explanation to Section 361, I.P.C. the said Director would be included within the definition of lawful guardian. As such said Director, while in lawful custody of the child, was also lawful guardian but his authority as lawful guardian would be valid against everybody except the natural guardian or lawful guardian. He could not challenge authority of the mother who had put the child in the school nor he could challenge the authority of the father who is natural guardian and as such the lawful guardian of the child. If anybody other than the petitioner No.1 would have enticed or taken away the child from the said hostel without consent of the Director, such person could be said to have committed offence of kidnapping from lawful guardian U/s.361 of I.P.C. However, this would not be applicable in case of lawful and natural guardian i.e. father.  [Para 6]

heading: Specific performance
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Specific performance - Suit for - Plaintiff's case that since suit property is situated near city, defendants were facing difficulty for its cultivation - After converting suit property into non-agricultural use, defendants agreed to sell same to plaintiff for consideration of Rs.3 lacs - Since defendants 3 to 5 were minors, defendant 1 being Karta agreed to obtain necessary permission from District judge - Although plaintiff had performed his part of contract by paying amount, defendants avoided to execute contract - Defendants took defence that suit agreement was nominal security towards debt and that said agreement is not binding on minors - Held, alienation of joint family property by Karta would bind minor when transaction is effected for legal necessity or benefit of family or estate - Plaintiff adduced no evidence to prove that as fact proximity to city renders cultivation of suit field difficult - Endorsement on suit agreement that Rs.1 lac is received to enable defendant 1 to enter into agreement to purchase another land - Does not necessarily suggest that suit agreement is executed for legal necessity or for benefit of family or estate - Suit agreement cannot bind minor children of defendant 1 - Order of Trial Court directing refund of amount is restored - Suit partially decreed. (2011) 12 SCC 220, AIR 1983 Orissa 135, 1964 ALLMR ONLINE 19 (S.C.), AIR 1966 Kerala 266, AIR 1957 AP 744, AIR 1938 Nagpur 476, AIR 1917 Privy Council 33 Ref. to. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - By minors upon attaining age of majority - On count that alienation made by their mother was without obtaining permission of Court u/S.8(2) of 1956 Act - Plaintiffs had only undivided interest in joint family property which was suit property - S.8 and S.6 of 1956 Act apply only to separate or absolute property of minors - Therefore, mother of plaintiffs was not required to take permission u/S.8(2) of 1956 Act - Dismissal of suit, proper. 2014 ALL SCR 127 Disting. 1996 (8) SCC 54, 2000(2) ALL MR 331 Rel. on. 	(Para 13)

heading: Suit for possession
Suit not maintainable
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - On ground that alienation made by mother of minors was without permission u/S.8(2) of 1956 Act - No prayer was made for setting aside of sale-deed - Suit not maintainable - As in absence of permission u/S.8(2) of 1956 Act when sale-deed was executed, it was voidable at instance of minor and that in such situation prayer for setting aside of sale-deed was necessary - Unless plaintiffs prayed for setting aside of sale-deed, they could not have sought decree for possession - Dismissal of suit is proper. 2004 (13) SCC 480, AIR 2000 SC 1099, 1993 (2) SCC 402, 2004 (13) SCC 480 Ref. to. 	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: Specific performance
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Specific performance - Grant of decree against minors - Challenge on ground that permission of Court u/S.8 of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956 not obtained - Respondent-plaintiff claiming that minors after attaining majority have not filed suit challenging agreement of sale within period of limitation therefore, they were estopped from taking such plea by way of written statement - Not acceptable - Limitation Act prescribes period of limitation for filing proceedings either suits, applications or appeals - If those proceedings are not taken within prescribed period, remedy is lost - It does not mean that right is extinguished - Limitation Act does not prescribe period of limitation for filing written statement - It is governed as per O.8 of CPC - Grievance that permission of Court u/S.8 of Act of 1956 not obtained, can be taken in written statement - Mother of minors raised grievance in written statement when defendants were minors - It shows intention to avoid contract - Decree of specific performance directing minors to execute sale deed, cannot be granted. (2002) 3 SCC 676 Rel. on. (Paras 14, 19, 20, 21)

heading: Against minors
Necessity of
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Against minors - Permission of Court u/S.8 of Act of 1956 - Necessity of - Plaintiff seeking specific performance of agreement of sale executed by father of minors - Property sought to be sold is separate property of father - Permission of Court u/S.8 of Act of 1956 is required. (Para 17)

heading: Against minors
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Against minors - Natural guardianmother on behalf of minor children can give consent for execution of sale deed on basis of agreement for sale executed by their predecessor-in-title - However, minor can challenge it on attaining majority on ground of not obtaining permission of Court u/S.8 of Act of 1956. (Para 18)

heading: Suit on behalf of minor
HeadNote.description:
Suit on behalf of minor - To be filed by 'next friend' - No requirement as to appointment or even obtaining permission by court - Concept of 'next friend' or 'guardian ad litem' is different from 'guardian' as defined under Guardianship Act - Any person who is of sound mind, major and whose interest is not adverse to minor, may act as next friend - Further, representation by 'next friend' is purely temporary and only for the purpose of a particular law suit.

	Not only, is there no provision for appointment of next friend by the Court, but the permission of the Court is also not necessary.

	"Guardian" as defined under the Hindu Guardianship Act is a different concept from the concept of "next friend" or the "Guardian ad litem". Representation by "next friend" of minor plaintiff or by "guardian ad litem" of minor defendant is purely temporary, that too for the purposes of that particular law suit.

	There is no hurdle for a natural guardian or duly constituted guardian as defined under Hindu Guardianship Act to represent minor plaintiff or defendant in a law suit. But such guardian should not have adverse interest against minor. If the natural guardian or the duly constituted guardian has adverse interest against the minor in the law suit, then a next friend or guardian ad litem, as the case may be, would represent the minor in the civil litigation.

	It is by now well settled and as per the provisions of Order XXXII of Code that any person who is of sound mind, who has attained majority, who can represent and protect the interest of the minor, who is a resident of India and whose interest is not adverse to that of the minor, may represent the minor as his next friend. Such person who is representing the minor plaintiff as a next friend shall not be party to the same suit as defendant.

	The principles arising out of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 and the Hindu Guardianship Act may not be apposite to the next friend appointed under Order XXXII of the Code.

AIR 1949 Madras 859, AIR 1972 Allahabad 81, AIR 2006 Kerala 138 Ref. to. 	 [Para 8,9,11,12]

heading: Not justified
HeadNote.description: Suit on behalf of minor - Filing by elder brother - Challenging sale deed executed by their father - Dismissal of suit on ground that during life time of father, elder brother cannot represent minor - Not justified - Suit is not governed by Guardianship Act but by O.32 of CPC - Interest of father being adverse to minor son, father cannot act as 'next friend' - Representation by elder brother would be proper - Order of dismissal set aside - Matter remitted back for fresh decision on merits. 			(Paras 6, 9, 10, 13, 17)

heading: Guardianship of minor girl
HeadNote.description: Guardianship of minor girl - Girl was brought up by both parents till the age of 7 - Girl was surreptiously removed by her mother from the custody of her father when she left the matrimonial home - Her custody was obtained under Court's order by the father and minor girl chose to stay with the father when she was interviewed by the Court - Father was lawyer by profession and was financially stable and not disqualified in any way from being guardian of minor child - Child was also well looked after by elder sister of respondent father - Held interest of the minor will be best served if she remains with the father but with sufficient access to the appellant to visit her at frequent intervals without disturbing her studies and other activities.	(Paras 25, 26)

heading: Guardian of minor
No evidence led
HeadNote.description: Guardian of minor - After death of mother - Custody of minor was with father of the demised mother - Application by father of minor under S.19(b) - No issue framed as to competency of father - No evidence led - Matter remitted to frame issue and to give opportunity to both parties to lead evidence and then to decide application of father under S.19(b).  (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction - Application for guardianship of minor - It is the District Court in whose jurisdiction minor resides has the jurisdiction to entertain and decide application - Economic condition or resourcefulness of parties to proceedings cannot be considered. 	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Guardian
HeadNote.description:
Guardian - His status and duties.

A Guardian stands in a fiduciary relation to his ward and he is not supposed to make any profit out of his office. On being appointed as Guardian of the property of minor, he is to act as a trustee and he cannot be permitted to gain any personal profit availing himself of his position and such action of the Guardian while dealing with the property against the interest of ward would be voidable in the eye of law. 			    [Para 13]

heading: Oral gift of property to guardian in lieu of his services as guardian
HeadNote.description: Oral gift of property to guardian in lieu of his services as guardian - Has no sanctity in eye of law.			(Para 14)

heading: Appointment of a guardian
HeadNote.description: Appointment of a guardian - Welfare of child is paramount consideration - Word "welfare" is to be construed literally and taken in its widest sense - Guardianship cannot be decided on the basis of rights of the parties.			(Paras 10, 13, 14)

heading: Consideration
HeadNote.description:
Interim custody of the child - Consideration - Is welfare of the child and not rights of parents. 

The controlling consideration governing interim custody of the child is the welfare of the child and not the rights of their parents. As such, the sole consideration to be weighed by the Court is what would be good for the paramount welfare of the child and nothing else. The Court will also have to examine what prejudice would occasion to such welfare by not changing the custody which is in existence at the time of the filing such application. To consider these aspects, the Court takes into consideration several factors such as the child's immediate environment and surrounding emotional security provided by those who have their custody and what would be conducive for the child to try and grow and become a good human being. Whenever there are conflicting demands of the parents the Court does not look into such claim on legalistic basis but takes the decision considering the welfare of such child. 

2010 ALL SCR 357, 2001(2) ALL MR 237 (S.C.) Rel.on.       [Para 8]

heading: Custody of child
Relevant considerations
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Relevant considerations - Relevant Statutes and legal rights of parents, have to be taken into account - However, issue not to be decided solely by interpreting legal provisions - Court is neither bound by statutes nor by strict rules of evidence or procedure nor by precedents - In selecting proper guardian, paramount consideration should be welfare and well-being of child - Wishes of child, also relevant. 	(Paras 22, 33)

heading: Interim custody
Challenge
Father remarried
HeadNote.description: Interim custody - Order directing father to hand over child to mother and providing police assistance to mother for securing child's custody - Challenge - Girl child aged more than 10 yrs. - Having resided in Canada with her mother for more than 7 yrs. after divorce of her parents - Father remarried - Child still wishes to live with her father in India and does not want to go back to Canada - Child being more than 10 yrs. of age, understands about her welfare - Order of court below disregarding her wishes, not justified - Allegations of parties against each other as to not taking proper care of child, tutoring child, documents and articles pertaining to child's mind and doctor's opinion etc. are all matters to be considered during trial - Not relevant at interim stage - Even as per Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, father is first natural guardian, mother comes after him - Impugned order liable to be set aside - Father entitled to interim custody - Mother can apply for visitation rights during pendency of matter. (2000) 9 SCC 745, 2009(1) ALL MR 925 (S.C.), 1982 ALLMR ONLINE 221 (S.C.), (2003) 10 SCC 760, 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 1686, 2018 ALL SCR (Cri) 1145, 2017 ALL SCR 588 Disting. 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 337, 2008 ALL SCR 2016, 2008(5) ALL MR 948 (S.C.), ILR 2003 KAR 1205, 2018 ALL SCR 2316 Ref.to.			(Paras 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 31, 32, 40, 44)

heading: Appointment of Guardian
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Guardian - Welfare of child of 11 years - Petitionerfather, a superrich, influential foreign national - Child born in India but having dual citizenship of Kenya and U.K. - Child in various personal interactions by Family Court, High Court and Supreme Court, found to be bright, self-confident and articulated - Had great clarity about his preferences and aspirations - Nationality, relevant aspect to be given due consideration - Educational opportunities which would be available to child is an aspect of great significance - Objection by mother that petitioner was being racist, not established - Allegation of marital infidelity against petitioner, not established - Pending criminal proceedings against petitioner for alleged dam outburst in his family farms, not valid ground to refuse custody of child to him - In view of facts it would be in best interest of child to transfer custody of child to his father i.e. petitioner - However, mother cannot be kept out of further growth, progress and company of her son - Thus, she would be provided with temporary custody of child for 50% of his annual vacations once a year either in New Delhi or Kenya - Custody of child handed over to father subject to obtaining mirror order from Kenyan Court to reflect directions given by Supreme Court. (Majority view - Per Indu Malhotra, J. (for herself and on behalf of Uday Umesh Lalit, J.)

A reading of the plaint of the Guardianship petition shows that respondent father relies upon availability of his parents in Kenya to take care of the child and, on the other hand, stress on the physical condition of appellant’s mother to look after the child. I find that the entire basis to seek appointment as guardian of the child is the availability of his parents in Kenya and the physical condition of appellant’s mother. The entire basis is incorrect as in the presence of parents of the child, the grandparents are not the determining factor to appoint a guardian. The question of where does the welfare of the child lie thus narrows down to the mother who has stopped practicing law to nurture child as against the father who travels quite substantially every month. In the absence of the father, the child will be in the custody of nannies, maids and servants. The grandparents would not be able to take care of the growing needs of a young child. All things being equal, the presence of grandparents can tilt in balance but where a mother who is available 24/7 for guiding, caring and nurturing a growing child as against a father who needs to travel outside his normal place of stay frequently, I find that the mother is more suitable in whose hands the welfare of the child is secured. (Para 76)

The question required to be examined is whether this Court should permit the child to be out of its supervisory jurisdiction so as to be a mute spectator to the possibility of defiance of the order of this Court. I am of the opinion that welfare of the Child would be to stay in India with his mother who has brought up the child for last 11 years. The Child is intelligent but not mature enough to take decisions by himself. Even, the law recognizes that the child of less than 18 years is incapable of representing himself. Therefore, any opinion of the child is not determinative of the final custody of the child but this Court as parens patriae is duty bound to assess the entire situation to return a finding whether the welfare of the child will be with the mother with visitation rights to the father or custody with the father with visitation rights to the mother. If the child is moved to Kenya, there is no way that this Court can enforce the orders to get the child back to India, even if it so desires. (Para 124)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Respondent father, pending proceedings, has met children regularly with grant of visitation rights - Children aged 17 and 13 years respectively are capable of understanding where their welfare lies - Children during interaction in Court never spoke ill of their father - But when it came to choosing a particular parent for purposes of custody, they preferred their mother - Welfare of children lies by allowing mother to retain custody of children. 			(Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Sale by guardian without prior permission of court
HeadNote.description: Sale by guardian without prior permission of court - Is not ab initio void but only voidable - Minor on attaining majority filing a suit for recovery of possession from purchaser but no prayer made for setting aside sale - Three years after minor applying for amendment of plaint to rectify the defect when period prescribed for seeking such relief had elapsed - Held suit was liable to be dismissed.	(Para 9)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Welfare of child is a paramount consideration - Daughters aged 17 and 11 years respectively were living with their father and are in his custody - On detailed interaction, both of them were firm that they want to continue to live with their father and did not want to go with their mother - On facts and circumstances, custody with father need not be disturbed - However, ends of Justice would be met by providing visitation rights to mother. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description:
Scope of - Power of natural guardian of Hindu minor - Natural guardian of a Hindu minor has power, subject to the provisions of S.8, to do all acts which are necessary or reasonable and proper for the benefit of the minor or for the realization, protection or benefit of the minor's estate - Held, protection of the interest of minors alone should be the necessary criteria.

Natural guardian of a Hindu minor has power, subject to the provisions of S.8, to do all acts which are necessary or reasonable and proper for the benefit of the minor or for the realization, protection or benefit of the minors estate. The import of this section is that protection of the interest of minors alone should be the necessary criteria. Further, sub-section (2) of section 8 of the said Act specifically bars the natural guardian to mortgage or charge, or transfer by sale, gift, exchange or otherwise, any part of the immovable property of the minor; or lease out any part of such property for a term exceeding five years or for a term extending more than one year beyond the date on which the minor will attain majority or disposal of the immovable property etc. without permission of the Court.  [Para 15]

heading: Habeas corpus for custody of minor
HeadNote.description:
Habeas corpus for custody of minor - Custody of minor who is below 5 years is "ordinarily" and not "necessarily" to be with the mother - Mother on her own leaving house when child was only a month old - Alleged detention of child by father would neither be illegal nor without any authority of law - Habeas Corpus cannot be issued - Petition dismissed.

The submission of the learned counsel for the applicant that the custody of the minor child below 5 years has to be given to the mother under all circumstances is patently erroneous.  From a bare reading of the provisions of Section 6-A of the Act it is clear that the custody of the minor who is below 5 years should ordinarily be with the mother.  The word 'ordinarily' does not mean "necessarily".  Once the matter is before the Court under Section 6 of the Act, the Court would consider all aspects of the matter including the provisions relating to the welfare of the minor.  The Court can also consider the provisions of Section 19 of the Guardians and Wards Act.  In view of the aforesaid, the detention of the child by the father of the opposite party was neither illegal nor could it be said to be without any authority of law.  The applicant has misused the process of the Court by invoking the writ jurisdiction of habeas corpus.   [Para 9]

heading: Alienation of property
HeadNote.description: Alienation of property - Mother of minor child can sell property owned by her as a guardian of the child - However, such alienation has to be justified - Fact that legal necessity existed has to be proved by the purchaser of such land. (1973)7 BLR 267 & AIR 1983 Kar. 222 - Rel. on.	(Paras 10 and 11)

heading: Custody of growing child
HeadNote.description: Custody of growing child - Custody of minor girl given to father - Child attaining age of puberty - Mother making application for custody of child - Held, company of mother is most vital and important for over all development - Availability of other members and relatives in the family of the father cannot be equated with the company of the mother - Even if the child is hostile today against the mother, it is the company and love of the mother that can change her attitude towards the mother. AIR 1973 SC 2090 - Followed.	(Paras 5 and 6)

heading: Alienation of minor's property by guardian
HeadNote.description:
Alienation of minor's property by guardian - Previous permission of court - Restriction does not apply to undivided share of minor.

Hindu Law - Undivided Share of minor - Alienation.

Section 8 of the Act of 1956. Prevents natural guardian of Hindu minor to transfer by sale, gift, exchange or otherwise any part of immovable property of the minor without previous permission of the Court. This restriction on the natural guardian in relation to the property  of the minor applies only to the separate or absolute property of the minor. It does not include the minor's undivided share in the joint family property, as, under Section 6, there cannot be a natural guardian in respect of such property which is specifically excluded.  [Para 8]

Under  the Hindu Law, the manager or karta of the family of the minor can alienate minor's undivided interest in the joint family property without the permission of the Court, provided  alienation is for legal necessity or for the benefit of the minor and this right is left untouched by the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956.  [Para 11]

Consequently, rejection of application filed by the guardian under S.8, for permission is legal and  valid.  [Para 12]

heading: Visiting rights
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Visiting rights - Single Judge giving custody of child to father and visiting rights to mother - Appeal - Division Bench depriving mother of her visiting rights though respondent had not objected - Held such further adverse order was not justified, visiting right restored and order further modified to entitle her to custody on Saturdays, Christmas and summer vacation.(Para 3)

heading: Guardianship
Gender equality
HeadNote.description:
Guardianship - Gender equality - Word "after" in S.6(a) must be read as "in absence of father" - Section 19(b) of Guardians and Wards Act has to be construed similarly.

Guardian and Wards Act (1890), S.19(b) - Does the word "after" in the Section mean only 'after the lifetime' ? If this question is answered in the affirmative, the section has to be struck down as unconstitutional as it undoubtedly violates gender-equality, one of the basic principles of our Constitution. The HMG Act came into force in 1956, i.e., six years after the Constitution. Did the Parliament intend to transgress the constitutional limits or ignore the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution which essentially prohibits discrimination on grounds of sex ? In our opinion - No. It is well settled that if on construction a given statute will become unconstitutional, whereas on another construction, which may be open, the statue remains within the constitutional limits, the Court will prefer the latter on the ground that the Legislature is presumed to have acted in accordance with the Constitution and courts generally lean in favour of the constitutionality of the statutory provisions.  [Para 9]

Section 6(a) is capable of such construction as would retain it within the Constitutional limits. The word 'after' need not necessarily mean 'after the lifetime'. In the context in which it appears in Section 6(a) (supra), it means 'in the absence of', the word 'absence' therein referring to the father's absence from the care of the minor's property or person for any reason whatever. If the father is wholly indifferent to the matters of the minor even if he is living with the mother or if by virtue of mutual understanding between the father and the mother, the latter is put exclusively in charge of the minor, or if the father is physically unable to take care of the minor either because of his staying away from the place where the mother and the minor are living or because of his physical or mental incapacity, in all such like situations, the father can be considered to be absent and the mother being a recognised natural guardian, can act validly on behalf of the minor as the guardian. Such an interpretation will be the natural outcome of harmonious construction of S. 4 and S.6 of HMG Act, without causing any violence to the language of S. 6(a).  [Para 10]

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child - Boy aged 10 years - His natural desire and his future development is very important to be kept in mind - After talking to the child court directed that his custody will continue with the mother.	(Para 2)

heading: Custody of minor children
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor children - Claim for, by wife - Custody of children was with husband in view of consent between parties, arrived at time of divorce by mutual consent - As per agreement between parties expenses of son to be born by husband whereas of daughter to be born by wife - Husband has born expenses of both children when initially wife failed to contribute towards expenses of daughter - Application for custody filed by wife only after husband asked her to contribute financially - Also action of wife of transferring amounts to her colleague but not for her daughter shows unwillingness of wife to contribute for her daughter - Further when wife has relinquished her right to claim custody at time of divorce by mutual consent, she cannot claim custody after divorce - Custody of children should remain with husband - Merely because husband has performed second marriage he cannot be deprived of custody of children - Moreover, when he was looking after children and fulfilling all his commitments - Wife not entitled to custody of children. 	(Paras 16, 17, 19, 20, 21)

heading: Minor's undivided interest in joint family property
HeadNote.description:
Minor's undivided interest in joint family property - Sale of minor's share - An adult member can sell the minor's share if it is for legal necessity - S.8 would not be applicable to minor's interest in the joint family property.

So far as Section 6 is concerned, it speaks about the natural guardian of a Hindu minor.  However, it specifically excludes a minor's undivided interest in joint family property.  Thus, the natural guardian father and, thereafter, the mother cannot be considered as natural guardian in respect of his undivided interest in joint family property.  Section 8 lays down the powers of natural guardian.  Since section 6 excludes the minor's undivided interest in the joint family property, section 8 also, would not be applicable to the minor's share in the undivided interest in the joint family property.  Thus, the provisions of obtaining prior permission by the natural guardian as envisaged under section 8 sub-clause (2) would not arise in respect of a minor's undivided interest in the joint family property.  Section 12 of the Act carves out an exception in respect of a minor's undivided interest in the joint family property when it states that the guardian is not to be appointed in respect of his undivided interest in joint family property.  It further states that if a minor has an adult member and the property is under the management of the joint family property, no guardian should be appointed for the minor.  Thus, an exception is carved out in respect of minor's interest in an undivided joint family property.  Thus in view of the said provision an adult member can sell the minor's share if it is for legal necessity.	 [Para 12]

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child - Interest and welfare of the child is the paramount consideration and not the convenience or pleasure of the parents.			(Para 6)

heading: Custody of minor daughter
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor daughter - Visitation rights of father - Appeal pending in High Court - Order granting access in favour of father to meet minor kept in abeyance by High Court till receipt of report of psychiatrist - Appeal against by father - Apex Court after meeting both the parties and minor in chamber coming to conclusion that complete denial of access to child was not proper and hence directions issued for expeditious disposal of appeal and to allow father to have access to his child, at least to some extent.	(Paras 15-17)

heading: Disposal of undivided and unidentified share of minors
HeadNote.description:
Disposal of undivided and unidentified share of minors - Need commensurate with liability to discharge load - It is legal necessity to sell the property - Pressing demands from creditors may not be in evidence, but there was a lawful need in the interest of Joint Hindu Family - Karta and senior member in the family, held, competent to dispose of undivided and unidentified share of the minors even without permission of the District Court.

The Joint Hindu Family by itself is capable as legal entity to act through its karta and other adult members of the family in the management of Joint Hindu family property. Therefore, it was not necessary to obtain permission under Section 8 of the Act, more so, when parents of the plaintiffs were party to the sale transaction effecting the sale for the purpose of repaying the bank loan of Rs.4,000/-. If need is commensurate with liability for to discharge loan, it is legal necessity to sell the property. Pressing demands from creditors may not be in evidence, but there was a lawful need in the interest of Joint Hindu Family. Under the circumstances, Karta and senior member in the family - parents in this case - were competent to dispose of undivided and unidentified share of the minors even without permission of the District Court. In the facts and circumstances of the case, no infirmity can be found in the conclusions drawn by the Courts below. 2001(2) Civil L.J. 97 (M.P.) - Ref. to. [Para 10]

heading: Disposal of
HeadNote.description: Undivided share of minor in ancestral property of joint family - Disposal of - In absence of father, mother can very well sell the property of minor for legal necessity or for benefit of the estate - The sale cannot be null and void but voidable in case it is not proved that the sale was for legal necessity and for the benefit of the estate. (1996)8 SCC 54 - Rel. on.			(Paras 16, 19)

heading: Sale of land standing in the name of minor
HeadNote.description: Sale of land standing in the name of minor - Custody of minor with maternal uncle - Maternal uncle had applied for declaring him as natural guardian and the same was pending - Hence, his application for sale of land would be premature, moreover, land was also grossly undervalued - Order permitting sale of land set aside and matter restored to its original file. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Powers of natural guardian
HeadNote.description: Powers of natural guardian - Father died leaving behind three minor daughters and their mother - Property left behind recorded in mutation register each having ¼th share - Mother cannot sell property of minor daughters without previous permission of the court. 			(Para 13)

heading: Custody of 3½ years girl child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of 3½ years girl child - Child citizen of U.K. - Parents having permanent resident status of U.K. - Matrimonial discords developing in parents - Child brought to India by the mother - Proceedings for custody of girl in U.K. Court by the father - Court passing interim order to submit to jurisdiction of U.K. Court - High Court taking into consideration welfare of minor child and comity of courts directing mother to take back minor to U.K. - Held order of High Court was proper and could not be interfered with.

It is but natural that in a matrimonial tussle both the parents would want the custody of the minor child. In this tussle, we have to decide who would be more suited to have custody of the child. The High Court appears to have taken the correct approach in a matter like this. Although, on first impression, it would appear that the interests of the minor child would best be served if she is allowed to remain with the appellant, the interim ex parte order passed by U.K. Court cannot be lost sight of. Moreover except for insisting that the minor be returned to its jurisdiction, the English Court did not intend to separate the child from the appellant, until a final decision was taken with regard to the custody of the child. The ultimate decision in that regard has to be left to the English Courts having regard to the nationality of the child and the fact that both the parents had worked for gain in the U.K. and had also acquired permanent resident status in the U.K. The High Court has taken note of the fact that the English Court has not directed that the custody of the child should be handed over to the respondent father but that the child should be returned to the jurisdiction of the Courts in the U.K. which would then proceed to determine as to who would be best suited to have the custody of the child. The approach of the High Court takes into consideration both the questions relating to the Comity of Courts as well as interest of the minor child, which, no doubt, is one of the most important considerations in matters relating go custody of a minor child. It has been rightly observed by the High Court that it was the English Courts which had the most intimate contact with the issue in question to decide the same. Hence, the High Court did not commit any error in relying on the doctrine of Comity of Courts since the question of what is in the interest of the minor still has to be considered by the U.K. Court and the interim order passed in the proceedings initiated by the 'Respondent is only of an interim nature with a view to return the child to the jurisdiction of the said Court.   [Para 26,27,29]

heading: Custody of child
Welfare of minor
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Welfare of minor - Father of minor is in live-in relationship with another woman - He has a child from said relationship - Though no divorce had taken place with mother of child - Besides, father is also stated to be a drunkard - It would not be in the welfare of minor girl to give her custody to father who is leading an immoral life - Custody granted to mother. 2003(2) RCR (Civil) 471, 1999(4) ALL MR 726 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Custody of illegitimate child
HeadNote.description: Custody of illegitimate child - Interim application by father - 6 years old special child taken care of by his mother ever since his birth - Father claimed that child was born not out of wedlock but out of romantic relationship between him and mother - He sought custody of child stating that mother is mentally unfit to take care of child or retain his custody - However, that by itself is no ground to deny custody to natural guardian except insofar as it bears on physical or mental security and welfare of child - Complaint that mother being of quarrelsome nature, having filed false sexual molestation complaint and made efforts to minimise child’s social interaction, does not prima facie indicate any "mental unsoundness" - Even cross FIRs filed between her and her neighbours do not indicate same - Mother has indefeasible right to its natural guardianship over father - Order rejecting interim custody, proper.			(Paras 8, 10, 11 12)

heading: Considerations involved
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor child - Considerations involved - Paramount consideration is "welfare of the child" and not the rights of parents.

The principles in relation to the custody of a minor child are well settled. In determining the question as to who should be given custody of a minor child, the paramount consideration is the 'welfare of the child' and not rights of the parents under a statute for the time being in force. Merely because there is no defect in fathers' personal care and his attachment for his children-which every normal parent has, he would not be granted custody. Simply because the father loves his children and is not shown to be otherwise undesirable does not necessarily lead to the conclusion that the welfare of the children would be better promoted by granting their custody to him. Children are not mere chattels nor are they toys for their parents. Absolute right of parents over the destinies and the lives of their children, in the modern changed social conditions must yield to the considerations of their welfare as human beings so that they may grow up in a normal balanced manner to be useful members of the society and the guardian court in case of a dispute between the mother and the father, is expected to strike a just and proper balance between the requirements of welfare of the minor children and the rights of their respective parents over them. When the court is confronted with conflicting demands made by the parents, each time it has to justify the demands. The Court has not only to look at the issue on legalistic basis, in such matters human angles are relevant for deciding those issues. The court then does not give emphasis on what the parties say, it has to exercise a jurisdiction which is aimed at the welfare of the minor.  					 [Para 35,40,42]

The word 'welfare' used in Section 13 of the Act has to be construed literally and must be taken in its widest sense. The moral and ethical welfare of the child must also weigh with the Court as well as its physical well being. Though the provisions of the special statutes which govern the rights of the parents or guardians may be taken into consideration, there is nothing which can stand in the way of the Court exercising its parens patriae jurisdiction arising in such cases. The trump card in appellants' argument is that the child is living since long with the father. The argument is attractive. But the same overlooks a very significant factor. By flouting various orders, leading even to initiation of contempt proceedings, the appellant has managed to keep custody of the child. He can not be a beneficiary of his own wrongs. It is true that taking the child out of the father's custody may cause some problems, but that is bound to be neutralized.   [Para 43,44,45]

heading: Coparcenary property
HeadNote.description: Coparcenary property - Claim of daughter for share in property of father after his death - Sons claiming that mother and daughter after death of father jointly executed registered release deed relinquishing their rights in property in favour of sons - Mother had executed release deed on behalf of daughter as she was minor at that time - Daughter claiming that mother had no right to relinquish her share - Mother acted as natural guardian of minor daughter and no steps taken by daughter on attaining majority to get release deed set aside within period of limitation of 3 years - Release deed is not void - Daughter not entitled to relief claimed. 	(Paras 14, 15, 18, 19)

heading: Natural guardian of Hindu minor
HeadNote.description: Natural guardian of Hindu minor - Karta cannot become guardian of minor members of joint family - As he is manager of family - However, said principle would not apply when family settlement is taking place between members of joint family - When such dissolution takes place and some of members relinquish their share in favour of Karta, Karta cannot act as guardian of that minor whose share is being relinquished in favour of Karta - As it would be conflict of interest - In such case it would be mother alone who would be natural guardian. 	(Para 17)

heading: Maintenance
Unchastity of wife
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Unchastity of wife - Proof - Excepting bare allegations of unchastity no evidence or proof that wife was unchaste - Held in absence of proof of unchastity maintenance could not be denied to wife.

When a matter comes to the Court, proof is required because proof is the corner-stone of the Court Procedure. It is not possible to the Court to accept any such allegation without proof. In the case in hand, there is no proof whatsoever except a bare allegation. It is not possible, therefore, for the Court to accept the husband's contention of unchastity against the wife-respondent. The hitch placed by sub-clause (3)  of Section 18 of the Act, cannot,  therefore, obstruct the grant of maintenance to the wife. It is for the husband to prove that the wife is unchaste because it is he, who levels the allegations and in accordance with Section 101 of the Evidence Act, it is on him to prove the same. It is no doubt true that it is difficult to prove unchastity but it is also true that it is easy to level such allegations.   [Para 8,9]

heading: Grant of maintenance
HeadNote.description: Grant of maintenance - Section makes no discrimination between a legitimate and illegitimate child - Proof of legitimacy is irrelevant. (Para 10)

heading: Maintenance to wife and daughter
HeadNote.description: Maintenance to wife and daughter - Husband a sepoy in Army - Daughter was around 16-17 years old - Husband earning Rs.7,800/- per month - Wife and daughter granted Rs.2,500/- p.m. each as maintenance. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Married minor girl
Natural guardian
HeadNote.description:
Married minor girl - Natural guardian - If a minor girl is married, her natural guardian would be husband. 

Minor is defined under Section 4(a) as a person who has not completed the age of 18 years. Section 6 defines the natural guardians of a Hindu minor and it lays down that the natural guardians of a Hindu minor, in respect of his person and property would be the father in case of a boy or a unmarried girl and then it mentions other guardians who can be guardians after the father. Under Section 6(c) it lays down that in the case of a married girl, the husband would be a natural guardian. So this Act in a way recognizes the marriages of minor girls. The Act deals with minors and mentions the husband as a guardian of a married girl. This itself conveys the intention of the legislature that for a married minor girl, guardian would be the husband. There cannot be any guardian for a major under the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956. Therefore the only meaning which has to be given to Section 6(c) is that if a minor girl is married, her natural guardian is the husband.  [Para 11]

heading: Suit by quondam minor
HeadNote.description: Suit by quondam minor - To set aside alienation of his property by his guardian in contravention of S.8(2) of Hindu Minority Act - Limitation prescribed u/Art.60 of Limitation Act, would apply - Arts.109, 110 or 113, would have no application in such case.			(Para 29)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit against alienation of property by guardian - Limitation - Several plaintiffs entitled to file suit - Property alienated in year 1982 - Suit filed in 1989 - One of plaintiffs is 20 yrs. old and other one was still minor on date of institution of suit - Other two plaintiffs though majors, not Manager or karta of joint family - They will not fall under Explanation 2 of S.7 of Limitation Act, could not give discharge without concurrence of such minor person - Hence, suit so filed held well within three year from date of attaining majority.			(Para 82)

heading: Female child custody
HeadNote.description:
Female child custody - Female child of growing age needs company more of her mother than the father - Remarriage of mother is not a disqualification.

Held on the paramount consideration of best safeguarding the interest of the child, the judgment of the High Court giving exclusive custody of the child to the mother and visitation rights to the natural father deserves to be maintained with little modification for the following reasons :-

1. The child is, at present, 9 years of age and on advent of puberty. This is the age in which she requires more care and attention of the mother. Mother, at this age of the child, deserves to continue to keep the custody of the female child. She is reported to have given up her service and now leading life of a house-wife. The progress report of child indicates that she is very good at studies and has a bright educational career.

2. It is reported that the wife is presently on the family way. The prospect of arrival of the second child in the family of the wife is another circumstance which would be in favour of the present child.

3.  The petitioner lives alone with his father. There are no female members living jointly with him although he may have female relations in the city but that would not ensure constant company, care and attention to the female child.

4. The petitioner/natural father is a busy Stock Broker allegedly carrying on his business with aid of on-line computer but it cannot be said that in the course of his business, he has not to remain out of residence for attending  his office and other business engagements.

5. The apprehension expressed against the second husband that he might poison the mind of the child and create ill-will towards natural father is not borne out from the evidence on record. On the contrary, the second husband in his deposition has made statements evincing a very co-operative and humane attitude on his part towards the problem of the estranged couple and the child.	

The visitation rights given to the natural father, in the present circumstances, also do not require any modification because with the passage of time, the growing child should eagerly wait for the company of his father as a happy and enjoyable moment rather than treat it as a part of empty ritual or duty. To make visitation rights of natural father effective and meaningful for proper growth of the child, active cooperation of both the parents and her step father is expected and it would not be found wanting from any one of them. Since the mother of the child is married to a famous cricketer, as and when she leaves the country on tour with her husband during school days or vacation period of the child without taking the child with her, instead of leaving the child to the care and custody of some other member of the family, the custody of the child during her absence from her home shall be given to the natural father.   [Para 18]

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - It could not be said that mother as parent should always be preferred to father to retain custody of the child.	(Para 17)

heading: Natural guardian
HeadNote.description:
Natural guardian - Petition filed by mother under Section 7 of Guardians and Wards Act seeking appointment as guardian of minor children and to permit her to sell their property and invest the proceeds - Not maintainable as father is alive - Father not examined nor his affidavit marked in evidence - Petition filed by mother ignoring natural guardian (father), not maintainable. Guardians and Wards Act, 1890, Sections 7, 29.

An affidavit given by the father of the minor children appears to have been filed wherein he expressed no objection for grant of reliefs sought for by the petitioner/mother of the minor children in the petition filed before the Court below. But, unfortunately, the said affidavit, though referred to by the Court below in the order under appeal, had not either been marked as a document nor the father of the minor children was examined as a witness to speak about the contents of the affidavit. In such a case, the petition filed by the mother of the minor children shall have to be treated as filed only by an incompetent person. The reasons for filing the petition by the mother of the minor children, ignoring their natural guardian (father) as contemplated in law are indiscernible.  [Para 20]

heading: Sale of land on behalf of minor
HeadNote.description: Sale of land on behalf of minor - Share of minor daughters in joint family property was sold by their natural guardian widow mother - Permission of court was not taken - Sale can be avoided if it is in contravention of S.8(1) or 8(2) - As there is no prayer for setting aside sale deed and no court fee is paid - Sale is binding on minor daughters/Respondent No.1 to 5. 2001(4) ALL MR 287 (S.C.), (2004)13 SCC 480 Followed.	(Paras 10, 13)

heading: Property of minor
Alienation by mother
HeadNote.description:
Property of minor - Alienation by mother - Permission of District Court not obtained - Alienation is invalid and void ab intio.

Under S.8 of the Act, the property of minor is fully protected even from the depredations of his parents and section 8 empowers only the legal guardian to alienate a minor's immovable property provided it is for the necessity or benefit of the minor or his estate and it further requires that such alienation shall be effected after the permission of the Court has been obtained.  In the instant case, no permission of the Court was obtained for such alienation, and therefore, the said alienation by mother would be void ab initio. [Para 13,18]

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of child - Welfare of the child and not the rights of parents is deciding factor - Better financial resources or love for the child may be one of the relevant considerations but not the sole determining factor.

While determining the question as to which parent the care and control of a child should be committed, the first and the paramount consideration is the welfare and interest of the child and not the rights of the parents under a statute.  Indubitably the provisions of law pertaining to the custody of a child contained in either the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 (Section 17) or the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956 (Section 13) also hold out the welfare of the child as a predominant consideration.  In fact, no statute, on the subject, can ignore, eschew or obliterate the vital factor of the welfare of the minor.  The question of welfare of the minor child has again to be considered in the background of the relevant facts and circumstances.  Each case has to be decided on its own facts and other decided cases can hardly serve as binding precedents insofar as the factual aspects of the case are concerned.  It is, no doubt, true that father is presumed by the statutes to be better suited to look after the welfare of the child, being normally the working member and head of the family, yet in each case the Court has to see primarily to the welfare of the child in determining the question of his or her custody.  Better financial resources of either of the parents or their love for the child may be one of the relevant considerations but cannot be the sole determining factor for the custody of the child.  It is here that a heavy duty is cast on the Court to exercise its judicial discretion judiciously in the background of all the relevant facts and circumstances, bearing in mind the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration.						 [Para 14]

heading: Custody of male child
HeadNote.description: Custody of male child - Mother leaving matrimonial home when child was less than three years - Child since then living with father at Allahabad - Studying in good school and having a group of friends there - Mother working as a teacher at Panipat and living all alone - Child when interviewed by Court clearly showed his reluctance to go with the mother - Uprooting him from Allahabad likely to impede his schooling and may also cause emotional strain and depression in him - Held order of High Court giving exclusive custody to father with visitation rights to mother deserved to be maintained.	(Para 17)

heading: Word "ordinarily"
HeadNote.description:
Word "ordinarily" - Onus is on father to prove that custody of infant child is not in the welfare of infant child.

A proviso is in the nature of an exception to what has earlier been generally prescribed. The use of the word "ordinarily" cannot be over-emphasised. It ordains a presumption, albeit a rebuttable one, in favour of the mother. The proviso places the onus on the father to prove that it is not in the welfare of the infant child to be placed in the custody of his/her mother. The wisdom of the Parliament or the Legislature should not be trifled away by a curial interpretation which virtually nullifies the spirit of the enactment.  [Para 9]

heading: Custody of child below five years
HeadNote.description:
Custody of child below five years - Custody should be given to the mother.

The HMG Act postulates that the custody of an infant or a tender aged child should be given to his/her mother unless the father discloses cogent reasons that are indicative of and presage the livelihood of the welfare and interest of the child being undermined or jeopardised if the custody retained by the mother. Section 6(a) of HMG Act, therefore, preserves the right of the father to be the guardian of the property of the minor child but not the guardian of his person whilst the child is less than five years old. It carves out the exception of interim custody, in contradistinction of guardianship, and then specifies that custody should be given to the mother so long as the child is below five years in age. This Section or for that matter any other provision including those contained in the G&W Act, does not disqualify the mother to custody of the child even after the latter's crossing the age of five years.  [Para 12]

heading: Custody of child below five years
HeadNote.description: Custody of child below five years - It is for father to plead and prove mother's unsuitability - Only then comparative characteristics of parents would come into play. (Para 13)

heading: Custody of child
Visitation rights
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Visitation rights - Are distinct from custody or interim custody. 	(Para 18)

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor child - Factors to be considered - Controlling consideration governing the custody of the minor is the welfare and well-being of the child concerned and not the right of their parents - Discretion vested in Court to be exercised judiciously - Father's fitness cannot override considerations of the welfare of the minor children - Court while dealing with the custody cases, is neither bound by statutes nor by strict rules of evidence or procedure nor by precedents - In selecting a guardian, the Court is expected to given due weight to the child's ordinary comfort, contentment, health, education, intellectual development and favourable surroundings.

(i)	The father in the case of a Hindu minor boy is the natural guardian of the person during his minority and it is permissible for the court to remove him from that position and to appoint either the mother and if the mother is also unfit somebody else as the guardian of the person of the minor boy if in the opinion of the court the father is unfit to be the guardian of the person of the minor. The controlling consideration governing the custody of the minor is the welfare and well-being of the child concerned and not the right of their parents.

(ii)	The discretion vested in the Court is, as is the case with all judicial discretions, to be exercised judiciously in the background of all relevant facts and circumstances. Each case has to be decided on its own facts and other cases can hardly serve as binding precedents.

(iii)	The father's fitness has to be considered, determined and weighed predominantly in terms of the welfare of his minor children in the context of all the relevant circumstances. If the custody of the father cannot promote their welfare equally or better than the custody of the mother, then he cannot claim indefeasible right to their custody merely because there is no defect in his personal character and he has attachment for his children - which every normal parent has. In short, the father's fitness cannot override considerations of the welfare of the minor children.

(iv)	Merely because the father loves his children and is not shown to be otherwise undesirable cannot necessarily lead to the conclusion that the welfare of the children would be better promoted by granting their custody to him as against the wife who may also equally be affectionate towards her children and otherwise equally free from blemish.

(v)	Section 6 of the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act constitutes the father as the natural guardian of a minor. But that provision cannot supersede paramount consideration as to what is conducive to the welfare of the minor.

(vi)	The father's right to custody of the minor children is neither an absolute nor an indefeasible one. The welfare of the child should be the paramount consideration. The mother can also be given custody of the minors, if their welfare or interest should require it, even if the father is otherwise fit to act as guardian.

(vii)	Female child on the advent of puberty primarily requires mother's care and attention. Absence of female company in the house of the father is relevant factor.

(viii)	Where the child is not in a position to express any intelligent preference between his/her parents, mature thinking is necessary to decide as to what will enure to his/her benefit welfare.

(ix)	In case of dispute between the mother and the father regarding custody of their child, the paramount consideration is welfare of the child and not the legal rights of either of the parties. The Court, therefore, should examine what is in the best interest of the child, whether her welfare would be better looked after if she is given in the custody of either the father or the mother. Such cases cannot be decided solely by interpreting legal provisions.

(x)	A court while dealing with the custody cases, is neither bound by statutes nor by strict rules of evidence or procedure nor by precedents. In selecting proper guardian of a minor, the paramount consideration should be the welfare and well-being of the child.

(xi)	In selecting a guardian, the court is expected to give due weight to the child's ordinary comfort, contentment, health, education, intellectual development and favourable surroundings. But over and above, physical comforts, moral and ethical value cannot be ignored. They are equally important, essential and indispensable considerations. 2000(3) ALL MR (S.C.) 667, 2005 ALL MR (Cri) 1822 (S.C.) & 2001(2) ALL MR 237 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	 [Para 11]

heading: Father as natural guardian of minor
HeadNote.description: Father as natural guardian of minor - Though S.6 of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, constitutes the father as the natural guardian of a minor, but that provision cannot supersede paramount consideration as to what is conducive to the welfare of the minor - Father's fitness has to be considered, determined and weighed predominantly in terms of the welfare of his minor children in the context of all the relevant circumstances. (1994)2 Mh.L.J. 1879 - Ref. to.	(Para 35)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Controlling consideration governing the custody of the children, held, is the welfare of the children concerned and not the right of their parents.	(Para 38)

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor child - Welfare of child is paramount consideration - Said principle serves twin objects - Firstly, it ensures growth and development of child in best environment - Secondly, by ensuring proper growth of children who are future of nation, it serves public interest too. 

The principle as to "welfare of minor" is aimed at serving twin objectives. In the
first instance, it is to ensure that the child grows and develops in the best environment. The
best interest of the child has been placed at the vanguard of family/custody disputes according
the optimal growth and development of the child primacy over other considerations. The
child is often left to grapple with the breakdown of an adult institution. While the parents aim
to ensure that the child is least affected by the outcome, the inevitability of the uncertainty
that follows regarding the child's growth lingers on till the new routine sinks in. The effect
of separation of spouses, on children, psychologically, emotionally and even to some extent
physically, spans from negligible to serious, which could be insignificant to noticeably critical.
It could also have effects that are more immediate and transitory to long lasting thereby
having a significantly negative repercussion in the advancement of the child. While these
effects don't apply to every child of a separated or divorced couple, nor has any child
experienced all these effects, the deleterious risk of maladjustment remains the objective of
the parents to evade and the court's intent to circumvent. This right of the child is also based
on individual dignity.
Second justification behind the 'welfare' principle is the public interest that stands
served with the optimal growth of the children. It is well recognised that children are the
supreme asset of the nation. Rightful place of the child in the sizeable fabric has been
recognised in many international covenants, which are adopted in this country as well.
Child-centric human rights jurisprudence that has been evolved over a period of time is
founded on the principle that public good demands proper growth of the children, who are
the future of the nation. 2009(1) ALL MR 925 (S.C.), (1997) 10 SCC 549 Ref. to.  [Para 10,11]

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of child - Change of interim custody of female minor child - Mother suffering from bipolar disorder and mental depression while in USA - Mother having American citizenship and not residing at fixed place when in Goa - Child was with paternal grandmother and no case made out by mother to change custody at interim stage - Held, custody would continue with grandmother and mother of child would have visitation rights for three days in a week.
(2000) 9 SCC 745 Rel. on.(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Property of minor plaintiff no. 1 and 2 was sold by de facto guardian step mother without permission - Real mother of plaintiff was alive at that time - Suit is within limitation as per S.65 - Concurrent finding of both courts below that suit is within limitation - Contention in this regard liable to be rejected. 
1986(0) BCI 39 - Ref. to. (Paras 30 to 32)

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - S.8 speaks of powers of natural guardian in respect of separate property of the minor - S.8 has no application to cases where the minor has an interest in Hindu undivided family - Permission of Court under S.8 would not be necessary where an interest in joint family is sought to be disposed of. (1996)8 SCC 54 - Rel. on.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Child custody
HeadNote.description: Child custody - Application by respondent father for custody of child - Also prayer for declaration that respondent is guardian - Application is under S.6 of Minority and Guardianship Act - Only remedy against order on application is to file writ petition.

heading: Child custody
HeadNote.description:
Child custody - Respondent is father and natural guardian in law - However, on interacting with child, Court found that child desires to stay with his grandfather - Child is taking education there - Child does not know name of his father - Child does not wish to return to respondent - Paramount interest of child is required to be looked into - Order to hand over custody of child to respondent is liable to be quashed aside.
2010 ALL SCR 2270, 2010 ALL SCR 357, 2010 ALL SCR 794, 2009(2) ALL MR 16, 2009(1) ALL MR 925 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Custody of child
Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Entitlement - Admission of wife that her brother had threatened to kill her son and that one day when her son had fall and had bump on his head with bleeding injury, she did not take him to doctor, shows that she was not taking proper care of son - Husband is paying sum of Rs.10,000/- to wife and son and also bearing other expense of son such as school fees, fees for speech and development therapy etc. - He shows his willingness to continue to pay maintenance to wife even if custody of their son is granted to him - Interim settlement made by parties that their son would be in custody of wife from Monday to Friday and from Friday evening to Monday Morning, custody would be with husband - Husband used to drop and collect son from school and coaching classes - Only because custody of child should normally remain with mother, if child is below five years of age, Family Court had given custody to wife - With view to give equal opportunity to both parents to spend time with son who is now seven years of age and is slow learner, husband is also permitted to have custody of son for some more time during school days and equally with wife during vacations. 	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Sale of minor's property
HeadNote.description:
Sale of minor's property - By his elder brother/de facto guardian - Would be void ab initio - Brother is not a natural guardian as defined u/S.6 hence benefit of S.8 would not be available - Fact that such a transfer is not challenged by minor on attaining majority, is no ground for alienee to retain the property - Question as to whether sale was made under duress or for legal necessity of minor, irrelevant.

	Natural guardians are vested with certain rights regarding transfer of minor's property as mentioned in Section 8 of the said Act. Section 8 Subsection (3) says while disposing of immovable property of a minor by the natural guardian, any contravention of Sub-section (1) of Sub-section(2) is voidable at the instance of the minor or any person claiming under him. Question arises whether any transfer if made by a person other than the natural guardian whether is voidable or a void transaction. In the present case the brother who transferred the property on behalf of the minor without permission of the Court is unauthorized transfer. Such an unauthorized transfer is voidable if it is done at the instance of the natural guardian but in other cases the transaction if so made should be considered a void one because the Act does not make it voidable. The brother who has transferred the property is in the position of a de facto guardian of a Hindu minor which is materially different from that of natural guardian or a guardian appointed by the Court. Therefore, this transfer on behalf of the minor is an unauthorized transfer and is void. 			 [Para 5]

	According to the intent of the legislature after commencement of the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956 no person is entitled to dispose of or deal with the property of a Hindu minor merely on the ground of his/her being the de facto guardian representing the minor. Alienation done by a de facto guardian is void and the alienee is in the position of a trespasser who has no right in the property. The object of Section 11 is to prevent any de facto guardian from dealing with the property of a minor and if any other interpretation is made the same will frustrate the object of Section 11.

	As the alienation made by the de facto guardian is invalid and not binding on the minor, alienee cannot justify it on the ground that the minor subsequently did not challenge the transfer which is void ab initio and does not get regularized for any eventuality in future. The brother who transferred the property is also not a natural guardian and as a result question whether such sale was made under duress or for legal necessity of the minor, can also not be considered. 	 [Para 8]

heading: Property of minor
HeadNote.description: Property of minor - Sale by natural Guardian in violation of conditions mentioned in S.8 of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act (1956) - Is voidable at instance of minor - Suit for declaration of sale deed as void can be filed within three years of date of attaining majority - Appeal against decree of suit for declaration through next friend - Application to remove natural guardian and sought permission to contest the suit of his own filed by plaintiff during the pendency of appeal after three years on attaining majority - Therefore, his claim was barred by limitation. 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1652 Rel. on. 			(Para 13)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Sale by natural guardian - Validity - Evidence on record shows that the plaintiff, minor was exclusive owner of the suit land - No evidence that father was neglecting the child and child was in care, custody and maintenance of the mother - Sale was not for legal necessity or benefit of the minor - Therefore, sale effected by mother of plaintiff is void and declaration that the sale deed was null and void, proper. 1999(2) ALL MR 416 (S.C.) Rel. on 			(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Sale by de-facto guardian - Validity - Plaintiff inherited and owned the property which is not a Hindu Joint Family property and father was not shown to be not taking care of the minor - In circumstances, mother is not natural guardian - She as a de facto guardian has no right to alienate the property of her minor son. 	(Para 20)

heading: Suit for declaration and possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and possession - On strength of release deed executed in favour of plaintiffs - Suit property alienated by natural guardian of minor allegedly in violation of S.8(2) of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act - Property claimed to have been released in favour of plaintiffs after death of minor before getting majority - Such alienations by natural guardian are voidable at instance of minor - Same required to be set aside before relief for possession can be claimed by plaintiffs - Suit filed without making prayer for setting aside sale deeds, not properly framed - Cannot be decreed. (2001) 6 SCC 534, 2001(4) ALL MR 287 (S.C.), (2002) 1 SCC 178, (2004) 8 SCC 785 Ref. to.	(Paras 14, 19, 20)

heading: Sale of minor's property by natural guardian
HeadNote.description: Sale of minor's property by natural guardian - Setting aside of sale is necessary for avoiding a registered sale deed - However, it is not necessary in every case that to avoid disposal of immovable property, minor has to file suit - It may depend on facts of each case as to whether it is necessary to bring suit or it can be done in any other manner.	(Para 28)

heading: Disposal of minor's property
HeadNote.description: Disposal of minor's property - By de facto guardian - Is prohibited u/S.11 of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act - Transfer made by de facto guardian is thus void and can be repudiated in any manner - It is not necessary for minor or any person claiming under him to file a suit for setting aside void deed - A void deed can be ignored - Same cannot be held to be applicable to transfer made by a natural guardian u/S.8(3). (2002) 1 SCC 178 Ref.to.	(Para 31)

heading: Parental alienation
HeadNote.description: Parental alienation - Child in custody of mother - Incessant fights between parties, allegations of adultery on part of father and alleged threat of forcible removal of child from mother - Filing of suit for permanent injunction against husband and his parents by mother of child on basis of alleged threats - Cannot be said to be instance of parental alienation - Moreso when prayer in suit was not absolute but only that defendants should not meet child without consent and presence of mother - Further, admission of child to school by mother or issuance of Aadhaar Card with single parent name, may not be proper, but such acts cannot be said to be parental alienation. (Per Hemant Gupta, J.) (Paras 104, 108, 109)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Fact that father has more financial resources with him - By itself would not entitle him to physical custody of child. (Per Hemant Gupta, J.) (1998) 1 SCC 112 Foll. (Para 113)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Permanent interest of child - Father is Hindu by religion while mother is Christian and American by citizenship - Initially Trial Court gave interim custody to mother with visitation rights to father - First Appellate Court reversed said order and thereafter, Supreme Court restored same - Father does not seem to have any college education and has no stable source of income - He also has no abode of his own and permissively occupying relative's flat - Whereas, mother is well educated, having worked in USA as Associate Professor - She has taken on lease one house at Goa and another at Mumbai to give child secured shelter at place - Doctor certified that boy suffers from no health problems and he is said to be hale and hearty for his age - Therefore, allegation about child’s health and nutritional needs is unacceptable - Order of Trial Court, proper.			(Paras 37, 38, 39, 40)

heading: Custody of child
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Father is Hindu by religion while mother is Christian and American by citizenship - Trial Court gave interim custody to mother with visitation rights to father - Father contended that child would have best education in USA, but that country distinguishes itself with gun culture and “fatherless families” - Not acceptable - Child’s custody is not matter of cultural war or inter-country comparison or competition - Each culture shapes itself - No universal pattern and therefore, no universal determinants - In fact, not possible to appreciate other cultural values without having grown up under their influence.	(Para 45)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Claimed by mother who is Christian and American by citizenship - Challenged by contending that mother has cultivated Christian faith and practices in child who is born Hindu - No religion is tool in hands of either parent to indoctrinate - Education will give boy discernment, that discernment discretion, and that discretion freedom - Grown-up boy will have all his choices open - Custody of child given to mother, proper.	(Para 42)

heading: Custody of child
To mother
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - To mother - Not violative of mandate of S.6 of 1956 Act and S.26 of 1890 Act - Literally read, S.6(a) of 1956 Act is not only archaic but also anarchic - Word 'after' in S.6(a) of 1956 Act to mean 'in absence of' - Therefore, mother can act as natural guardian of minor during lifetime of father who would be deemed to be 'absent' - As far as S.26 of 1890 Act which concerns about removal of ward from jurisdiction of guardian, removal may happen with Court's leave and for purposes Court specifies.	(Paras 22, 23, 24)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Arts.21A, 51A(k) - Custody of child - Mother is American citizen and having worked in USA as Assistant Professor - She homeschools the child - Mother’s inaction in educating 8 years old child in school is not violative of fundamental rights of child under Art.21A - Homeschooling is said to be progressive phenomenon around world and in America as it is legalised - Parents educate their children at home instead of sending them to traditional public or private school. 	(Paras 28, 30, 32)

heading: Custody of child
Maintainability
