HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Habeas corpus petition for - Maintainability - Plea of father that petition is not maintainable as custody of minor daughter with him who is natural guardian u/S.6 of Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act and Guardians and Wards Act, is not illegal and petitioner has alternative remedy of filing petition for custody of minor under Act of 1956 - Mere availability of alternate remedy of filing custody petition under Act of 1956 or Guardians and Wards Act is no bar to exercise of extra ordinary writ jurisdiction for issuance of writ of Habeas Corpus - Question of custody of minor child is to be decided on paramount consideration of her welfare - Habeas corpus petition not liable to be dismissed. (Paras 11, 20, 21, 22)

heading: Custody of child
Habeas corpus petition
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Habeas corpus petition - Seeking direction to respondent-father to hand over custody of minor daughter aged three and half years to petitioner-mother - Respondent-father claiming that he has well settled business whereas petitioner-mother is disturbed due to problems in her parental family - He also stated that criminal case was registered against her father, her brother has matrimonial dispute with his wife and petitioner-mother was involved in case of theft and was in custody - Petitioner has nothing to do with criminal case against her father and matrimonial dispute of her brother is personal matter - Petitioner cannot be said to be disabled by these matters from properly looking after and taking motherly care of minor daughter - Father being businessman has to go out of house to attend business therefore he cannot be said to be in better position to take care of minor child as compared to mother - Father has not given cogent reasons indicative of welfare and interest of minor daughter being jeopardized by entrusting interim custody to mother - As per proviso to S.6(a) of Act of 1956 custody of minor who has not completed age of five years shall ordinarily be with mother - Petitioner entitled to interim custody of minor daughter till question of custody is decided by Guardian/Family Court. 	(Paras 24, 29)

heading: Guardianship Petition
Before High Court
Not maintainable
HeadNote.description: Guardianship Petition - Before High Court - Not maintainable - S.7 r/w. S.8 of Family Courts Act reserves exclusive jurisdiction to entertain suit or proceeding in relation to guardianship of person of any minor to Family Courts by virtue of Cl.(f) of Explanation to S.7(1). 			(Para 3)

heading: Guardianship Petition
HeadNote.description: Guardianship Petition - Seeking declaration about property of minor which is said to be fraudulently or unauthorisedly transferred and an order for recovery of property - Such reliefs cannot be claimed in guardianship petition independently of any claim for being appointed as guardian of property of minor or to deal with property of minor - No relief for being appointed as guardian of property of minor sought by petitioner - Guardianship petition dismissed. 			(Paras 4, 7)

heading: Guardianship Petition
HeadNote.description: Guardianship Petition - Application seeking direction to mother to deposit amount in bank account of minors withdrawn by her from their accounts - Such application is covered by clause (f) of Explanation to S.7(1) of Family Courts Act - Such application would lie before Family Courts and not before High Court - Petition dismissed.			(Paras 6, 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Suit for declaration and possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and possession - To extent that plaintiff was daughter of deceased tenant and certificate issued u/S.38(E) of Hyderabad Tenancy Act in defendants' favour set aside - Deceased had no issue from his first wife - Evidence of plaintiff that deceased was married to her mother and after his death, she was cultivating land along with his first wife - No evidence about date, time, month and mode of marriage nor that her mother was residing along with deceased continuously and during her cohabitation with him, she begot plaintiff - Neither birth certificate nor ration card showing her name along with deceased is produced - Her name never appeared in revenue record of suit land - Case of defendants that they were nephews of deceased and by virtue of Will, suit land was bequeathed on them - After death of deceased, plaintiff took no steps to get suit land transferred in her name for long period of 23 years - Meanwhile, suit lands were mutated in name of defendants and tenancy proceedings were held in their names and 38(E) certificates are issued in their name - Thereafter, consolidation proceedings also took place - Though Will was executed on stamp paper with no attesting witness, defendants being nearest legal heirs of deceased, were entitled under law to inherit suit land even in absence of Will - Plaintiff even by preponderance of probabilities failed to show that she was daughter of deceased - Suit dismissed. 2003(2) ALL MR 689 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 1240, AIR 2001 SC 2802 Ref.to.(Paras11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 21, 22, 23, 25, 27, 28, 29)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.59
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.59 - Suit for title and possession after redemption of mortgage - Defence that oral mortgage was invalid - Defendant-tenant in lawful possession of the property and in whose favour declaration of ownership under Section 38-E of the H.T. & A.L. Act is issued and who is declared owner of the property, could not have been dispossessed by order of the civil court.

In a suit for title and possession of property after redemption of mortgage; the trial court was fully justified in holding that it had no right to dispossess the tenant who had been declared owner and given the certificate under Section 38-E of the H.T. & A.L. Act. The District Court clearly exceeded its jurisdiction in entering into the question whether the oral mortgage was valid or invalid and whether original defendant No.1 had right to induct tenant without considering the fact that as stated in plaint itself, said defendant No.1, was lawfully put in possession of the suit property. It may be that Defendant No.1 may not have rights of mortgagee though recognized by the plaintiffs, but he was definitely in permissive possession of the property. 2007(2) ALL MR 288 - Foll. 				 [Para 25,27,30,31]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Resjudicata
Application under S.103
Application dismissed
HeadNote.description: Resjudicata - Application under S.103 - Application dismissed - Applicant directed to file civil suit for establishing his ownership - No appeal filed against the order - Order would operate as res judicata - Second successive application under S.103 on same facts - Not maintainable.	(Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Jurisdiction of Civil Courts
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Civil Courts - Challenge to sale transaction - By plaintiff widow and sons of one deceased 'R' - Matter in Civil Court - Status of 'R' as protected tenant was confirmed at various stages of litigation - Contention that Civil Courts should not have decided issue, liable to be rejected.  (Para 23)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.34
HeadNote.description: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.34 - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Bar of S.99 of Hyderabad Tenancy Act - Plaintiff claiming herself to be daughter of deceased - She sought declaration before Civil Court for setting aside 38(E) certificate issued in favour of defendants who are claiming title by virtue of Will - In terms of S.99 of Hyderabad Tenancy Act, plaintiff was bound to approach competent authority under said Act - Suit dismissed. 1983 (3) Mh.L.J. 542, 2002(2) ALL MR 944 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 34, 39)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Grant is illegal
HeadNote.description:
Grant of statutory ownership certificate - Person who was not declared as protected tenant of land granted certificate wrongly - Grant is illegal - Can be rectified subsequently at any time - No bar of Limitation is applicable.

Section 37-A makes it amply clear that deeming effect is given to tenancy of a class of persons in possession of tenanted land. The rights of a protected tenant are required to be entered in the Record of Rights. The fact situation in the present case is that rights of tenant were not recorded in the Record of Rights as contemplated under section 37-A(2) nor in the provisional list in Form VII required to be prepared under Rule 14 nor his name was shown in the final list of protected tenants which is required to be drawn in Form XV under Rule 23(1) of the Act.  [Para 12]

In the present case, the statutory ownership certificate was issued in favour of deceased even though he was not declared as a protected tenant of land Survey and his name did not appear in the relevant register. His name was surreptitiously entered and mistakenly, the certificate of statutory ownership was issued in his favour without any basis. Obviously, such inherent defect could be rectified at any time. There is no bar of limitation in case the decision is rendered without any legal basis.  [Para 15]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Creation of tenancy
Co-owner
HeadNote.description: Creation of tenancy - Co-owner - Tenancy in respect of an undivided share can be created by a co-sharer in favour of another co-sharer - Held, there is no prohibition in-law that one co-owner cannot be a tenant of the other co-owner cultivating his undivided share of the property - One co-owner can certainly lease out his share in the property to be cultivated by another on payment of rent. 1991 Mh.L.J. 68 - Rel. on.	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Proof
HeadNote.description: Transfer of Statutory Ownership - Proof - Where certificate under sub-section 6(a) of S.38 is issued, no further proof is required to infer transfer of statutory ownership - Certificate shall be conclusive evidence of such sale not only against land holder but also against all persons interested in the land. 1965 Bom.L.R. (Vol.47) 774 - Ref. to.			(Paras 10 and 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Suit filed under Tenancy Act claiming possession of lands from defendant tenant
HeadNote.description:
Suit filed under Tenancy Act claiming possession of lands from defendant tenant - On failure to obtain possession plaintiff filing suit under Act of 1952 - Defendant tenant is entitled to protection under Govt. circular.

The petitioners plaintiff instituted proceedings under the Hyderabad Tenancy Act. They claimed possession from defendant on the ground that the petitioners were landlords and defendant was the tenant. The possession was claimed on the ground of failure to pay rent. Having failed to secure possession, Petitioners filed the suit under Hyderabad Atiyat Inquiries Act, 1952. In the earlier proceedings, Petitioners did not plead non applicability of Hyderabad Tenancy Act. In the earlier proceedings, the petitioners did not claim that the lands were service Inam lands. In the earlier proceedings, Petitioners did not plead that defendant was not entitled to claim tenancy rights as the lands in question were service Inam lands. In the earlier proceedings defendant was admitted to be a tenant. Under the circumstances, it was not open to the Petitioners to plead that the lands in question were service Inam lands and, therefore, defendant was not entitled to the status of being a tenant. The Atiyat Deputy Collector erred, therefore, in coming to the conclusion that defendant was not a tenant.  [Para 6]

On scrutiny of the provisions of the Hyderabad Tenancy Act, the Hyderabad Abolition of Inam Act and Hyderabad Atiyat Inquiries Act, it is clear that there is no bar on creation of tenancy by the Inamdar under the three enactments. On the contrary, the Hyderabad Tenancy Act divides the tenants into protected tenants and ordinary tenants. Tenants falling under sections 34, 37 or 37-A are protected tenants while others are ordinary tenants. In the circumstances, the Circular dated 9/8/1955 seeks to protect the tenants who are cultivating Inam Lands. Hence, although the Circular does not confer status of tenant on a person, still, in cases where the cultivator is in possession for last several years, security of tenor is granted to such cultivator on his payment of rent. In the circumstances, it could not be contended by the Petitioners that the Circular overrides section 102A of the Hyderabad Tenancy Act. Defendant as an ordinary tenant, was certainly entitled to be protected from eviction. Hence, in such cases, the Circular is squarely applicable.  [Para 6]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Owner of land executing Kabulnama in favour of person
HeadNote.description:
Owner of land executing Kabulnama in favour of person - Proceeding under S.38 initiated on application of both parties - Certificate under S.38A was issued in name of such person - Validity of certificate not challenged before revenue authorities and it was never set aside - Validity of certificate has to be accepted and it has to be given due value and importance - Order of Revenue Tribunal directing Tahsildar to cancel certificate is totally wrong and could not be sustained. (Para 15)

Constitution of India, Art.227.

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Statutory tenancy
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Statutory tenancy - Challenge - After rejection of land owner’s application for personal cultivation in 1960, statutory certificate issued to appellants in 1970 - No further challenge raised by owner till his death - His sons laid fresh challenge, but failed, both in revenue proceedings and civil suit - About 10 yrs. later, widow of owner again raised challenge (in respect of part of property) on ground that she was unaware of mutations in name of appellant - Not a case that she was living separately from her sons - Not even a case that appellant obtained statutory tenancy by fraud or misrepresentation - Findings in favour of appellant already attained finality - Appellant cannot be vexed twice - Repeated challenge, abuse of process of law - Not sustainable. 
2014(2) ALL MR 468 (S.C.), 2005(5) ALL MR 152 (S.C.) Ref.to. 	(Paras 7 to 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Proceedings under
Limitation
Protected tenant
HeadNote.description:
Proceedings under - Limitation - Protected tenant - Purchase of suit property in 1966 - Challenge to purchase of suit property made by alleged legal heirs of protected tenant in the year 1985 - Held, it would not be justified for a person who has purchased the property in the year 1966 to face such a proceeding under S.98 after about lapse of 18/19 years - Finality to the actions has to be there - Even though no limitation is provided under S.98, it has to be accepted to be a reasonable time either for the authority initiating suo motu action or the party concerned, resorting to S.98 of the Act of 1950.

Coming to the case at hand, undisputedly deceased - a protected tenant, since date of sale deed i.e. 18.2.1966 till his death, never filed any application raising any plea in relation to the suit property and/or his right as a protected tenant and/or regarding transaction in question i.e. sale deed dated 18.2.1966 or his illegal dispossession. The exact date of death of Kisan is not on record. From the record it appears that he died some where in the year 1981. Date of filing of the application, as noted in the foregoing paragraphs is 10.11.1985. About 18/19 years have been passed for filing such an application by the original petitioners i.e. legal heirs of Kisan. It would not be justified for a person, who has purchased the property in the year 1966 to face such a proceeding under section 98 after about lapse of 18/19 years. Finality to the actions has to be there. Even though no limitation is provided under section 98, it has to be accepted to be a reasonable time either for the authority initiating suo motu action or the party concerned, resorting to section 98 of the Act of 1950. 1992(1) Mah.L.R. 861 & 2001(4) Mh.L.J. 31 - Ref. to.						  [Para 15]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Restoration of possession
Claim for
Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Restoration of possession - Claim for - Petitioner occupying suit land as tenant - Termination of tenancy - Landlord obtaining possession for personal cultivation - Auction of suit property for recovery of excise dues - Records showing that auction was conducted and name of respondent recorded in revenue record showing him as auction purchaser - Discontinuation of cultivation by original landlord - Said discontinuation not being voluntary with object to defeat right of ex-tenant - Petitioner tenant not entitled to possession.	(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Dispute about possession of tenanted land
HeadNote.description: Dispute about possession of tenanted land - Taking possession without resorting to S.32(2) is an offence under S.32(4) - Only remedy available to take possession from protected tenant is resort to S.32(2) by filing application thereunder. (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Application for personal cultivation
HeadNote.description: Application for personal cultivation - Can be filed only by person who was owner prior to appointed date - Minor, born on 23.08.1953, on attaining majority applying for personal cultivation on basis of will executed by original land holder in 1966 - Held, Revenue Tribunal was justified in rejecting application. 	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
HeadNote.sub_clause: S.102 A(c), Govt. Circular dt.9-8-1955 and dt.3-11-1970
heading: Service Inam Lands
HeadNote.description: Service Inam Lands - Application by petitioner Inamdar for possession - Respondents claiming tenancy rights of lands leased out to them - Held, respondents claim cannot be allowed as their rights were to be safeguarded for particular year only. (Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Eviction of unauthorised occupier of Land
HeadNote.description: Eviction of unauthorised occupier of Land - Plaintiff's husband becoming owner of land under S. 38E - On his death plaintiff becoming owner and filing civil suit for eviction of defendant in wrongful possession of part of land - Defendant alleging that he had purchased disputed land through plaintiff's husband - Alleged sale deed falls within mischief of S. 50-B and is rendered void - Possession of defendant not less than that of an unauthorised occupier - Suit is maintainable and S.98 could not be invoked. (Para 4)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Eviction of unauthorised occupier of land
HeadNote.description: Eviction of unauthorised occupier of land - Plaintiff's husband becoming owner of land under S. 38E - On his death plaintiff filing civil suit for eviction of defendant in wrongful possession of part of land - Defendant alleging to have purchased land through plaintiff's husband - Alleged sale deed is hit by S.50-B and rendered void - Defendant's possession is unauthorised - Suit is maintainable and is not barred by S. 98. (Para 4)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Sale of lands
HeadNote.description: Sale of lands - No prior permission of Collector obtained - Sale deeds were void - Suit by plaintiff for permanent injunction and peaceful possession - Court cannot grant relief and parties are left to suffer consequences.	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: S 38 applies to both protected and ordinary tenant
HeadNote.description:
S 38 applies to both protected and ordinary tenant - S. 38E applies to protected tenant only - Mere default by tenant in part payment is not ground to make transfer under S.38E ineffective.

W.P. 564/80 dt 17-11-87 (Bom) Overruled.

To declare the purchase transfer under S.38E of the Act as ineffective two conditions are essential viz. the first is that the tenant commits a default in the payment of entire purchase price and second inspite of the proceeding for recovery, the entire price amount could not be recovered. WP 564/80 dt 17-11-87 (Bom) overruled.  [Para 9]

Both sections i.e. 38 and 38 E are required to be read independent of each other specially when section 38 applies for both protected as well as ordinary tenant and deals with a voluntary act on the part of the tenant and the landlord and section 38 E deals with the statutory right of ownership automatically from the date notified by the Govt. in favour of protected tenant alone and there is no role assigned to the landholder except to apply for fixation of reasonable price. To make transfer under Section 38 E effective, the provisions of subsection 3 of the said Section alone will apply and the provisions of Clause [d] of subsection 6 of Section 38 do not come into play at all. Both the provisions apply in the case of respective purchase transfers independently and it cannot be read that for declaring the purchase transfer under Section 38 E as ineffective, the provisions of Clause [d] of subsection 6 of Section 38 would apply.  [Para 6,8]

The Legislature has  provided a separate methodology for declaring the transfer of ownership under Section 38 E ineffective and the procedure provided for making the transfer ineffective under section 38 of the Act cannot be transposed or implied to be included under the provisions of Section 38 E. Though subsection 3 states that the provisions of subsection 4 to 9 of Section 38 shall "mutatis mutandis" apply, that does not mean that the provisions of subsection 6 of Section 38 are made applicable suo motu for declaration of the transfer as ineffective and the term "mutatis mutandis" means "with necessary changes".

(1983) 2 SCC 82.  [Para 7]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Proceedings for termination of tenancy and restoration of possession of land for non-payment of rent for period from 1967-68 to 1972-73
HeadNote.description: Proceedings for termination of tenancy and restoration of possession of land for non-payment of rent for period from 1967-68 to 1972-73 - Compliance of requirement of giving intimation by landlord to tenant of default in payment of rent within six month's period of each default under proviso to S.28(1) - No convincing evidence led on behalf of petitioner landlord that such intimations were given to tenant to satisfy requirement of S.28(1) Proviso - Held, Revenue Tribunal had rightly set aside order of restoration made by Deputy collector in favour of landlord - There being no apparent error on the face of record and no perversity in impugned judgment being seen, exercise of jurisdiction under Art.227 of Constitution not called for. (2000)8 SCC 400 Referred.			(Paras 18, 20, 23)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Eviction
Application for
Maintainability
Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Application for - Maintainability - Petitioner, a 'protected tenant', having possession of suit land - Said suit land being situated in then Osmandabad district, proceedings initiated to confer ownership on tenant - Provisional declaration made in favour of tenant as per Hyderabad Transfer of ownership Rules, 1955 - Objection raised by original owner - Rejection of - Issuance of certificate in favour of tenant declaring him owner - Landlord ceasing to have any title over suit land so as to create any tenancy in favour of any other person - Remedy sought by petitioner under S.98 - Held, maintainable.		(Paras 15, 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Preferential right to purchase
HeadNote.description: Preferential right to purchase - Petitioners entered into agreement to sell disputed land - Respondent No.1 asserting that he has inherited tenancy of said land and hence claiming preferential right to purchase said land - Application allowed by Tenancy tribunal and sale certificate also granted to him - Said order was upheld by Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal - Petitioners challenging this order of MRT - After death of landlady her daughter became owner of disputed land - Daughter admitted tenancy rights of respondent No.1 and also gave no objection to issuance of sale certificate in his favour - Petitioners have filed suit for injunction against respondent No.1 - Petitioners have also filed suit for specific performance of agreement against daughter of deceased landlady - Rights are not yet finally adjudicated by Civil Courts - Issue of tenancy is not decided against respondent No.1 and petitioners have not acquired ownership of land as yet - Petitioners have no locus standi to challenge judgment of MRT - Issuance of sale certificate also cannot be set aside as same is sequel to order of MRT - Order by MRT is not liable to be interfered with.	(Paras 7 to 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Restoration of possession
HeadNote.description: Restoration of possession - Petitioner sought restoration from respondent to whom he had leased out suit land - Respondent denied case of petitioner and claimed that he had been the tenant of suit land even prior to its purchase by petitioner - Also claimed that being a protected tenant he had preferential right to purchase suit land and purchase of same by petitioner is illegal - Facts also show that subsequent to sale of suit land, Revenue Board has revoked permission on ground of respondent being protected tenant - Thereafter petitioner had even filed a suit for recovery of purchase price paid by him - Held, after filing aforesaid suit for recovery petitioner ceased to have any right in suit land - He is neither entitled to arrears of rent nor for recovery of possession.			(Paras 8, 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Non-compliance with provisions of S.28 - Effect.

Bare perusal of section 28 would make  it abundantly clear that before any proceedings are initiated by the Tahsildar or Additional Tahsildar, as the case may be, to eject or evict the tenant, on the ground of default in depositing the rent, a notice is required to be issued, calling upon the tenant to tender to the land holder the rent in arrears together with the costs of proceedings within ninety days from the date of the order and if the tenant complies with such order, the Tahsildar shall, in lieu of making an order of ejectment pass an order directing that the tenancy has not been terminated and thereupon the tenant shall hold the land as if the tenancy had not been terminated. Under sub-section (2) of Section 28 of the Act, land-holder is entitled to apply to Tahsildar for recovery of rent not exceeding three years. In the instant  case merely by general observations, without following the relevant provisions under Section 28 of the said Act, or without adhering to the said provision, the Additional Tahsildar has recorded the finding that there is default in depositing the rent by Respondents and, on said ground, the application filed by the petitioner came to be allowed. Therefore, the findings recorded by the Additional Tahsildar on the aspect of default in depositing the rent, cannot be sustained since those findings are without adhering to the provisions of Section 28 of the said Act. There was no document on record to show or suggest that respondent was in possession of the suit land.			          [Para 12,13]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Lease
HeadNote.description: Lease - There can be oral lease accompanied by delivery of property - No registered document or any lease deed is required as per the S.5 of H.T. & A.L. Act.	(Paras 6, 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Reference of issue of tenancy by Civil Court to Revenue Authorities
HeadNote.description:
Reference of issue of tenancy by Civil Court to Revenue Authorities - Some decision rendered by authority - Matter taken to Tribunal in revision - Tribunal holding that issue of tenancy did not arise from pleadings in Civil Court - Such finding is beyond jurisdiction of Revenue Tribunal.

Provisions in S.99A(2) prescribed limitation upon the authority of the Revenue Courts to deal with the issue of tenancy referred to them by the Civil Court and does not empower the Revenue Courts to deal with the scope of the pleadings before the Civil Court and to decide whether those pleadings give rise for the issue of tenancy or not.  The jurisdiction to decide whether the pleadings before the Civil Court give rise for the issue of tenancy or not is entirely with the Civil Court and the Revenue Courts cannot encroach upon the said jurisdiction of the Civil Court.  It is also to be remembered that the tenancy legislation is a special statute and, therefore, the authorities constituted under the said Statute cannot travel beyond the scope of jurisdiction bestowed upon them under such statute. Therefore, the Tribunal could not interfere with the order passed by the Revenue authorities on ground that issue of tenancy did not arise from the pleadings in the written statement in the case.		 [Para 7,9]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Bar of jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Bar of jurisdiction - Suit for possession of agricultural land filed by trust on basis of title - Defendants claiming tenancy through one of the Mahants of the trust - Defendants were in possession of suit land since 1953 - Issue raised was whether defendant was a protected tenant or not - Trial judge however ventured to decide it own his own - First appellate court also overlooked provisions of 1950 Act as to bar of jurisdiction - If defendant is protected tenant, then jurisdiction of civil Court is ousted - Therefore, decree of courts below held not sustainable - Trial judge directed to frame issue in this regard and proceed only after receiving finding of competent authority. 	(Paras 16, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - S.38(E)(1) explanation does not provide for any limitation for presenting application by a tenant who is declared as owner seeking recovery of possession - Held, in absence of any specific provision debarring remedy after lapse of certain period, only alternative available to tenancy authority was to entertain application and pass appropriate orders in consonance with law. (1997)6 SCC 73 - Ref. to.	(Paras 7, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Any person unauthorisedly occupying or wrongfully in possession of any land
HeadNote.description:
Any person unauthorisedly occupying or wrongfully in possession of any land - The person is required to be evicted by following summary eviction - Said steps are required to be taken by the collector.

The person who is in possession of the property may be in a wrongful possession or unauthorizedly occupying the property, is required to be evicted by following summary eviction. Said steps are required to be taken by the Collector. However, in the instant case, the order passed by the Deputy Collector is passed in appeal filed by the appellant where the petitioner who is appellant therein, has questioned the correctness of the order of the Tahsildar directing the Circle Inspector to take possession of the suit land and retain the same with the Government. Therefore, the said order of the Tahsildar was confined to the provisions of Section 98-C of the said Act. However, the Deputy Collector in appeal filed by the petitioner travelled beyond the pleadings and prayers in the appeal and granted something which was not even asked by the respondent No.1 in the said proceedings. Therefore, though the Counsel for respondent No.1 strenuously contended that, even his application under section 98A of the said Act has been allowed and decided by the Deputy Collector on 23-10-2009, said contention is required to be rejected since the Deputy Collector has only adjudicated and decided the Appeal No. TNC-1/2009 filed by the petitioner herein.

Though the Counsel for respondent No.1 submits that, his application under Section 98-A of the said Act is not pending before the Deputy Collector, in that regard it has to be observed that, if the application is not pending and decided under section 98 of the said Act, it was open for respondent No. 1 to bring on record under which proceedings the said application is adjudicated and decided by the Deputy Collector separately, by giving opportunity to the petitioner to put forth his case. Nothing has been placed on record by respondent No.1 alongwith affidavit in reply to show that, his application under section 98A of the said Act has been adjudicated and decided by the Deputy Collector, who is competent to hear and decide the said application and the decision is rendered thereupon by directing the authorities to give possession to respondent No.1 herein. Therefore, what is challenged in this writ petition is the order of the Deputy Collector dated 23-10-2009 in Appeal No. TNC-01/2009 which is confirmed by the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal.

On careful perusal of the judgment and order of the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal, in para-10 the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal has mechanically confirmed the order passed by the Tahsildar and also the order passed by the Deputy Collector, without appreciating the contention of the petitioner that the order of the Deputy Collector was in excess of his jurisdiction.

Therefore, for the reasons aforesaid, Court allowed this writ petition. In the result, the judgment and order passed by the Tahsildar, Kalamnuri dated 10-11-2008 in Case No. 2008/Land/KV, confirmed by the Deputy Collector in Appeal No. TNC-1/2009 and further confirmed by the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal in Case No.43-B-2009-H is quashed and set aside.  [Para 17,20]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - The appeal is a valuable right of the parties - When any party approaches by way of filing appeal, necessarily authority has to restrict the judgment and order to the pleadings and prayers in the appeal. (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Right of pre-emption of co-owner
HeadNote.description:
Right of pre-emption of co-owner - Co-owner intending to purchase land should not possess more than 3 times of family holding - Relevant date to be considered is date of filing of suit and not date of decree.

 The relevant date for considering the right of pre-emption of co-owner to purchase lands of other co-owner in regards to deciding three times of family holding, is the date of filing of the suit and not the date of decree in the suit.

The right which has been claimed by the plaintiff to be exercised is a right of a pre-emption i.e. right to purchase the property in preference to the other purchasers being the co-sharer or co-holder of the said survey number and, therefore, the time at which the plaintiff is supposed to exercise the said right is the date on which the defendant no.2, his brother decided to sell away his share from the survey no. 82 and the respondent no.1 was about to purchase or purchased the said land. At that time the petitioner has to come forward and state that he has a right to purchase the said land and should offer the price for the said share. This is being analysed only for the purposes that, whether the plaintiff is entitled to purchase the said land on the basis of the pre-emption and if at all he is entitled to purchase on the basis of pre-emption, whether his holding exceeds as per the provisions of Section 47 on that day is a question to be considered, because if it is found that the co-owner also showed a willingness to sell this land to the plaintiff and actually transaction is completed, still if on that day it is found that the plaintiff's holding is more than three times as provided under section 47, the sale becomes invalid in view of the provisions of Section 47. Not only that but even if the defendant is not ready to sell the property to the plaintiff, however, the plaintiff's right by way of an entitlement to the purchase has to be considered in the light of Section 47 and if it is found that the plaintiff's holding exceeds three times of the family holding, even though the right of pre-emption is recognised, it cannot be enforced because of the Section 47 of the Act.  [Para 5]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Right of pre-emption of coowner
HeadNote.description: Right of pre-emption of coowner - Determination of holding of pre-emptor - Transfer made by pre-emptor during pendency of suit cannot be taken into consideration. (Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Mutation entry
Change of
Effect
HeadNote.description: Mutation entry - Change of - Effect - Both brothers were cultivating land jointly as ordinary tenants - Joint ownership vested in both u/s. 38 - Manipulation of mutation entry by one showing his share in excess of the other - Mutation entries do not confer any title - In absence of any registered document executed between brothers showing their shares as unequal - Individual shares of both remain equal.

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Revision under
Deemed tenant
Possession continued thereafter
HeadNote.description: Revision under - Deemed tenant - Person put in possession under a registered document - Possession continued thereafter - No Specific evidence that Landlord permitted possessor to stay on suit land and cultivate it - Though possessor pleaded contractual tenancy he failed to prove the same - Fact that initial possession was lawful does not mean that subsequent possession continued to be lawful - Finding by Revisional Court that possessor was lawfully cultivating land and hence was tenant - Improper. (Para 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Revision under
Scope
HeadNote.description: Revision under - Scope - Concurrent findings of lower Courts that Petitioner failed to prove his contractual tenancy - Reassessment of entire evidence by Revisional Court in reaching a contrary conclusion that Petitioner was a tenant - Improper and not within scope of revisional powers - Order of Revisional court set aside. (Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Validity
HeadNote.description:
Declaration of protected tenancy U/S.38E - Validity - Contention that as declaration U/S.38E made without notice to landlords of properties, it was violative of natural justice - In proceedings for declaration U/S.38E landowners given ample opportunities to dispute right to declaration - Also declaration made only after detailed enquiry U/S.38E and S.38A - Not necessary before declaration to issue individual notice to land owners - Contention unsustainable.

1994(5) SCC 566, 1993(4) SCC 727, (1994) 5 SCC 267, 1993 Supp. (4) SCC 260, 1995(1) SCC 537, 1991 Supp. 1 SCC 81 - Rel on.	(Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Appeal under
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Appeal under - Maintainability - Term "order" in S.90 - Declaration of tenancy U/S. 38E not a adjudication of rival claim and thus not a order - Ownership certificate U/S.38E a formal certificate of declaration of protected tenant in respect of property held by him - Appeal against declaration U/S.38E not maintainable.

1995(5) SCC 760 - Rel on.	(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Inam lands
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - Inam lands - Lands governed by Hyderabad Abolition of Inams and Cash Grants Act - Provisions of Tenancy Act, not applicable to Inam lands.		(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Eviction petition
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Eviction petition - Limitation - S.98(1) does not prescribe for any limitation period in respect of remedy available against unauthorised possessor. 2000(2) ALL MR 338 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Tenancy rights
HeadNote.description: Tenancy rights - Where the rights of the statutory tenants are protected under the Agrarian Law, which is a social welfare Legislature, held, it is difficult to read something to wipe out the tenancy rights which is not provided for under the Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act.	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Tenancy
Suit dismissed
Appeal, matter remanded
HeadNote.description: Tenancy - Certificate issued by Tribunal - Civil suit filed for declaring such certificate illegal - Suit dismissed - Appeal, matter remanded - Further appeal from such order - Plaintiff should have issued notice under section 80 of Civil P.C. and impleaded the Tribunal as party.	 (Para 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Tenancy
Suit dismissed
HeadNote.description: Tenancy - Certificate issued by Tribunal - Civil suit filed for declaring such Certificate illegal - Suit dismissed - Appeal, matter remanded- Further appeal from such order, held, issuance of Certificate can be challenged in accordance with the Act of 1950, plaintiff may challenge such Certificate before the forum provided under the Act of 1950 - Appeal partly allowed. 	(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Plea of fraud
Collusion
HeadNote.description: Suit for Specific Performance - Plea of fraud - Collusion - Plea of fraud cannot be vaguely adopted - Particulars of such plea must be given by the party - Mere proximity of the properties and good relations between plaintiff and defendant will not be a sufficient ground to reach conclusion that they are in collusion with each other. AIR 1977 SC 671 & 2007(3) Bom.C.R. 118 - Rel.on.	(Para 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Protected tenant
HeadNote.description: Protected tenant - Is entitled to purchase land holders interest in the land held by former as a protected tenant. (Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Notification dated 25.5.1957
HeadNote.description: Notification dated 25.5.1957 - Land held by protected tenant - From the date of notification, ownership of all lands held by protected tenants which they are entitled to purchase from their land holders, stands transferred to and vested in protected tenant holding it and from that date the protected tenant is deemed to have become full owner of such lands - Issue of ownership certificate in his favour is only a formality and it does not depend upon payment of purchase money by him. (Paras 15, 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Ownership certificate to protected tenant
HeadNote.description: Ownership certificate to protected tenant - No time limit is laid down and there is also no obligation to act within reasonable time - Further there is also no need for application for issue of ownership certificate. (Para 26)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Petition against unlawful dispossession
HeadNote.description:
Petition against unlawful dispossession - Non-prescription of limitation period - Legislature does not intend to fetter scope of proceedings u/s.98 - Application made after 20 years of dispossession, held, maintainable.
2007(5) Bom.C.R. 93 Disagreed.
2011(4) ALL MR 25, 2010(2) ALL MR 179 Rel. on.(Paras 40, 42)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Petition against unlawful dispossession
HeadNote.description: Petition against unlawful dispossession - Respondents were allegedly dispossessed by petitioner in 1974 - Bank parties related to each other and having common ancestors - Documents on record show that prior to 1974, respondents were in possession of suit land - Respondents who were protected tenants became full owners of land from notified date - No explanation by petitioners as to how they obtained possession - At no point of time petitioners raised issue of relationship so as to prevent claim of tenancy in accordance with S.5 - Possession by petitioners is unlawful - Order of restoration of possession to respondents, not to be interfered with.(Paras 43, 44, 46, 51, 53)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Tenant
HeadNote.description: Tenant - Respondent declared as trespasser in 1978 and was dispossessed - Earlier in 1965 Dy. Director (Land Reforms) had held that respondent was not tenant - Despite this he remained silent till 1976 and did not challenge the decision declaring that he is not a tenant - Belated attempt after such a long lapse of time to file application under S.8 cannot be countenanced.  (Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Revision
HeadNote.description:
Revision - Grounds.

A bare perusal of the provisions of Section 91 of the said Act would make it abundantly clear that, the revision is available only on three grounds. Firstly, that the order of the Collector was contrary to law; secondly, that the Collector failed to determine some material issue of law; or, thirdly, there was a substantial defect in following the procedure provided by the Act, which has resulted in the miscarriage of justice.  [Para 16]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Revisional jurisdiction of Revenue Tribunal
HeadNote.description:
Revisional jurisdiction of Revenue Tribunal - Tribunal Re-appreciating oral evidence of witnesses and disagreeing with findings of Dy. Collector (Land Reforms) - It was impermissible to re-appreciate evidence and as such order of tribunal cannot be sustained.

(1994) 4 BCR 432, AIR 1974 SC 2051 Rel. on.  (Para 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Second appeal
Interference with
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Concurrent finding of facts - Interference with - Courts below rendering concurrent findings of facts, as regards only part payment of agreed amount of consideration - Failure of appellants to prove the plea of full payment of consideration amount - Held, these findings of facts cannot be interfered with in second appeal.	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Permanent alienation
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of - Permanent alienation - Mere agreement of sale is neither a permanent alienation, nor it amounts to transfer of property - S.98-A would come into play only when a transfer is of permanent nature.

Mere agreement of sale is neither a permanent alienation, nor it amounts to transfer of property. Section 98-A would come into play only when a transfer is of permanent nature. The purport of section 98-A is to validate the permanent alienations which were effected in contravention of certain provisions of the H.T. & A.L. Act. The provision does not apply, in any case, to those transfers which were in embryonic stage. Obviously, it does not stand to reason that mere validation certificate under section 98-A would be of any avail to the appellants, though, admittedly, there was no permanent alienation effected in respect of the suit field. It would be futile to refer such a question to the Tenancy Tribunal in view of admitted facts.  [Para 10]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Hindu Law
Joint family property
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Joint family property - Activity for benefit of estate - Developing a land for residential purpose and then selling plots or selling land for development for residential purpose, held, is definitely an activity for benefit of estate - In absence of any challenge to alienations made by karta during his life time, all those sale-deeds need to be protected. 1994 Mh.L.J. 1127 - Ref. to.	(Para 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Invalid transaction
HeadNote.description: Invalid transaction - Such a transaction is made equivalent to a voidable transaction and not a void transaction. (1994)2 GLR 1168 - Rel. on.			(Para 27)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Restriction on sale
S.50B is attracted
HeadNote.description: Restriction on sale - Sale of land by two widows of one deceased 'R' - 'R' was protected tenant in said land - Permission of competent authority before sale is necessary - S.50B is attracted - Said permission not taken hence transaction is invalid.  (Paras 24 to 26)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Bar of jurisdiction of Civil Court
HeadNote.description:
Bar of jurisdiction of Civil Court - Relief sought is not only of recovery of possession on ground that transaction is invalid under S.50B - Relief also sought that sale deed should be held null and void and not binding on plaintiffs - Ground that Appellants purchasers have played fraud on widows of protected tenant - These contentions could not be agitated under S.98 - Suit before Civil Court is maintainable. 
1999(2) ALL MR 666 - Ref.to.  (Para 28)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Sale
HeadNote.description:
Sale - Transaction entered into on behalf of minor plaintiff no.1, 2 - Appellant purchasers failed to prove any legal necessity for sale transaction - Concurrent findings recorded by Courts below on basis of evidence - Contention that financial condition of plaintiffs was not good and defendant gave them jobs etc - Contentions to show legal necessity liable to be rejected. 
AIR 2011 SC 2344 - Ref. to. (Para 29)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Right of protected tenant to purchase land
HeadNote.description: Right of protected tenant to purchase land - Determination of market price - When it is for tenant to exercise the rights and to decide whether to purchase or not under S.38-E, tenant becomes owner even against his wish and obligation is cast upon the land owner to apply for determination of market price. 2000(2) ALL MR 338 - Ref. to.			(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Option to protected tenant
HeadNote.description:
Option to protected tenant - S.38 which gives option to protected tenant to purchase land does not contemplate situation where such protected tenant is not in possession.

The provisions of Section 38 which gives option to protected tenant to purchase land does not contemplate situation where such protected tenant is not in possession. Section 38-E with which this Court is concerned, vide its Explanation provides a remedy to protected tenant if he is not in possession of the land on the date of notification and his dispossession is otherwise then in manner and by order of Tahsildar as provided in Section 32. Explanation itself contemplates that such a tenant shall be deemed to have been holding the land on the date of notification and the Tahsildar has been given powers to pass appropriate orders for restoring actual possession. Thus, again this deeming fiction for possession is for the purposes of operation of main clause 38-E which statutorily transfers ownership to that tenant. Thus, when landlord has taken or procured both lands contrary to the provisions of Section 32, and therefore, the protected tenant is found not in possession on the date of notification, legi has taken precaution to confer the statutory ownership upon him and for restoration of his physical possession. Here, on 01.02.1957, father of petitioner was very much alive and was in cultivating possession, therefore, this Explanation does not provide any remedy to him. Section 46 is also a provision in 1950 Act which enables tenant to approach the Tahsildar for recovery of possession but then that operates only when the landlord who after termination of tenancy under Section 44 or Section 44-A, does not within one year of resumption of possession, start personal cultivation. That remedy therefore is again not available to the present petitioner.  [Para 17]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Summary eviction of person in unauthorised occupation or wrongful possession
HeadNote.description:
Summary eviction of person in unauthorised occupation or wrongful possession - S.98 does not contemplate filing of any application by any party to initiate proceedings under S.98.

In Section 98 only Collector has been enabled to summarily evict a person in unauthorised occupation or wrongful possession. It does not contemplate filing of any application by any party to initiate proceedings under Section 98. Thus, it only casts obligation on the Collector to evict such unauthorised or wrongful occupant. The fact of such wrongful or unauthorised occupation may come to knowledge of Collector belatedly through different sources & in various situations. It is therefore obvious that Legislature has only conferred the powers upon the authority to act in furtherance of provisions and for the purposes of 1950 Act to see that its aims and objections are achieved & preserved. No period of limitation therefore has been deliberately prescribed as such fact of unauthorised occupation or wrongful possession may also be deliberately suppressed by the parties from the Collector by adopting various means and measures. When the legislature has vested title in protected tenant on tiller's day against the wishes of land-holder, it is obvious that its design to advance the said cause, to protect or preserve that title from unscrupulous influences whenever it comes across such instances can not be allowed to be defeated by such technical pleas. Held, the absence or non-prescription of any period of limitation in Section 98 is deliberate and in tune with that object. (1997)6 SCC 71 and 2010(6) ALL MR 81 - Ref. to.   [Para 22]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Eviction of ex-landlord
Application u/S.98
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of ex-landlord - Application u/S.98 - Maintainability challenged on ground that tenant had to invoke S.32 - However, S.32 requires existence of tenant landlord relationship - As statutory transfer has already taken place by which the tenant became owner, relationship required u/S.32 does not exist - After such statutory transfer, possession by ex-landlord is unlawful - Remedy of summary eviction available u/S.98. 
1975 Mh.L.J.521 Ref. to. (Paras 5, 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Application u/S.98
HeadNote.description:
Application u/S.98 - No period of limitation prescribed - Application can be entertained by competent authority at any point of time.
2010(2) ALL MR 179, (1994) 1 SCC 44, 2010(6) ALL MR 81 Rel. on. (Paras 8, 9, 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Maintainability
Sale became ineffective
HeadNote.description:
Sale to protected tenant - Non-payment of price and refusal to take possession - Subsequent application by son of tenant seeking sale certificate - Maintainability - Sufficient opportunity given to protected tenant whose refusal recorded only after 7 yrs. of fixation of price - Sale became ineffective - Application by son of tenant after lapse of 32 yrs. not maintainable - Specially when possession was not with him but with landlords - Son of tenant left with no vested right.

1988(3) Bom.C.R. 311, 1983(1) Bom. C.R. 30, 2000(2) ALL MR 338 Ref. to. 			(Paras 6, 22, 35)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Sale of land
HeadNote.description: Sale of land - To son of protected tenant - After several years of refusal by protected tenant himself - Challenge raised by some persons who had established purchase of part of subject land from original landlady, allowed - Challenge raised also by petitioners claiming themselves to be sons of original landlord - However, they failed to establish any connection of their father with land in issue - Claim not appearing to be truthful - Petitioners having no locus standi to challenge impugned sale - Petition dismissed. 			(Paras 33, 34, 36)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Persons in unauthorised occupation of property - Remedy would be under S.98 and not under S.32(1) - Person who wrongly approached authorities under S.32(1) is not thereby estopped from initiating proceedings under S.98.			(Paras 9, 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Surrender of tenancy in favour of landlord or of successive transferee
HeadNote.description: Surrender of tenancy in favour of landlord or of successive transferee - Surrender to be lawful and valid must comply with provisions of Ss.19(1) and 47 - Surrender must be verified by Tahasildar as voluntary and lawful.	(Paras 9, 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - On ground that land being cultivated by brothers of original tenant - Nowhere in original application for eviction it was mentioned that brothers of original tenant residing separately and there was no undivided Hindu family at relevant time - Only contention made that original tenant had permitted his brothers to cultivate lands and in that way he sub-let suit lands to his brothers - Held, in absence of any specific averments in original application, presumption required to be drawn about undivided Hindu family - If land is cultivated by any member of such family, it shall be deemed to be cultivated personally in terms of provisions of S.2(1)(g) of Tenancy Act 1950. 1974 Mh.L.J. 972, 2005(1) ALL MR 168 Disting. 	(Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Termination of tenancy
Service of notice
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Service of notice - Compliance with S.19(2) of Hyderabad Tenancy Act (1950) - Mere production of postal acknowledgment receipt on record cannot be construed as due compliance of S.19(2) first Proviso - It is essential for petitioner to establish that six months notice in writing given to tenant for termination of tenancy and also to prove grounds of such termination as incorporated in said notice - Non-compliance with said provision, held fatal. 1980 Mh.L.J. 213 Ref.to.	(Paras 12, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Application for eviction
HeadNote.description: Application for eviction - Whether barred by limitation - Nowhere in application it is mentioned when cause of action arose - However, in cross-examination applicant admitted that suit lands given to original tenant in April 1955 - Further, for 5-7 years tenant cultivated suit land personally, thereafter sub-let suit lands to his real brothers - Inference drawn that in year 1967 right to possession of suit lands accrued to applicant as per provisions of S.32(2) of Tenancy Act (1950) - Application however filed in Aug., 1973 - Thus, application barred by limitation. 	(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Proceedings under
HeadNote.description: Proceedings under - Ground of bonafide need for personal cultivation - Landlord expired pending proceedings - Landlord's heirs must prove their bonafide personal need - Writ petition by tenant - As 40 yrs. elapsed since initiation of proceedings - Trial Court directed to record finding of bonafide requirement and send record to High Court for hearing.

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Joint-tenants
Improper
HeadNote.description: Proceedings for declaration of sub-tenancy - Joint-tenants - Property under two different survey numbers - Both tenants entitled to half share in property in each of survey numbers - Declaration in favour of one tenant in relation to property in excess of half share in property under one survey number - Improper - However a tenant's tenancy rights in respect of entire joint property remain intact.	(Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Occupancy rights
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Deputy Collector - Occupancy rights - Grant of occupancy rights - Rights to be conferred on person who is in possession of inam lands on 1-7-1960 - Grant of occupancy whether individually or as karta of joint family, is to be decided by the Civil Court and not by the Deputy Collector under S.99 of Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.9.  1977(LXXIX) BLR 234 - Rel. on. (Para 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Rent
What includes
HeadNote.description: Rent - What includes - Rent means any consideration, in money or kind or both, paid or payable by a tenant but does not include rendering of any personal service or labour. (Para 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1950)
heading: Tenant
HeadNote.description: Tenant - No record or document produced to show that respondent was tenant - Entry in 7/12 extract from 1963 to 1979 - From 1980 entry was in the name of appellant - Mere entry in 7/12 extract is not sufficient to declare respondent as tenant in absence of fulfilling requirements of definition of 'tenant'. (Para 13)

heading: Home Guards

HeadNote.act_name: High Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act (1954)
heading: Pension to High Court Judges
HeadNote.description:
Pension to High Court Judges - Computation of service period - As regards Judges who were appointed from Bar being eminent lawyers, their service period will be computed by including ten years of practice as advocate - Fixing lesser pension of such Judges than Judges appointed from subordinate judiciary would be violative of Art.14. 

When persons who occupied the Constitutional Office of Judge, High Court retire, there should not be any discrimination with regard to the fixation of their pension. Irrespective of the source from where the Judges are drawn, they must be paid the same pension just as they have been paid same salaries and allowances and perks as serving Judges. Only practicing Advocates who have attained eminence are invited to accept Judgeship of the High Court. Because of the status of the office of High Court Judge, the responsibilities and duties attached to the office, hardly any advocate of distinction declines the offer. Though it may be a great financial sacrifice to a successful lawyer to accept Judgeship, it is the desire to serve the society and the high prestige attached to the office and the respect the office commands that propel a successful lawyer to accept Judgeship. The experience and knowledge gained by a successful lawyer at the Bar can never be considered to be less important from any point of view vis-a-vis the experience gained by a judicial officer. If the service of a judicial officer is counted for fixation of pension, there is no valid reason as to why the experience at Bar cannot be treated as equivalent for the same purpose. The fixation of higher pension to the Judges drawn from the Subordinate Judiciary who have served for shorter period in contradistinction to Judges drawn from the Bar who have served for longer period with less pension is highly discriminatory and breach of Article 14 of the Constitution. The classification itself is unreasonable without any legally acceptable nexus with the object sought to be achieved. In most of the States, the Judgeship of the High Court is offered to advocates who are in the age group of 50-55 years, since pre-eminence at the Bar is achieved normally at that age. After remaining at the top for a few years, a successful lawyer may show inclination to accept Judgeship, since that is the culmination of the desire and objective of most of the lawyers. When persons holding constitutional office retire from service, making discrimination in the fixation of their pensions depending upon the source from which they were appointed is in breach of Articles 14 and 16(1) of the Constitution. One rank one pension must be the norm in respect of a Constitutional Office.				    [Para 24,25,27]

heading: Grant of
Powers of Magistrate
HeadNote.description:
Family Courts Act (1984), S.7 - Maintenance to unmarried daughter - Grant of - Powers of Magistrate - U/S.20 of Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, unmarried daughter unable to maintain herself, entitled to maintenance from father till she is married even though she attained majority - Proceedings for maintenance u/S.20 of said Act to be filed only before District Court or Subordinate Civil Court - Magistrate while deciding proceedings u/S.125 Cr.P.C., could not exercise jurisdiction u/S.20.
	Section 20(3) of Act, 1956 recognised the right of a minor girl to claim maintenance after she attains majority till her marriage from her father. Unmarried daughter is clearly entitled for maintenance from her father till she is married even though she has become major, which is a statutory right recognised by Section 20(3) and can be enforced by unmarried daughter in accordance with law. (Para 31)
	After enactment of Family Courts Act, 1984, a Family Court shall also have the jurisdiction exercisable by a Magistrate of the First Class under Chapter IX of Cr.P.C. relating to order for maintenance of wife, children and parents. Family Courts shall have the jurisdiction only with respect to city or town whose population exceeds one million, where there is no Family Courts, proceedings under Section 125 Cr.P.C. shall have to be before the Magistrate of the First Class. In an area where the Family Court is not established, a suit or proceedings for maintenance including the proceedings under Section 20 of the Act, 1956 shall only be before the District Court or any subordinate Civil Court.
	There may be a case where the Family Court has jurisdiction to decide a case under Section 125 Cr.P.C. as well as the suit under Section 20 of Act, 1956, in such eventuality, Family Court can exercise jurisdiction under both the Acts and in an appropriate case can grant maintenance to unmarried daughter even though she has become major enforcing her right under Section 20 of Act, 1956 so as to avoid multiplicity of proceedings. However the Magistrate in exercise of powers under Section 125 Cr.P.C. cannot pass such order. (Paras 32, 33, 38)
	In the instant case, the application was filed under Section 125 Cr.P.C. before Judicial Magistrate First Class, Rewari who passed the order dated 16.02.2011. The Magistrate while deciding proceedings under Section 125 Cr.P.C. could not have exercised the jurisdiction under Section 20(3) of Act, 1956 and allowed the application for maintenance even though she has become major. (Paras 34, 37)
	The purpose and object of Section 125 Cr.P.C. is to provide immediate relief to applicant in a summary proceedings, whereas right under Section 20 read with Section 3(b) of Act, 1956 contains larger right, which needs determination by a Civil Court, hence for the larger claims as enshrined under Section 20, the proceedings need to be initiated under Section 20 of the Act and the legislature never contemplated to burden the Magistrate while exercising jurisdiction under Section 125 Cr.P.C. to determine the claims contemplated by Act, 1956. (Para 36)

heading: Adoption of child
women and men
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Art.21 - Adoption of child - Adoption is a facet of the right to life under Art.21 of the Constitution - The right to live that is asserted is, on the one hand, the right of parents and of individuals - Women and men who seek to adopt a child to give meaning and content to their lives.

Adoption is a facet of the right to life under Article 21 of the Constitution. The right to live that is asserted is, on the one hand, the right of parents and of individuals - women and men - who seek to adopt a child to give meaning and content to their lives. Equally significant, in the context of the Juvenile Justice Act, 2000, the right to life that is specially protected is the right of children who are in need of special care and protection. The legislature has recognized their need for rehabilitation and social integration to obviate the disruptive social consequences of destitution, abandonment and surrender. There is legislative recognition of adoption as a means to subserve the welfare of orphaned, abandoned and surrendered children. (1982)2 SCC 202 - Ref. to.	 [Para 19]

heading: Adoption of child
HeadNote.description:
Adoption of child - Scope and applicability of Juvenile Justice Act - Juvenile Justice Act is a special enactment dealing with children in conflict with law and children in need of care and protection - Religious identity of child or of parents who adopt is not a pre-condition to applicability of the law - Law is secular and deals with conditions of social destitution which cut across religious identities.

The Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956 and the Juvenile Justice Act, 2000 must be harmoniously construed. The Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956 deals with conditions requisite for adoption by Hindus. The Juvenile Justice Act of 2000 is a special enactment dealing with children in conflict with law and children in need of care and protection. While enacting the Juvenile Justice Act, 2000 the legislature has taken care to ensure that its provisions are secular in character and that the benefit of adoption is not restricted to any religious or social group. The focus of the legislation is on the condition of the child taken in adoption. If the child is orphaned, abandoned or surrendered, that condition is what triggers the beneficial provisions for adoption. The legislation seeks to ensure social integration of such children and adoption is one method to achieve that object. The religious identity of the child or of the parents who adopt is not a precondition to the applicability of the law. The law is secular and deals with conditions of social destitution which cut across religious identities. The legislature in its wisdom clarified in sub-section (6) of Section 41 that the Court may allow a child to be given in adoption to parents to adopt a child of the same sex irrespective of the number of living biological sons or daughters. This provision is intended to facilitate the rehabilitation of orphaned, abandoned or surrendered children. The condition must apply to all persons irrespective of religious affiliation who seek to adopt children of that description. The object of rehabilitation and providing for social reintegration to orphaned, abandoned or surrendered children is a matter of high legislative policy. It is in effectuation of that policy that the legislature has stipulated that adoption of such a child must proceed irrespective of the marital status of a person taking in adoption and irrespective of the number of living biological children of the parents seeking adoption. Consequently, where the child which is sought to be adopted falls within the description of an orphaned, abandoned or surrendered child within the meaning of sub-section (2) of Section 41 or a child in need of care and protection under clause (d) of Section 2, the provisions of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000 must prevail. In such a case the embargo that is imposed on adopting a child of the same sex by a Hindu under clauses (i) and (ii) of Section 11 of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956 must give way to the salutary provisions made by the Juvenile Justice Act. Where, however, the child is not of a description falling under the purview of Chapter IV of the Juvenile Justice Act, 2000, a Hindu desirous of adopting a child continues to be under the embargo imposed by clauses (i) and (ii) of Section 11 of the Act of 1956. If the two pieces of legislation, both of which are enacted by Parliament are harmoniously construed, there is no conflict of interpretation.  [Para 20]

(Para 7)

heading: Maintenance
Liability of father
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Liability of father - Every father is under an obligation to maintain his daughters and even get them married - A father who lives separately from his wife, therefore, cannot escape the liability to maintain his daughters - Definition of "maintenance" includes the provision of reasonable expenses of and incidental to marriage of daughter.

The question as to whether plaintiff's suit should completely fail simply because the evidence of borrowing money from these persons is found to be not worthy of credit. We have seen that defendant is admittedly the father of the three daughters whom the plaintiff got married. Every father is under an obligation to maintain his daughters and even to get them married. The obligation to maintain the daughter and get her married is said to be personal in character and arises from the very existence of the relationship. Under the Hindu Law, a daughter is entitled to be maintained out of estate of her father even after the death of the father. In the instant case, the father is alive and admittedly has source of income from salary and agriculture land. A father who lives separately from his wife, therefore, cannot escape the liability to maintain his daughters. Here, it would be necessary to look into the definition of the word maintenance as given in the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956. The word has been defined as follows -

"maintenance" includes -

(i)	in all cases, provision for food, clothing, residence, education and medical attendance and treatment;

(ii)	in the case of an unmarried daughter, also the reasonable expenses of and incidental to her marriage;

The definition is inclusive. It includes the provision of the reasonable expenses of and incidental to marriage of daughter. It is thus clear that father, who has deserted his wife and daughters is also liable to make a provisions of reasonable expenses for the marriage of daughters. Thus, not under the old Hindu Law but under the codified Hindu Law also the father is bound to make such a provision as can be seen from the definition of word maintenance.

In the instant case, the plaintiff who is the mother of daughters filed the suit. She has made a specific plea that she had incurred loans and had spent for the marriages of the daughters. The defendant admitted during the course of his examination before the court that his wife did spend for the marriages of his daughters. The Law envisages that a father is bound to make provision for the marriage expenses of the daughters as a part of maintenance. Therefore, if wife has spent for the performance of the marriage of the daughter, the husband would certainly be liable to reimburse the wife. He cannot escape his liability in any case.  AIR 1992 Madras 242 - Ref. to.   [Para 9,10]
