heading: Suit filed by wife for "Stridhan" and maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Suit filed by wife for "Stridhan" and maintenance - Compromise decree passed and amount of maintenance fixed on basis of her income at that time - Income of wife substantially increased - Application by husband for altering amount of maintenance is maintainable.

The amount of maintenance though fixed by the agreement between the parties can be altered subsequently if there is a material change in the circumstances justifying such alterations and therefore, the application filed by the Applicant under Section 25 of the Act of 1956, is maintainable.	 [Para 12]

It is no doubt true that when the trial court pases compromise decree in the civil suit, the terms and conditions on which the compromise decree is passed by the court are binding on the parties to such compromise decree and in the normal circumstances such compromise decree can only be reopened, altered, modified or revoked if it is obtained by fraud, misrepresentation, coercion etc. and not otherwise.	 [Para 8]

It is evident that one of the considerations to be kept in mind by the Court while determining the amount of maintenance to a wife is the earning/income, if any, of the wife and whether it is sufficient or otherwise to fulfill her reasonable wants.  Therefore, after determining the amount of maintenance if the decree is passed accordingly or by agreement of the parties the amount of maintenance is fixed, however, at later point of time if there is material change in the circumstances, on the basis thereof the amount of maintenance is fixed and if such change justifies the alteration of the amount of maintenance so fixed, in such situation the right is given to either of the spouse to move the Court for such alteration.						 [Para 9]

heading: Second marriage while first marriage is subsisting
HeadNote.description:
Second marriage while first marriage is subsisting - Marriage is void under S.11 read with S.5(1) - Second wife however is not disentitled from claiming maintenance pendente lite under S.24 - She is also not disentitled from claiming interim maintenance under S.18 of 1956 Act.

Words and phrases - Wife.

Even in a case of bigamous marriage one of the parties can seek a decree of nullity of marriage by way of petitioner or respondent which is permissible under Section 23-A of the Act.  In pending proceedings even at the instance of the second wife in a void bigamous marriage, the court is empowered to make an attempt for re-conciliation, to pass necessary orders with regard to the custody of children and disposal of the property exchanged at the time of marriage.  The court has also power in such proceedings to make an order of permanent alimony or maintenance under Section 25 of the Act.  The Act confers wide powers on the matrimonial Court so as to regulate matrimonial relationship between the parties and such powers are to be exercised by the court even in a case of alleged or proved bigamous marriage.  In enacting Section 24 a special provision is made for ordering interim maintenance and the expenses of litigation to be provided for the contesting husband or wife if he or she had no independent sufficient income.  Therefore, there is no reason why the words "wife" or "husband" used in Section 24 should not be interpreted so as to include a man and woman who have gone through a ceremony of a Hindu marriage which would have been valid but for the provisions of Section 11 read with clause (i) of Section 5 of the Hindu Marriage Act.  These words have been used as convenient terms to refer the parties who have gone through a ceremony of marriage whether or not that marriage is valid or subsisting, just as the word "marriage" has been used in the Act to include a purported marriage which is void ab initio.  [Para 9]

heading: Adoption by widow
HeadNote.description:
Adoption by widow - Cannot deprive adoptive mother of power to dispose of her separate property by transfer or Will.

An adoption of a son does not deprive the adoptive mother of the power to dispose of her separate property by transfer or by Will (See: Hindu Law by Mulla - 17th Edn. pages 447 and 449). In the present appeal, we are concerned with plaintiff's title to the suit property. The plaintiff was adopted in 1964-65. However, adoption did not divest 1st defendant of the suit property which vested in her by succession on the death of her husband. It is for this reason that the plaintiff relied on Ex.P-1 contending that the said deed was a deed of adoption-cum-settlement. Transfer of title in favour of the plaintiff had no relevance with the adoption because mere adoption did not deprive defendant No.1 of her right to dispose of her own disposable property. In the present case, the High Court had erred in holding that the recital in Ex.P.1 was sufficient to constitute transfer of the title. That Ex.P-1 itself vested the suit property on the plaintiff. As held by the lower appellate Court, Ex.P-1 has not been stamped. It does not identify the suit property. It did not contain Valuation. In the circumstances, it did not convey any right, title or interest in favour of the plaintiff. The High Court has not gone into these aspects at all. There was no valid settlement. Consequently the lower appellate Court and the trial Court were right in dismissing the suit.   [Para 6]

heading: Adoption by female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Adoption by female Hindu - Crippled lady having practically no legs getting married - Her husband left her right from the date of marriage and both were living separately for a very long period - Lady adopted a son to look after her and he was in fact doing so - Held, in absence of dissolution of marriage she was unable to adopt a son because there was conceptual and contextual difference between a divorced woman and one who was leading life like a divorced woman - Both cannot be equated.		(Para 10)

heading: Interim maintenance under S.24
HeadNote.description:
Interim maintenance under S.24 - Reimbursement of medical expenses incurred by dependant wife - Word "support" in S.24 can be given same meaning as is given to the word "maintenance" in S.3(b)(i) of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act - Hence wife would he entitled to reimbursement of medical expenses in an application under S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act.

Provisions of Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act provides for support to be nby the earning spouse in favour of non earning spouse during the pendency of proceedings before the Court. The question is as to whether medical expenses incurred by the claimant can form part of an application under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act. The word "support" has not been defined under the Hindu Marriage Act. We will have to only look at the definition as given in the dictionary or as understood in general parlance. However, we can draw inspiration from the word "maintenance" which has been defined under the provisions of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act. Section 3(b)(i) of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act defines maintenance to be inclusive of provision for food, clothing, residence, education and medical attendance and treatment. The definition here is also not an extensive definition, but inclusive one and nevertheless specifically mentions about medical attendance and, treatment. The meaning attributed to the word "maintenance" and as defined under Section 3(b)(i) can be taken to be the meaning even under the word "support" used under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act.  [Para 10,11]

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Encompasses a provision for residence.

Maintenance, necessarily must encompass a provision for residence. Maintenance is given so that the lady can live in the manner, more or less, to which she was accustomed. The concept of maintenance must, therefore, include provision for food and clothing and the like and take into account the basic need of a roof over the head. Provision for residence may be made either by giving a lump sum in money, or property in lieu thereof. It may also be made by providing, for the course of the lady's life, a residence and money for other necessary expenditure. Where provision is made in this manner, by giving a life interest in property for the purposes of residence, that provision is made in lieu of a pre-existing right to maintenance and the Hindu lady acquires far more than the vestige of title which is deemed sufficient to attract Section 14(1).  1995(6) SCC 88, 2005(2) SCALE 105 - Foll.   [Para 9]

heading: Possession of premises by female Hindu

heading: Maintenance of widowed daughter-in-law
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance of widowed daughter-in-law - Scope and applicability of S.19(1) - Self acquired property of father-in-law - Even though there may have been as per uncodified Hindu law, some obligation upon a father-in-law to maintain his widowed doughter-in-law even out of his self acquired property, it has ceased to have effect and cannot be implemented if the right to claim accrued after 1956 Act came into force - An obligation which cannot be legally enforced cannot be recognized as legal obligation - S.19(1) of the Act cannot be read independent of S.19(2) of the Act.

Even though there may have been as per uncodified Hindu law, some obligation upon a father-in-law to maintain his widowed daughter-in-law even out of his self acquired property; it has ceased to have effect & can not be implemented if right to claim it accrued after 1956 Act came into force.  An obligation which cannot be legally enforced cannot be recognized as legal obligation at all.  Section 19 is a complete scheme in itself which provides for an obligation and also its enforcement.  It creates a right in daughter-in-law with corresponding liability on father in law.  It specifies in what circumstances & to what extent the right accrues and when or how it is enforceable.  It is therefore not possible to read Section 19(1) independent of Section 19(2) of Act.  AIR 1977 Madras 372 and AIR 1981 AP 88 - Ref.to.  [Para 9,10]

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Grant of maintenance to wife - Challenge to - Decree of restitution of conjugal rights against wife - Held, when the husband has succeeded in obtaining a decree of restitution of conjugal rights against the wife, it is implied that wife was required to join the company of the husband at her matrimonial home and therefore, there is no question of maintenance at least from the date of the said order - Order to that extent is required to be set aside - However, Court refused to interfere in the maintenance granted to daughter.

When the husband has succeeded in obtaining a decree of restitution of conjugal rights against the wife, it is implied that the wife was required to join the company of the husband at her matrimonial home and therefore, there is no question of maintenance at least from the date of the said order. If the wife is directed to be paid maintenance despite the said decree, reluctance of the wife to join the husband would be further strengthened and she would be encouraged to stay away from the husband despite the decree passed by the Court. The decree for restitution of conjugal rights would be rendered inoperative and for such an act of the wife, the husband would be penalized to pay the maintenance to the wife, who does not subject to the decree passed by the Court. Such a direction would be incentive to frustrate the decree passed under Section 9 of the Act. If such a decree is passed at the instance of the wife and against the husband, the Court would be justified in directing the husband to pay maintenance to the wife till he resumes co-habitation with her or calls upon her to join him at the matrimonial home pursuant to the decree passed by the Court in her favour. Such is not a case before Court. Court is, therefore, satisfied that the Family Court acted without jurisdiction in directing the husband to pay maintenance at least from the date when the impugned order was passed and therefore, the impugned order to that extent is required to be set aside. However, the Court refused to interfere in the maintenance granted to the daughter. AIR 2005 SC 986 - Ref. to.  [Para 12]

heading: Maintenance of wife
HeadNote.description: Maintenance of wife - Woman marrying a man whose first marriage was subsisting and wife living - Not entitled to claim maintenance. 1975(1) MLJ 142 (DB) Followed.	(Paras 10, 17)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125 - Maintenance - Right of second wife - Second marriage during subsistence of first one is void ipso jure being in contravention of S.5(i) of Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 - A woman entering into such Marriage is not a "wife" within the meaning of either Hindu Marriage Act or Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act or S.125 of Cr.P.C. - Hence cannot claim maintenance under any of these statutes.

A marriage contravening S.5(i) of Hindu Marriage Act is void ipso jure and the woman entering into such a marriage is not a "wife" within the meaning of either Hindu Marriage Act or S.125 of Cr.P.C.  The expression "wife" used in both statutes means only a legally wedded wife.  The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act cannot be treated differently for the meaning to the expression "wife" used therein.  The expression must be given the meaning in which it is understood in law applicable to the parties.  Since the institution of Marriage and the very relationship of husband and wife originates from personal law applicable to the parties, there can be no escape from reference to personal law while understanding the expression "husband" and "wife" used in different statutes.  As far as Hindus are concerned, the law relating to Marriage amongst Hindus is codified by Hindu Marriage Act and therefore unless the marriage is valid under the provisions of Hindu Marriage Act the parties entering into such a Marriage cannot describe themselves as "husband" and "wife" for the purposes of application of different statutes or for deriving the benefits available under different statutes.

As regards the argument based on S.18(2)(d) of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act (which enables a wife to live separately and claim maintenance if her husband has any other wife living) is concerned, such a provision can obviously exist only in case of Marriages solemnized before Hindu Marriage Act came into operation.  Had the Hindu Marriage Act not laid down monogamy as a rule of law and that Hindu husband cannot marry another wife after the commencement of that Act, clause (d) could not have been included in S.18(2) of Hindu Adoption & Maintenance Act.  Further, a bigamous marriage contracted after coming into force of Hindu Marriage Act being null and void, question of having another wife cannot arise after the Hindu Marriage Act came into operation.  Therefore, it can be applicable only in cases where a husband has entered into two Marriages prior to coming into operation of Hindu Marriage Act.

Therefore, the expression "Hindu wife" used in S.18 of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act, means legally wedded Hindu wife and no less. A second wife not being the legally wedded wife cannot resort to S.18 to claim maintenance.  AIR 1999 AP 19 - Rel. on.  AIR 2008 Delhi 7 - Dissented from.   2004(3) Mh.L.J. 487, I(2002) DMC 136 (DB) Distinguished.		 [Para 22,23,28]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Death of sole surviving Co-parcener - Son adopted by widow of another deceased Co-parcener after death of sole surviving Co-parcener - Cannot divest-properties vested in heirs immediately after death of sole surviving Co-parcener - He cannot claim any share.

Adoption relates back to the death of the adopting father and an adopted son must be looked upon as if he was in existence at the date of the death of the adopting father. But it is not a correct proposition to say that the rights of adopted son are in all respects identical with that of a natural born son. The principle of relation back is not an absolute principle but it has certain limitations.  AIR 1950 Bom. 360 Approved of.   [Para 20]

On the date of death of a sole surviving coparcener the properties of the joint family in his hands devolve on his heirs, i.e., his sons and daughters as per Section 6 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, subject to rights of maintenance of the widow of another coparcener who died prior to death of sole surviving coparcener.  Opening of succession and devolving of properties operate immediately on the death of the sole surviving coparcener and the joint family properties stand vested in his heirs.  Where a son was adopted by the widow of a deceased coparcener about four months after the death of sole surviving coparcener by which time the properties had already been vested in his heirs, the adopted son by virtue of his adoption four months after the death of sole surviving coparcener could not divest the properties vested in the heirs of the sole surviving coparcener so as to claim his share in view of the proviso (c) of S.12

S.A. No.405 of 1994 dt.27.6.1994 (Bom) Reversed.		   [Para 15]

heading: Term 'consent' used in proviso and explanation
HeadNote.description:
Term 'consent' used in proviso and explanation - Not defined in Act - It should be in writing or reflected by affirmative/positive act voluntarily and willingly done by - Consent cannot be inferred from silence or lack of protest.

The term 'consent' used in the proviso to Section 7 and the explanation appended thereto has not been defined in the Act. Therefore, while interpreting these provisions, the Court shall have to keep in view the legal position obtaining before enactment of the 1956 Act, the object of the new legislation and apply the rule of purposive interpretation and if that is done, it would be reasonable to say that the consent of wife envisaged in the proviso to Section 7 should either be in writing or reflected by an affirmative/positive act voluntarily and willingly done by her. If the adoption by a Hindu male becomes subject matter of challenge before the Court, the party supporting the adoption has to adduce evidence to prove that the same was done with the consent of his wife. This can be done either by producing document evidencing her consent in writing or by leading evidence to show that wife had actively participated in the ceremonies of adoption with an affirmative mindset to support the action of the husband to take a son or a daughter in adoption. The presence of wife as a spectator in the assembly of people who gather at the place where the ceremonies of adoption are performed cannot be treated as her consent. In other words, the Court cannot presume the consent of wife simply because she was present at the time of adoption. The wife's silence or lack of protest on her part also cannot give rise to an inference that she had consented to the adoption.   [Para 20]

heading: Consent to adoption
HeadNote.description: Consent to adoption - Wife's presence in ceremonies of adoption was only as a mute spectator and not as active participant - Witnesses only stating that she was sitting with other women below the platform - No evidence that after execution of adoption deed wife was made aware of the same or the copy thereof was made available to her - Moreover important lacuna in the case was non-examination of natural father who had taken active part in adoption ceremony and execution of adoption deed - His testimony was most crucial but he was not examined - Held it could not be said that adoption was effected with the consent of wife of adopter.			(Paras 30-34)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction - Act does not have extra-territorial jurisdiction.	(Para 8)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Personal obligation of husband - In-laws' obligation when arises - During subsistence of marriage obligation of maintenance of wife is on husband, it is a personal obligation - Obligation to maintain a daughter-in-law arises only when husband has died - Properties in which husband is not co-sharer cannot be attached for maintenance dues.

Maintenance of a married wife, during subsistence of marriage, is on the husband. It is a personal obligation. The obligation to maintain a daughter-in-law arises only when the husband has died. Such an obligation can also be met from the properties of which the husband is a co-sharer and not otherwise. For invoking said provision, the husband must have a share in the property. The property in the name of the mother-in-law can neither be a subject matter of attachment nor during the life time of husband, his personal liability to maintain his wife can be directed to be enforced against such property. It is not for an owner of the property to establish that it is his self-acquired property, onus would be on one, who pleads contra. An order of maintenance might have been passed but decree must be executed against her husband, only his properties could be attached therefor, not of her mother-in-law. Impugned orders passed by the High Court are wholly unsustainable.   [Para 21,22,30]

heading: Maintenance
Obligation
In laws' obligation
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Obligation - In laws' obligation - Statutory liability in regard to maintenance of wife is of her husband, and only on his death upon the father-in-law-Mother-in-law cannot be fastened with any legal liability to maintain her daughter-in-law from her own property or otherwise.

Sections 18 and 19 prescribe the statutory liabilities in regard to maintenance of wife by her husband and only on his death upon the father-in-law, Mother-in-law, thus, cannot be fastened with any legal liability to maintain her daughter-in-law from her own property or otherwise.   [Para 24]

heading: Interim maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Interim maintenance - Grant of - Application by wife and minor son for maintenance - During its pendency family court has jurisdiction to grant interim maintenance.

Where the principal power to grant relief asked for is conferred upon a Court, such Court will also have power to grant such interim reliefs which are incidental to the main relief.  In the instant case, the wife and minor child filed a petition under sections 18 and 20 of the Act before the Family Court for maintenance and same is pending for adjudication before the  said Court.  Since the Court has a power under sections 18 and 20 of the Act to grant maintenance, which is the final relief sought by the claimants, then by necessary implication, the Court will also have power to grant interim maintenance which is incidental to the main relief of maintenance claimed by them.  [Para 17]

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Husband earning Rs.20,000/- per month - Grant of interim maintenance of Rs.5000/- to minor son - Held proper, since wife is entitled to enjoy and maintain same standard as her husband. (Para 14)

heading: Divorce
Decree granted
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Decree granted - Wife not entitled to maintenance. (Para 32)

heading: Application for maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Application for maintenance - Applicant second wife of her husband - Second marriage null and void when solemnised on account of subsistence of the first marriage of husband - Divorce of first wife - Parties to second marriage continue to live as husband and wife even after divorce of first marriage - Second wife entitled to the status of a wife and consequently has a right to claim maintenance. Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125.

In the present case, the evidence adduced by the wife shows that although on the date of her marriage with the husband on 2-6-1978 the first marriage of the husband was subsisting, the first marriage of the husband had come to an end with the execution of Deed of Divorce dated 7-4-1980.  It was contended on behalf of the wife that since the husband has not led any evidence to establish the subsistence of his first marriage, her testimony as well as her tendering xerox copy of the divorce deed does neither conclusively establish the validity of the first marriage of the husband nor its dissolution.  Before the Family Court, no such issue was framed and there is no finding to that effect.  Moreover, the husband instead of rebutting the above contentions, has in fact chosen to make capital out of it.  Therefore, court proceeded on the footing that the first marriage of the husband was subsisting on 2-6-1978.  If the first marriage of the husband was subsisting on the date of the second marriage, then as per law and as per the judicial decisions of the Apex Court the second marriage is null and void.  But the question in the present case is, if the first marriage has come to an end by a Divorce deed dated 7-4-1980 and both the parties to the second marriage continue to live together as husband and wife after the dissolution of the first marriage, whether the second wife can be deprived of the status of a wife ? Even though the second marriage of the husband during the subsistence of the first marriage was null and void, on the dissolution of the first marriage, if the parties to the second marriage continued to live together as husband and wife, then there is no impediment in conferring the status of 'wife' to the second wife. In other words, even if the second marriage was null and void when solemnised on account of the subsistence of the first marriage of the husband, if the parties to the second marriage continue to live as husband and wife even after the divorce of the first marriage then the second wife would be entitled to the status of a wife and consequently has a right to claim maintenance.   [Para 16]

With the ever increasing matrimonial offences, time has come for the Parliament to have a fresh look and see whether the existing laws strike a balance in the matter of rights and obligations cast upon the husband and wife in preserving the sanctity of the sacred institution of marriage.  Luckily in the present case, the first marriage of the husband ended in a divorce, as a result whereof maintenance could be granted to the wife.  But in a given case, if the wife is an innocent victim and it is only after the marriage, she realises that the husband has cheated her by not disclosing the existence of a living spouse, should the wife be at the mercy of the husband and stay with him as a concubine ? Should there be no legislation granting some protection for her to live independently in a dignified way by seeking maintenance from the husband ? In a society where the marriage between a man and woman is considered to be sacred and supposed to last beyond the existence of the physical body and extend for generations, whether the existing legislations strike a balance in the matter of matrimonial offences committed by man or a woman?  It is for the legislature to consider and take appropriate measures.  AIR 1965 SC 1564 and AIR 1975 SC 83 - Referred to.	 [Para 18]

HeadNote.description: Application for maintenance - Applicant wife forced to leave matrimonial home on account of cruelty and immoral and unethical behaviour of husband - Wife entitled to maintenance. AIR 1956 Bom. 251 - Rel.on.	(Para 17)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Court has implicit power to grant ad interim and interim maintenance.

The Court hearing the suit under section 18 clearly has power and competence to pass proper and required interim and ad-interim orders.  [Para 16,22]

The entitlement of a Hindu wife to be maintained by her husband during her life time is the most important provision of S.18. The question whether the Court has jurisdiction to pass interim order can never be dependant on the possibility of the defences to the suit. What is more important is that the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956 avowedly is for codifying the law relating to maintenance amongst Hindus.  It is extremely relevant to notice that the inclusive definition of "maintenance" states that "maintenance" includes (i) in all cases, provision for food, clothing, residence, education and medical attendance and treatment; and (ii) in the case of an unmarried daughter, also the reasonable expenses of and incident to her marriage. These aspects of maintenance clearly contemplate grant of the same when the same is needed. That the wife, if she succeeds, will be entitled to arrears is no consolation. For example, there may be urgent need of medical attendance and treatment which surely cannot await the decision of the suit after several years. For ought one knows, in the absence of proper medical attendance and treatment, the plaintiff may not survive to obtain the fruits of her decree by way of arrears of maintenance. The inclusive definition of maintenance is also a pointer to indicate that in the very nature of things, if the absolute right of maintenance granted by the Legislature to a Hindu wife is to be effective, then the Court must necessarily have the power to pass ad-interim and interim orders. Otherwise, the very purpose and object of the Act is likely to be defeated. Similar is the case in respect of section 20 which provides for maintenance of children and aged parents. Now if an unmarried daughter of a marriageable age requires reasonable expenses of and incidental to her marriage, surely she cannot be asked to wait until the conclusion of the trial. Taking into consideration the scheme of the Act and the definition of "maintenance", it is implicit that though there is no express provision in section 18 or for that matter in section 19 or 20, the power and jurisdiction to pass ad-interim and interim order can legitimately and justifiably read into those provisions. Otherwise, the very object of the Act is likely to be defeated.  [Para 10,16]

It cannot be said absence of express provision enabling the Court to pass interim orders cannot be read as prohibition to pass such orders. Not passing such an order is not only more disastrous but may defeat the entire object and purpose of the Act. The provisions of section 18(1) give absolute entitlement to a Hindu wife to be maintained by her husband during her life time. If this has to be ensured, urgent ad-interim and interim orders as required under the circumstances of the case will have to be passed.  [Para 21,23]

heading: Maintenance
Passing of
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Ad interim and interim order - Passing of - Existence of conditions enumerated in sub-s. (2) of S.18 - Judge has to prima facie satisfy as to existence of conditions and form ad hoc opinion - Appellate Court will not normally interfere with discretion to pass such order.

It is true that before the Court passes an order in a case where the wife is living separately, the existence of conditions enumerated in sub-section (2) of section 18 has to be shown. However, since there is power in the Court to pass interim and ad-interim orders, whether there is existence of such conditions at such a stage cannot be determined finally and, ultimately, it will have to be determined on the prima facie view of the matter. At this stage of passing interim order what is required is only prima facie satisfaction of the Judge. In the very nature of things, while passing such ad-interim orders, the Judge has to take some ad hoc view of the matter and it is also settled law that the appellate Court will not interfere with the discreation used by the Judge in such matters.  [Para 24,26]

On the basis of material on record, it was held in instant case that such prima facie satisfaction can legitimately and justifiably be reached. The amount granted to the wife, inclusive of maintenance to a female child of two-and-a-half years, of Rs. 7,500/- per month was held not in any way, excessive.  [Para 24,26]

heading: Matrimonial proceedings pending
HeadNote.description:
Matrimonial proceedings pending - Application for interim maintenance need not necessarily be only to family court under S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act.

(1993) 3 SCC 406 Rel.on. (Para 5)

heading: Maintenance to children
Issue of paternity
HeadNote.description: Maintenance to children - Issue of paternity - Marriage between parties, not established - However, appellant did not deny cohabitation with respondent - Appellant also admitted his photograph with daughter of respondent - He was aware that in the birth certificates of children, his name was shown as father - Yet, he did not oppose to it - In fact, he had signed the application for birth certificate - Held, there is no doubt that appellant is father of two children - Grant of maintenance cannot be faulted even though marriage is not proved. 			(Paras 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - When the validity of marriage is not established, it would not be appropriate to grant maintenance under S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act - However, in view of cohabitation, maintenance can be granted under S.20 of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act. (1993) 3 SCC 406, (2006) 5 SCC 461 Ref. to. 	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Adoption of married man - Validity - Appellant claiming that he was adopted by deceased husband of respondent when he was of 32 years old and married - Plea of appellant that it was custom prevalent in their community - Appellant and priest who performed adoption in their evidence stated how adoption ceremony was performed - There were many contradictions in evidence of witnesses regarding adoption - Appellant failed to prove his adoption by deceased husband of respondent - Adoption of appellant i.e. married son, invalid. 	 (Paras 17, 21, 22, 23, 24)

heading: Custom
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Custom - Burden of proof - Is on person who sets up plea of existence of any custom. 	(Para 13)

heading: Custom
HeadNote.description:
Custom - Necessary ingredients for establishing valid custom, stated.

	As per the settled law under Section 3(a) the Act, the following ingredients are necessary for establishing a valid custom-

a. 	Continuity.
b. 	Certainty.
c. 	Long usage.
d. 	And reasonability.
As customs, when pleaded are mostly at variance with the general law, they should be strictly proved. Generally,there is a presumption that law prevails and when the claim of custom is against such general presumption,then, whoever sets up the plea of existence of any custom has to discharge the onus of proving it, with all itsrequisites to the satisfaction of the Court in a most clear and unambiguous manner. It should be noted that, there are many types of customs to name a few-generalcustoms, local customs and tribal customs etc. and the burden of proof for establishing a type of custom depend on the type and the extent of usage. It must be shown that the alleged custom has the characteristics of a genuine custom viz., that it is accepted willfully as having force of law, and is not a mere practice more or less common. The acts required for the establishment ofcustomary law ought to be plural, uniform and constant.Custom evolves by conduct, and it is therefore a mistake to measure its validity solely by the element of express sanction accorded by courts of law. The characteristic of the great majority of customs is that theyare essentially non-litigious in origin. They arise not from any conflict of rights adjusted, but from practicesprompted by the convenience of society. A judicial decision recognizing a custom may be relevant, but these are not indispensable for its establishment. When acustom is to be proved by judicial notice, the relevant test would be to see if the custom has been acted upon by acourt of superior or coordinate jurisdiction in the samejurisdiction to the extent that justifies the court, which is asked to apply it, in assuming that the persons or the class of persons concerned in that area look upon thesame as binding in relation to circumstances similar to those under consideration. 	 [Para 13,14]

heading: Custom
HeadNote.description: Custom - Of adoption of married son - Is matter of proof and cannot be based on priori reasoning or logical and analogical deductions. 	 (Para 17)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Fact that wife tolerated conduct of husband for long cannot be held against her - Husband having an affair with daughter of a family friend - She giving birth to a child by the husband - Husband providing Add on card of the City Bank to her - She also using surname of the husband - Held these allegations made by wife were substantive in nature and wife could not be said to have left matrimonial home without justification. (Para 8)

heading: Maintenance
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Determination of - Amount to be awarded should be by and large acceptable to both the spouses.

The amount of maintenance would have to be fixed by taking a rational and balanced view of various factors. The Court has to be guided by the relevant provisions of the Act and the object of Sections 18 and 23. Thus the Court has to bear in mind the status of the parties, reasonable wants of the claimant, the income and property of the claimant and the number of persons whom the husband has to maintain. Whilst it is important to ensure that the maintenance amount is sufficient to enable the wife to live in somewhat the same degree of comfort, as in the matrimonial home, the amount of maintenance should not be so exorbitant that the husband is unable to pay. By adoption of such a course, no purpose would be served. In other words, the amount of maintenance should not be punitive in nature. It should aid the wife to live in a similar style as she enjoyed in the matrimonial home. It should not expose the husband to unjustified contempt or other coercive proceedings. On the other hand the amount of maintenance should not be so low, as to make the order meaningless. Naturally, there can be no mathematical exactitude, in these matters. The Court has to take a general view, and try to fix an amount which would be by and large acceptable to both the husband and the wife.  [Para 10]

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Factors to be considered - Wife well placed and earning Rs. 12,000/- p.m. with chauffeur driven car - She was paying Rs. 2500/- p.m. to chauffeur - Husband in advertising business and earning Rs. 40000/- p.m. - Parents of either not dependent on him or her - Payment of Rs. 7500/- p.m. held was proper and justified. (Para 10)

heading: Application under
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Application under - Maintainability - U/S.18 wife entitled to seek maintenance only if marriage is subsisting - A divorced wife can seek maintenance only U/S.25 of Marriage Act.1993 Mh.L.J. 1731 - Rel. on.	(Para 23)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Adoption by female Hindu - Validity - Adoption document shows age of mother as 33 years and age of son as 15 years - Document itself shows difference of age of hardly 18 years between them - Date of birth shown in birth certificate of mother is 10.5.1945 and that date of birth of son is 23.4.1954 - So, on 22.3.1971, i.e. date of adoption, age of mother was 26 years and of son was 17 years - In any case, age difference was 16 to 18 years and not 21 years as required by law - Hence, adoption was void. 1994 Mh.L.J. 1078 Bom Ref. to. 			(Para 20)

heading: Adoption
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Burden to prove its validity - Is on person claiming adoption - For reason that adoption seeks to displace natural succession to property - No need of specific pleading from person objecting adoption.	(Paras 15, 20)

heading: Adoption
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Adoption - Validity - Adoption of child by widow not for herself but to the husband - Act makes no such provision - Law applicable would be the law as it stood prior to the enactment of the Act - Shastric law provides for an express authority by husband to the widow to adopt child - In absence of such authority adoption would be void.

Hindu Law - Adoption - Validity.	 (Para 12)

heading: Divorced person when may remarry
HeadNote.description:
Divorced person when may remarry - First marriage dissolved by exparte decree of divorce - Second marriage performed after expiry of appeal period though appeal as also application for setting aside exparte decree pending - Held, Second marriage a valid marriage - However as Husband has reconciled with first wife and his relationship with second wife had reached rock-bottom - In circumstances second wife entitled to live separately from Husband and claim maintenance for herself and child.

AIR 1978 SC 1351 - Rel on.	(Para 39)

heading: Hindu Law
Effect of adoption
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Vesting of Property on heirs - Effect of adoption - An adopted child cannot divest any person of any estate which vested in him or her before the adoption.	(Para 14)

heading: Hindu Law
Inheritance
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Inheritance - Share of adopted son - Upon death of one 'S' property equally devolved upon his window and three daughters - Widow subsequently adopted a son - Widow also died intestate - Held, property which had been vested in widow and three daughters, would not be disturbed due to subsequent adoption - Property of widow would be divided among her adopted son and heirs of her three daughters who had predeceased the widow.	(Para 15)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Husband not taking any steps to bring back wife from her parental home where he had left her - Though he asserted that he was prepared to take wife back he took no steps for giving restitution of conjugal rights to his wife - Wife is entitled to maintenance.	(Para 10)

heading: Amount of maintenance
HeadNote.description: Amount of maintenance - Husband getting Rs.10,000/- p.m. - Grant of maintenance of Rs.1500/- p.m. cannot be said to be excessive. (Para 13)

heading: Adoption or custody
HeadNote.description:
Adoption or custody - Welfare of child is of prime importance in cases relating to adoption or custody - Welfare of child concerned will outweigh all other considerations.

The welfare of the child is of prime importance in the cases relating to adoption or custody.  Time and again the Honourable Apex Court has reiterated that welfare of the child concerned will outweight all other considerations.  Hence, in the instant case also, the facts have to be considered keeping in view of the sole objective of the welfare of child and not the desires or pleadings of the applicants or even of biological parents who had relinquished the child, which act of theirs had become irrevocable, from the act of surrender and failure or omission to claim it within reasonable span of time.  [Para 16]

heading: Adoption or custody
HeadNote.description: Adoption or custody - Maintaining secrecy and confidentiality of adoptive parents and or biological parents is an essential element for welfare of child and for preventing abuse of information by any unscrupulous person. AIR 1984 SC 469 - Rel. on.	(Paras 27 & 30)

heading: Maintenance to wife
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance to wife - Grant of - Marriage between parties allegedly took place prior to about 48 years as per rites and tenets of Hindu religion - As per appellant (wife) after consortium of about 2 years respondent (husband) drove her away and since then wife is residing with her natural family members - Appellant for first time decided to exercise her right to maintenance when she came to know of execution of adoption deed by respondent in favour of other 2 respondents in year 2003 - Plea raised by respondent that appellant was and is half mad - Found to be untrue - Version of appellant about her marital status - Duly corroborated from entries in voters list and Bank record - Conduct of respondent husband denying matrimonial relation - Showing that he is unwilling to maintain respondent and has neglected her - Appellant held entitled to maintenance of Rs.2,000/- p.m..			(Paras 20 to 28)

heading: Matrimonial cases
HeadNote.description: Matrimonial cases - It is the duty of the court to locate truth though the parties may indulge in blame game or attempt to hide some facts.	(Para 24)

heading: Maintenance
Claim by minors
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Claim by minors - Liability to pay maintenance can be fixed on both father and mother - Use of the word "or" in S.20 has to be read as "and" - Father can be made liable to pay though minors were being looked after by their mother.	(Para 3)

heading: Maintenance to minor children
HeadNote.description: Maintenance to minor children - Agreement at time of divorce that mother would look after minors and not claim any maintenance from husband - Such an agreement cannot divest statutory right available to minors - Agreement adverse to interests of minors cannot be enforced in law. (Paras 4, 5)

heading: Maintenance to wife
HeadNote.description: Maintenance to wife - Scope and applicability of S.27 of Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act - Charge on husband's property on his death - Charge can be kept on the assets of the husband - Held, once there is a valid order of the Court thereby giving right to wife to recover maintenance from the husband and as per the provision of Criminal Law she is entitled to proceed even against the assets of the husband - S.27 of the Act of 1956, not applicable in such case.	(Para 20)

heading: Validity of adoption
HeadNote.description: Validity of adoption - Rituals as per Hindu Law strictly followed - Deed of adoption was also registered - Photographs and their negatives were on record - Adoption cannot be disbelieved.			(Para 13)

heading: Adoption
Validity of
Adoption of respondent
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Validity of - Adoption of respondent - Respondent married at the time of adoption and completed the age of 15 years at that time - Non-compliance with requirements of Ss.10(iii) and (iv) as well as S.11(iv) of the Act - However, Custom judicially recognised as regards the adoption of a child at any age - Once the Custom is judicially recognised, it is not required to be independently proved by evidence before trial Court in subsequent cases. AIR 1983 Bom. 391 and 1991(2) SCC 218 - Followed. 		(Para 8)

heading: Adoption
Non-compliance with
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Condition imposed U/s.11(iv) of the Act - Non-compliance with - One of the conditions for a valid adoption is the difference in ages prescribed by clause (iv) - Therefore, this is not a merely directory provision but something which is mandatory and the violation where of results in the invalidity of the adoption. 1992 Mh.L.J. 165 - Followed.	(Paras 12 and 13)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Order to pay maintenance to respondent daughter-in-law against appellant father-in-law after death of his son - Appellant did not file any document on record to show that he paid share in consideration to his son on sale of agricultural land - Appellant did not pay single penny to respondent after death of his son - Court below held that respondent unable to maintain herself - Finding was not challenged by appellant - Finding of Court below upheld.

AIR 1995 Allahabad 70, AIR 2010 CG 80, AIR 1961 Punjab 391, II 1999 DMC 671, AIR 2009 Madras 120 Disting. 	 [Para 12]

heading: Maintenance
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Entitlement to - Respondent widowed daughter-in-law claiming maintenance from appellant father-in-law - Appellant father did not pay his son share of consideration after sale of agricultural land - That share of deceased would constitute 'other property' from which respondent is entitled to maintain herself - It would be a part of 'estate of respondent's husband' - Appellant is in possession of share of sale consideration of deceased - Hence appellant is liable to maintain respondent daughter-in-law - Respondent is entitled to maintenance under S.19. 	(Para 21)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Respondent widowed daughter-in-law claiming maintenance from appellant father-in-law - Appellant father did not pay his deceased son share of consideration after sale of agricultural land - Appellant is in custody of estate of deceased son - Argument that father of respondent should be shown that he is not able to support her - Argument liable to be rejected.

AIR 1995 Allahabad 70, AIR 2010 Chhaisgarh 80, II 1999 DMC 671, AIR 2009 Madras 120 Disting. 	 [Para 22]

heading: Maintenance and permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Maintenance and permanent alimony - Husband claiming his income to be approximately Rs.10,000/- p.m. - Offering to pay maintenance of Rs.7000/- p.m. to daughter - Offer accepted with a direction that maintenance will be payable to daughter till her marriage and expenditure for her education shall also be reimbursed - Wife would be entitled to permanent alimony of Rs.3000/- p.m. - Liberty also given to wife to approach Family Court for enhancement in view of her claim that husband earns more and possessed of large immovable property. 	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Wife bringing co-habitation to an end and living separately - Her minor daughter was also living with her - Family Court failed to analyze pleadings and evidence in proper perspective - Matter remanded for fresh consideration.(Paras 14 to 18)

heading: Petition for maintenance by wife
HeadNote.description: Petition for maintenance by wife - Substantive evidence of wife as to husband assaulting her on flimsy ground and was putting lot of restrictions on wife - Trial Court erred in coming to conclusion as to non-entitlement of wife for getting maintenance under S.18. 	(Para 9)

heading: Petition for maintenance by wife for herself and her daughter aged 3 years
HeadNote.description: Petition for maintenance by wife for herself and her daughter aged 3 years - Husband working in police department and drawing salary of Rs.7000/- per month - By passage of time of about 13 years there must have been increase in his salary - Demand of maintenance of Rs.1500/- for wife and Rs.1,000/- for child was proper. 	(Paras 9 to 12)

heading: Expression 'custom'
HeadNote.description:
Expression 'custom' - Meaning of.

Custom is an established practice at variance with the general law. A custom varying general law may be a general, local, tribal or family custom. A general custom includes a custom common to any considerable class of persons. A custom which is applicable to a locality, tribe, sect or a family is called a special custom.

Custom is a rule, which in a particular family, a particular class, community, or in a particular district, has owing to prolonged use, obtained the force of law. Custom has the effect of modifying general personal law, but it does not override statutory law, unless the custom is expressly saved by it.

Such custom must be ancient, uniform, certain, continuous and compulsory. No custom is valid if it is illegal, immoral, unreasonable or opposed to public policy. He who relies upon custom varying general law, must plead and prove it. Custom must be established by clear and unambiguous evidence. 					      [Para 7]

heading: Custom
HeadNote.description:
Custom - Must be ancient, certain and reasonable - Custom when judicially recognized by Court becomes law of the land and proof of it becomes unnecessary under S.57(1) of Evidence Act (1872).

AIR 1968 SC 1299 Rel. on. 	 [Para 9]

heading: Adoption
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Special customs which prevail in a family, particular community require strict proof. 			(Para 15)

heading: Adoption
Proof
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Proof - Adopted child was 8 years old and adoptive mother 70 years old at time of Datta Homan Ceremony - Adoption deed was also executed and registered on the same day - Seven witnesses had signed the deed - Person who had given his son in adoption appeared in witness box and proved validity of deed - Other witnesses did not challenge validity of deed of adoption, in fact, they did not make any reference to the same - Held adoption deed was valid and same cannot be doubted simply because natural parents of adoptive child had signed along with seven other witnesses as attesting witnesses and not as executors. 			(Paras 25 to 27)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Adoption of Muslim boy - After converting him into Hindu religion - Validity - Respondent, Muslim boy claims to have converted into Hindu religion to marry petitioner, a Hindu girl - Alleged ceremony of converting him from Muslim to Hindu though said to have been performed in temple in presence of priests of both sides, elders, he did not file any certificate in proof of it - It is not even his case that it is after conversion, he was adopted, but for saying that he was made to adopt and was made to convert - Tenor of his contention shows that it is not even a voluntary outcome - No registered deed of adoption to presume so called adoption - No customary usage proved to claim as adopted son of Hindu couple - Respondent was even by then a major, for having completed 15th year, by reason of which adoption is not valid even otherwise - No specific pleading as to what is procedure adopted for conversion - Factum of adoption not proved by any evidence - Alleged adoption held void. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Adoption
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Change of the initials of adopted child - Held, name of biological parents in births and deaths register, should not be changed - Adoptive parents can issue a private notification in the Gazette about change of initials for adopted child - School Authorities and Passport Authorities have to follow the mandates of S.12 of Hindu Adoptions Act - And name of parents in their records should be that of adoptive parents.			(Para 6)

heading: Adoption
Appropriate Authority
HeadNote.description: Adoption - Change of initials of adopted child - Appropriate Authority - Parties cannot approach Magistrate u/S.13(3) of Births and Deaths Act - But, can only file a Civil Suit.	(Para 5)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Wife left matrimonial home within one month of marriage - Explanation given that on first day of marriage itself, she was subjected to forcible sexual intercourse - That her arms were tied up by husband and he behaved cruelly - Such an allegation cannot be proved by independent evidence - Only circumstances can prove or disprove them - Husband admitted that wife used to avoid sleeping in night fearing any touch by him - Husband also stated to have taken wife for treatment for her strange behaviour - Wife admitted that she was sleepless in those days - When she was produced before Magistrate, she expressed her wish to go to her parents and not to husband - Statement of parties and circumstances make it clear that it is only due to misbehavior of husband that wife left matrimonial home - Case of wife falls under clauses (b) and (g) of S.18(2) - Wife entitled to maintenance. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Fact that wife is employed - Not a ground to relieve husband from his liability to maintain her - This factor, at the most, can mitigate quantum of maintenance.		 	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Maintenance
Quantum
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Quantum - Husband is a driver of a Tipper Lorry - Plea of wife that he also owns an omni van and auto-rickshaw and earning from all sources comes around Rs.44000/- p.m. - No evidence in support of said plea except admission by husband that he had taken auto-rickshaw on rent - Considering sources of income of husband and fact that wife is also employed in a hospital, maintenance of Rs.2500/- p.m. would be just and proper - Order of court below granting Rs.3000/- p.m. towards past maintenance and Rs.5000/- p.m. towards future maintenance, is on higher side - Modified accordingly. 	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.13 - Maintenance - Single instance of adultery - Not sufficient to decline maintenance even though it may be a ground of divorce - "Wife living in adultery" means she should continue to live in adultery. 1987 (2) KLT 892, 2002 ALL MR (Cri) JOURNAL 145, 2003 (2) KLT 548, 1995 ALLMR ONLINE 1283, 2000 ALL MR (Cri) 996 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Partition
HeadNote.description: Partition - Claim by adopted son - As per provisions of Sangli Widow's Right to Property Act, upon death of husband of Hindu woman she becomes 'Sahabhagidar' in joint family property in place of her husband and entitled to claim partition - Right to claim partition thus accrued to original plaintiff-wife under Sangli Act, notwithstanding death of her husband in 1932 - Substituted plaintiff was adopted in 1978 - On death of original plaintiff, adopted son/substituted plaintiff must be legal heir in respect of property of original plaintiff - Adopted son has right to claim partition and separate possession.  (Paras 9, 10, 14, 15)

heading: Correction in birth certificate
HeadNote.description:
Correction in birth certificate - Entry of name of step-father replacing name of biological father - Permissibility.

A bare perusal of the provision of S.15 of Registration of Births and Deaths Act shows that the applicant has to prove to the satisfaction of the Registrar about the error in the entry of a birth or death in form or substance which may crept in fraudulently or improperly, which can be corrected or cancelled by the Registrar by making suitable entry in the margin but without any alteration of the original entry and he shall sign the marginal entry and add thereto the date of the correction or cancellation.

In the instant case the entry in the Birth Certificate of the petitioner, which was conveyed to the authorities on 23.10.1993 about birth of the petitioner on 05.10.1993 out of the wedlock of his biological parents is neither recorded fraudulently or improperly and is also not erroneous in form or substance. The mother of the petitioner has only divorced his biological father and after remarriage he has become the step-son of his step-father, who cannot replace the biological father but the things would have been different had it been a case of adoption because as per Section 12 of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956.

Perusal of S.9 of 1956 Act it transpires that even if there is a divorce between biological parents of the petitioner, in the presence of the biological father, the step-father of the petitioner cannot give the petitioner in adoption with his biological mother. Even under Section 8 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, the step-son is neither Class-I nor Class-II heir.

Thus, from the aforesaid discussion, it transpires that correction in the Birth Certificate in the Register of Births and Deaths of the adoptive parents can be made if it is proved to the satisfaction of the Registrar, that too in accordance with the other terms and conditions mentioned in Section 15 of the Act but the entry of a step-father, replacing the name of the biological father in the Birth Certificate maintained under the Act, cannot be made. 	 [Para 8,9,13,14]

HeadNote.act_name: Hindu Temple (Devasthans) of Goa, Daman and Diu Regulation (1933)
heading: Budget requirement
Compliance of requirement
HeadNote.description: Budget requirement - Compliance of requirement - Offer of deposit of all the amounts taken from devotees which have not been used in the exact mode contemplated by the devotees but which is made available to them, held, would be sufficient compliance of the budget requirement under the order of Administrative Tribunal - The best possible mode of doing complete justice to all the parties would be to create options and opportunity for the devotees/kulavis to be either repaid the amounts paid by them or utilising them in the way they would deem appropriate so as to remove the cause for complaint and the grievance of their trust having been breached, keeping secure the sentiments of the other section of the same religious society.	(Para 10)
