heading: Divorced person when may remarry
HeadNote.description:
Divorced person when may remarry - First marriage dissolved by exparte decree of divorce - Second marriage performed after expiry of appeal period though appeal as also application for setting aside exparte decree pending - Held, Second marriage a valid marriage - However as Husband has reconciled with first wife and his relationship with second wife had reached rock-bottom - In circumstances second wife entitled to live separately from Husband and claim maintenance for herself and child.

AIR 1978 SC 1351 - Rel on.	(Para 39)

HeadNote.act_name: Haryana Compassionate Assistance to the Dependents of Deceased Government Employees Rules (2006)
heading: Just compensation
HeadNote.description:
Just compensation - Upon death of Govt. employee in State of Haryana - Question as to whether compensation received by dependents of deceased under Rule 2006 from State to be deducted - Discussed.

		Rule 5 of Haryana Compassionate Assistance to Dependents of Deceased Government Employees Rules, 2006 broadly deals with two aspects. Firstly, to compensate the dependents of the deceased Government employee by granting ex-gratia financial assistance on compassionate grounds for the loss of pay and other allowances for a specified period. The second part of Rule 5 is to compensate the dependents of the deceased Government employee by way of allowances and concessions - of retaining occupation of the Government residence on specified terms, of family pension and other allowance. As regards the second part, it deals with income from other source which any way is receivable by the dependants of the deceased Government employee. That cannot be deducted from the claim amount, for determination of a just compensation under the Act of 1988.

	The claimants are legitimately entitled to claim for the loss of "pay and wages" of the deceased Government employee against the tortfeasor or Insurance Company, as the case may be, covered by the first part of Rule 5 under the Act of 1988. The claimants or dependents of the deceased Government employee (employed by State of Haryana), however, cannot set up a claim for the same subject falling under the first part of Rule 5 - "pay and allowances", which are receivable by them from employer (State) under Rule 5 (1) of the Rules of 2006. In that, if the deceased employee was to survive the motor accident injury, would have remained in employment and earned his regular pay and allowances. Any other interpretation of the said Rules would inevitably result in double payment towards the same head of loss of "pay and wages" of the deceased Government employee entailing in grant of bonanza, largesse or source of profit to the dependants / claimants.

	The amount receivable by the dependants / claimants towards the head of pay and allowances in the form of ex-gratia financial assistance, therefore, cannot be paid for the second time to the claimants. True it is, that the Rules of 2006 would come into play if the Government employee dies in harness even due to natural death. At the same time, the Rules of 2006 do not expressly enable the dependents of the deceased Government employee to claim similar amount from the tortfeasor or Insurance Company because of the accidental death of the deceased Government employee. The harmonious approach for determining a just compensation payable under the Act of 1988, therefore, is to exclude the amount received or receivable by the dependents of the deceased Government employee under the Rules of 2006 towards the head financial assistance equivalent to "pay and other allowances" that was last drawn by the deceased Government employee in the normal course. This is not to say that the amount or payment receivable by the dependents of the deceased Government employee under Rule 5 (1) of the Rules, is the total entitlement under the head of "loss of income". So far as the claim towards loss of future escalation of income and other benefits, if the deceased Government employee had survived the accident can still be pursued by them in their claim under the Act of 1988. For, it is not covered by the Rules of 2006. Similarly, other benefits extended to the dependents of the deceased Government employee in terms of sub-rule (2) to sub-rule (5) of Rule 5 including family pension, Life Insurance, Provident Fund etc., that must remain unaffected and cannot be allowed to be deducted, which, any way would be paid to the dependents of the deceased Government employee, applying the principle expounded in Helen C.Rebello [1999(1) ALL MR 670 (S.C.)] and Patricia Jean Mahajan's case [2002(4) ALL MR 886 (S.C.)].

1999(1) ALL MR 670 (S.C.), 2002(4) ALL MR 886 (S.C.) Rel. on. 	 [Para 20,21,22]

heading: Election
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Election - Disqualification of member of panchayat on ground of increase in number of children after cut-off date - Challenge - Contention that third child born after cut-off date but died before submission of nomination, therefore petitioner has only two living children - Held, in absence of word 'living' in S.14(1)(j-1), death of third child would be of no consequence - Disqualification held, proper.

The object of introducing clause (j-1) under Section 14(1) of the Maharashtra Village Panchayats Act is of creating a disincentive, as has been highlighted by the Apex Court in respect of Section 175(1)(q) of the Haryana Panchayati Raj Act, 1994 in paragraph 8 of its decision in Javed's case, (2003) 8 SCC 369 What is prohibited by Section 14(1)(j-1) of the Maharashtra Village Panchayats Act is the increase in the number of children after the cut-off date, which is apparent from the language used in the First Proviso below Section 14(1)(j-1) of the said Act. The number of children and should they be living, are the matters of legislative wisdom, and altering it in any manner would amount to tinkering with the legislation or reframing it. The conspicuous absence of the word 'living' in Section 14(1)(j-1) of the said Act is an indication of deviation in the policy of having more than two living children, incorporated under Section 175(1)(q) of the Haryana Panchayati Raj Act, 1994 and the same is not open to judicial scrutiny. Hence, the fact that a third child born after the cut-off date and expired prior to the submission to nomination paper cannot be an escape route from the disqualification. 2003(4) ALL MR 707 (S.C.) Ref. to.	  [Para 7,9]

heading: Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion of time - Applicability of S.14 of Haryana Panchayati Raj Act in election petition - To be tested not from provisions of Limitation Act but that of relevant election law - No provision in relevant election law for condonation of delay - S.14, therefore, not applicable - Election petition liable to be dismissed. 

(1974) 2 SCC 133, (1973) 2 SCC 530, (1999) 8 SCC 532 Rel. on. 	(Para 9)

heading: Disqualifying person with more than two children from holding elective office in Panchayat
HeadNote.description: Disqualifying person with more than two children from holding elective office in Panchayat - Disqualification cannot be got over by giving excess children in adoption - Evil of over population sought to be cured by the Act has to be kept in view.(Para 62)

heading: Disqualification for holding elective office for a person with more than two children
HeadNote.description: Disqualification for holding elective office for a person with more than two children - Contention that women have no independence and they helplessly bear a third child and hence provision would affect them most - Held a male who compels his wife to bear a third child would disqualify both of them and merely because women are not excepted from disqualification it does not render it unconstitutional.			(Para 63)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Disqualification for holding elective office in case of person with more than two children - Validity - Cannot be judged on basis of abnormal situation like birth of triplet or twins on second pregnancy - One swallow does not make a summer, a single instance of something is not necessarily significant.	(Para 64)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Disqualification of a person contesting election on ground of absence of functional toilet - Not unreasonable in any manner.

Clause (w) of S.175 of Haryana Panchayati Raj Act disqualifies a person from contesting an election to the Panchayat if such a person has no functional toilet at his place of residence. Those who aspire to get elected to those civic bodies and administer them must set an example for others. To the said end if the legislature stipulates that those who are not following basic norms of hygiene are ineligible to become administrators of the civic body and disqualifies them as a class from seeking election to the civic body, such a policy, can neither be said to create a class based on unintelligible criteria nor can such classification be said to be unconnected with the object sought to be achieved by the Act. [Para 95]

This provision is enacted essentially in the larger public interest and is indeed the need of the hour to ensure its application all over the country and not confining it to a particular State. Moreover, the State having provided adequate financial assistance to those who do not have toilet facility for construction of toilet, there arise no ground to challenge this provision as being unreasonable in any manner. [Para 107]

HeadNote.act_name: Himachal Pradesh Kutlehar Forests (Acquisition of Management) Act (1992)
heading: Management of Kutlehar Forests
HeadNote.description:
Management of Kutlehar Forests - Before coming into force of said H.P. Act (1992) these forest were managed by appellant earstwhile Ruler of Kutlehar - Appellant in 1995 offered resin blazes to State Forest Corporation and claimed cost of resin tapping for 1995 season - Held, appellant was entitled for his legitimate dues - Question of vesting of forest on or after 11-3-1995 appointed day by H.P. Act (1992) was immaterial - Matter remitted to High Court for fresh consideration.

In the instant case, Kutlehar was a small princely State in Kangra Hills having 16 Tapas (Tikas) as forests which were known as 'Kutlehar Forests'. These forests were managed by the Raja of Kutlehar subject to the terms and conditions specified by the then Government. By Notification No.4531-FT(CH-58/523 dated 1.10.1958 issued under Section 2(2) of the Forest Act, Raja was appointed as a Forest Superintendent and the employees working under him in the aforesaid forest declared as Forest Officers with respect to Kutlehar Forest. As per the terms of his appointment, he was held entitled to retain 3/4th of the income derivable from the forest where 1/4th of the gross income was payable to the Government.

Held that, appellant earstwhile Ruler was entitled to his legitimate dues. It cannot be said that in view of S.4 of H.P. Act (1992) the right, title and interest of the plaintiff/appellant herein grantee/superintendent of Kutlehar Forests stood extinguished on the appointed day, i.e. 11.03.1995, therefore, he was under no obligation to continue with the management of the forests nor has any right to share in income arising out of the produce of the said forests on and after 11.03.1995. It is true that after 11.03.1995, the appellant cannot have any right over the forest produce. However, in view of the earlier order Dt.31-3-1999 in Civil Appeal No.9495 of 1995 the passed by Supreme Court clarifying the position and his entitlement, there is no need to go into the vesting right etc. as claimed by the State Government.   [Para 9]

Inasmuch as the appellant was continuing as Superintendent of Forests without a specific salary but with an assurance of 3/4th price of forest produce such as resin blazes etc. till the appointed day, i.e. 11.03.1995, the appellant is entitled for his legitimate dues till such date. Those aspects were not being correctly adverted to and appreciated by the single Judge as well as by the Division Bench of the High Court and mainly concentrated on the "vesting" of forests on or after 11.03.1995 in favour of the State Corporation by holding that the appellant was not entitled to claim anything thereafter. Even though the appellant placed relevant materials including the assertion and statement of PW-3 who is none else than the Divisional Manager for the State Corporation, those aspects have not been properly appreciated. In those circumstances, ends of justice would be met by remitting the matter to the Single Judge for fresh disposal and quantifying the eligible amount.   [Para 9,10]

heading: Hazardous Waste (Management, Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules (2008)
HeadNote.description:
Hazardous Waste (Management, Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules (2008) - Jurisdiction of Member Secretary of Maharashtra Pollution Control Board after enactment of 2008 Rules - He is not denuded of authority to assign areas of operation. 

The authority of Member Secretary of Pollution Control Board is not denuded under the new rules. Under 2008 rules the person engaged in the collection of hazardous waste has to obtain authorisation from respondent No.2 in the State of Maharashtra as much as respondent No.2 would authorise such facility to collect waste under the old rules by an application made in a specified format in that behalf. Not only the collection and treatment, but recycling reprocessing, storage and disposal of the waste by such facilities would be only as per the authorisation of respondent No.2 in the State of Maharashtra. Only the proviso with relation to the assignment of the area of operation is not expressly incorporated in the new rules. However, since the very collection as also the treatment, recycling, reprocessing, storage and disposal is under the authorisation of respondent No.2, the area of such operation would fall impliedly within the jurisdiction and authority of respondent No.2 to grant and authorise. The work of collection, treatment, management and disposal of the chemical effluents would be better managed by more facilities in a given area as required by the economic situation. The monopoly of a facility may, therefore, be denuded. It may give way to a duopoly and later a perfectly competitive market. Of course, market forces determining the business of these facilities would be expected to play a role as in all other trades and businesses. However, it is the duty of the Central Government to see that the relevant departments of the State Government monitor the operations of the effluent treatment and waste disposal facilities. It is in that behalf that the monitoring and supervisory role of respondent No.2 would be required. Consequently, the facilities would require obtaining the authorisation from respondent No.2 as such monitoring authority in the State of Maharashtra. Respondent No.2 would monitor the activities from the collection to the disposal of the effluent waste of hazardous chemicals. In the course of such monitoring the area of operation also may be fixed. Consequently, the refixing of the areas under 2008 Rules by the order dated 11 December 2008 does not come up for challenge on the ground of it being a case of an act in excess of jurisdiction of respondent No.2.               [Para 19,21]

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Non-disclosure of cause of action - Suit for partition and separate possession of share in ancestral property filed by virtue of amendment in S.6 of Hindu Succession Act - Averment that cause of action arose on 1.12.2014 when plaintiffs first came to know about orders passed in earlier suit filed by their father seeking similar relief - Once it is held that plaintiffs are claiming through their father, whatever orders are passed in earlier suit are binding on them - They cannot contend that their knowledge about said orders gave them cause of action to file present suit - As regards bundle of other material facts stating to constitute cause of action, those are similar facts which were pleaded in earlier suit - If plaintiffs claiming through their father who was very much representing their interests, they are estopped from raising contention about their non-joinder as necessary parties in earlier suit - Amendment in S.6 of Hindu Succession Act was effected from 9.9.2005 - Thus, plaintiffs were not having any independent right in suit property as coparceners when second appeal in that suit was dismissed on 31st March, 2005 - As per judgment passed in earlier suit, partitions was effected and acted upon in 1958, much prior to commencement of Amendment of Act - Proviso to S.6(1) would come into play - Respondents have no right or share in suit property - No real cause of action for filing suit - Plaint rejected. 2014(5) ALL MR 846 (F.B.), 2015 ALL SCR 3568, 2018 ALL SCR 689 Ref. to. 			(Paras 22, 23, 24, 28, 29)

headline:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.7 R.11(a) – Rejection of plaint – On ground that suit is barred by principle of res-judicata – Suit for Partition & separate possession of share in ancestral property
Issue raised in present suit that no such partition was effected nor it was acted upon, were directly and substantially raised in earlier suit – Judgment of Trial Court, Appellate Court and Revisional Court produced on record - Plaint rejected, on ground of res judicata

heading: Right of married daughter
HeadNote.description:
Right of married daughter - S.6 of Amendment Act is prospective in nature and does not relate back to incidence of birth of daughter in coparcenary property.
2012(1) ALL MR 443 (S.C.) Ref. to.(Para 19)

heading: Partition suit
HeadNote.description:
Partition suit - Parents and thereafter brother of respondent have expired - Respondent daughter filed suit against wife and daughters of brother - Respondent was married before 1994 - Parents died before coming into force of S.6 of Amendment Act - Respondent daughter would acquire equal rights in coparcenary property by virtue of her birth in Hindu joint family.

Respondent daughter would acquire equal rights in coparcenary property by virtue of her birth in Hindu joint family, undisputedly governed by Mitakshara Law, in coparcenary property as she would have had, if she had been a son. That means right of respondent as coparcener , equal in status and effect as that of a son, would have to be understood as having arisen on date on which she took birth and therefore , she would be entitled to claim her equal share in coparcenary property from that date, unless property has lost its character as coparcenary property by disposition or alienation made before 20/12/1994, as contemplated in proviso to sub section (1) of S. 6(1) read with sub section (5). In instant case, there has been no disposition or alienation including any partition or testamentary disposition as contemplated under S. 6(1) read with sub -section (5) before 20/12/2004 having taken place and, therefore, respondent would have equal share in coparcenary property and would be entitled to even re open notional partitions, which are not covered under explanation to sub section (5) of Section 6.

S.6 makes respondent coparcener in her own right. Respondent daughter is not claiming share in property through her father. Property is ancestral and there was no disposition of property through testamentary succession. Contention that when substantive right under S.6 of Succession Act was created in year, 2005, there was no coparcenary in existence in relation to joint family of which respondent claimed to be member together with deceased brother, hence question of respondent claiming any share in property equally with brother would not arise. Contention is liable to be rejected.

2011(6) ALL MR 207, 2012(1) ALL MR 443 (S.C.), 2011(4) ALL MR 858 (S.C.) Ref. to.      [Para 20]

heading: Scope and applicability of S.3 of Act of 2005
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of S.3 of Act of 2005 - Operation of the statute, held, is prospective in nature.	(Para 23)

heading: Operation of an amendment Act
HeadNote.description:
Operation of an amendment Act - Question as to whether an amendment is prospective or retrospective in nature, will depend upon its construction.

Question as to whether an amendment is prospective or retrospective in nature, will depend upon its construction.It is merely a disabling provision. Such a right could be enforced if a cause of action therefor arose subsequently. A right of the son to keep the right of the daughters of the last male owner to seek for partition of a dwelling house being a right of the male owner to keep the same in abeyance till the division takes place is not a right of enduring in nature. It cannot be said to be an accrued right or a vested right. Such a right indisputably can be taken away by operation of the statute and/or by removing the disablement clause.   [Para 26]

heading: Both daughters died prior to their father and prior to Amendment Act coming into force
HeadNote.description: Both daughters died prior to their father and prior to Amendment Act coming into force - On death of father when his succession opened both daughters were not alive to be coparceners in their own right in same manner as son - No devolution of interest in coparcenery property can take place upon deceased coparcener daughters - Son of daughter cannot claim right on property after death of his maternal grandfather. ILR 2007 KAR 4790, AIR 2008 ORISSA 133, 2007 ALL SCR 1632, 2009 ALL SCR 2476, 2010(3) ALL MR 262, 2008 (5) ALL MR 302, AIR 2010 KAR 27	(Para 18)

heading: Daughters of coparcener
HeadNote.description: Daughters of coparcener - Not entitled to any right as coparceners ipso facto before devolution of any interest - No interest can devolve in coparcenery property except upon death of coparcener. (Para 11)

heading: Section is not retrospective in operation
HeadNote.description:
Section is not retrospective in operation - Words "shall", "on and from" and "become" - These words are inconsistent with any retrospectivity - Devolution would accrue by opening of succession on or after 9-9-2005 in case of daughters born before that date or by birth itself in case of daughters born after that date. 

The express words in the section clearly indicate the intention of the legislature to make daughters coparceners in coparcenery property on and from the date the amendment Act came into force. The Act also clearly shows that from that date they shall become coparceners with the same rights and liabilities and the reference to the Mitakshara would also be reference including the daughter from then on. The express provisions in the Act are, therefore, inconsistent with any retrospectivity.  [Para 24]

It is settled law that unless the Statute makes a provision retrospective expressly or by necessary intent it cannot be interpreted to be retrospective. It is also settled law that vested rights cannot be unsettled by imputing retrospectivity upon a legislation by judicial interpretation or construction. Making the section retrospective would wholly denude the words "on and from" in the section; they would be rendered otiose. These words are unique and clear. They express the intent of the legislature which is not far to seek.   [Para 25]

The rights of a coparcener vest in him/her upon an interest devolving upon such coparcener. This interest would devolve by succession, intestate or testamentary. Upon the death of a coparcener his interest in a coparcenery property would devolve upon other coparceners. This devolution under the unamended Section 6 of the HSA was by survivorship in case of only male heirs and by succession, if there were female heirs also. After the amended Section 6 this devolution of interest would be upon the son and the daughter alike.  [Para 26]

A reading of Section as a whole would, therefore, show that either the devolution of legal rights would accrue by opening of a succession on or after 9 September 2005 in case of daughters born before 9 September 2005 or by birth itself in case of daughters born after 9 September 2005 upon them.
AIR 2010 Karnataka 124 Dissentor from.  [Para 27]

HeadNote.act_name: High Court of Madhya Pradesh Rules (2008)
heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction - Clarification sought on interlocutory order passed in election petition - Contradiction between Section 80A(2) of Representation of People Act which prescribes hearing by Single Judge and High Court Rules which prescribe hearing by DB - Held, High Court Rules are subject to provisions of any law of the appropriate Legislature - It cannot curtail statutory provision under S.80A(2). 

	The adjudication of election petitions including the examination of all incidental questions in interlocutory proceedings arising during the course of the adjudication of the election petition is entrusted by Section 80A of the Representation of People Act, 1951 to the High Court within whose jurisdiction the election dispute arises. Section 80A(2) stipulates that the jurisdiction shall be exercised ordinarily by a Single Judge who is to be designated by the Chief Justice.

	Though the said Section indicates that the Chief Justice has a discretion to entrust trial of an election petition to a Bench consisting of more than one judges, such a discretion is to be exercised by the Chief Justice alone.

	The Rules of the High Court are framed by the High Court pursuant to the power vested in it under Article 225. The exercise of such power is subject to the provisions of the Constitution and the "provisions of any law of the appropriate legislature". Rule 13 mandates the listing of certain matters (nature of which is described therein) before a Division Bench. Such stipulation is contrary to the stipulation of Section 80A(2) that election petitions are to be tried by a single judge of the High Court leaving a discretion in the Chief Justice to decide whether in a given case, an election petition shall be heard by more than one Judge. Such a statutory discretion vested in the Chief Justice of the High Court cannot be curtailed by a rule made as the High Court in view of the clear declaration by the Constitution (in the opening clause of Article 225) that "any rule shall be subject to the law made by the appropriate legislature". 				 [Para 31]

heading: Eligibility
HeadNote.description: Re-nomination of Haj Committee - Eligibility - Petitioner was earlier elected as member of Haj committee of India in 2008-09 and 2010-13 - His name was again considered for nomination for third term in 2016 - However, he was held ineligible for reason that he being 'outgoing member' cannot hold office for more than two terms - Held, S.8(2) used word "outgoing" in present and coupled with word "re-nomination', thereby suggesting that if nomination of candidate for third term considered in continuation of his earlier two terms, he would be ineligible - Since nomination of petitioner for third term was not in continuation of his earlier terms, it is not an re-nomination and petitioner is also not "outgoing member" - He is very much eligible for nomination to membership of Haj Committee of India. (2002) 3 SCC 722 Ref. to. 			(Paras 28, 29)

heading: "Outgoing member"
HeadNote.description:
"Outgoing member" - Interpretation of S.8(2).

The word "outgoing" has been defined in Webster's Third New International Dictionary as going outward, departing, retiring or withdrawing from place or position, something that goes out. The word, therefore, must receive a meaning consistent with the other provisions enabling constitution of the committee. The proviso to subsection (2) of section 8 of Haj Committee Act does not rule out nomination of the members of the past committee for a second term in such manner as may be prescribed. However, such members should not exceed more than 50%. If an outgoing member as is referred to in sub-section (2) is eligible for re-nomination on the committee for not more than two terms, then, if all the sections in Chapter II read together and harmoniously with their subsections, it is evident that a member of the outgoing committee shall be eligible for re-nomination on the committee. However, his re-nomination is restricted to not more than two terms.

The word "outgoing" would mean not a member departing or laying down office, but a member who had at one time held the office. He could have held that office even in the remote past. He, then, need not be a member of the immediate past committee or the committee whose term has recently come to an end. If that had been the intent, the wording would have been different and to exclude from re-nomination any past member. The Legislature could have excluded any person who held this office not in a recent Committee but one of the past. Therefore, insertion of the word "outgoing" and before the words "member shall be eligible for re-nomination" would indicate that the same is a reference to the committee whose term or extended term has expired or is expiring.

It is in these circumstances that whenever the Legislature had in mind a embargo or prohibition, it has specifically carved out the same as in the sub-section (6) of section 7 of Haj Committee Act, where it states in no uncertain terms that the term of office of the Chairperson and the Vice-Chairperson, as the case may be, shall be coterminous with the term of the Committee and no person shall hold office of the Chairperson or Vice-Chairperson, as the case may be, for more than two consecutive terms. Therefore, if such a person is holding office, his term is clear and the words "holding office for not more than two consecutive terms" conveys that if a person holds office of Chairperson or Vice-Chairperson, he shall not hold it for more than two consecutive terms. Holding office for two consecutive terms is, therefore, permitted. 	 [Para 17,18,19]

heading: Office of profit
HeadNote.description: Haj Committee Rules (2002), R.11 - Office of profit - Chairperson of State Haj Committee for Kerala - Receiving only compensatory allowances by way of TA and DA for attending meetings - Post did not carry any other benefit 'receivable' by chairperson - Held, chairperson of Kerala Haj Committee was not disqualified to contest election. (Paras 12, 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Revision
Power of Court
HeadNote.description: Revision - Power of Court - Order in eviction proceedings on ground of Bona fide requirement - Bonafide requirement being a question of fact - Concurrent findings of such fact by lower courts cannot be interfered in revision - Especially so when findings not perverse or based on no evidence and no misdirection in interpreting evidence. (Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Revision
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Revision - Maintainability - Eviction proceedings filed by Petitioner through his mother as he was minor at that time - Petitioner had become major at time of decision in such proceedings - Appeal filed by Petitioner again as minor and through his mother - Appeal cannot be considered as   filed by petitioner - Hence, revision filed by Petitioner against order in appeal not maintainable. (Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Revision under
Necessary party
HeadNote.description: Revision under - Necessary party - Revision application against order of lower courts passed in eviction proceedings on ground of sub-tenancy - As eviction decree could be passed only against tenant - Tenant a necessary party to such revision. (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Revision
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Revision - Scope - Revision against orders passed in eviction proceedings - Plea that tenant's son had obtained alternative accommodation during pendency of revision application - Plea to be decided by leading evidence - In revision Court cannot permit introduction of new evidence to disturb findings of lower courts.

AIR 1991 SC 1760 - Distinguished. (Paras 23, 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Revision-Concurrent findings- Scope for interference- Concurrent findings of courts below on the points of alternative accommodation, willful default and bonafide requirement of landlord- No inconsistency with evidence on record-Findings not to be disturbed in revision. 	(Paras 13 to 15)
HeadNote.description: Revision-Concurrent findings- Scope for interference- Concurrent findings of courts below on the points of alternative accommodation, willful default and bonafide requirement of landlord- No inconsistency with evidence on record-Findings not to be disturbed in revision. 	(Paras 13 to 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Application by tenant alleging withdrawal of electric connection
HeadNote.description:
Application by tenant alleging withdrawal of electric connection - Appropriate order can be passed in case of emergency.

Unless it is found that the tenant was enjoying certain amenities and it is also established that those were withdrawn by the landlord, no orders can be passed under Section 17 of the Act except, however, interim orders, which are to be passed in emergency under sub-section 3 of Section 17 read with the explanation. When no ex parte order are passed and both the parties are before the Rent Controller, there is no propriety for passing interim orders and for keeping original application pending. Proceedings under Section 17 themselves are matters involving some urgency and require early disposal. If both parties are before the Rent Controller, it is his bounden duty to dispose of the application itself under Section 17 forthwith. Inquiry under Section 17 is of summary nature.  [Para 5]

It is true that firstly direction will have to be given to the landlord but if it is found that landlord cannot restore amenity for one reason or the other, Rent Controller will not be powerless to give such permission as is necessary to the tenant to take further steps so that amenities could be restored. Intention of the legislature is quite evident from the sub-section 5 of Section 17, If the amenities enjoyed by the tenant are stopped by any other person other than the landlord for failure of payment of tax, etc., then the tenant can pay those taxes or charges and get amenities restored. Therefore, any direction which is necessary for the restoration of the amenities in real sense is well within the powers of the Rent Controller.  [Para 6]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction proceedings under
Bonafide personal requirement
Ground of
HeadNote.description:
Eviction proceedings under - Bonafide personal requirement - Ground of - U/S. 15(3a)(iii) Landlord must be having running business, when he claims eviction - When Landlord wanted premises to start new business - Rejection of claim for eviction - Proper.

1977 Indian Law Reports, Bombay Series, Pg.1334 - Rel.on. (Para 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Tenancy
HeadNote.description: Tenancy - Father of applicant was tenant - After termination of his tenancy, son became the tenant - Rent, however, was paid by M.O. by father - For non-payment of rent by tenant land lord terminating tenancy of son - Son, however, contending that he was not the tenant but his father was tenant - But in view of rent note executed by son himself and which was admitted document father was no more a tenant - Held, Rent Controller and District Court had rightly recorded finding that there was willful default by applicant and in absence of jurisdictional errors or failure to record correct findings no interference was needed. (Paras 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction of tenant
"Wilful default"
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant - "Wilful default" - It is for tenant to prove that default wa not wilful.

The obligation to pay and/or tender the rent due is on tenant.  This contemplates that if there is an agreement to pay and/or tender the rent due on a fixed time, that the rent due shall be paid within fifteen days from the time specified in the agreement or contract and on such a failure the tenant will be defaulter.  If there is no time specified in the agreement for the payment of the rent due, then in that eventuality the tenant shall pay the rent by the last day of the month next following that for which the rent is payable and if the rent is not paid by the last day of the month next following that for which the rent payable, then the tenant becomes a defaulter.  Thus, in the first contingency tenant becomes a defaulter on completion of fifteen days from the time specified for the payment of the rent due in the agreement and in the absence of such agreement a tenant becomes a defaulter on completion of 30 days of the next following month of the due rent of the  earlier month.    [Para 9]

Whenever the Rent Controller finds that the default as provided under clause (i) of sub-section  15  (2) is established, the Rent Controller shall find out as to whether the tenant has offered any explanation and/or has pointed out any facts which may point out that the tenant's default to pay or tender the rent was not wilful and whether the said explanation or the facts have been proved and established by the tenant and thereafter the Controller will have to consider whether such explanation and the established fact is sufficient to satisfy the controller that the tenant's default to pay or tender the rent was not wilful.  Therefore, the burden to prove that the tenant's default to pay or tender the rent was not wilful is on the tenant, because the circumstances and/or the facts as a result of which the tenant failed to pay rent and/or tender it are within the knowledge of the tenant which tenant can only allege and prove.  Therefore, even though prima facie it appears to be negative burden, factually and in reality it is a positive burden on the tenant.   [Para 10]

In the circummutence the finding recorded by the Distict Judge that the tenant was wilful default and that he had failed to prove that he was not a defaulter was proper and had to be confirmed.  [Para 12,14]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Non residential premises
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant for change of user - Non residential premises - Purpose of letting not specifically mentioned in deed - Breach of deed simplicitor is not ground for eviction.

The landlord in the instant case is totally silent regarding the purpose for which or the business for which the tenanted premises were to be used by the tenant. The rent note on which the landlord has based his claim, is totally silent in this regard, and neither the purpose of letting out the premises nor the business to be carried out by the tenant is mentioned in the rent note. Consequently, the landlord does not fulfil the necessary requirement of Section 15(2)(ii)(b) that he had let out the premises for a particular purpose and that the tenant has used the premises for some other or different purpose.  [Para 12]

It is true that there is a specific condition in the rent note preventing the tenant from using the suit premises, for storing explosives or inflamable articles. However, Hyderabad Rent Control Act initially empowers the landlord to evict the tenant only on account of pure and simple breach of the terms of the rent deed. The breach of the agreement has to be with reference to the object and purpose for which the premises are leased out and eviction is therefore permitted under Section 15(2)(ii)(b). The breach simplicitor of the lease deed is not made a ground for eviction and therefore, even if the landlord succeeds in proving that the tenant committed breach of clause 5 of the lease deed regarding storing of explosives he cannot succeed in evicting the tenant.	  [Para 13]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Wilful default by tenant - Civil court holding that tenant was wilful defaulter - Finding is binding on Rent control authority - Lower court in one breath holding that tenant had defaulted but default was not wilful - Decision could be interfered with in revision though High Court does not normally interfere with decision. Civil P.C. (1908), S.115.	(Paras 26,27)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Ground of reasonable and bonafide requirement - Landlord is the best judge of his requirement but at the same time, for claiming decree for possession on the ground of bonafide requirement, there must be some element of necessity and the need put forth if found to be mere desire cannot be said to be reasonable and bonafide requirement.	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction suit
HeadNote.description: Eviction suit - Bona fide requirement of suit shop for the third son of landlord - Finding recorded in consonance with evidence brought on record - No perversity noticed in findings - District court is the last fact finding authority and such findings cannot be interfered with in revision. 	(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Rent Act would operate prospectively

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Grounds of bonafide requirement and wilful default - Rent controller passing order of eviction on both grounds - Appellate court not recording separate reasons to reverse said findings - Matter remanded back to appellate Court, in exercise of revisional jurisdiction by High Court.

It is true that re-appreciation of the evidence is not possible in the revisional jurisdiction. However, the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction can certainly interfere into the findings recorded by the appellate Court if the appellate Court fails to consider the evidence on record, which amounts to failure to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it under the law and whole judgment is vitiated because of it. This court can also interfere in the judgment if perverse findings are recorded by the  appellate Court.	 [Para 9]

In the instant case,  the appellate Court has not recorded separate reasons so as to reverse the findings of the Rent Controller that the respondent / tenant is a willful  defaulter. The appellate Court has recorded perverse findings and on this count alone, the matter is required to be remanded back to the appellate Court.	 [Para 10]

Further, On careful perusal of the findings recorded by the appellate Court on the point of bonafide requirement of the petitioner, it further appears that cryptic findings are recorded by the appellate Court. In fact, when the Rent Controller has held in favour of the landlord on both counts i.e. willful default and bonafide requirement, it was incumbent upon the appellate Court to record cogent and sufficient reasons while reversing those findings.	 [Para 11,12]

(1998) 5 SCC 21 Ref. to.  	(Paras 7, 8, 9, 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of wilful default
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of wilful default - Non payment of rent - Plea of tenant that he was in confusion to  whom he could pay rent - No recourse taken to S. 14(3)- Defence of practice of payment of accumulated rent - Tenant can be held to be wilful defaulter.

The obligation to pay and/or tender the rent due is on tenant. This contemplates that if there is an agreement to pay and/or tender the rent due on a fixed time, that the rent due shall be paid within fifteen days from the time specified in the agreement or contract and on such a failure the tenant will be defaulter. If there is no time specified in the agreement for the payment of the rent due, then in that eventuality the tenant shall pay the rent by the last day of the month next following that for which the rent is payable and if the rent is not paid by the last day of the month next following that for which rent is payable, then the tenant becomes a defaulter. Before a tenant could ask for benefit of Proviso to S.15(2), he must claim and prove to the satisfaction of the Controller that the tenant's default to pay or tender rent was not wilful and, therefore, in case of a default the tenant has to come forward with an explanation and prove the said explanation so that the Controller can be said to be satisfied that the tenant's default to pay/tender the rent was not wilful, in the absence of such a plea and the explanation and proof of the same the Controller has to pass an order directing the tenant to put the landlord in possession of the premises and, therefore, on a proper analysis of the provision in respect of the default and wilful default.  [Para 11,12]

In case the tenant is in confusion as to whom he should pay rent because there were co-owners, he could take recourse to S.14(3) and in the absence of adopting such course, simpliciter ground of confusion made and cannot be a valid defence to hold that the tenant was not a wilful defaulter.  [Para 14]

Further, the practice of payment of accumulated rent could not be accepted by way of explanation or defence to infer that the default was not wilful default. If such practice is accepted for any defence covered under the proviso, the main provision is permanently defeated, and therefore, such a practice which defeats the main provision permanently and makes the law nugatory cannot be accepted as an explanation for inferring the tenant as not wilful defaulter. If a man claims the benefit of the statutory provisions, then he is equally under an obligation to discharge his statutory duty initially. However, the plea of practice of a payment of accumulated rent to be paid by the tenant shows that basically the tenant fails to discharge his statutory duty as provided under clause (1) of Section 15(2) of the Act, but claims the benefit of the proviso, which is against the settled principles of law.  [Para 15]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of wilful default
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of wilful default - Property belonging to Hindu Joint Family - Disputed premises coming to share of landlord after partition - Attornment of tenancy not necessary before suit is filed eviction.

In the instant case, the person who was already landlord in part and was entitled to recover the rent on behalf of others, his exclusive right has been crystalised as a result of partition, and such partition is permissible among Hindus even by the oral agreement between the parties. Therefore, the attornment as expected by the tenant was not necessary.  [Para 17]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description:
Bombay High Court Civil Manual (Vol. 1) (1960)Chap.VII, Para 96(3) - Eviction of tenant - Death of tenant during pendency of proceeding - Bringing LRs of tenant on records - Provisions of CPC apply and not of High Court Civil Manual - Orders passed and notices issued to LRs - Names of LRs not recorded - Recording of names is ministerial act - Proceeding cannot be dismissed for omission.

The Hyderabad Rent Act makes a clear provision that the procedure laid down in the C.P.C., 1908, is applicable for proceedings  pending before the Rent Controller.  There is nothing in the Hyderabad Rent Act to indicate that the directions and guidelines issued under the Civil Manual by the High Court are also made applicable for the proceedings pending before the Rent Controller. The directions and guidelines issued under the Civil Manual are for the Civil Courts.  The Civil manual nowhere indicates that these are the directions and guidelines also applicable to the Rent Controller acting under the Hyderabad Rent Act.  So, the Rent Controller was not expected to follow the provisions of the Civil Manual.   [Para 19]

In the instant case, there was only a ministerial mistake of not recording the names of the legal representatives of the tenant in the title of the proceedings and, for that mistake, the petitioner cannot be held guilty and the petition cannot be dismissed, especially when not only notices were served on the legal representatives, but the legal representatives had filed appearance and had contested the matter and even had filed appeal against the judgment of the Rent Controller.	  [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Wilful defaulter
Onus to prove
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of wilful default - Wilful defaulter - Onus to prove - Framing of issue.

Civil P.C.(1908) O.14, R.1.

The landlord has to prove that the tenant is defaulter and then, the onus is on the tenant to show that he is not a wilful defaulter.  In that case, he has to bring on record certain circumstances, which may indicate that even if there is default in payment of rent, because of those circumstances, it cannot be said that the default is wilful.  So, in whatever way the issue is framed, the question whether there was wilful default has to be decided on the basis of evidence led by the tenant. The tenant in the case has not taken the stand that due to certain circumstances, he could not pay the rent.  He has taken the stand that he had paid the rent.  So, when the landlord proves that rent was not paid, no question of proving that default was not wilful arises.  Some minor technical defect in framing of the issue will not give chance to the Petitioner tenant to say that the whole judgment and order is required to be set aside.  No specific prejudice was caused to the Petitioner in framing the issue in the manner framed by the Rent Controller.  The Petitioner had not entered into the witness box to show that the default was not wilful.  They had not even entered into the witness box to show that the rent was actually paid and there was no default.				 [Para 26]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Meaning
HeadNote.description:
"In the absence of any such agreement ------" - Meaning - Yearly tenancy agreement for one year - No further extension of agreement - No dare or time for payment of rent specified in agreement - Held tenancy was yearly and rent ought to have been paid within a month next after completion of tenancy year.
Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.111 - Applicability to tenancies covered under Rent Act.

In the present case, the tenancy was inducted into possession of the premises initially by an agreement between the parties on year basis and the period was for one year. The agreement was not further extended but the tenant continued to be in possession of the premises. The date or time on which the rent was payable was not specified in the agreement. The case of the tenant was that it continued to yearly tenancy after completion of one year and as he had deposited the rent as per the summons issued in the civil suit before the eviction petition he was not defaulter. The landlord's contention was that in absence of further extension of agreement it was monthly tenancy and as the tenant had not paid monthly rent, he was defaulter.

Held that as the initial agreement was on yearly basis in the absence of further extension, it continued to be yearly tenancy. It was covered by the second half portion of S.15(2)(i). The rent, therefore ought to have been paid, after completion of one year of tenancy, within a period of one month next after the Last day of the month when it had become due. In the present case, the rent was due for the period 1-11-78 to 29-9-81 and as the tenancy was from Diwali to Dewali, two defaults were committed by the tenant i.e. from 1-11-78 to 20-10-79 and 21-10-79 to 7-10-80. The amount of first default should have been paid within a period 30 days from 7-10-80. As the rent was paid only on 7-10-81, the tenant was defaulter.  [Para 7,9]

The provision of S.111 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, provides for termination or determination of tenancy by efflux of time. However, the Rent Act is a special statute which governs the relations of the Landlord and the tenant in respect of certain premises and therefore the said provisions cannot be applied to the tenancies covered under the Rent Act. Therefore, once the tenant is inducted into possession of the premises on yearly and/or monthly basis for a particular specific period, he continues to be the tenant of the said premises as per the initial agreement between the parties and the tenancy will not come to an end after the agreed period. AIR 1978 Andhra Pradesh 319 (FB), AIR 1976 SC 869 and AIR 1974 SC 818 foll.  [Para 7]

The first half of the clause of S.15(2)(i) applies to those tenancies where in the agreement of tenancy either oral or written, the parties have fixed the time for payment of rent after it has become due and payable. The second half portion i.e. "in the absence of any such agreement ------- for which the rent is payable applies when the parties have not fixed the time for payment of rent after it has become due and payable. This clause does not govern the nature of tenancy. It only speaks as to what point of time a tenant is said to have committed default. The words in the absence of any such agreement referred not to the tenancy either monthly or yearly but it refers to the clause in the agreement of tenancy which specifies the date or time fixed for payment of rent after it has become due and payable and in the absence of such a clause, the second half portion of the clause comes into operation. If this analysis is not accepted, the yearly tenancy which is in the absence of any agreement, will not be governed by any clauses of the Act and in the result there will not be any default in respect of yearly tenancy. Such anomalous interpretation cannot be allowed to exist.  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Hyderabad Houses (Rent, Eviction and Lease) Control Act (1954)
heading: Wilful default
HeadNote.description:
Wilful defaulter Burden of proof - Non-acceptance of rent by landlord - Other modes such as payment of rent by money order or by cheque not adopted - Payment during tendency of proceedings for eviction - Held tenant was wilful defaulter
Evidence Act (1872), Ss.101 To 104
Eviction of tenant - Default in payment of rent - Burden of proof.
Eviction of tenant - Wilful default - Instance.

Once the default in payment of rent is proved by the landlord, the burden of proof that the tenant is not a wilful defaulter is on the tenant. In the present case, the tenant made efforts to make the payment, but the rent was not accepted. He did not make any efforts to send the same by money order or by cheque. The rent was not paid as stipulated in second half portion of S. 15(2)(i) but deposited as per the summons issued in the civil suit and before filing the petition for eviction.

Held that the tenant was wilful defaulter. The moment the rent not being accepted and/or was found to have been avoided he should have, to protect himself taken every precaution to see that the payment was made by any modes as provided in S.15(2)(i) and should have taken care to show that the rent was tendered within time. The subsequent payments or the payments during tendency of eviction proceedings cannot be considered for the purchase of deciding as to whether the tenant was wilful defaulter or not, such payments cannot be said to be voluntary and wilful. They were made because of the threat of proceedings and consequence of being declared as wilful defaulter. 1985(1) BCR 403 and AIR 1978 Andhra Pradesh 319 (FB) Foll.  [Para 11,11A]

heading: Dismissal
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and permanent injunction - Dismissal - Challenge - Plaintiff challenged legality of Will (giving half of suit property to defendant) - On ground that deceased was not owner - Deceased was plaintiff’s aunt and suit property was portion of joint family property - From admission of plaintiff’s father itself, it appears that deceased had got said portion in lieu of maintenance - She was in separate and exclusive possession - Not a case that she was given any restricted estate attracting Sec.14(2) of Hindu Succession Act - Though plaintiff claimed suit property through a Will of his grand-mother, he sought no declaration for himself - Having failed to establish his own possession, plaintiff also not entitled to injunction - Dismissal proper. (Paras 7, 8, 9, 10)

headline:
Specific Relief Act (1963), Ss.34, 39 – Hindu Succession Act (1956), S.14 – Suit for declaration and permanent injunction – Dismissal – Challenge - Legality of Will

From Plaintiff's admission, deceased got said portion in lieu of maintenance - Separate/exclusive possession, not restricted estate attracting S.14(2) of Hindu Succession Act- Failure to establish own possession, not entitled to injunction - Dismissal proper.

heading: Letters of Administration
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Letters of Administration - Petition for - Petition by alleged widow of deceased - Petitioner already divorced from deceased pleaded remarriage - True that u/s.14 widow of Hindu deceased holds property as full owner - However as petitioner's legal status as wife not established, Petitioner not entitled to deal with deceased's property till grant of Letters. (Para 11)

heading: Succession certificate
HeadNote.description: Mullah's Mohammedan Law, S.321 - Succession certificate - Muslim father renounces Islam and converted himself into Hinduism - Children from Muslim wife continued to pursue Islamic faith - Properties acquired by their father after his conversion to Hinduism would remain beyond their reach - As they cannot be heir of a disbeliever of Islam, not entitled to succession certificate - Even the Hindu Law does not permit inheritance to a son who renounces Hinduism during life time of his father. 	(Paras 30, 31, 32, 33, 34)

heading: Contract to sell immovable property
HeadNote.description: Contract to sell immovable property - Property belonging to three sons, mother and three sisters - Agreements to sale executed by only two sons - Held, in view of right accrued to remaining heirs under S.8 of Hindu Succession Act agreement is not enforceable in law in view of S.17 of the Specific Relief Act. 	(Para 29)

heading: Will
Validity
HeadNote.description: Will - Validity - Mother-Hindu female bequeathed property by way of Will - Said property was mutated by son in favour of mother - Son has not executed any document for transferring property in favour of his mother - Only on basis of mutation entry mother cannot be said to have acquired property within meaning of S.14 of Hindu Succession Act - Mother cannot bequeath property by way of Will.  1980 ALLMR ONLINE 319, 1997 (Suppl.) SCC 262 Rel. on. 	(Paras 12, 13, 15)

heading: Suit for possession and cancellation of sale deed
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession and cancellation of sale deed - Defendants claiming to have purchased suit property from adoptive mother of plaintiff i.e. 'L' - Plaintiffs stating that by a settlement deed they had created only life interest for 'L' for her maintenance and she had no right to sell it - Defendant contending that such a document is covered by S.14(2) of Hindu Succession Act and once fact of L's possession over suit property is established her limited interest becomes absolute - Held, 'L' could enforce right of maintenance only against ancestral or joint family property of husband - No evidence brought on record to prove that suit property was purchased out of nucleus of joint family property - Therefore, it cannot be said that there was pre-existing right of maintenance of 'L' which could be enforced against suit property - Thus, settlement deed not covered by S.14 of Hindu Succession Act - Hence, 'L' was not absolute owner of suit property. 	(Paras 19, 23, 24, 28)

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description:
Suit for declaration - Plaintiffs sought declaration that settlement deed executed between defendants exchanging immovable properties is invalid - Declaration sought on ground that property in question is ancestral property - Record showing that property is ancestral property which had fallen to share of defendants on partition and had retained character of coparcenary property - Plaintiffs being son and grandsons of defendants have right in property - Suit is maintainable.

	It is settled that the property inherited by a male Hindu from his father, father's father or father's father's father is an ancestral property. The essential feature of ancestral property, according to Mitakshara Law, is that the sons, grandsons, and great grandsons of the person who inherits it, acquire an interestand the rights attached to such property at the moment of their birth. The sharewhich a coparcener obtains on partition of ancestral property is ancestral property as regards his male issue. After partition, the property in the hands of the son will continue to be the ancestral property and the natural or adopted son of that son will take interest in it and is entitled to it by survivorship.Therefore, the properties acquired by defendant No.2 in the partition dtd. 31.07.1987 although are separate property qua other relations but it is acoparcenary property insofar as his sons and grandsons are concerned. In the instant case, the properties are ancestral properties which have been divided as per the deed of partition dated 31.07.1987. The property which had fallen to the share of defendant No.2 retained the character of a coparcenary property and the plaintiffs being his sons and grandson have a right in the said property. Hence, it cannot be said that the suit filed by the plaintiffs was not maintainable. 	 [Para 12,16]

heading: Impleadment of necessary party
HeadNote.description: Impleadment of necessary party - Suit for declaration as to ownership over joint family property after partition between parents and brothers - Rejection of application made by daughter for impleadment - On ground that she has not challenged decree in partition suit which was passed on basis of oral family partition between her parents and brothers - As per law prevailing at that time daughters as matter of right cannot claim share in joint family property to be partitioned - Absence of challenge to decree in partition suit by daughter is irrelevant - Applicant-daughter claiming that after death of her parents she is entitled to share in property left behind by parents - As per Hindu Succession Act, daughters are entitled to share in property left behind by parents - Daughter is necessary and proper party in suit - Rejection of application for impleadment, improper. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Rejection of plaint
Suit for partition
Deceased died issueless
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Suit for partition - In respect of properties received by deceased wife from her parents - Deceased died issueless - Plaintiffs are her husband and children of husband from second wife - In view of S.15(2)(a) of 1956 Act, husband and his children cannot inherit property of deceased wife in absence of her son or daughter - Suit property will devolve upon legal heirs of her father - Relief sought that heirship certificate obtained by legal heir of father of deceased is not binding on husband, also cannot be considered - No cause of action to file suit for partition of deceased's property - Plaint rejected. 	(Para 13)

heading: Necessary party
HeadNote.description: Necessary party - Suit for dissolution of partnership firm - Assets of partnership firm were inherited by deceased from her father's share in firm - After her death, her husband along with her daughter sought to be joined as party-defendants in suit filed for dissolution of partnership firm - In view of S.15(2)(a) of Succession Act, her daughter alone can claim right therein - Only if deceased had died issue-less, then in that case property will devolve on her husband - Since deceased died leaving behind her daughter, husband stands excluded from inheritance right of suit property - However, testamentary suit in respect of Will executed by deceased bequeathing property in favour of her husband and daughter is pending - On count of S.2(11) and O.1 R.10(2) CPC also, husband can be entitled to be impleaded. (1994) 5 SCC 761, 2001(2) ALL MR 574, 2007(2) ALL MR 856, (2000) 9 SCC 714, 2017(5) ALL MR 468 (S.C.), 2004(5) LL MR 171 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 11, 19, 25, 26, 27, 28, 34, 35, 37)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Against order passed in suit for partition, granting equal share to daughters in joint family property - Suit property not partitioned either by registered partition deed or by decree of competent civil Court before cut-off date - In such case daughters would be entitled to equal share in joint family property as per S.6 of Hindu Succession Act - Order passed by first Appellate Court granting equal share to daughters, proper - Second appeal dismissed. (Paras 11, 12)

heading: Rejection of plaint
Suit for
Defendants not responding
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Non disclosure of cause of action - Right of pre emption - Suit for - Plaintiff allegedly issued notice to defendants informing them his willingness to purchase property - Defendants not responding - Plaintiff filed suit and based his claim on S.22 of Act - Defendant i.e. father of plaintiff still alive - Right under S.22 accrues to heirs of deceased - Since father is still alive and property is said to be ancestral and not self acquired in hands of father, there is no application of Section 22 at all - Moreover plaintiff is seeking to set aside alienation of property by his father in favour of other defendants - Therefore, until a partition is sought there could not be setting aside of alienation for alienation could be set aside only to extent of share of plaintiff and that cannot be done unless suit for partition is filed - Plaint liable to be rejected for non disclosure of cause of action.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Injunction
HeadNote.description: Hindu Succession (Amendment) Act (2005) S.6 - Injunction - Father and his son executed registered development agreement and power of attorney - Possession of suit properties given to Developers - Developers claim that suit properties did not belong to father at time of his death - On death of father when his succession opened both daughters were not alive to be coparceners in their own right in same manner as son - No material produced to show that suit properties are ancestral - Son of daughter cannot claim right on property through mother after death of his maternal grandfather - Interim relief not liable to be granted to plaintiff daughter's son. 			(Paras 28, 29, 30, 31)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Scope and applicability of Amendment Act - Appellate Court is entitled to take into consideration any change in the law. 2007(2) ALL MR 679 - Rel. on.	(Para 13)

heading: Second appeal
New plea
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - New plea - Plea that in view of S.14 of Hindu Succession Act, mother has become full-fledged owner of suit property, raised for first time in second appeal at time of arguments - Such plea is mixed question of law and facts - Cannot be raised for first time in second appeal.  2018(3) ALL MR 681 Rel. on. 			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Contents of Will
Proof as to
HeadNote.description:
Contents of Will - Proof as to - Original document of Will not produced before Court - Nor it is pleaded that original Will has been lost or a copy thereof is not available - Oral evidence as to execution of Will inadmissible - Oral evidence u/s.63(5) would be admissible only when loss of original or non-availability of its copy is proved - Defendants having failed to do either of the things, alleged Will not proved.

S.59 of Evidence Act says that all facts except the contents of document may be proved by oral evidence.  Contents of documents must be proved by production of such document alone.  The contents according to S.61 can be proved by primary or secondary evidence.  Primary evidence is defined a the document itself; that is the original. The original Will is not at all produced before the Court. Since there is no pleading or evidence of loss of original, secondary evidence is also not admissible. No amount or oral evidence about execution of any Will would be admissible unless the original is produced or a copy is produced or the loss of original is proved. An oral evidence under Cl.5 of S.63 of Evidence Act would be admissible only when the loss of original is pleaded and proved and non-availability of even a copy is proved.  In the instant case, defendant does not do either of the things.  In the circumstances the alleged Will cannot be said to be proved.  [Para 9]

heading: Accident claim
HeadNote.description: Accident claim - Remarriage of claimant widow during pendency of claim petition - Does not disentitle her from receiving compensation - By virtue of S.14 of Hindu Succession Act, a widow becomes entitled to award of compensation as a legal heir - In instant case, after death of mother of deceased, no other class-I legal heir available - Widow entitled to entire compensation amount. 2012 ACJ 945, 2011 ACJ 1625 Rel. on. 			(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Accident claim
HeadNote.description:
Accident claim - Eligibility to claim compensation - Mother of deceased remarried after death of her husband i.e. father of deceased and begot three children - Held, u/s.8 of Hindu Succession Act, a mother along with other Class-I heirs, inherits estate of her deceased son - This right is an absolute one u/s.14 of 1956 Act - Same will not be divested due to remarriage.
AIR 1976 SC 2595 Ref. to.(Para 17)

heading: Accident claim
HeadNote.description: Accident claim - Entitlement of father and brother upon death of married son - Deceased was living separately with wife and daughter - Father and brothers not dependent on him - They fall in Class II of heirship, not entitled to compensation - However, amount of Rs. 1.25 lakh granted to father as concession considering his age and fact that deceased was his eldest major son. 2009(4) ALL MR 429 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 1617 Ref. to. 	(Paras 25, 26, 29)

heading: Tenancy created by Hindu woman
HeadNote.description: Tenancy created by Hindu woman - Not only recognition of right of maintenance but also acquisition of property by Hindu woman by document dt.14-06-1921 for her maintenance - Hindu woman entitled to become absolute owner of the property on coming into force of Hindu Succession Act - Therefore, held, the tenancy created by her could not come to an end automatically upon her demise - Her heirs can step into her shoes. AIR 1977 SC 1944 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Tenancy rights
HeadNote.description: Tenancy rights - Claim by adopted son - He was minor when widow landlady conferred tenancy rights on her son-in-law - Held, she had a right to create tenancy in favour of her son-in-law and such a lease was not barred by law.(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Administration of estate
HeadNote.description:
Administration of estate - Powers of Administrator General - Ambit of, stated.

	Provisions enacted by Parliament u/Ss.7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 14, 20 of Administrators General Act define the ambit of the powers vested in the Administrator General and the circumstances in which he can move the High Court. Essentially, the Administrator General steps in to protect the estate of a person who has died and no person to whom any court would have jurisdiction to commit the administration of the estate has come forth. The Administrator General is authorised by law to move the High Court to obtain letters of administration. Where the property or estate of the deceased is in imminent danger, the Administrator General can be empowered by the High Court to take immediate steps to safeguard the estate. While permitting the Administrator General to apply to the High Court for the grant of letters of administration, the law allows any other individual to appear and establish a claim before the High Court. Where a claim to probate or letters of administration in preference to the Administrator General is established, an order of revocation can be passed by the High Court. Such adjudicatory functions are entrusted to the High Court. The Administrator General, as a public official, is conferred with duties and obligations to secure and safeguard the administration of the estate left behind by a deceased individual in the circumstances adverted to in the statute. The legislation has not reserved a judicial power to the Administrator General. Parliament in its wisdom has made provisions to ensure that estates are not frittered away upon the death of persons who do not leave behind legal heirs, by allowing the Administrator General to invoke the jurisdiction of the High Court to safeguard such estates. The conferment of adjudicatory functions upon the High Court safeguards against an abuse of power and facilitates an adjudication of private claims. 	   [Para 23]

heading: Apportionment of compensation
Legality
HeadNote.description: Apportionment of compensation - Legality - Father purchased acquired land in name of his eldest son out of love and affection when he was 13 years old - Hence, at that time it was benami transaction - Son had attained majority, retained land with him so also his name remained entered throughout in revenue record and then died before father - Father did not transfer said property either in his name or in name of his other children during life time or after death of son - When father executed Will, he neither mentioned about such benami purchase nor disposed of same because till then son had become full owner of suit property - Therefore, inference of lapse of legacy drawn by Reference Court as son died before father, is improper - After death of son, his widow and children being legal representatives entitled to receive amount of compensation. 	(Para 9)

heading: Apportionment of compensation
Legality
HeadNote.description: Succession Act (1925), S.163 - Apportionment of compensation - Legality - Father bequeathed 2 acres land from acquired land to his daughter during his life time - He died after acquisition of entire land but before award - Once father has bequeathed land and did not challenge same till his death, bequeath continued and it effected after his death and legacy continued - Bequest of land due to acquisition was transformed into compensation amount - Bequest remained unaffected by virtue of S.163 of Succession Act - Therefore, claim of daughter alone is to be acknowledged. 			(Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Ownership of female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Ownership of female Hindu - Female Hindu in possession of property, actual or constructive or in any form in pursuance of her right of life interest - She becomes absolute owner of the said property by virtue of S.14(1) on date of commencement of the Act. 2006(8) SCC 75 - Ref.to.			(Paras 10 to 13)

heading: Suit for partition
Non-production of Will
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Non-production of Will - Will said to be not traceable - Court, therefore, proceeded on the basis that the said purported Will being non-existent, the parties did not inherit any property pursuant thereto or in furtherance thereof.(Para 9)

heading: Partition
Coparcenary property
Claim for
Partition by plaintiff-appellant
HeadNote.description: Partition - Coparcenary property - Claim for - Partition by plaintiff-appellant - Grand-daughter cannot claim higher right than right of her father - 'J' and 'P' succeeded to ancestral property equally on death of their father 'Su' - They effected partition and property came to exclusive share of 'J' - Father of plaintiff 'Sa', predeceased his father 'J' and even his grandfather 'Su' - During lifetime of 'J', 'Sa' could not have succeeded to property - For same reason appellant being daughter of 'Sa' could not claim any right higher than that of 'Sa'.			(Paras 19, 20, 22)

heading: Applicability of S.22 to agricultural lands
HeadNote.description: Applicability of S.22 to agricultural lands - Preferential right given to heir of Hindu u/S.22 - Is applicable even if property in question is agricultural land - In the instant case, field is occupied in State of Himachal Pradesh - Therefore S.22 would operate in respect of succession to agricultural lands in state. 1970 PLR (72) 958, AIR 1970 All 238, AIR 1974 MP 141, AIR 1981 Raj 16, 2007 SCC On line P&H 1257, 2010-5 L.W. 941 Overruled.	(Paras 16, 21)

heading: Nominee of deceased person
HeadNote.description: Nominee of deceased person - Is entitled to receive beneficial interest after the death of person concerned - Property or the amount so received by nominee is to be distributed according to law of succession. (1984)1 SCC 424, 1988 Lab.I.C. 500, 2000(4) ALL MR (S.C.) 688 - Rel.on.	(Para 17)

heading: Female Hindu
Ascertainment of
HeadNote.description:
Female Hindu - Devolution of her property - Heirs of her Husband - Ascertainment of - Heirs must be determined not at the time of Husband's death but at wife's death.

In order to decide who are the heirs of a female Hindu under category (b) of S. 15(1), one does not have to go back to the date of the death of husband to ascertain who were his heirs at that time. The heirs have to be ascertained not at the time of the husband's death but at the time of the wife's death because the succession opens only at the time of her death. Her heirs under S.15(1)(b) will have to be ascertained as if the succession to her husband had opened at the time of her death.  [Para 4]

heading: Provision respecting dwelling houses
HeadNote.description:
Provision respecting dwelling houses - Ss.23 and 24 of Hindu Succession Act omitted by the Amended Act - Provision of S.29-A part and parcel of Chapter II of Hindu Succession Act which contains S.23 - S.29-A shall not apply to a daughter married before the date of commencement of the Hindu Succession (Maharashtra Amendment) Act, 1994.

In the present case, not only defendant - Madhukar but his son (respondent No.1-(b) Manoj) are the male members, who were residing in the suit house. The residence of respondent No.1(b) Manoj in the suit house would continue the process of keeping right of the appellant in abeyance. She cannot claim partition in the dwelling house when the same is occupied by respondent No.1(b) - Manoj and other members of the family. Due to death of Madhukar, there will be no change in the legal position qua the present appellant.

Coming to the question of effect of the change due to Amendment Act No.39 of 2005, it is important to note that Section 29-A is added under Chapter II-A.
