No doubt, it gives equal rights to daughter in coparcenery property irrespective of limitations contained in Section 6 of the Hindu Succession Act. By the amended Act, Section 23 and Section 24 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 have been omitted. The omissions of these two Sections, of course, has nexus with introduction of Section 29-A under Chapter II-A. Section 23 stands omitted under the amended Act in order to pave the way for effective operation of Section 23-A. The amended provision of Section 29-A is introduced under Chapter II-A, which is part and parcel of Chapter II of the Hindu Succession Act, which contains Section 23. The provision of Section 29-A, as applicable to the State of Maharashtra reveals that the Chapter II-A shall not apply to a daughter married before the date of the commencement of the Hindu Succession (Maharashtra Amendment) Act, 1994. Thus, the daughters, who had married before the commencement of the Hindu Succession (Maharashtra Amendment) Act, 1994 are kept outside the beneficial zone of the amended provision of Section 23-A. In other words, the provision would be available prospectively. In the present case, the appellant was married much prior to commencement of the Hindu Succession (Maharashtra Amendment) Act, 1994 (MAH XL of 1994). Hence, she cannot claim benefit of Section 29-A. The omission of Section 23 under the Amendment Act does not open floodgate to the ineligible female heirs for the purpose of seeking partition of dwelling house. Their rights are still in abeyance until the male heir is in occupation of the dwelling house. Under these circumstances, the appellant is not entitled to claim partition of the suit house. 					 [Para 15,16]

heading: Right of succession
HeadNote.description: Right of succession - Natural born son of adoptee father - No provision denying it, under Act - Therefore succession will be in terms of provisions of Act alone - There was full blood relationship between three sons born to adoptee father ‘L’ before adoption and the daughter who was born after adoption - Thus, all children of ‘L’ entitled to property of their natural father and mother in accordance with provisions of Act as succession opened after death of ‘L’ in 1987 and subsequently his wife in 1992. 	(Para 21)

heading: Suit for Specific performance of contract of sale of a house property
HeadNote.description: Suit for Specific performance of contract of sale of a house property - Agreement of sale entered into by defendant with deceased brother of plaintiff - Locus standi of plaintiff - Locus standi challenged on ground that since deceased brother had wife, surviving sister will not inherit property - High Court holding that in view of alleged remarriage of widow, plaintiff was entitled to maintain a suit for specific performance - However, factual position was clearly contrary - Held, High Court was clearly in error.	(Para 11)

heading: Suit for compensation
HeadNote.description: Suit for compensation - Deceased while travelling on scooter on Bombay Pune road, some jawans of military fired shots from their guns as a result of which deceased died - Suit filed for compensation - Held, under the Hindu Succession Act, it is not the father, but it is the mother along with widow and children of deceased were entitled for compensation - Legal heirs can file writ petition instead of filing suit for getting compensation. AIR 1966 SC 1697 - Distinguished.	(Paras 9 & 11)

heading: Joint family property
Right of maintenance
HeadNote.description: Joint family property - Right of maintenance - Plaintiff/petitioner being wife of one of the co-parceners who died in 1979 - Plaintiff/petitioner entitled to have a right of maintenance when the said properties are in possession of father-in-law and other co-parceners.	(Para 6)

heading: Devolution of property
HeadNote.description:
Female Hindu dying intestate and issueless - Devolution of property - Property inherited by her from her mother - Devolves upon her sister and not on brother of pre-deceased husband - Devolution is on basis of source from which property was inherited by female and fact that she initially had limited right and later acquired full ownership is immaterial.AIR 1985 P & H 86 Overruled.

Admittedly, Smt. Santi inherited the property in question from her mother. If the property held by a female was inherited from her father or mother, in the absence of any son or daughter of the deceased, including the children of any pre-deceased son or daughter, it would only devolve upon the heirs of the father and, in this case, her sister was the only legal heir of her father. Deceased Smt. Santi admittedly inherited the property in question from her mother. It is not necessary that such inheritance should have been after the commencement of the Act. The intent of the Legislature is clear that the property, if originally belonged to the parents of the deceased female, should go to the legal heirs of the father. So also under clause (b) of sub-section (2) of Section 15, the property inherited by a female Hindu from her husband or her father-in-law, shall also under similar circumstances, devolve upon the heirs of the husband. It is the source from which the property was inherited by the female, which is more important for the purpose of devolution of her property. The fact that a female Hindu originally had a limited right and later, acquired the full right, in any way, would not alter the rules of succession given in sub-section (2) of Section 15.	  [Para 8]

The source from which she inherits the property is always important and that would govern the situation. Otherwise persons who are not even remotely related to the person who originally held the property would acquire rights to inherit that property. That would defeat the intent and purpose of sub-section (2) of Section 15, which gives a special pattern of succession.

AIR 1978 SC 793 and AIR 1991 SC 2301 Rel.on.				 [Para 13]

heading: Co-widows
HeadNote.description:
On death of husband in 1946 two widows inheriting property - They inherit as joint tenants with right of survivorship - They become absolute owners after coming into force of 1956 Act - On death of one widow, other widow would inherit entire property - In case of her death his daughter would inherit property entirely.

Hindu Law - Co-widows - Succession to property.

The deceased owner of property died in 1946 leaving behind him two widows. The third wife had predeceased the owner leaving a daughter A behind. The second widow died in 1974 and the third widow alone survived who had only daughter B. The third widow also died in 1977.

Held, that the two widows, who were surviving in 1946 at the time of death of owner inherited the property as their widow's estate as joint tenants with right of survivorship and on their becoming the absolute owners after coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, the right of survivorship inherited by them would continue to be there and if that be so then on the death of another widow in 1974, the sole surviving widow i.e. mother of B the plaintiff would succeed to the entire property by survivorship. Consequently B would be entitled to succeed to the entire property on her mother's death in 1977. 'A' the daughter of predeceased wife is not entitled to any share in the property.  [Para 5,9]

heading: Coparcener
Meaning of
HeadNote.description: Coparcener - Meaning of - Only a person who would derive an interest by virtue of his/her birth in a family would become a coparcener - A coparcener being a much narrower body than Hindu joint family - In HUF only sons (vertically) and brothers (laterally) would constitute a coparcenary in joint Hindu family - Their wives may be members of joint Hindu family but not coparcener. (Paras 8, 11)

heading: Death of husband in 1953
HeadNote.description:
Death of husband in 1953 - Leaving behind widow and two unmarried daughters - Limited interest of widow ripening into full ownership after coming into force of S.14(1) - Sale deed executed by her cannot be questioned by her two daughters - They could not claim limited ownership in said properties on basis of their right to receive maintenance from the properties left by father.

2003(1) ALL MR 398 (S.C.), AIR 2000 SC 1908 Rel. on.	 [Para 13,15]

heading: Property acquired by a female Hindu
HeadNote.description:
Property acquired by a female Hindu - By a will, gift, giving her only a 'life interest', would remain the same even after commencement of the Act - Such Hindu female cannot acquire absolute title.

If a Hindu female has been given only a "life interest", through Will or gift or any other document referred to in Section 14 of the Act 1956, the said rights would not stand crystallised into the absolute ownership as interpreting the provisions to the effect that she would acquire absolute ownership/title into the property by virtue of the provisions of Section 14(1) of the Act 1956, the provisions of Sections 14(2) and 30 of the Act 1956 would become otios.

Section 14(2) carves out an exception to rule provided in sub-section (1) thereof, which clearly provides that if a property has been acquired by a Hindu female by a Will or gift, giving her only a "life interest", it would remain the same even after commencement of the Act 1956, and such a Hindu female cannot acquire absolute title.

AIR 1971 SC 745 Rel. on.

AIR 1976 SC 794, (2012) 2 SCC 628, AIR 2006 SC 3282 Ref. to. 		     [Para 13]

heading: Gift by Hindu widow
HeadNote.description:
Gift by Hindu widow - Widow having life interest in house in lieu of her right to maintenance - Gift deed executed by her of house in favour of daughter would be a valid gift.

Sub-section (1) of S. 14 applies to the cases where the conferment of right to a Hindu widow was in lieu of maintenance or in recognition of her pre-existing right as provided under the Shastric law and Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act. Sub-section (2) of Section 14 of the Act would apply only to such cases where grant conferred a fresh right or title for the first time and while conferring the said right certain restrictions were placed by the grant or transfer.  [Para 7]

In the present case, the widow was conferred the limited right in lieu of maintenance in recognition of her pre-existing right. The limited interest conferred upon her by virtue of the Will being in lieu of maintenance and in recognition of her pre-existing right, the said right transformed into an absolute right by virtue of Section 14(1) of the Act. The said right was not conferred on her for the first time. Thus sub-section (2) of Section 14 of the Act has no application to the present case. Under such circumstances, the widow became the absolute owner of House No. 27 and was fully competent to execute the Gift Deed in favour of her daughter. The Gift Deed executed by the widow was thus valid.  [Para 8]

heading: Notional partition
HeadNote.description:
Death of coparcener after commencement of Act - Notional partition - Joint family status does not come to an end.

AIR  1978  SC  1239 Followed. (Para 4)

heading: Widow's estate
HeadNote.description: Widow's estate - Remarriage by widow admitted - She forfeits her right over property on remarriage - Sale of property by her is invalid.	(Para 4)

heading: Right of illegitimate child
HeadNote.description: Right of illegitimate child - An illegitimate child is entitled to the estate of father only if marriage of parents was null and void u/S.11 of HM Act - If there is no marriage, even if it is proved that child is born out of relationship between a male and a female Hindu, the child is not entitled to legal heirship with respect to the property of father. 2007 (3) KLT 270, 2016 (2) KLT 81 Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Joint family property
Disting. (Paras 14,15,16)
HeadNote.description:
Joint family property - Right of widow in - Under a compromise deed widow in possession of land for limited purpose of maintenance - Deed merely recognized already existing right to maintenance of widow - On coming into force of S.14(1) widow became absolute owner of land without any restrictions - Alienation of property by widow - Not improper.

AIR 1977 SC 1944, 1999(1) SCC 292 - Rel on.

AIR 1970 SC 1099, 1994 Mh.L.J. 1025 - Disting. (Paras 14,15,16)

heading: Partition between F and his brother's wife J
HeadNote.description:
Partition between F and his brother's wife J - J already residing in 1/3 portion of house - Her right recognised by partition - She becomes full owner of that part under S.14(1).

A partition was effected in 1938 between F and his brother's wife J after coming into force of Hindu Women's Right to Property Act 1937. F and J were living together even after death of J's husband. The effect of partition deed was that J's half share in the joint property held by her husband and F was recognised and was allotted to her by effecting partition by metes and bounds and so far as the agricultural lands were concerned, they started separate cultivation and in the residential house J started living in the 1/3rd eastern portion.

Held that J had already acquired half share in the property which belonged to her deceased husband and the effect of partition deed is to give her that half share by metes and bounds and as such it is only allotment of her half share which was even upheld by the Court and, therefore, the 1/3rd eastern portion of the house was the property which J had acquired prior to coming into force of Hindu Succession Act.  [Para 5]

In the instant case the agricultural land was given to J and F not only equal in acerage but having same assessment of land revenue and the partition deed also mentioned the value of the suit house in which house of 1/3rd valuation i.e. worth Rs. 100/- was given to J for residential purpose. It is not a case in which after partition in which entire house was allotted to F, he allowed J to reside in 1/3rd portion as a licensee. J was earlier residing in 1/3rd eastern portion of the house in her own right and was in possession of it. That property became her absolute property after coming into force of Hindu Succession Act.  [Para 8]

heading: Suit land as well as two houses given to widow for her maintenance on death of her husband in 1954
HeadNote.description:
Suit land as well as two houses given to widow for her maintenance on death of her husband in 1954 - She becomes a full owner thereof and not a limited owner.

AIR 1996 SC 869 and 1999 (3) Supreme 173 Rel.on.	(Para 8)

heading: Succession
Claim to succeed
HeadNote.description: Succession - Claim to succeed - By step-son of one of deceased legal heir - Expression "son" has not been defined under Hindu succession Act - As per S.2(56) of General Clauses Act, expression "son" includes only adopted son and not step-son - Even otherwise "son" as understood in common parlance means natural son born to person after marriage - In view of S.8 r/w Schedule under Hindu Succession Act, step-son does not fall as relative specified either in class I or class II - Therefore, step-son cannot claim to defend suit as legal heir. 1968 ALLMR ONLINE 255 Disting. 			(Paras 5, 8, 9)

heading: Adoption by widow
HeadNote.description:
Adoption by widow - Cannot deprive adoptive mother of power to dispose of her separate property by transfer or Will.

An adoption of a son does not deprive the adoptive mother of the power to dispose of her separate property by transfer or by Will (See: Hindu Law by Mulla - 17th Edn. pages 447 and 449). In the present appeal, we are concerned with plaintiff's title to the suit property. The plaintiff was adopted in 1964-65. However, adoption did not divest 1st defendant of the suit property which vested in her by succession on the death of her husband. It is for this reason that the plaintiff relied on Ex.P-1 contending that the said deed was a deed of adoption-cum-settlement. Transfer of title in favour of the plaintiff had no relevance with the adoption because mere adoption did not deprive defendant No.1 of her right to dispose of her own disposable property. In the present case, the High Court had erred in holding that the recital in Ex.P.1 was sufficient to constitute transfer of the title. That Ex.P-1 itself vested the suit property on the plaintiff. As held by the lower appellate Court, Ex.P-1 has not been stamped. It does not identify the suit property. It did not contain Valuation. In the circumstances, it did not convey any right, title or interest in favour of the plaintiff. The High Court has not gone into these aspects at all. There was no valid settlement. Consequently the lower appellate Court and the trial Court were right in dismissing the suit.   [Para 6]

heading: Right of pre-emption
HeadNote.description: Right of pre-emption - Plaintiffs claiming right over suit property - Plaintiffs and defendants were legal heir of same ancestor - Suit for injunction was decreed in favour of plaintiff no.1 - Predecessor of defendants was directed to sell suit property to plaintiff no.1, if he agrees to pay market price - During life time of predecessor of defendants, plaintiff no.1 did not take any step to purchase suit property as per said decree - After death of predecessor of defendants, other plaintiffs cannot be said to be his Class-I heirs - Right u/S.22 cannot be carried forward to next generation, when for first generation, direction to sell suit property was granted - Plaintiffs cannot claim right of pre-emption against defendants. 			(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Female who got properties from her parents dying issuless
HeadNote.description:
Female who got properties from her parents dying issuless - Only heirs of her father are entitled to succeed to the properties left by her.

Sub-section (2) of Section 15 carves out an exception in case of a female dying intestate without leaving son, daughter or children of a pre-deceased son or daughter. In such a case, the rule prescribed is to find out the source from which she has inherited the property. If it is inherited from her father or mother, it would devolve as prescribed under Section 15(2)(a). If it is inherited by her from her husband or father -in-law, it would devolve upon the heirs of her husband under Section 15(2)(b). The clause enacts that in a case where the property is inherited by a female from her father or mother, it would devolve not upon the other heirs, but upon the heirs of her father. This would mean that if there is no son or daughter including the children of any predeceased son or daughter, then the property would devolve upon the heirs of her father. Result would be - if property is inherited by a female from her father or her mother, neither her husband or his heirs would get such property, but it would revert back to the heirs of her father.  							 [Para 10]

In the present case, it is not disputed that she died intestate without leaving any son or daughter or children of predeceased son or daughter. Hence, the property would devolve on the heirs of her father. It is contended that she got the property because of the compromise decree and, therefore, the property is not inherited by her from her father or mother. This submission, is without any substance. She was entitled to inherit the property of her maternal grandmother as her mother had expired. As some dispute was raised by the other heirs, a suit was filed. In that suit, heir rights were recognized and compromise decree was passed in her favour. Result is - she got the property as daughter of her mother. That means, she got the property not from her husband or father-in-law, but from her mother side. In that state of affairs, the heirs of her father, would be entitled to inherit her property in view of Section 15(2)(a) of the Act.   [Para 11]

heading: Property of female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Property of female Hindu - On date of commencement of Hindu Succession Act, female Hindu had sold her share and she was not in possession of the property - Held, she could not get any advantage from coming into force of the Act. AIR 1989 S.C. 1179 - Rel. on.	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Survivorship
Devolution of interest
HeadNote.description: Survivorship - Devolution of interest - Partition of coparcenary property - Filing of suit by wife of deceased on 10th July 1996 after death of husband on 9th December, 1993 - By survivorship interest of husband in the property devolved upon surviving members of coparcenary consisting of his two widows and two sons - Plaintiff entitled to ¼ share in the property.	(Para 12)

heading: Appeal,
HeadNote.description: Devolution of interest in co-parcenary property - Applicability of section 8 - B died in 1972 leaving behind son S and 3 daughters - Suit property partitioned, their names mutated in revenue records of 1973-74 - Appellant, son of S born in 1977, filed suit to set aside alienation by S- Trial Court held property as of joint family, S being 'Karta' could not have transferred same, except for legal necessity - Appeal Court reversed findings holding that upon B's death, S became a co-sharer - Appeal, - Held properties of B devolved upon S and his sisters, having regard to Sec.8 as also sec.19 of the Act, properties ceased to be joint family property, all heirs and LRs. of B would succeed to his interest as tenants in common, joint co-parcenary did not continue - Appeal dismissed. 2007 ALL SCR 1632 - Dist.			(Paras 3, 5, 7, 12, 13)

heading: Right of Hindu female to maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Right of Hindu female to maintenance - Hindu female's right to maintenance is not an empty formality - S.14(2) applies to instrument, decrees, awards, gifts, etc which create an independent new title in favour of the females for the first time and has no application where the instrument concerns merely seek to confirm, endorse, declare or recognize pre-existing right.

Hindu female's right to maintenance is not an empty formality. Sub section (2) of Section 14 applies to the instrument, decrees, award, gifts, etc which create an independent new title in favour of the females for the first time and has no application where the instrument concerns merely seek to confirm, endorse, declare or recognize preexisting right. Where, however, an instrument merely declares or recognize preexisting right such as claim to maintenance or partition or share to which the female is entitled. Sub section (2) of Section 14 has absolutely no application and female's interest would automatically be enlarged into absolute one by force of Section 14 (1) and the restrictions placed, if any, under the document would have to be ignored.
2011 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 1 Rel. on.  [Para 12]

heading: Possession of premises by female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Possession of premises by female Hindu - No issue framed and no evidence led to substantiate the plea that widow was occupying premises in lieu of maintenance - Section 14(1) is not attracted. 1966(2) SCR 626, 2006(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 112, 2006(8) SCC 75 - Rel. on.	(Para 22)

heading: Subsequent remarriage
HeadNote.description: Succession Act overrides provisions of Remarriage Act - Widow inheriting property of her husband on his death - Subsequent remarriage - She is not thereby divested of her property. (2000)2 SCC 139, AIR 1999 Kerala 62, AIR 1983 Patna 33 and AIR 1976 SC 2595 - Rel. on.			(Para 13)

heading: Inheritance of property
HeadNote.description: Inheritance of property - Relations of wife in a family - Married wife in a family becomes related to it wholly through her male spouce - Wife predeceased her husband - Relations of a wife in her original family would not be entitled to inherit the property that she may in turn have inherited from her husband's side. 1980 Mh.L.J. 586 - Ref. to.	(Para 16)

heading: Co-parcenary property
Succession
Disqualification
HeadNote.description: Co-parcenary property - Succession - Disqualification - Son who has murdered his father will be deemed to have pre-deceased him - He cannot be treated to have any relationship whatsover with deceased's estate - His whole stock also stands disinherited i.e. wife or son - Wife can have no better claim in the property of deceased father-in-law.			(Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Adverse possession
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.101 - Adverse possession - Burden of proof - Burden to prove ouster by adverse possession lies on defendant in given facts - Mere statement that defendant did not allow plaintiff or his mother to plough field for about 25 years, cannot lead to ouster of plaintiffs from land, because plaintiff then was a minor - Held, contention that defendant's right had perfected into title by adverse possession cannot be accepted.			(Paras 11 to 14)

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Property in dispute allotted to K pre-decessor-in-interest of plaintiffs in both suits viz. one by legal representatives of heirs of one daughter of K and another by D son of second wife of K - On death of K in 1969 i.e. after coming into force of Hindu Succession Act D cannot be held to be coparcener as second marriage by K was invalid in view of S.5 of Hindu Marriage Act - However, due to legal fiction under S.16 of Hindu Marriage Act; said illegitimate son was entitled to get 1/3 share in the property, by application of S.8 of Hindu Succession Act, alongwith other L.Rs. in second suit.			(Paras 13 to 16 & 18)

heading: Hindu female
Life interest
HeadNote.description: Hindu female - Life interest - Owner of suit land died leaving behind his widow and two daughters - During his life time he executed a gift deed in favour of his daughter 'M.', mother of plaintiff - Widow of deceased, 'K' filed suit against 'M' resulting in a compromise on 3rd August, 1945 under which a right was conceded in favour of 'K' to enjoy suit land during her life time - Defendant adopted by 'K' by a deed, who executed a gift deed in favour of defendant - Mother of plaintiff filed suit in 1959 for cancellation of gift deed and declaration that adoption was illegal - Suit decreed in 1960 and decree upheld by High Court in 1981 - 'K' adoptive mother of defendant, died in 1967 -'K' had no preexisting right of maintenance and therefore, case was covered by S.14(2) of Act and not by S.14(1) - Suit for possession of immovable property against defendant filed by appellant-plaintiff on 14-12-1982, held barred by limitation under S.65(b) of Limitation Act since widow had died on 5-9-1967 and suit for possession was not filed within 12 years of her death - Limitation Act (1963), S.65(b).	(Para 6)

heading: Suit for Specific performance of contract of sale of a house property
HeadNote.description: Suit for Specific performance of contract of sale of a house property - Agreement of sale entered into by defendant with deceased brother of plaintiff - Locus standi of plaintiff - Locus standi challenged on ground that since deceased brother had wife, surviving sister will not inherit property - High Court holding that in view of alleged remarriage of widow, plaintiff was entitled to maintain a suit for specific performance - However, factual position was clearly contrary - Held, High Court was clearly in error.	(Para 11)

heading: Notional partition
HeadNote.description:
Notional partition - Finding out undivided interest of deceased co-parcener - For the purposes of finding out undivided interest of deceased co-parcener, a notional partition has to be assumed immediately before his death and the same shall devolve upon his heirs by succession which would obviously include the surviving co-parcener who, apart from the devolution of the undivided interest of deceased upon him by succession, would also be entitled to claim his undivided interest in the co-parcenery property which he could have got in notional partition.

When a co-parcener dies leaving behind any female relative specified in Class I of the Schedule to the Act or male relative specified in that class claiming through such female relative, his undivided interest in the Mitakshara co-parcenary property would not devolve upon the surviving co-parcener, by survivorship but upon his heirs by intestate succession.

Explanation 1 to Section 6 of the Act provides a mechanism under which undivided interest of a deceased co-parcener can be ascertained and, i.e., that the interest of a Hindu Mitakshara co-parcener shall be deemed to be the share in the property that would have been allotted to him if a partition of the property had taken place immediately before his death, irrespective of whether he was entitled to claim partition or not. It means for the purposes of finding out undivided interest of a deceased co-parcener, a notional partition has to be assumed immediately before his death and the same shall devolve upon his heirs by succession which would obviously include the surviving co-parcener who, apart from the devolution of the undivided interest of the deceased upon him by succession, would also be entitled to claim his undivided interest in the co-parcenary property which he could have got in notional partition.  AIR 1978 SC 1239 - Ref. to.						 [Para 11,12]

heading: Bar under S.25
HeadNote.description: Succession to estate of deceased-husband - Bar under S.25 - Appellant-wife acquitted from charges under Ss.452, 307 r/w. 34 of I.P.C. - In view of clear acquittal, it cannot be said that appellant is a person who has committed a murder or has abetted commission of murder of deceased-husband and, therefore, disentitled or disqualified to succeed to property of deceased under provisions of S.25 of Hindu Succession Act. AIR 1977 Delhi 97 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Disposition of undivided coparcenary interest by will
HeadNote.description:
Disposition of undivided coparcenary interest by will - Right of female Hindu - Held, a female Hindu can bequeath her share or interest by executing a will.

Inspite of the restrictions on the disposition of undivided coparcenary interest by coparcener or by a widow by will under the Mitakshra School of law, in view of the drastic change brought in by Section 30 and particularly Explanation to section 30 of the Hindu Succession Act, the interest of a male Hindu in a Mitakshara coparcenary property shall be deemed to be property capable of being disposed of by a male or female within the meaning of this Section.

Sitabai got interest of her husband in the coparcenary property in 1942 as a limited estate but she became full owner of that interest in 1956 and by virtue of Section 30, she could bequeath her share or interest by executing a Will.

Even though she was not in physical possession of the property, she was presumed to be in possession of the property as a person having share in the Joint Family property and her brother-in-law Balkrishna was possessing that property as Karta of the joint family and therefore she was supposed to be in the joint possession of the property.

Taking into consideration the legal position stated above, it is clear that Sitabai was entitled to bequeath her interest or share in the joint family property by executing a Will in view of the provisions of Section 30 of the Hindu Succession Act. Whether the Will allegedly executed by her and propounded by the present appellant is a genuine or not is a different question which will be required to be looked into when the applicant will be called upon to prove the Will. However, it was wrong to reject the application to bring him on record as legal representative of deceased Sitabai in the Appeal at the threshold holding that she was not entitled to bequeath property by Will. Thus, the impugned order is clearly illegal and wrong and is liable to be set aside.  A.I.R. 1987 SC 2394 and 1993(4) SCC 392 - Ref. to.   [Para 8,10]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Succession opening earlier to amended section coming into force - Provision of amended section is not applicable. 2007 ALL SCR 1632 - Rel. on.	(Para 19)

heading: Hindu Law
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Hindu Law - Suit for administration of estate - Limitation - Property is claimed to be estate of deceased father of parties upon succession - Devolution of property is complete on date of death of father - Suit for administration of estate of deceased upon such succession has to be filed within 3 years from date of death - Suit filed after 12 years of death of father is beyond limitation. 

Case of plaintiff that he has sued only when he learnt that defendant no. 1 sought to appropriate entire suit property to himself to exclusion of other co owners , would not start period of limitation. Plaintiff must have filed suit within 3 years of death of father when cause of action to sue accrued to plaintiff upon succession. 

2013(2) ALL MR 497, AIR 1987 SC 558, AIR 1971 SC 2184, 2009(4) ALL MR 358, 2009(2) ALL MR 718 Ref. to.           [Para 31,34]

heading: Female hindu dying intestate
HeadNote.description:
Female hindu dying intestate - Property inherited from deceased's husband - Deceased's father's legal heirs i.e. her sister's sons claiming to be only existing legal heirs of deceased - Held, nothing in Ss.15 and 16 suggested that in such situation property would be escheated - Though such property should fall in hands of a person related to husband, in absence of such relatives, property would go to deceased's father's legal heirs. 
2002(1) ALL MR 270 (S.C.), 2010(1) ALL MR 453 (S.C.), 2010 ALL SCR 1582, (1994) 5 SCC 761 Disting.             (Para 6)

heading: Partition of dwelling house
HeadNote.description: Partition of dwelling house - After 9/9/2005, a female heir can seek for partition even of the dwelling house - Subsequent event arising out of the change of Law is obviously to be applied and therefore, the dwelling house is also to be partitioned as per shares of the parties.	(Para 10)

heading: Coparcenery property
HeadNote.description:
Coparcenery property - Coparcener getting share in property in partition - Subsequently son was born - Property becomes coparcenery and son gets interest in it and he becomes a coparcener.

So long, on partition an ancestral property remains in the hand of a single person, it has to be treated as a separate property and such a person shall be entitled to dispose of the coparcenary property treating it to be his separate property but if a son is subsequently born, the alienation made before the birth cannot be questioned. But, the moment a son is born, the property becomes a coparcenary property and the son would acquire interest in that and become a coparcener.

2010(1) ALL MR 490 (S.C.) Followed.

2008 ALL SCR 784 Disting       [Para 11,12]

heading: Hindu Succession after 1956 enactment
HeadNote.description:
Hindu Succession after 1956 enactment - Changes brought in pre-existing Hindu Law - In view of S.8 read with S.4 and Preamble of the Act, now if a Hindu son inherits the self-acquired property of his deceased father, it becomes his individual property and not the property of HUF.

In view of the Preamble to the Act of 1956 i.e. that to modify where necessary and to codify the law; and the Schedule indicating Class I heirs, it can be said that when a Hindu son inherits the property in the situation contemplated by S.8, he takes it as his individual property and does not hold the same in the capacity of Karta of his own undivided family. Holding otherwise would mean that though the son of a predeceased son and not the son of a son who is intended to be excluded under S. 8 to inherit, the latter would by applying the old Hindu law get a right by birth of the said property contrary to the scheme outlined in S. 8. Furthermore the Act makes it clear by S. 4 that one should look to the Act in case of doubt and not to the pre-existing Hindu law. It would be difficult to hold today the property which devolved on a Hindu under S. 8 of the Hindu Succession Act would be HUF property in his hand vis-a-vis his own son; that would amount to creating two classes among the heirs mentioned in Class I, the male heirs in whose hands it will be joint Hindu family property and vis-a-vis son and female heirs with respect to whom no such concept could be applied or contemplated. It may be mentioned that heirs in Class I of Schedule under S. 8 of the Act included widow, mother, daughter of predeceased son etc. The express words of S. 8 of The Hindu Succession Act, 1956 cannot be ignored and must prevail. The Preamble to the Act reiterates that the Act is, inter alia, to 'amend' the law. With that background the express language which excludes son's son but included son of a predeceased son cannot be ignored.	  [Para 20,22]

heading: Succession to property of deceased first wife
HeadNote.description:
Succession to property of deceased first wife - She left behind her son and husband - Property was mutated in the name of son and defendant father did not object to such mutation - Son claiming whole of the property including half share of defendant on basis of mutation entry in his favour - Held, High Court was not justified in upholding claim of plaintiff to entirety of property on basis of mutation entry because mutation entries are relevant only for purpose of collection of land revenue and do not convey or extinguish title to property. 
(1997) 7 SCC 137 Rel. on.	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Widow's remarriage
HeadNote.description:
Widow's remarriage - Widow remarrying after death of her husband in the very same year - No partition took place on death of her husband - Held, in view of her remarriage she will not get any right in the joint family property of her deceased husband and his brother. 
AIR 2000 SC 434 Rel. on. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Scope and applicability
Section 15(1), applied
Rights of parties
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability - Hindu widow dying intestate - Self acquired property of, would be her absolute property and not property which she inherited from her parents - Section 15(1), applied - It would go to heirs of her pre-deceased husband - Rights of parties - Determination of, sympathy, no factor.

'N' married to one 'D' in year 1955, became a widow within 3 months of her marriage and driven out of her matrimonial home immediately after death of her husband. It was at her parental home, that she was given education, got an employment and died intestate on 11-7-1996 leaving various bank accounts and a huge sum also in her provident fund account. Application for grant of succession certificate in terms of Section 372 of Succession Act filed by mother of deceased 'N' as also by respondents/heirs of re-deceased husband of 'N'. Admittedly all her properties were self acquired and not inherited from her parents' side. Question arising for consideration as to whether sub-section (1) of Section 15 of Hindu Succession Act or sub-section (2) thereof would be applicable.

Held, clause (a) of sub-section (2) of Section 15 providing for a non-obstante clause, however, carves out an exception viz. when the property is devolved upon the deceased from her parents' side, on her death the same would relate back to her parents' family and not to her husband's family. Similarly, in a case where she had inherited some property from her husband or from her husband's family, on her death the same would revive to her husband's family and not to her own heirs. The law is silent with regard to self-acquired property of a woman. Sub-section (1) of Section 15, however, apart from the exceptions specified in sub-section (2) thereof does not make any distinction between a self-acquired property and the property which she had inherited. It refers to a property which has vested in the deceased absolutely or which is her own. The self-acquired property of a female would be her absolute property and not the property which she had inherited from her parents. In that view of the matter, sub-section (1) of Section 15 would apply and not the sub-section (2) thereof, In such a situation, the normal rule of succession as provided for by the statute, must prevail.	 [Para 9]

It is now a well settled principle of law that sentiment or sympathy alone would not be a guiding factor in determining the rights of the parties which are otherwise clear and unambiguous.  2008(9) Scale 241, (2008)7 SCC 210, (2008)7 SCC 770 - Rel. on.							 [Para 10]

heading: Right of inheritance
HeadNote.description: Right of inheritance - Suit based on custom prevalent in kolam community of Scheduled Tribe - Evidence regarding custom not produced to decide right of inheritance - Proceedings need to be remanded for amending pleadings and to lead evidence on aspect of custom being followed in the matter of succession/inheritance. (Paras 10, 16)

heading: Widow of son
Right to property
HeadNote.description: Widow of son - Right to property - Mere right to maintenance without actual acquisition in any manner is not sufficient to attract S.14 of the Hindu Succession Act. (2004)9 SCC 302 - Rel. on.	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Female Hindu
Dying issueless
HeadNote.description: Female Hindu - Property inherited by daughter from her father - Dying issueless - Property will devolve to legal representatives of her parental family and not to husband's family.	(Para 11)

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.6-A (as amended by Hindu Succession (Karnataka Amendment) Act (1990))
heading: Suit for partition
Preliminary decree
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Preliminary decree - Unsuccessful unmarried daughter at time of preliminary decree - Can seek enhancement of her share in joint family property on basis of subsequent event i.e. her marriage after coming into force of State Amendment Act of 1990 w.e.f. 9-8-1994, when shares of parties were determined but actual partition had not taken place. AIR 1990 AP 263 - Foll.	(Paras 13, 14, 15 and 20)

heading: Mode of succession
HeadNote.description: Female Hindu dying intestate - Mode of succession - Deceased has no children - Sister of her husband entitled to succeed to property left by her, unless the later had executed any Will - Once alleged execution of Will by deceased in favour of her brother/petitioner is disbelieved, only consequence is that succession has to take place, as provided for under Section 15 of Act.	(Para 9)

heading: Succession Certificate
HeadNote.description:
Succession Certificate - In favour of widow of deceased - Widow not disqualified even if she remarries - As the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act, 1856 has been repealed, reliance placed on S.2 thereof is wholly misplaced.

It is true that section 2 of the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage Act 1856 inter alia stipulates that all rights and interests which any widow may have in her deceased husband's property by way of maintenance, or by inheritance or by virtue of any will or testamentary disposition conferring upon her, without express permission to re-marry only a limited interest in such property, with no power of alienating the same, shall upon her re-marriage cease and determine as if she had then died. This was obviously in a case where no express permission to re-marry was given. However, we find that the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act, 1856 was repealed by Parliament by enacting the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage (Repeal) Act, 1983. Therefore the reliance on section 2 of the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage Act, 1856 is wholly misplaced.

Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 inter alia stipulates that the property of a female Hindu is to be her absolute property. Section 14(1) categorically states that any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of the Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and not as a limited owner. The explanation to section 14(1) clarifies that property includes both movable and immovable property acquired by a female Hindu by inheritance or devise, or at a partition, or in lieu of maintenance or arrears of maintenance or by gift from any person, whether a relative or not, before, at or after her marriage, or by her own skill or exertion, or by purchase or by prescription, or in any other manner whatsoever etc. Provision in Hindu Succession Act, 1956 in pari materia with section 2 of the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage Act, 1856. In other words, there is no provision that disqualifies a widow of a male Hindu from inheriting from her husband if she remarries, after his death.  [Para 5,8]

heading: Right to property
HeadNote.description: Right to property - Gift deed executed prior to enforcement of Act in favour of minor son - Wife was to act as caretaker of property on behalf of minor while enjoying a life estate for herself - No intention that income from property was in lieu of maintenance to her - Held her rights came to be governed by S.14(2) and they did not blossom into absolute estate under S.14(1). AIR 1977 SC 1944 - Rel.on.	(Para 19)

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Deceased leaving behind three sons and five daughters - His two wives had predeceased him - Held, all the eight heirs were class I heirs entitled to 1/8th share each in suit property. (Para 4)

heading: Preferential right to acquire property in certain cases
HeadNote.description:
Preferential right to acquire property in certain cases - Remedy to seek enforcement of the right u/s.22 - Such a right is to be exercised through a suit - An application filed at the stage of proposed transfer is not contemplated under provisions of S.22(1) of Hindu Succession Act.

An application filed at the stage of proposed transfer is not contemplated under the provisions of Section 22(1) of the Hindu Succession Act. Such a right is required to be exercised through a suit.

Section 22(1) confers upon one co-heir a preferential right to purchase the property of the other co-heirs. This right is akin to the right of preemption. The expression "one of such heirs proposed to transfer his or her interest" also include the final transfer of such interest by way of sale, gift or any other mode. The right of preemption is not obliterated after the transfer of the interest is completed through an instrument like sale deed or gift deed. There is no provision in either of the sub-clauses to take away right of the other heirs, who are not party to such transfer of interest, to acquire the interest of the heir/heirs who proposed to transfer their interest or actually transferred the same.  1982 Mh.L.J. 169 and AIR 1986 Orissa 119 - Ref. to.   [Para 9,11]

heading: Inheritance
S.14(2) would apply
HeadNote.description: Right of limited estate - Inheritance - Under a compromise decree, deceased defendant was given limited right to possess a share in suit property during his lifetime without any right to sell or mortgage it - After his death, his widow would possess the same - After death of widow, property would revert back to plaintiffs - Neither defendant nor his widow had any pre-existing right in suit property - Their rights flowed only from compromise decree - S.14(1) does not recognize pre-existing right of a male Hindu - Widow of defendant could not have obtained a better title than her husband - As she did not hold suit property in lieu of maintenance, no question of it being enlarged into full ownership by virtue of Sec.14(1) - S.14(2) would apply - Heirs of defendant not entitled to any share.  (Paras 12, 14)

heading: Re-marriage of widowed mother
HeadNote.description: Re-marriage of widowed mother - Succession rights in son's property, whether lost - Re-marriage took place in 1952 - Son from first husband died intestate in 1972 - By virtue of S.8 of Hindu Succession Act, mother would inherit the property excluding other heirs (brothers herein) - She continues to be mother even after re-marriage - S.2 of Hindu Widow's Re-marriage Act, depriving mother of succession rights on re-marriage, shall not govern or regulate any future succession to which she may be entitled - Even assuming there is some inconsistency between S.8 of Succession Act and S.2 of Re-marriage Act, provisions of Hindu Succession Act would have overriding effect in view of its S.4 - Succession rights of mother, not lost. (1976) 4 SCC 674 Rel. on. 	(Paras 11, 12, 13, 15)

heading: Testamentary suit
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Testamentary suit - Maintainability - Property of female Hindu dying intestate - Plaintiffs claimed to be sole legal heirs from maternal side of deceased as per S.8 r.w.S.9 of Hindu Succession Act - However, in family tree they themselves admitted applicants as legal heirs of deceased from paternal side as per S.15 - Since deceased is female, S.15 is applicable and not S.8 - By dishonest drafting, plaintiffs have created illusion to get out fact that if they had stated S.15 was applicable then they would have been out and they will have no case - Plaintiff's knowingly made false statement in plaint - Hence, suit held not maintainable, dismissed with costs. (1998) 2SCC 70, 2016 ALL SCR 370, 2014 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 129, (2010) 4 SCC 728, (2010) 2 SCC 114 Ref. to. 			(Paras 11, 12, 16, 17, 19)

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.6 (As amended by Maharashtra Amendment Act 1994)
heading: Partition suit
By married daughter
HeadNote.description: Partition suit - By married daughter - Challenge to disposition of share received in partition by father between two sons only, by will - Nature of property before partition is coparcenary - Partition took place in 1978 and in 1990 father bequeathed his share and died in 1991 - Enjoyment of bequeathed share by two sons never been questioned by third son - On partition, property ceased to be coparcenary and became separate property of father and thus, he had absolute right to deal with same - No case that any male member born after 1978 in order to lay claim to any share in property - Disposition of suit property amongst coparceners had taken place before Amendment to Hindu Succession Act in 1994 - Even assuming that amendment to S.6 of Hindu Succession Act is retroactive, intention of legislature is clear that disposition of properties made before 20th December, 2004, would remain unaffected - Hence, suit dismissed. 2013(4) ALL MR 972 (S.C.), 1996 (2) Bom.C.R. 183 Disting. 	(Para 13)

heading: Right of inheritance
HeadNote.description: Right of inheritance - Entitlement of a Hindu converted to Muslim - Right of inheritance is not choice but it is by birth and in some case, is acquired by marriage - Renouncing particular religion and to get converted is matter of choice and cannot cease relationships which are established and exist by birth - S.26 of Hindu Succession Act also disqualifies convert's descendants, but, no mention about disqualification of converts himself or herself - Therefore, Hindu convert is entitled to his/her father's property, if father died intestate.  (2007) 5 ALD 140 Disting. CDJ 2012 MHC 2346, (1972) 2 SCC 350, AIR 1976 Calcutta 272 Ref. to. 			(Paras 14, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Right of daughter
To ancestral property
HeadNote.description: Right of daughter - To ancestral property - As per amended provision daughter of co-parcener acquires right to co-parcenary property by birth - Aspect of daughter being married prior to 1994 is not relevant - Daughter entitled to share in ancestral property.  2018 ALL SCR 689 Rel.on. 			(Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Testamentary suit
HeadNote.description: Testamentary suit - Refusal of permission to defend - On ground that appellant has incurred disqualification u/S.25 of Hindu Succession Act, as she was convicted for offence of murder by criminal court - However, judgment of Criminal Court has no independent impact upon Civil Court and it has to independently decide issue as to whether appellant had committed murder - But Civil Court has not decided said issue - Further, court failed to consider that said issue was expressly raised by appellant in suit for administration of estate and which is yet to be decided in said suit - Appellant cannot be said to have incurred disqualification u/S.25 till said issue is decided - Order refusing permission to defend testamentary suit liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 10, 12, 13, 15)

heading: Ownership right of widow
HeadNote.description: Ownership right of widow - Suit property was held by widow for purpose of maintenance - Further, property was recorded in name of widow and she was in possession of it when Succession Act came into force - Nothing on record to show that she was dispossessed at any point of time - Widow acquired full ownership right over suit property. 	(Paras 4, 5, 6)

heading: Succession to property of Hindu male
HeadNote.description: Succession to property of Hindu male - Claim for on basis of tradition or usage - Petitioner claiming right over property of deceased mahant on ground that he was disciple of deceased-Sanyasi and on his death he was made Gaddinashin following customs and practices of sect - No evidence to show that deceased was Sanyasi - Further, petitioner failed to prove any tradition or practice on basis of which he claimed to have succeeded deceased - Also ration card produced by petitioner to prove that he was heir of deceased contained material omissions - Petitioner failed to prove his status as heir of deceased - Not entitled to property of deceased. 	(Paras 4, 5, 8)

heading: Right of widow
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Right of widow - To execute sale deed of her property - Widow-mother was granted life interest in property by way of Will - Property was received by widow in recognition of pre-existing right of maintenance - Limited right of widow in property become absolute right by virtue of S.14(1) of Hindu Succession Act - Plea of plaintiff-son that widow has no right to alienate property because as per Will after death of widow he along with his brother will become owner of property - Not tenable - Widow has right to execute sale deed of property. 2016(1) ALL MR 434 (S.C.) Ref. to.  (Paras 9, 13, 15)

heading: Testamentary succession
HeadNote.description: Testamentary succession - Claim for independent share in joint family property as member of family - Testator-Hindu male bequeathed his undivided share in joint family properties by Will - Independent share cannot be claimed in joint family properties as member of family. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Female Hindu - Hindu woman having pre-existing right of maintenance in suit property - Women receiving possession of suit property in lieu thereof, held, would be absolute owner of the suit property in view of provisions of S.14(1) of the Act. 2003(1) ALL MR 398 (S.C.) and 2006(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 112 - Ref. to.	(Paras 13, 21)

heading: Right of widow
HeadNote.description:
Right of widow - Widow granted life interest in property by way of a will in lieu of her maintenance - Her limited right becomes absolute right to suit property by virtue of S.14(1).

Under the Hindu Law, the husband has got a personal obligation to maintain his wife and if he is possessed of properties then his wife is entitled to a right to be maintained out of such properties. It is equally well settled that the claim of Hindu widow to be maintained is not a mere formality which is to be exercised as a matter of concession, grace or gratis but is a valuable, spiritual and moral right. From the judicial pronouncement, the right of a widow to be maintained, although does not create a charge on the property of her husband but certainly the widow can enforce her right by moving the Court and for passing a decree for maintenance by creating a charge.

In this case the original owner of the property, realized the fact that his wife 'V' was issueless and she has a pre-existing right to be maintained out of his property. He further realized that physically he was weak and may not survive for long period. He therefore, decided to give his properties to his family members. For the maintenance of his third wife 'V', he gave the tiled house with site and compound wall with the stipulation that she shall enjoy the property for life in lieu of maintenance. She will also be entitled to fetch water from the well and use other facilities. Admittedly, no one disputed the arrangements made in the Will and 'V' continued to enjoy the said property. In view of the admitted position, held that by virtue of S.14(1) of the Act, her limited right became absolute right to the suit property.  [Para 15,32]

heading: Right of petitioners to inherit disputed property
HeadNote.description: Right of petitioners to inherit disputed property - Writ petition filed under Arts.226 & 227 challenging order of Additional Commissioner holding that petitioners are not the L.Rs. of deceased - Petition based only on the proposition laid down in Purushottam's case reported in AIR 1976 Bom 375 and no other serious contentions raised - Decision in Purshottam's case expressly overruled in Waman's case reported in 1984 Mh.L.J. 1 - Hence, held, this petition cannot succeed - Petition dismissed. 1984 Mh.L.J. 1 - Rel. on. AIR 1976 Bom 375 - Overruled by 1984 Mh.L.J. 1.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Death of son
HeadNote.description: Enlargement of estate of female Hindu - Deed of maintenance executed in favour of son of Mistress/concubine and his wife - Death of son - His wife by virtue of S.14(1) acquires absolute right over lands in respect of which she was given right of enjoyment and she become full owner thereof - Hence sale deeds executed by her were legal and Courts below did not commit any error by declining to nullify the same.	(Para 16)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration of rights in ancestral property - Filed by sister of defendant - Decree of first Appellate Court in favour of plaintiff - Second appeal - Plaintiff and defendant's father died in 1944 - Their mother became absolute owner of the property by virtue of S.14 of Hindu Succession Act, though her interest shall be limited interest as Hindu woman's estate by virtue of sub-section (2) of S.3 of Hindu Women's Right to Property Act - Mother died after 1956 - Therefore, her interest in property would devolve as per the scheme in terms of S.15 of Hindu Succession Act - Property would devolve upon her son and daughter - Thus, plaintiff will have right in suit property - No substantial question of law in second appeal - Second appeal dismissed. 	(Paras 4, 10, 12, 13, 14, 16)

heading: Widow's estate
HeadNote.description:
Widow's estate - Widow inheriting estate of her husband before coming into force of Act 1956 - She can subsequently sell said property for consideration.

In the present case the widow inherited the estate of her husband on his death in the year 1954. She had undivided shares in Chak Nani and Chak Kaljer. By a family arrangement, said widow had relinquished her share in Chak Kaljer and instead, she took the share of her brothers-in-law Kharia and Delu in Chak Nani. Thus, said widow and her daughter became full owner of the Chak Nani and consequently had full right to dispose of the said property at Chak Nani. They had sold the property (at Chak Nani) to the appellant herein. The property was sold for consideration and in good faith. In the aforesaid circumstances it is not necessary to examine the applicability of Sections 14(1) and 14(2) of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956.  R.S.A. No.75 of 1993, Dt.26-7-2000 (H.P.) Reserved.   [Para 16,17,18]

heading: Property possessed by female Hindu
HeadNote.description:
Property possessed by female Hindu - Female Hindu in possession of ancestral property after death of her husband in 1939 - Held, property possessed by female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of Hindu Succession Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and not as a limited owner.

The property possessed by a female Hindu would include both movable and immovable property acquired by a female Hindu in lieu of arrears of maintenance.  In the present case it is not disputed that Chinnu died some time in the year 1939 leaving behind him widow Premabai who continued to be in possession of the suit property, as a limited owner. She had a limited interest in the property on account of maintenance, it would follow that she continued to be in possession of the said property, even after coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 and therefore, it is obvious that she became exclusive owner of the suit property by virtue of explanation to Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956.	 [Para 11]

The plaintiff's contention that she was only a licensee of the property is required to be rejected because after the death of Chinnu in the year 1939, Premabai would be entitled to the right of maintenance in the said property by virtue of provisions of Hindu Women's Right to Property Act, 1937 (Act No.XVIII of 1937).  Hindu woman's estate recognized a woman's pre-existing Hindu law right to claim maintenance and the legislature did not intend to create a new kind of interest in her favour nor intended to make her to become a coparcener, though her interest in the family property is to be the same as that of her deceased husband, except that it becomes the estate of the widow.  Thus any property possessed by the female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of the Hindu.  Succession Act, 1956, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and not as a limited owner, and as per the explanation enacted to Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, the property includes both moveable and immovable properties acquired by the female Hindu in lieu of arrears of maintenance.  The wording in the explanation "and also any such right held by her as stridhana immediately before the commencement of this Act", would indicate that Premabai came into possession of the suit property after the death of her husband Chinnu in the year 1939, and therefore, she would become exclusive owner after coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 because the Hindu Woman's estate recognize a woman's pre-existing Hindu law right to claim maintenance and the legislature did not intend to create a new ground of interest in her favour nor intended to make her to become the coparcener, though her interest in the family property is to be the same, as that of her deceased husband, except that it becomes the estate of the widow. AIR 1991 SC 1581 - Followed.   [Para 13]

heading: Property of female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Property of female Hindu - Property given to wife by deceased husband in his Will made after 1956 - No indication that it was given to her in view of her right of maintenance - Held she received only a limited right, namely, life interest in the suit property.			(Para 18)

heading: Joint Family and Joint Family property
HeadNote.description:
Joint Family and Joint Family property - No presumption that family because it is joint, possessed of joint property. 

By the amendment to the Hindu Succession Act 2005, now, the daughter of the coparcener is also a coparcener, in her own right and, in the same manner, as a son. So, after the amendment of 2005, the status of the daughters are equated with the sons. So also, there is a presumption of the Hindu Joint Family, unless a severance is proved, but such presumption is not regarding Hindu Joint Family property. There is no escape from the Joint Hindu Family. May be in one generation, it is broken it is brought to end by partition, but again in the next generation it comes into existence automatically. For example, father dies then his sons and daughters constitute a Hindu Joint Family automatically. The death of the common ancestor does not mean that the joint family will come into an end. Upper links are removed and lower ones are added and in this manner, so long as the line does not become extinct the joint family continues and can continue indefinitely, almost till perpetuity.

Further, the settled law governing Hindus that there is no presumption that a family because it is joint possessed of joint property and therefore, the person alleging the property to be joint has to establish that the family was possessed of some property with the income and which the property could have been acquired. But such a presumption is a presumption of fact which can be rebutted. But, where it is established and admitted that the family which possessed joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed sufficient nucleus from which the property in question may have been acquired, the presumption arises that it was the joint property and the burden shifts to the party alleging self-acquisition to establish affirmatively that the property was acquired without the aid of joint family. 

Character of any joint family property does not change with the severance of the status of the joint family and a joint family property continues to retain its joint family character so long as the joint family property is in existence and is not partitioned amongst the co-sharers. By a unilateral act, it is not open to any member of the joint family to convert joint family property into his personal property. 	 [Para 27,28,30,32]

heading: Question of law "whether a daughter could acquire any right, either limited or absolute, by inheritence prior to coming into force of Hindu Succession Act"
HeadNote.description: Question of law "whether a daughter could acquire any right, either limited or absolute, by inheritence prior to coming into force of Hindu Succession Act" - Single Judge of this Court in Laxman Vs. Smt. Bendrabai reported in 2005(3) Mh.L.J. 506, holding in similar set of facts that a daughter of predeceased wife of a Hindu male in Bombay presidency is entitled to a share in her father's property simultaneously with her step mother - Decision of Single Judge in the above case, not agreed with - The question of law referred to Larger Bench. 2005(3) Mh.L.J. 506 - Not agreed with. 2004 ALL MR (Cri) 2231 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	(Para 25)

heading: Applicability
Overruled..	 [Para 8]
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Hindu female acquiring property in lieu of her right of maintenance - She was, however, given only a life interest and was not allowed to alienate property - Alienation made by her in 1960 and 1961 that is after coming into force of Act in 1956 - Held, she had every right to alienate property because she was deemed to have become full owner of property by virtue of S.14(1) notwithstanding that compromise gave her only a limited interest in property. 

Section 14(1) is larger in its amplitude and every kind of acquisition of property by a female Hindu including acquisition in lieu of maintenance and where such property was possessed by her at the date of commencement of the Act or was subsequently acquired and possessed, she would become the full owner of the property. S.14(2) is more in the nature of a proviso or exception to sub-section (1) and it excepts certain kinds of acquisition of property by a Hindu female from the operation of sub-section (1) and being in the nature of an exception to a provision which is calculated to achieve a social purpose by bringing about change in  the social and economic position of women in Hindu society, it must be construed strictly so as to impinge as little as possible on the broad sweep of the ameliorative provision contained in sub-section (1). It cannot be interpreted in a manner which would rob sub-section (1) of its efficacy and deprive a Hindu female of the protection sought to be given to her by sub-section (1). The language of sub-section (2) is apparently wide to include acquisition of property by a Hindu female under an instrument or a decree or order or award where the instrument, decree, order or award prescribes a restricted estate for her in the property and this would apparently cover a case where property is given to a Hindu female at a partition or in  lieu of maintenance and the instrument, decree, order or award giving such property prescribes limited interest for her in the property. But that would virtually emasculate sub-section (1), for in that event, a large number of cases where property is given to a Hindu female at a partition or in lieu of maintenance under an instrument, order or award would be excluded from the operation of the beneficent provision enacted in sub-section (1), since in most of such cases, where property is allotted to the Hindu female  prior to the enactment of the Act, there would be a provision, in consonance with the old Shastric law then prevailing, prescribing limited interest in the property and where property is given to the Hindu female subsequent to the enactment of the Act, it would be the easiest thing for the dominant male to provide that the Hindu female shall have only a restricted interest in the property and thus make a mockery of sub-section (1). The Explanation to sub-section (1) which includes within the scope of that sub-section property acquired by a female Hindu at a partition or in lieu of maintenance would also be rendered meaningless, because there would hardly be a few cases where the instrument, decree, order or award giving property to a Hindu female at a partition or in lieu of maintenance would not contain a provision prescribing  restricted estate in the property. The social purpose of the law would be frustrated and the reformist zeal underlying the statutory provision would be chilled. That surely could never have been the intention of the Legislature in enacting sub-section (2). It is an elementary rule of construction that no provision of a statute should be construed in isolation but it should be construed with reference to the context and in the light of other provisions of the statute so as, as far as possible, to make a consistent enactment of the whole  statute. Sub-section (2) must, therefore, be read in the context of sub-section (1) so as to leave as large a scope for operation as possible to sub-section (1) and so read, it must be confined to cases where property is acquired by a female Hindu for the first time as a grant without any pre-existing right, under a gift, will, instrument, decree, order or award, the terms of which prescribe a restricted estate in the property. Where, however property is acquired by a Hindu female at a partition or in lieu of right of maintenance, it is in virtue of a pre-existing  right and such an acquisition would not be within the scope and ambit of sub-section (2), even if the instrument, decree, order or award allotting the property prescribes a restricted estate in the property.  [Para 3,4]

In the present case, the properties in question were acquired by the appellant under the compromise in lieu or satisfaction of her right of maintenance,  it is sub-section (1) and not sub-section (2) of Section 14 which would be applicable and hence the appellant must be deemed to have become full owner of the properties notwithstanding that the compromise prescribed a limited interest for her in the properties. AIR 1972 Bom. 16 Approved.  AIR 1967 Mad 429, ILR (1967)1 Mad 68, AIR 1972 Mad 279, (1968) ILR 47 Pat 1118, ILR (1968) Andh Pra 621, AIR 1975 All 151, AIR 1959 J and K 92 (FB), AIR 1970 Orissa 131 and (1976)1 SCC 574 - Overruled..	 [Para 8]

heading: Scope
Female
Hindu
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Female - Hindu - Right conferred on, as coparcener under Section 6(1) to seek partition of Joint family property, independent of and different from right to succeed under Sections 6(3) and 8 - While partition of joint family properties can be sought at any point of time, succession would open, only on death of owner of property.

Though the title of the Hindu Succession Act suggests that it deals with matters of succession, it has several ingredients, relating to coparcenary also. It may be that, one and the same individual may be entitled for the rights as a coparcener, on the one hand, and right to succeed, on the other hand. While the succession would open, only on the death of the predecessor, the right to seek partition can be exercised even while the other coparceners, including the manager of the family is alive. Sometimes it may so happen, that against the same set of persons, an individual may have rights, partly of coparcenary in nature, and partly of succession. It can certainly be said that, one and the same item of property cannot be subject-matter of partition, on the one hand, and succession, on the other hand. More often than not, these two aspects are treated as interchangeable, or different facets of the same right. This naturally would give rise to certain complications.	 [Para 17]

Sections 6(3) and 8 of the Act deal with succession to the property, by a Hindu, who is governed by the Mitakshara Law. The succession provided for, under those provisions, has nothing to do with the right to seek partition.	 [Para 18]

The recent amendment to Section 6 of the Act has virtually obliterated the distinction between male and female members of a joint Hindu family, as regards conferment of coparcenary rights. The result is that wherever it is competent for a Hindu male, to exercise rights of coparcener, including the one, of seeking partition, it is equally competent for a Hindu female of the same degree, to exercise such rights. In view of this development, the right of the respondent, to seek partition of the joint family properties; cannot be denied. If at all she has to wait for the opening of succession, it is only in respect of the properties, that are exclusively owned by the appellants, and which are not part of joint family properties. Her right to seek partition of joint family properties is absolute, and not subjected to any riders.						 [Para 19]

The result of this discussion is that, the right to seek partition of the joint family properties conferred upon the respondent under Section 6(1) of the Act, and it is independent of, and different from, the right to succeed under Sections 6(3) and 8 of the Act. While the partition of the joint family properties can be sought at any point of time, the succession would open, only on the death of the owner of the property.   [Para 22]

heading: Hindu female
HeadNote.description: Hindu female - Right of, to seek partition of joint family properties as a coparcener, absolute, and not subjected to any riders - Change of religion by her, would have no adverse effect upon her right as a coparcener - Section 26 imposes disqualification, in event of conversion, in a limited way, that too, upon offspring of convert, and not upon herself/himself. 			(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Ancestral property
HeadNote.description: Ancestral property - 'R'-a Hindu inherited self acquired property from his predecessor - It becomes his own self acquired property and it cannot be treated as ancestral property - Son of 'R' would not acquire any right in said property by birth. 	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Applicability of S.14(1)
Joint family property
Partition of
HeadNote.description: Applicability of S.14(1) - Joint family property - Partition of - Mother getting share in said property as of right - Mother would become full owner of same by virtue of S.14(1) - She therefore would have every right to dispose of suit property according to her Will.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Suit for possession
Joint family property
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Joint family property - Plaintiff claiming his right by virtue of partition deed whereas defendant claiming ownership over suit property by virtue of gift deed - Property in question was partitioned twice among three brothers and mother - In subsequent partition mother clearly made disposition of property in favour of plaintiff - Said document was signed by mother and attested by two attesting witnesses - Defendant himself admitted that mother had made disposition in favour of plaintiff - Under circumstances treating partition deed as last will of deceased mother - Proper and it could not be said that deceased mother died intestate.	(Para 11)

heading: Female Hindu
HeadNote.description: Female Hindu - Limited and absolute ownership - Widow succeeded to the property of her husband after his death in 1909 - After 1956 the limited ownership transformed into full ownership - In view of the Will executed by the widow in favour of her only daughter, the plaintiff became the absolute owner of the suit property - Plaintiff is entitled to the declaration to that effect and is also entitled to the possession thereof.	(Para 24)

heading: Coparcenary property
HeadNote.description: Coparcenary property - Claim of daughter for share in property of father after his death - Sons claiming that mother and daughter after death of father jointly executed registered release deed relinquishing their rights in property in favour of sons - Mother had executed release deed on behalf of daughter as she was minor at that time - Daughter claiming that mother had no right to relinquish her share - Mother acted as natural guardian of minor daughter and no steps taken by daughter on attaining majority to get release deed set aside within period of limitation of 3 years - Release deed is not void - Daughter not entitled to relief claimed. 	(Paras 14, 15, 18, 19)

heading: Coparcenary property
HeadNote.description: Coparcenary property - Devolution of property of deceased member - As per S.6 of Hindu Succession Act, interest of male Hindu in coparcenary property shall devolve by survivorship upon surviving members of coparcenary - But if deceased leaves behind female heir specified in Class-I of Schedule, interest of deceased devolve either by testamentary or by intestate succession - As per first explanation to S.6, interest of Hindu coparcener shall be deemed to be his share in property which would have been allotted to him if partition had taken place immediately before his death - However, when no partition taken place and there were Class-I female heirs, property would devolve on Class-I legal heirs in accordance with S.8. 	(Para 10)

heading: Dwelling house
Partition
Suit decreed
Second Appeal
HeadNote.description: Dwelling house - Partition - In 1918 suit house purchased by plaintiff-widow's father-in-law who died in 1928 - Plaintiff stayed in suit house along with her husband and his brother - Husband died in 1946 - Suit by widow for partition of suit house and possession of half share therein - Widow claiming it as joint property of husband and his brother - Suit decreed - Decree modified by Appellate Court - Possession and partition of rented portion of suit house granted while denying claim in portion of suit house in which member of joint family resided due to section 23 of the Act - Second Appeal - Held, S.23 does not apply to the suit filed by plaintiff-widow as she did not fall in Class I heirs.	(Para 4)

heading: Retrospective applicability
HeadNote.description: Application of special provisions - Retrospective applicability - In 1918 suit house purchased by plaintiff-widow's father in law who died in 1928 - Plaintiff's husband died in 1946 - Suit by widow for partition against brother of husband - Held, plaintiff's right to suit house governed by section 3 - Plaintiff stayed in suit house along with husband and his brother and by then Hindu Succession Act was in force - There was no question of retrospective applicability of Hindu Succession Act to her claim.	(Para 6)

heading: Right of maintenance claimed by third wife
HeadNote.description: Right of maintenance claimed by third wife - Marriage with three wives not challenged as illegal - All three wives can be accepted as legal wives and claim of third wife for maintenance is valid.	(Para 3)

heading: Widow's estate
