It appears from the provisions of the Maharashtra Civil Services (Conduct) Rules that the marriage during the life time of a spouse could be accepted only if the marriage is permissible under the personal law applicable to both the parties to the marriage. For example, Rule 116 (6) (a) (i) could be made applicable to more than one Mohmedan widows or also to more than one Hindu widows where the marriage between the Hindu male Government servant and the women (widows) was performed before the coming into force of the Hindu Marriage Act on 18.5.1955. Pension is liable to be paid to the widows in equal shares under Sub Rule (6) (a) (i) of Rule 116 of the Rules only where the family pension is payable to more widows than one. The said Rule was framed with an intention to provide pension to more widows than one, in the cases akin to the aforesaid categories of cases only. 

	Family pension cannot be made payable to more than one Hindu widows in equal shares, if the marriage between the male Hindu Government servant and the woman (widow) was performed after the coming into force of the Hindu Marriage Act. The object of Sub Rule 6 (a) (i) is to provide family pension to more widows than one only in certain contingencies and a woman contracting a marriage with a man during the life time of his wife would not be entitled to family pension, unless such marriage is permissible under the personal law applicable to such person and also the other party to the marriage. In view of the provisions of various Laws, pension is payable to the issues or children born from the illegal or void marriages but pension is not payable, at least under the Maharashtra Civil Services (Pension) Rules to a woman whose marriage with the Government servant is void ab initio. Some weightage would also be required to be given to the word "widows" as expressed in Rule 116 (6) (a) (i) of the Maharashtra Civil Services (Pension) Rules, 1982. According to the Black's Law Dictionary, a widow would be a woman whose husband has died and who has not remarried. As per the Oxford English Dictionary, the widow would be a woman who has lost her husband by death and has not married again. It appears from the dictionary meaning of the word "widow" that a widow would be a woman who is married and has lost her husband. As the marriage between a Hindu male Government servant during the life time of his wife is void, the marriage between the said Government servant and the second wife would not be a marriage in the eye of law. The woman performing the so called 'marriage' with a Hindu Government servant during the life time of his wife cannot be said to be his widow. Rule 116 (6) (a) (i) of the Rules makes the pension payable only to widows and a woman claiming to have married a Hindu man during the life time of his wife cannot be said to be either his wife or his widow. On a reading of the provisions of the Maharashtra Civil Services (Pension) Rules, the Maharashtra Civil Services (Conduct) Rules, the Maharashtra Civil Services (General Conditions of Services) Rules as also the provisions of the Hindu Marriage Act and Hindu Succession Act, it appears that Rule 116 (6) (a) (i) of the Maharashtra Civil Services (Pension) Rules, 1982 does not provide pension to a woman who marries a Hindu male Government servant during the subsistence of his marriage with his wife and during her life time. Even according to the Hindu Succession Act, a woman like the petitioner does not fall within the ambit of the term 'heir' and is not entitled to inherit the property of a Hindu male dying intestate, though the issues born to the said woman from a void wedlock would be entitled to inherit the personal property of the Hindu male dying intestate. 

2000(4) ALL MR 237 (S.C.), 2008 ALL SCR 1211 Foll. 	 [Para 7]

heading: Family pension
HeadNote.description: Family pension - Refusal on ground that claimant widow married to deceased-employee during life time of his first wife - Such marriage is null and void under provisions of Hindu Marriage Act - Marriage by Govt. employee during life time of spouse is treated as misconduct under Service Rules unless such marriage is permissible under personal law applicable to employee - Intent and purpose of statutory scheme is to discourage such marriage by Govt. employees - Therefore, woman whose marriage to male Hindu Govt. employee is void, not entitled to pension. 2016(7) ALL MR 5, 2015(5) ALL MR 584 Rel. on. 	(Para 19)

heading: Maintenance
Rejection of application
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Rejection of application - Ground that marriage of appellant-wife with respondent was nullity as it took place during pendency of appeal filed by wife against decree of dissolution of marriage with her first husband - S.15 permits second marriage after dissolution of marriage if there is no right of appeal against decree or even if right of appeal exists, period to file appeal is expired - Wife has filed appeal after expiry of period of limitation - Bar u/S.15 is not applicable - Marriage of wife with respondent was not void - Order rejecting application set aside.  (Paras 34, 35, 36, 39, 40)

heading: Claim of maintenance
Permissibility
HeadNote.description:
Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act (1956), S.18 - Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (2005), S.20 - Claim of maintenance - Deduction of income earned by claimant wife - Permissibility - Wife not in service during subsistence of marriage - However constrained to find a job after separation in order to make ends meet - Earning of wife in such a case can hardly be considered for determining maintenance - Normally in such a case, maintenance would be determined on the basis of husband's income only.

What is contemplated to be income in any provision for grant of interim maintenance, be that u/s.24 of Hindu Marriage Act, S.18 of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act, S.20 of protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, U/s.125 of Cr.P.C. or any other similar legislation is that the wife, of her own volition, and upon her educational or professional qualifications, pursues a settled career either by way of service or profession or business in which she derives her own independent, separate income.  Sufficiency or otherwise of such income is required to be seen and calculated to grant or reject her claim of maintenance.

However, it would be unjust and unreasonable to disallow maintenance when it is seen that she did not pursue a career during subsistence of marriage and had taken up a job only when parties separated.  A paltry income earned by wife, specially after separation or upon neglect of husband to maintain wife cannot be termed as her income.  It is only an amount received upon the constraint to serve to make ends meet.  Such amount can hardly be considered for sufficiency of income.

In normal circumstances, husband would be obliged and bound to maintain wife and maintenance would be determined based only upon income of husband.  Wife cannot be penalised for legitimate means of earning her modest and honest livelihood.  [Para 12,18]

heading: Grant of maintenance
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Grant of maintenance - Challenge - Wife filed application u/S.125 Cr.P.C - During pendency of application, husband moved petition for restitution of conjugal rights - In that petition, application filed u/S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act was allowed - Order was specific that husband shall pay financial assistance of Rs.3,000/- and litigation expenses till disposal of petition - Before passing judgment on application u/S.125, Cr.P.C., petition for restitution of conjugal rights was already decided - No bar to Court to grant maintenance u/S.125 Cr.P.C. even though financial assistance/maintenance was granted by Matrimonial Court dealing in matrimonial proceedings - Challenge, not tenable. 2000(1) ALL MR 371, 2000(3) ALL MR 216 Rel.on. 	(Para 6)

heading: Proof of offences
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss.494, 109 - Process for offences under Ss.494 or 109 IPC - Proof of offences - Complainant or after hearing of mangalastaka and slokas chanted in the presence of gathering of persons concluded that her husband was marrying another woman - She was unable to give names of persons who had gathered - Magistrate without examining whether customary rites and ceremonies were performed or not or that whether Saptapadi was a necessary ceremoney or not issued process for offences under S.494, 109 IPC - Held, order issuing process was illegal and could not be permitted to survive - Process quashed.			(Paras 5, 6, 7)

heading: Claim for maintenance
HeadNote.description: Claim for maintenance - Declined, on count that appellant was not legally wedded wife - Parties cohabited together for four years - Husband filed petition for annulment of marriage u/S.11 of H.M. Act, but failed to substantiate his case - Resultantly, petition was dismissed and attained finality - Adverse inference must be drawn against husband - Husband's case that there was no spousal relationship between parties and that wife was only caretaker is belied by his own case - As he had contacted marriage bureau and not nursing agency through whom he had come to know of appellant - Impugned order not sustainable - Wife was entitled to claim maintenance. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Maintenance under S. 125 - Adjustment against alimony granted under S. 24 - Validity - Held setting aside order of High Court that amount awarded under S. 125 (Rs. 500/- p.m.) was not over and above what was granted under S. 24 (Rs. 800/- p.m.) - Looking to claims of both spouses husband ordered to pay total sum of Rs. 1000/- p.m. from date of original order passed by Magistrate u/s. 125. (Para 6, 7)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of - Claim of maintenance by wife u/s.125 of Criminal P.C. - Husband already paying higher amount of maintenance in compliance with the order passed under S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act - Wife not entitled to claim maintenance under S.125 of Criminal P.C. in view of the order passed u/s.24 of Hindu Marriage Act. 2000 ALL MR (Cri) 372 - Followed.	(Paras 18 & 19)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Marriage annulled under S.12(1)(d) by a decree of annulment - Applicant cannot be termed as "divorced wife" - She is not entitled to maintenance - In absence of material on record to conclude that she gave birth to a child borne from opponent grant of maintenance to child was also liable to be rejected.	(Paras 10, 14, 15)

heading: Maintenance
Divorced wife
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Divorced wife - Not remarried or living in adultery - She is entitled to maintenance - Her husband was earning - Wife granted maintenance of Rs.650/- p.m. from date of order granting dissolution of marriage. (Paras 8, 10)

heading: Maintenance proceedings
Stay of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance proceedings - Stay of - Petition for dissolution of marriage filed by husband - Interim maintenance already granted by Civil Court to wife - Application of respondent wife for maintenance filed before Judicial Magistrate, held, should have been stayed in view of pendency of civil proceeding at Civil Court. 1992(1) Mah.L.R. 246 - Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Maintenance
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Enhancement of - Trial court enhanced amount of maintenance from Rs.1,000/- to Rs.5,000/- - Subsequently interim maintenance of Rs.3000/- was also granted in proceeding under S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act - During this period salary of husband increased four times - Amount of maintenance would be equivalent to four times of maintenance earlier granted which comes to Rs. 4000/- - Maintenance modified accordingly. 	(Para 7)

heading: Grant of maintenance
Challenge to legality
HeadNote.description: Grant of maintenance - Challenge to legality - Contention that amount of award was much more than 1/3 of net salary of applicant and after making necessary deduction and amount of maintenance granted, hardly anything would be left with applicant for maintaining himself and his parents - Salary slip not showing any compulsory deductions - Impugned order showing deductions by way of savings for applicant and therefore, not excluded while computing income of applicant for grant of maintenance - That apart, parents of applicant are not dependent upon him as his father is retired Police Officer and as such drawing pension - Hence, impugned order is not illegal. 	(Paras 7, 9, 10)

heading: Transfer petitions
Matrimonial dispute
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), S.25 - Transfer petitions - Matrimonial dispute - Settlement arrived at between parties - Decree of divorce by mutual consent directed to be passed in view of factual situation and settlement arrived at by parties - All the proceedings including proceeding under S.125 of Criminal P.C. shall stand quashed.	(Para 2)

heading: Bigamy
Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description:
Bigamy - Decree of divorce - Decree, as a general rule, operates from the moment it is pronounced - However, if appeal filed against Decree - Parties cannot remarry till Appeal is finally decided - Any marriage during pendency of Appeal is void.

A decree of divorce, as a general rule, operates from the moment it is pronounced.  Subject to the limitation relating to remarriage by either spouse as laid down in Section 15 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, the effect of a decree of divorce is to dissolve the marriage for all intents and purposes from the date of its pronouncement.  Admittedly the divorce petition was decreed in favour of petitioner no.1 by the trial Court on 21/12.2002; respondent no.1 preferred appeal against the said judgment and decree on 16/1/2003; respondent no.1 moved an application for stay under Order 41 Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure along with appeal; petitioner no.1 appeared in the appeal and filed her say on 21/2/2003.  She however remarried on 9/3/2003 and hence by order dated 24/3/2003 the stay application moved by respondent no.1 was disposed of.  In the appeal preferred by respondent no.1 against the decree of divorce, though no ex-parte stay was granted to the decree, petitioner no.1 had appeared in the appeal and she was fully aware of the pendency of the appeal as well as the application for stay.  Hence it was obligatory on her part to wait till the order on stay application as well as till the decision of the appeal; instead petitioner no.1 remarried on 9/3/2003 and tried to get advantage of her own wrong by submitting before the appellate court that the application for stay had become infructuous because of the remarriage.  In view of Tejinder Kaur's case the said decree had not become final and as such she was not free to remarry till the decision of the appeal.  In this situation the relationship between petitioner no.1 and respondent no.1 is deemed to have been continued as husband and wife.  As such she could not have remarried during the pendency of the appeal.  In view of this position it cannot be said that the marriage between petitioner no.1 and petitioner no.7 is merely unlawful and not void.  The marriage between petitioner no.1 and petitioner no.7 is void and as such the provisions of Section 494 of the Indian Penal Code would be attracted.  Thus the learned trial Magistrate was justified in issuing process against the petitioners.  AIR 1988 SC 839 - Rel.on.   [Para 11]

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
Validity of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Christian Marriage Act (1872), S.5 - Special Marriage Act (1954), S.4 - Foreign Marriage Act (1969) - Maintenance - Grant of - Validity of marriage - Marriage between a Christian and a Hindu performed as per Hindu rites with full consent of both parties - Cannot be said to be invalid for purposes of claiming maintenance u/S.125 Cr.P.C.

As per Section 11 of the Hindu Marriage Act, the marriages performed in contravention of Clauses (i), (iv) and of Section 5 of the Hindu Marriage Act are void, whereas under Section 12 of the said Act, for contravention of any of the conditions enumerated therein, the marriages are voidable. It is necessary to notice that neither Section 11 nor Section 12 of the said Act renders a marriage between a Hindu and a Christian void or voidable on the ground that the parties belong to two different religions. The rigour of voidness covered by Section 4 of the Indian Christian Marriage Act is stressed and attached more to the persons that officiate in the solemnisation of the marriages, and it does not envisage as regards the validity or otherwise of a marriage simpliciter that took place between a Hindu and a Christian. This view is again fortified by Section 4 of the Special Marriage Act, which permits a marriage between two persons of different faiths. Therefore, a Hindu can marry a Christian under the Special Marriage Act. Such a marriage cannot be held to be void on the ground that it was not performed according to the provisions of Section 5 of the Indian Christian Marriage Act. Similarly, Section 4 of the Foreign Marriage Act permits a marriage between parties, one of whom at least is an Indian citizen residing outside India. On a similar anology as noted supra, even a marriage under this Act, if performed between a Hindu and a Christian both or one of whom is an Indian citizen, cannot be held to be void on the ground that it is not performed in accordance with the provisions of Section 5 of the Indian Christian Marriage Act. Accordingly, in view of the above discussion, it has to be held that the marriage between a Christian and a Hindu performed as per the Hindu rites with the full consent of both parties cannot be said to be invalid for purposes of claiming maintenance u/S. 125, Cr.P.C. 1967 Ker LT 24, (1939) 40 Cri.L.J. 653, (1970) 1 SCWR 589 Ref. to.   [Para 14,15,16,17]

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of, where husband has obtained decree of restitution of conjugal rights - Held, if wife gives justifiable cause for not complying with decree of restitution, maintenance cannot be denied to her.			(Para 18)

heading: Maintenance
Factum of marriage
Proof
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Factum of marriage - Proof - Marriage between parties performed in 'Gandharva' form - 'Gandharva' form of marriage is nothing but garlanding each other without performing any rite and rituals - In view of S.7 of H.M. Act, to make marriage complete and binding, marriage has to be solemnised in accordance with customary rites and ceremonies of either parties including 'saptapadi' - No case of wife that any such custom is prevailing in their community to perform marriage - On contrary, said marriage is performed when earlier marriage of parties is subsisting - In absence of any valid marriage between parties, wife is not entitled to maintenance u/S.125. 2005 ALL MR (Cri) 1309 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Para 6)

heading: Grant of maintenance
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Grant of maintenance - Challenge - On ground that decree for restitution of conjugal rights was passed in favor of husband - Application for restitution of conjugal rights was filed by husband before eight months of filing written statement in proceeding u/S.125 - However, fact of filing of restitution of conjugal rights petition, not mentioned in written statement - Even when wife was under cross-examination she was also not confronted with said decree - Not a case that wife deliberately disobeying decree - No step taken by husband for execution of said decree - Conduct of husband shows that only for namesake he instituted proceedings u/S.9 of Hindu Marriage Act - Even no attempt made by husband to provide maintenance to his son - In view of facts it can be said that husband neglected to maintain his wife and son - Order granting maintenance proper. 2002 ALL MR (Cri) 704 Disting. 			(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Award of maintenance
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Award of maintenance - Legality - Husband's allegations that one time settlement made and they accepted divorce by mutual consent - Wife not waived her rights for maintenance from husband - Alleged consent decree presented on 10th Jan and decreed on 11th Jan, said consent decree does not bear signature or thumb impression of wife or her advocate - Such declaration of divorce or mutual divorce would be against the spirit of H.M. Act and not acceptable - Marital status between the parties cannot be said to have come to an end - Wife did not remarry after alleged divorce - She comes within the ambit of S.125 for the sake of maintenance - Furthermore so called one time settlement or divorce will not take away rights of maintenance of wife - Award of maintenance would be proper. 

1989 Cri. L.J. 211, 2003 ALL MR (Cri) 1094, 2005 ALL MR (Cri) 314, 1990 Cri L.J. 2415, 2009 ALL SCR 1804, 1996(4) ALL MR 497, 1995 (2) Mah.L.J. 740. Ref.	(Paras 9 to 12)

heading: Maintenance
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Claim for - Even after grant of permanent alimony to wife u/S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act, wife is entitled to claim maintenance before Magistrate u/S.125 of Cr.P.C.	(Paras 17, 19, 20)

heading: Maintenance
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Claim for - Even after grant of permanent alimony to wife u/S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act, wife is entitled to claim maintenance before Magistrate u/S.125 of Cr.P.C. (Paras 17, 19, 20)

headline:
Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125 – Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.25 – Grant of permanent alimony u/S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 - Whether prayer u/S.125 of Cr.P.C. 1973, for maintenance, over and above what Court granted (u/S.25 of 1955 Act), maintainable?
Answered in Negative - S.25(2)/(3) correct remedy for seeking modification in maintenance granted u/S.25 of 1955 Act - Wherein wife initially prefers application u/S.125 Cr.P.C. to sustain herself, she can avail of S.25 of 1955 Act subsequently but reverse cannot be accepted

heading: Maintenance
Effect
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Refusal by wife for DNA test in divorce proceedings - Effect - Refusal for DNA test in proceedings for divorce u/S.13 of Hindu Marriage Act cannot be taken into consideration in case u/S.125 of Cr.P.C. for drawing presumption against wife. 			(Para 22)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of - Challenge - On ground that respondent is not legally wedded wife of petitioner-husband as they were minor at time of marriage - If any Hindu marriage is solemnized between parties in contravention of requirement as to age of parties as specified in Act of 1955, it is not void or even voidable - Marriage between parties in not nullity on ground of minority of parties - Order granting maintenance, proper. (Para 21)

headline:
1) Criminal P.C. (1973), S. 125 – Maintenance – Grant of – Challenge – On ground that respondent is not legally wedded wife of petitioner-husband – Petitioner claiming that he has married to another lady and he has three children – Respondent stated that her marriage solemnized with petitioner in accordance with Hindu rites and customs – Respondent also mentioned name of priest and barber who were present at time of marriage – Evidence of witnesses also showing that respondent is legally wedded wife of petitioner and their marriage was solemnized prior to marriage of petitioner with another lady – Evidence on record is sufficient to draw inference that respondent married to petitioner – Order granting maintenance, proper. 

2) Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S. 12 – If any Hindu marriage is solemnized between parties in contravention of requirement as to age of parties as specified in Act of 1955, it is not void or even voidable.

3) Criminal P.C. (1973), S. 125 – Maintenance – Claim for enhancement – Wife claimed maintenance of Rs. 2,000/- p.m. as husband was employee of Railway – Magistrate granted maintenance to wife at rate of Rs. 40/- per day i.e. of Rs. 1,200/- p.m. – Rs. 40/- per day is too meager for maintenance of human being – Amount of maintenance enhanced from Rs. 1,200/- p.m. to Rs. 2,000/- p.m.

heading: Inherent powers u/s.482
HeadNote.description: Inherent powers u/s.482 - Passing order of divorce while quashing criminal proceedings - Grievances of parties against each other are of such nature that there is no possibility of reconciliation between them, even within period of 6 months, for which they have situation keeping petition pending before Family Court for 6 months would be empty formality - Hence, decree of dissolution of marriage by mutual consent needs to be passed. 	(Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Petition for dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Petition for dissolution of marriage - By parties whose marriage had taken place in the State of J & K - Parties have option to proceed under State Act or under Central Act. 	(Para 34)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Validity
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - On ground of mental cruelty and irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Validity - Husband claiming that due to allegations of illegitimate relationship levelled on him by his wife and proceedings initiated u/S.107/151 of Cr.P.C. against him, he has suffered mental cruelty - Allegations of illegitimate relationship levelled by wife after 21 years of marriage due to misunderstanding between parties, required minor adjustment to reassure each other and iron out crease - Such allegations cannot be said to have inflicted mental cruelty as required u/S.13 - Also proceedings u/S.107/151 were initiated by wife to protect her right and possession of property - Such action taken in accordance with law cannot be considered as inflicting cruelty - Further, irretrievable breakdown of marriage by itself is not ground provided under statute for dissolution of marriage - Order of dissolution of marriage on ground of mental cruelty, improper. 		(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
Ex-parte decree
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ex-parte decree - Appeal against - Husband obtained said decree by mentioning wrong address of wife and preventing her from participating in divorce proceedings - Husband not present before appellate court - His counsel also not able to contact him - Legitimate rights of wife, defeated - Impugned decree liable to be set aside. 			(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Jurisdiction of Court
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Court - Suit for divorce by husband in Foreign Country under English personal law - Application for Anti suit injunction by wife - S.1(2) should be r/w. S.19 which provides jurisdiction of Court where petition under Act shall be presented - Marriage between parties solemnized, registered in Mumbai, under Hindu Marriage Act - Merely because husband having domiciled of U.K., whether by birth or by choice or otherwise - Would be of no significance and would not divest jurisdiction of Court provided u/S.19 for purpose of filing of proceeding under Hindu Marriage Act - Wife, held, entitled to anti suit injunction against said suit filed by husband - Appropriate forum (Forum Convenient) for wife would be Court in India i.e. Court within whose jurisdiction parties married under the Act and maintenance not paid to wife by husband - Even otherwise, husband had created such a situation for wife that she cannot defend proceedings filed by husband as husband after marriage forced her to return to India with assistance of police and also cancelled her sponsorship. (Paras 38, 43, 45, 44, 47, 50, 52)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grant of by exercise of powers u/Art.142 - Parties engaged in multifarious litigation including divorce proceeding for almost two decades - Stay of parties was only for about two months after marriage - Wife then left for Canada and also obtained Canadian Citizenship - Wife claiming that she had travelled to Canada as husband wanted immigration to Canada - However, she admitted that she had not taken any documents of husband with her - Relationship appears to have deteriorated to such an extent that both parties see little good in each other - Though wife insists that she wants to live with husband, mere say of such willingness would not suffice - This is only to frustrate efforts of husband to get decree of divorce - Continuity of marriage is fruitless and causing emotional trauma and disturbance to both parties - Hence, decree of divorce granted. (Paras 6, 13, 20, 21, 24)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Wife has filed criminal cases against husband and his relatives - She admitted in her statement that she doesn't want to live with husband - She refused to wear 'sakha and sindoor' which signifies her refusal to accept her marriage with husband - Under such circumstances, compelling husband to continue to be in matrimony with wife may be construed as harassment inflicted upon him by wife - Further, criminal case against husband u/S.498A was dismissed as not pursued by wife - Such acts of lodging criminal cases on unsubstantiated allegations against husband or his relatives amount to cruelty - Also wife compelled and prevented husband from performing his statutory duties towards his aged mother under provisions of Act of 2007 - Such act can be construed as cruelty, as non-compliance of provisions of Act of 2007 has criminal consequences leading to punishment of imprisonment as well as fine - Husband entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Paras 15, 20, 22)

heading: Grant of divorce
Ground
HeadNote.description: Grant of divorce - Ground - That parties have already obtained customary divorce through Panchayat - Cannot be a ground for divorce - Filing petition under S.13 itself means that both parties were of the view that divorce granted by Panchayat was not legal.			(Para 3)

headline:
Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 Ss.5,7,11 - Evidence Act, 1872 - S.102 - Whether marriage of Plaintiff (Respondent) legally valid and thereofore plaintiff entitled to claim in D1's ancestral property (HUF)? 
Plaintiff (Respondent) not entitled to succeed only on the basis of alleged registration of an agreement of marriage (Ex.P/1, not certificate of marriage u/Special Marriage Act, 1954), in absence of proof of solemnization of rites/ceremonies u/S.7(2) of 1955 Act, or pleading of custom permitting marriage within prohibited degree u/S.5(v) of 1955 Act - Failure of Plaintiff (Respondent) to prove her marriage, means she has no valid claim to share in entitlement to estate of D1 - Appeal allowed

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - On ground that plaintiff has married her uncle i.e. deceased son of defendant - Plea of plaintiff that in her community such marriage can be performed, cannot be accepted - As no judicial precedent or proof of custom of such marriage was brought on record by plaintiff - Plaintiff failed to prove custom of marriage to her uncle - Plaintiff’s claim that she has married her uncle was based on agreement of marriage - However, in said agreement also there was no proof of solemnization of marriage between plaintiff and her uncle by customary ceremonies and rites or in manner contemplated u/S.7 of Hindu Marriage Act - Plaintiff failed to prove her marriage - Plaintiff cannot succeed to estate of her uncle - Plaintiff not entitled to decree of partition. 			(Paras 14, 15, 17, 18)

headline:
Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 – S. 24 – Maintenance – Grant of -- Effective date -- Petitioner -wife claiming the maintenance from date of application - Validity
Not case of petitioner that during pendency of application seeking interim maintenance, she was not being taken care of by husband - Resp.-husband paying amount regularly - Considering lavish lifestyle of parties, maintenance granted by Court from date of passing of order is proper.

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
Effective date
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of - Effective date - Petitioner-wife claiming the maintenance from date of application - No case of petitioner that during pendency of application seeking interim maintenance she was not being taken care of by husband - Respondent-husband was paying the amount regularly - Thus, considering the lavish life style of the parties, maintenance granted by court from date of passing of order is proper. (Para 13)

heading: Place of trial
HeadNote.description: Proceedings for maintenance and divorce - Place of trial - In the interest of justice and in the facts and circumstances of the case, held, it would be just and proper and time and money saving, when parties are same, they are made to face the proceedings at one place, Particularly when they are required to face multiple legal Proceedings.	(Para 4)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Mental cruelty by wife - Marriage not allowed to be consummated by wife - Husband denied sexual access, subjected to abuse, locked out of his room, kicked out of the bed, his mother was abused and pushed about as also she was not performing any household work/chores - All this stood established by evidence on record - Husband in such a case cannot be expected to make his predicament public by disclosing it with his superiors and hence corroboration from independent witnesses cannot be insisted upon - Husband, held, was entitled to divorce on ground of cruelty. 2007 ALL SCR 881 - Rel. on.			(Paras 12, 15)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Wife filing complaint under Ss.498-A, 406, IPC - Husband and his family members stood convicted in the case - Allegations of wife could not be said to be totally false - Husband is not entitled to decree of divorce on ground of cruelty by wife - It is only when prosecution is held to be motivated, mala fide and false that the act of wife can be taken, to be one amounting to cruelty.			(Paras 20, 24)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - No evidence of marriage between the parties - Petition filed only to blackmail respondent and petitioner was a married person having a daughter studying in school - Trial court dismissed the petition but high court strangely enough attempting conciliation between parties without coming to any conclusion about marriage between parties and also giving certain directions - Held giving directions was wholly inappropriate.	(Para 5)

heading: Desertion
Proof
HeadNote.description: Desertion - Proof - Wife under compulsion leaving matrimonial house in October 1999 - Petition by husband filed even before completion of two years by giving notice in December 1999 for divorce and not for restitution of conjugal rights - Stand of wife consistent in trial court, lower appellate court and in High Court that she still is ready for co-habitation - Petitioner husband was ill-treating wife because he wanted to remarry and this is what he admitted in his cross-examination - Held lower appellate court was right in concluding that husband was not entitled to decree of divorce.  (Paras 15, 16, 18)

heading: Cruelty and desertion
HeadNote.description: Cruelty and desertion - Wife was earning but refused to part with her salary in favour of her husband - No evidence produced about insulting behavior of wife except stating that she used to insult him in presence of her relatives - Couple having a minor child - Held Family Court rightly dismissed marriage petition - Wife directed to take steps to obtain social security number of her husband who was now residing in Norway to enable her to receive maintenance amount directly from the employer of her husband.  (Paras 8, 9)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Husband in USA and wife in India - Both filing affidavit expressing their consent to mutual divorce - Parties can thereby be said to have waived their right to be heard - Court can on basis of affidavits decide the case.	(Para 4)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Petitioners filing affidavit to the effect that they were married as per customary law and marriage was not registered - Court cannot insist for marriage certificate as a pre-condition for entertaining petition for divorce.	(Para 13)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Petition for annulment of marriage - Limitation - Husband contended that wife had intentionally concealed about her first marriage at time of their marriage and therefore, their marriage is null and void - Wife admitted fact of her first marriage - She adduced evidence of witnesses to prove that her first marriage was dissolved by notarized document as per custom prevalent in her community - Can’t be considered as custom has to be ancient and from time immemorial - Husband stating that he came to know about first marriage of wife only when quarrel broke between them on 02-02-2013 and thereon, filed petition on 01-03-2013 - Admission of husband that his marriage with wife was performed in temple in form of "Shiv Vivah" which generally followed in cases of second marriage of either of spouses - Testimony of two independent witnesses who were present at time of marriage that wife had given knowledge about divorce from her first husband to the husband prior to marriage - It is proved that husband was under impression that said divorce document was correct and didn’t question legality of same - Therefore, petition filed by husband is beyond period of limitation. 

2017(7) ALL MR 525, 2002(2) ALL MR 264 (S.C.), 2017(3) ALL MR 735 Ref. to. 			(Paras 14, 17, 18)

headline:
(1) Hindu Marriage Act, 1955- S.13, S.9 - Dissolution of Marriage - Petition for - By Husband - Ground of wife's alleged intemperate behaviour - Criminal complaint filed by wife, leading to acquittal of husband - Whether grant of dissolution/divorce decree to husband, based on HC taking cognizance of filing of false criminal complaint against him by his wife (of which he is acquitted), as substantial question of law, is justified, when husband has not pleaded cruelty as ground for divorce, while initiating petition for dissolution of marriage or even as an issue at Trial Court? -  Answered in Negative

HC not justified in granting a decree of dissolution of marriage/ divorce in favour of husband, by taking cognizance of false criminal complaint against him by his wife (cruelty), as a substantial question of law and arriving at its conclusion, when husband has not pleaded cruelty on account of said false complaint (of which he stands acquitted), as basis for initiating petition for dissolution of marriage, or as an issue before Trial Court by tendering evidence leading to a decision to be taken - To attain benefit of dissolution/divorce on ground of false criminal complaint/proceedings, same has to be pleaded by the husband as cruelty in his divorce petition and before the Trial Court.

(2) Hindu Marriage Act, 1955- S.13, S.9 - Dissolution of Marriage - Irretrievable break-down of marriage - Leading to dissolution of marriage/ grant of decree of divorce
Dissolution of marriage, merely because parties have been litigating and residing separately for quite some time, would not be justified in cases where restitution of conjugal rights considered simultaneously; daughter aged 13 years; both parties from conservative background.

heading: Dissolution of Marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of Marriage - Ground of cruelty by wife - In second appeal High Court granted divorce on ground that acquittal of husband from criminal complaint filed by wife, amounted to mental cruelty - But husband sought divorce before trial court on ground that behaviour of wife was intemperate, causing mental cruelty to him - Trial Court denied divorce holding that husband failed to prove his case and said finding was affirmed by first appellate court - Further, ground on which High Court granted divorce was not ground on which divorce was sought before trial court - High Court could not have granted divorce on said ground - Order of divorce, liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Divorce
Petition by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband - Husband alleging quarrelsome nature of wife and unjustified desertion on her part - Even before Court, conduct of wife was such that she was only trying to prolong litigation - Attempts of amicable settlement failed because of her persistent non-appearance - At last when she appeared, she expressed her willingness to join husband in place of his employment - However, failed to do so - Her conduct showing no intention to live with husband - It amounts to willful desertion and cruelty on her part - Husband cannot be expected to live with her - He is entitled to divorce. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Restitution of conjugal rights ordered by Court - No restitution taking place because of reluctance of husband for over one year - He cannot take advantage of his own wrong of not obeying the decree - Divorce cannot be granted.	(Paras 24, 25)

heading: Divorce
Decree passed
Effect
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Decree passed - Effect - Wife cannot continue to reside in the house of husband as of right - Husband cannot, however, evict her, except after following procedure established by law. (Para 11)

heading: Petition u/S.9
HeadNote.description: Petition u/S.9 - Wife residing at distant place because of her govt. job - Not a case that husband was unaware of her job before marriage - In facts of case, wife's living apart, would not amount to "withdrawal from society of husband" - Assuming it to be withdrawal, it is not intentional - Order u/S.9 passed in favour of husband, liable to be set aside.	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Ground of cruelty - Husband alleging that wife used to quarrel with her parents, she was reluctant to perform household duties, insisted him to live separate and used to frequently visit her parents home which caused him mental cruelty - Except bare words, no corroborative evidence placed on record by husband - Nothing could be elicited from cross-examination of wife who has denied all allegations - Allegation of termination of pregnancy by wife without consent of husband, proved to be baseless - Therefore, if in defence any general allegations are made by wife against husband, it does not amount to mental cruelty to husband - No irresponsible, false allegations made by wife against husband - Allegations made by husband against his wife were of routine wear and tear - It does not amount to cruelty to husband - Divorce petition liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 15, 16, 19, 20, 22, 24)

heading: Mental illness
HeadNote.description: Mental illness - Medical examination for ascertaining mental condition - Court has complete inherent power in an appropriate case under Section 151 to pass all orders for doing complete justice to the parties to the suit. 2003(3) ALL MR 331 (S.C.) - Foll.			(Para 3)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (2005), S.26 - Divorce petition - Petition filed by husband with a false and misleading statement to defeat the right of wife - Held, in view of false and misleading statement by husband, petition dismissed with costs quantified in sum of Rs.25,000/- to be paid by husband to wife. 2007 ALL MR (Cri) 3589 (S.C.) : 2007 ALL SCR 908 - Ref. to.		(Paras 19, 21, 22)

heading: Proof of marriage
HeadNote.description: Proof of marriage - Registration of marriage, for the purpose of facilitating the proof of Hindu marriages - From the time of the alleged marriage the parties are recognised by all persons concerned as man and wife and are so described in important documents and on important occasions - Held, there is a strong presumption in favour of validity of a marriage and the legitimacy of its offspring. 2007(6) Mh.L.J. 518 - Ref. to.			(Para 17)

heading: Order granting interim alimony and expenses of litigation to wife
HeadNote.description:
Order granting interim alimony and expenses of litigation to wife - Petitioner husband refusing to pay - Wife need not be driven to file execution proceedings - Court can in exercise of inherent powers stay proceedings for divorce for non-compliance with its order.

A Court can, in exercise of its powers under section 151 of the Civil Procedure Code, pass an order of staying the petition of divorce if it is found that the husband deliberately and contumatiously flouts the order of the Court. There is a power in the Court to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of justice and to prevent any abuse of process of the Court. The Matrimonial Court, therefore, was under duty to invoke the inherent powers under section 151 of the Civil Procedure Code and should have compelled the erring husband to deposit whole of the arrears of interim alimony and the expenses of the proceedings in the Court within certain point of time. If inspite of passing of such orders, the party under liability flouts the order deliberately, the Court can stay the petition or the proceedings of divorce if the erring party is a petitioner. Similarly, if the erring party is the respondent, the Court can strike off the defence of such a party if it is found that the respondent is deliberately flouting the orders of the Court.  [Para 9]

heading: Petition on ground of fraud
HeadNote.description: Petition on ground of fraud - Petitioner wife a Hindu and respondent husband a christian - Wife alleging that respondent had agreed to convert himself to Hinduism but not doing so and her consent on the form filed with Registrar was obtained by fraud - Held as one of the spouses was not Hindu petition was not tenable in view of S.2 of the Act. (Para 4)

heading: Application for transfer of petition under S.9
HeadNote.description: Application for transfer of petition under S.9 - Proceedings stayed and matter referred to Lok Adalat - Parties agreeing to dissolve their marriage by mutual consent - Wife accepting sum awarded in lieu of her claim of maintenance and parties agreed to file petition under S.13-B - Their application allowed and divorce granted - No need to pass any order on S.9 application.			(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Interim maintenance
Appeal by wife
Foll.			(Paras 5, 7)
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Decree of divorce in favour of husband - Appeal by wife - During pendency of appeal Court granting interim maintenance of Rs.1,000/- p.m. for maintenance and education of her two daughters - Failure of husband to pay maintenance right since 1999 when order was passed - Husband is contumacious defaulter - Appeal by wife allowed and defence of husband struck down. AIR 1996 P & H 175 and (2001) DLT 545 - Foll.			(Paras 5, 7)

heading:
Scope cannot be interpreted to mean that the court can or ought to grant a decree for judicial separation where it cannot or does not grant decree for divorce.

S.13-A cannot be interpreted to mean that the court can or ought to grant a decree for judicial separation where it cannot or does not grant decree for divorce.  If the Section is interpreted in the way as suggested, every petition may either end in a decree for divorce or judicial separation.  There would be no occasion to dismiss the petition for divorce at all.  The Legislature certainly did not intend to grant decree for judicial separation even where no ground for divorce was made out.  Therefore, the Section has to be interpreted differently.  What section envisages is that even where ground for divorce is made out, the court may refuse decree for divorce and instead grant a decree for judicial separation.  Therefore, essentially the appellant must first make out a ground for divorce and then the court may exercise its discretion to grant decree for judicial separation or a decree for divorce.  When no ground is at all made out, there could be no occasion to use the discretion.  In the instant case, the finding on issue of desertion and cruelty has gone against the appellant/petitioner and that has assumed finality.  There, therefore, exists no ground for divorce.  Necessarily, therefore, the court cannot exercise the discretion of granting decree for judicial separation.  There is, therefore, no substance in the appeal.  It is dismissed.  No order as to costs.   [Para 8]

heading: Annulment of marriage on ground of non-consummation
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage on ground of non-consummation - Petitioner husband deposing  that respondent wife did not allow consummation of marriage - Even after repeated efforts wife leaving matrimonial home - Wife choosing not to enter witness box - Deposition of petitioner not found believable in view of letter written by him five months after marriage the tone and tenor of which indicated his satisfactory sexual relations with her and not his frustration - Held non-consummation was not proved and non-examination of wife in witness box was of no significance. (Para 6)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Statutory period of six months prescribed under S.13-B(2) of Act - Application to waive the statutory period - Both husband and wife living separately since about 1 1/2 years - No hasty decision on part of husband and wife - Application for waiver of statutory period of six months - Can be allowed.  2005(1) DMC 571 and AIR 2005 Del. 365 - Ref. to. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Interim maintenance
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Enhancement of - Held, interim maintenance is an order which is meant for providing subsistence during the pendency of proceedings - In these circumstances, enhancement or the reduction in the interim maintenance can be sought by an application, if there is change of circumstances or extra-ordinary long delay in disposal of matter, even though there is no express statutory provision to pass such order.	(Para 6)

heading: Proceeding before Family Court
HeadNote.description: Proceeding before Family Court - A party cannot be permitted to give his evidence through his power of attorney - The party must adduce evidence which is within his personal knowledge - Held, in a matrimonial matter, presence of spouses before Court is vital as there are certain aspects which are only within the personal knowledge of the spouses. (2005)2 SCC 217 - Rel. on.			(Para 14)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Proof - Evidence of landlady that there was no serious misunderstanding between spouses and there was nothing amiss in their relationship - Problems were created by the relatives of the wife - Their behaviour cannot be considered to be act of cruelty on the part of wife though she could have resisted their attempts to disturb matrimonial home - No case for divorce under S.13(1)(i.a) is made out.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Void marriage
HeadNote.description: Void marriage - Violation of condition u/S.5(i) of Hindu Marriage Act - Specific statement by respondent-husband in affidavit at time of his marriage with appellant that her first husband was alive - Not controverted by appellant - No pleading about dissolution of her first marriage as per custom applicable to sindhi community - Failure of appellant to prove and establish prevalence of customary divorce in sindhi community in accordance with law and also the customary divorce having taken place - Probablises case of respondent that there was violation of S.5(i) by appellant - Declaration that marriage of parties was null and void in terms of S.11 - Not perverse and illegal. 1961 CRI.L.J.469 Disting. 	(Para 22)

heading: Suit for maintenance
Presentation of petition
HeadNote.description:
Suit for maintenance - Presentation of petition - Scope of S.19(1) of Hindu Marriage Act - Provisions of S.19(1), applicable only to that Act and cannot be extrapolated to Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act - S.19(1) is, however, relevant for limited purpose of demonstrating that it embodies legislative recognition of fact that place where marriage was solemnized, does constitute a part of cause of action, in certain cases.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.20. AIR 1983 SC 235 - Referred to.  (Para 5)

heading: Maintenance pendente lite and litigation expenses
HeadNote.description: Maintenance pendente lite and litigation expenses - Petitioner having partnership business with his brother turnover of which was about rupees two crores - He was also having agency business in luxury coaches and cars from which he received about rupees four to five crores - Respondent wife was working in leave vacancy for some time and was getting Rs.6000/- p.m. - She had spent Rs.80,000/- on litigation out of Rs.1 lakh given to her by petitioner - Held trial court was justified in ordering Rs.20000/- p.m. as maintenance.	(Paras 3,4)

heading: Grant of permission
HeadNote.description:
Petition for divorce by husband - Respondent wife contesting same on grounds of husband deserting her and leading adulterous life - Respondent seeking DNA test of petitioner and child born out of alleged adulterous life - Grant of permission - Not proper since the respondent wife had sought DNA test not in interest of child but in her own interest for establishing her husband's adultery - DNA test cannot be directed as of routine unless such a test becomes indispensable to resolve the controversy - Moreso, since it violates natural justice principles as child has not been made a party to the proceeding.

Indubitably, Deoxyribonucleic acid test, which is commonly know as 'DNA' test, is useful to determine the question of disputed paternity.  Though the Court is empowered it cannot order a person to submit to such a test as a mater of routine and only in deserving cases such direction can be given.  The Court is expected to exercise such discretion/power, in matrimonial cases, only when such a test is in the best interest of the child.  The courts should exercise this discretion wisely.  The object of the court always is to find out the truth.   It is true that no person can be compelled to give a sample of blood for analysis against his/her will.  However, in the event of refusal it is open for the Court to draw an adverse inference.

Merely because either of the parties have disputed a factum of paternity does not mean that the court should direct DNA test or such other test to resolve the controversy.  The parties should be directed to lead evidence to prove or disprove the factum of paternity and only if the court finds it impossible to draw an interference or adverse inference on the basis of such evidence on record or the controversy in issue cannot be resolved without DNA test, it may direct DNA test and not otherwise.  In other words, only in exceptional and deserving cases, where such a test becomes indispensable to resolve the controversy the court can direct such test.  DNA test, in any case, cannot be directed as a  matter of routine.  The courts should record reasons as to how and why such test in the case is necessary to resolve the controversy and is indispensable.

In the present case, the respondent-wife is seeking DNA test not in the interest of the child but in her own interest to establish that the petitioner-husband lives in adultery and is, therefore, not entitled for divorce.  The learned Judge has not recorded the reasons as to why DNA is indispensable and that the other evidence produce on record is not sufficient to draw an inference or adverse inference in favour or against either of the parties.

Moreover, the child and his mother were not represented in the proceedings and the impugned order was passed behind their back clearly in violation of the principles of natural justice.  The court cannot direct DNA or any such test without hearing the persons concerned irrespective of the fact whether he is minor or major.  If such a person is minor, he should be heard through natural guardian. [Para 5,6,7,8]

heading: Divorce
Application by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Application by husband - Refusal to pay maintenance pendente lite - Amounts to committing a wrong under S.23 - Also refusal to keep wife with him - He is not entitled to decree of divorce. 2001(1) Marriage Law Journal 624 - Rel. on.			(Para 5)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Application by divorced wife for maintenance under S.25 - Has to be filed only before the Court which granted divorce - S.18 of Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act is not applicable - Application filed by divorced wife in Court other than which granted divorce, for past and future maintenance - Not maintainable. Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act (1956), S.18.	(Para 9)

heading: Proceedings for divorce
HeadNote.description: Proceedings for divorce - Spouses living apart for last 19 years - Marriage took place on 25-07-82 and both spouses lived together only upto 01-04-85 - Wife left the matrimonial home along with the child and started living with her mother - Her case was that she was tortured and brutally assaulted for non-fulfilment of demand of dowry of Rs.10,000/- - No chance of reconciliation between them - Divorce granted.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance to wife - Determination - Husband employed as Medical Officer and his take home salary was Rs.27,276/- - Wife living separately with her two daughters - Looking to number of family members and expenses involved in education of daughters, sum of Rs.2,500/- awarded to wife held to be grossly inadequate and arbitrary - Sum enhanced to Rs.5,000/- p.m. - Wife also held entitled to Rs.1,000/- for each date she attended court for proceedings.			(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Concealment of material fact or circumstance concerning wife at time of marriage - Wife allegedly suffering from mental illness - She lived with respondent husband only for three days after marriage and on fourth day was taken to psychiatrist due to abnormal behaviour - Medical evidence that her mental illness required continuous medication and due to which there was irritability, unco-operativeness and hostility on part of wife - Concealment of such thing is definitely fraud within meaning of S.12(1)(c) - Allegation of ill-treatment and suspicion raised by wife, falsified by her own statements - Husband held entitled to annulment of marriage. AIR 1972 Bom 132 - Overruled.			(Paras 15, 20, 21, 23, 24, 25)

heading: Divorce petition by husband on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition by husband on ground of cruelty - Wife chose not to contest petition - She did not file written statement and was absent on all except one date - She did not cross-examine petitioner or his witnesses - Her day to day behaviour revealed through innumerable specific instances cited in petition and by witnesses made life unbearable for husband - He was not properly served with food and he was compelled to eat out side - He had to wash his own clothes - His two children were tutored to turn against him - He never fell like returning to his house in the evening and used to while away time outside - He in fact was compelled to leave his own house in disgust and stayed with his relatives - He was also denied conjugal relations since 1991 and they were living as strangers under one roof - All these facts were not controverted by wife as she chose not to contest - Order of dismissal of Petition by Family Court set aside - Marriage dissolved by a decree of divorce.	(Paras 10-12)

heading: Petition for divorce by wife on ground of cruelty and desertion
HeadNote.description:
Petition for divorce by wife on ground of cruelty and desertion - Family Court converting it into a petition under S.13-B and passing divorce decree by mutual consent - Admittedly petition for divorce by mutual consent was not filed by either wife or husband - Held decree under S.13-B was one without jurisdiction and illegal.

Parties merely agreeing orally at the time of arguments that they have mutually agreed that their marriage should be dissolved, the Petition filed under Section 13(1)(i-a) and (i-b) cannot be treated to have been filed under Section 13-B and decree for divorce by mutual consent cannot be passed in such a situation.  Further, it is also a mandatory provision under Section 23(1)(bb) of the Act that before passing the decree under Section 13-B, the Court has to satisfy itself that consent has not been obtained by force, fraud or under undue influence.  Since there was no petition before the Family Court under Section 13-B of the Act by both the parties mutually agreeing for a divorce by mutual consent, the decree passed by the trial Court in the present case is liable to be set aside as the same has been passed without jurisdiction and, therefore, is illegal.  The judgment and decree set aside and the matter remanded to the Family Court for its fresh decision on petition under S.13(1)(i-a) and (i-b).  [Para 5]

heading: Divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty - Allegation by wife that husband resorted to unnatural carnal relationship with her - Husband making no attempt to counter the allegation in cross-examination of the wife - Held allegation stood proved and wife was entitled to divorce. (Paras 1)

heading: Petition for restitution of conjugal rights by wife
HeadNote.description: Petition for restitution of conjugal rights by wife - On her own showing husband had suppressed the fact of his previous marriage and it was subsisting - Her marriage being void she cannot maintain application for restitution. (Para 1)

heading: Second marriage while first marriage is subsisting
HeadNote.description:
Second marriage while first marriage is subsisting - Marriage is void under S.11 read with S.5(1) - Second wife however is not disentitled from claiming maintenance pendente lite under S.24 - She is also not disentitled from claiming interim maintenance under S.18 of 1956 Act.

Words and phrases - Wife.

Even in a case of bigamous marriage one of the parties can seek a decree of nullity of marriage by way of petitioner or respondent which is permissible under Section 23-A of the Act.  In pending proceedings even at the instance of the second wife in a void bigamous marriage, the court is empowered to make an attempt for re-conciliation, to pass necessary orders with regard to the custody of children and disposal of the property exchanged at the time of marriage.  The court has also power in such proceedings to make an order of permanent alimony or maintenance under Section 25 of the Act.  The Act confers wide powers on the matrimonial Court so as to regulate matrimonial relationship between the parties and such powers are to be exercised by the court even in a case of alleged or proved bigamous marriage.  In enacting Section 24 a special provision is made for ordering interim maintenance and the expenses of litigation to be provided for the contesting husband or wife if he or she had no independent sufficient income.  Therefore, there is no reason why the words "wife" or "husband" used in Section 24 should not be interpreted so as to include a man and woman who have gone through a ceremony of a Hindu marriage which would have been valid but for the provisions of Section 11 read with clause (i) of Section 5 of the Hindu Marriage Act.  These words have been used as convenient terms to refer the parties who have gone through a ceremony of marriage whether or not that marriage is valid or subsisting, just as the word "marriage" has been used in the Act to include a purported marriage which is void ab initio.  [Para 9]

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Interim maintenance - Cannot be denied on ground of misconduct of the spouse claiming maintenance.

While considering the application for maintenance pendente lite, the only consideration before the court is inability of the spouse to maintain herself or himself for want of financial means or inadequacy of financial means to maintain at the level of social status of the other spouse from whom interim maintenance is sought and not the misconduct of the applicant spouse because in the matrimonial dispute between spouses, there would always be allegation of matrimonial offence or misconduct. If misconduct of the spouse seeking maintenance pendente lite could be relevant factor, in no proceeding of divorce or dissolution of marriage or judicial separation, the, opponent spouse unable to maintain could seek interim maintenance since there would always be allegation of matrimonial misconduct against him or her in such proceeding. This was never and is not legislative intention of Section 24. While enacting Section 24, the legislature has provided the interim measure to the spouse having no means or inadequate means to seek maintenance from the spouse who has means to pay the same since because of matrimonial dispute till its resolution by the court, such affected party must be able to maintain herself or himself and contest the proceedings. The proceedings under section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act are summary in nature and at this stage, the court cannot embark upon the enquiry about misconduct of the spourse claiming maintenance or commission of marital offence.  [Para 7]

It is true that granting interim maintenance under section 24 of Hindu Marriage Act is a matter of discretion but like all other discretions exercisable by the court, this discretion too has to be exercised judicially and in accordance with law. The consideration of a factor which does not flow from a statutory provision if taken into consideration while exercising discretion, such exercise of discretion cannot be said to have been exercised in accordance with law.  [Para 8]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty by wife - Husband claiming that wife has arrogant attitude and used to misbehave with him - No cogent evidence to show misbehavior of wife - Record showing that husband did not take any information regarding his wife and daughter after he left paternal home of his wife and did not pay any maintenance to his wife and daughter - Husband shown his status as unmarried in service book and has not corrected it till date - Evidence showing that husband did second marriage and have girl child from said marriage - Husband failed to show any cruelty meted out by wife - Husband not entitled to decree of divorce. (Paras 8, 9, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Wife filing false criminal complaint u/S.307 r.w. Ss.34, 148A, 384, 324 IPC and Ss.4 and 6 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 against husband and seven members of his family - They were arrested and incarcerated - Husband and members of his family were, however, acquitted - Held, wife had filed a false criminal complaint, and even one such complaint was sufficient to constitute matrimonial cruelty. (Paras 4, 5, 6, 7)

heading: Divorce petition
Ground of adultery
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Ground of adultery - Proof - In most of such cases there is no direct evidence regarding adultery - It can be established by circumstantial evidence - It is not always possible that witnesses would see one of the spouses with paramour in objectionable posture or position so as to prove charge of adultery. 	(Para 10)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty by wife - After marriage couple settled in London - Wife not allowing sexual intercourse without any reason and marriage not consummated - Seven months after marriage wife suffered from tuberculosis and was given best available treatment in London - Both returned to India and treatment of wife continued in Chennai - Husband returned to London by giving return ticket to wife to join him in London - Wife, however, did not go to London refused to join his company - Held, there was no ground to interfere with decree of divorce granted by High Court, husband directed to pay her Rs.40 lakhs as one time alimony.(Paras 12, 14)

heading: Divorce petition
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Cruelty and desertion by wife - Proof - Allegation as to occasional outburst by wife or use of offensive language once in a while - Cannot be termed as cruelty - Nor filing of petition under DV Act constitutes cruelty - No evidence that wife had filed any false complaint against husband - On contrary, filing of petition u/S.9 of HM Act by wife indicates that she intends to live with husband - She left matrimonial home only due to circumstances created by husband - Husband cannot be permitted to take advantage of his own wrong - Dismissal of petition proper. 	(Para 10)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Husband addicted to alcohol, abandoned wife and children completely - Compelling wife to stay in a dead marriage, constitutes mental cruelty - Wife entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Para 9)

heading: Petition for
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Restitution of conjugal rights - Petition for - Maintainability - Petition merely states that marriage took place as per Hindu rites and customs at Bandra, Mumbai - No details of marriage as to time and place of marriage are given in petition - No documentary evidence such as invitation card of marriage or photographs of marriage have been filed by appellant - Annexing such documents to petition was necessary because respondent had in reply to notice of appellant to resume his company specifically denied that any marriage had ever taken place - All these details are conspicuously lacking in petition - Petition not maintainable. 
2011 ALL SCR 2403 Rel.on. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Challenge - Wife lived only for 42 days in matrimonial home - She filed criminal case wherein husband stood convicted - Misbehaviour of wife with mother-in-law on second day of marriage and telling husband on first night, that she wanted to marry somebody else - Indicative of her cruel behaviour - It was wife who firstly filed divorce petition but later on withdrew it - Explanation given that wife wanted to file petition u/S.9 but mistakenly filed it u/S.13 - Not satisfactory, since petition u/S.9 never came to be filed - Parties living apart for past 11 yrs. - Cannot be expected to resume cohabitation - Decree of divorce, upheld. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Husband alleged that wife has love affair with another man in connivance with whom she had filed false criminal cases against husband and in-laws - Wife admitted exchange of e-mails with said another man and also apologized for same - However, she is also trying to cover her mistakes by alleging that husband had fabricated those emails (on getting to know password from one of messages) - Stories made by her, not convincing - Husband already acquitted in criminal case - Conduct of wife amounts to cruelty - Divorce validly granted to husband. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
Challenge by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Challenge by wife - Wife without informing her husband, borrowed money on interest from many persons, made purchases on credit, used to steal ornaments and valuables from her own house - When money was not paid, lenders who were gangsters started threatening husband and he has to ultimately wind up his business and return to hometown - Wife had also made allegations that husband is characterless person and he has illicit extra-marital relations with another woman - Wife failed to prove said allegations - Wife also made complaint u/S.494 IPC - All these acts constitute mental cruelty - Wife was indulged in repeated acts of cruelty and misbehavior with husband - Conduct of wife also caused danger to life, limb or health of husband - There was apprehension in mind of husband that it would be harmful or injurious for him to live with wife - Nothing to indicate that husband contributed in any way for alleged breakdown of marriage - Order granting divorce, proper. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Application for transfer of - Applicant wife residing at a distant place with her 5 years old child - Several allegations raised by applicant and denied by respondent - Without entering into the same, held, convenience of wife should be looked into - Moreso because she had liability of a minor child - Divorce petition transferred accordingly. 
AIR 2002 SC 396 Rel. on.              (Para 6)

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description: Desertion - Letters admitted but not exhibited - Letters indicating that wife was prepared to cohabit when petition on ground of desertion came to be filed - Trial Court while giving judgment not taking into consideration such documentary evidence - Judgment and order quashed and set aside. (Para 10, 12)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Exercise of power by court - Scope - While passing decree of divorce by mutual consent trial court issued direction as to grant of lien for minor child of the parties over property of appellant husband and his father, that too without any issue having arisen in this regard - Held, trial court is not supposed to issue such directions in its whims and fancies - It cannot traverse beyond mutual consent agreed between parties - Hence, direction so issued struck off. 	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Marriage petition
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Marriage petition - Maintainability - Husband filed petition for annulment of marriage which is pending in Court at Goa - On ground that wife is transgender and as such is not able to discharge matrimonial obligations - Wife filed application under O.7 R.11 (d), CPC for rejection of plaint for want of jurisdiction which is pending before Trial Court - Husband filed application for direction to wife to subject herself for medical examination whereas wife filed application u/S.24 of H.M. Act for grant of maintenance - Held, unless marriage petition is shown to be ex-facie maintainable, both applications cannot be considered - Both applications are directed to be sent back to Trial Court - In event, application under O.7 R.11(d), CPC is dismissed and petition is held to be maintainable, Trial court shall decide both application afresh. 	(Para 12)

heading: Maintenance pendente lite and expenses
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance pendente lite and expenses - Marriage alleged to be null and void on ground of fraud and deception - Alleged deception cannot disentitle wife to claim interim alimony.

When a fact of marriage is acknowledged or proved alimony follows subject of course to the discretion of the court in the matter having regard to the means of the parties and it would be no answer to the claim for maintenance pendente lite that the marriage was void ipso jure or was voidable. The Family Court was not right in taking into consideration the allegation of fraud and deception made in the petition for the purpose of deciding the prayer of interim alimony. The fact that there is a strong possibility of the marriage being declared as a nullity is no ground for declining even the basic right to claim interim alimony and expenses of the litigation. The family Court was clearly wrong in postponing the determination of interim alimony till the trial of the main petition.  [Para 6]

The direction for interim alimony and expenses of litigation under Section 24 is one of urgency and it must be decided as soon as it is raised and then only the other matter in controversy can be gone into.  [Para 7]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Hindu woman marrying a Christian - Provisions of the Act could not be invoked and no relief could be sought under the Act - Fact that husband practices Hindu religion is of no help to the petitioner. (Para 1)

heading: Wife's petition for
Allowed
Husband's appeal
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Wife's petition for - Allowed - Husband's appeal - Husband's claim of making efforts to bring wife back not supported by evidence - Under compromise also husband failed to take wife home without genuine cause - Conclusion of husband withdrawing himself without reasonable cause from wife's company follows.

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty and desertion by wife - Husband claiming that wife was fickle minded, disrespectful and uncaring and had no affinity towards him and his parents - She used to leave matrimonial home without reasons - Statement of witness showing that wife was not treating guests with respect - Evidence on record showing that wife was never interested in staying with husband and therefore refused to move to rental accommodation with husband - Circumstances showing that there was no act of cruelty on part of husband against wife - Wife’s attitude was indifferent and unconciliatory, that she was rude exhibiting no intention to honour her relations with husband as his wife - Such acts not only showed cruelty on part of wife but clearly proves that she deserted husband without reasonable cause - Order granting decree of divorce, proper.  		(Paras 21, 23)

heading: Order of maintenance
Whether appealable
HeadNote.description:
Order of maintenance - Whether appealable - As per S.19 of Family Courts Act, appeal is maintainable against a 'judgment' or 'order' not being interlocutory order - Order of maintenance u/S.24 of HM Act though limited in its duration till main proceedings are decided, is a final order - It is a 'judgment' because it decides matters of moment and which affects a valuable right of parties - Appeal maintainable.

	A reading of sub-section (1) of Section 19 of the Family Courts Act, 1984 shows that an appeal is maintainable in two cases. It is maintainable against a judgment. It is also maintainable against an order if it is not an interlocutory order.

	As per the decision of the Supreme Court in Shah Babulal Khimji V/s Jayaben D.Kania [1981 SC 1786], an order and for that matter even an interlocutory order would be a 'judgment' if it has the quality of finality attached to it.

	What is noticeable in sub-section (1) of Section 19 of the Family Courts Act, 1984 is that it has deviated from Section 96 of the Code of Civil Procedure and from sub-section (1) of Section 28 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, in that, it provides for appeals against judgment. The Code of Civil Procedure does not provide for an appeal against judgments. It provides for an appeal against decrees and orders. Likewise Section 28 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 also does not provide for appeals against judgment. It provides for appeals against decrees and certain orders.

	An order passed under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 though limited in its duration till the main proceedings are decided, is a final order. Indeed, the order would be a judgment because it decides matters of moment and which affects a valuable right of the parties. The expression 'some right or liability' is not restricted to the right in controversy in the main proceeding itself.
