It may be an order which is of an ancillary nature but is determinative of the rights and liabilities for the reason a spouse who is not able to maintain himself/herself without maintenance being awarded would be handicapped in litigating and per contra if the maintenance awarded is beyond the means of the other spouse and the spouse cannot pay the same the proceedings can be halted.

	The reference is answered by holding that an appeal shall lie under Section 19(1) of the Family Courts Act, 1984 against an order passed by a Family Court under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955.

2005(23) LCD 1, AIR 2010 Utr 67, 192 (2012) DLT 714, 1981 SC 1786 Ref. to. RLW 2011 (2) Raj.1615 Held Not Good Law.			 [Para 13,14,16,20,21,23]

heading: Grounds for divorce
HeadNote.description: Grounds for divorce - Wife seeking  decree of divorce alleging mental and physical cruelty - Allegations of cruelty not at all justified so as to break matrimonial bond - No evidence of existence of strained relationship between two spouses so as to justify judicial divorce - Marriage not becoming completely irretrievable - Variance in pleadings and evidence - Held, marriage cannot be dissolved on the basis of proof of some trivial events. (Paras 21, 23, 24, 25)

heading: Interim maintenance
Validity
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of to wife - Consideration of income of husband's brother and his family and assets standing in name of husband's brother - Validity - Husband's brother is builder and his various construction projects are in progress and he also possesses various luxurious cars - Though none of vehicles or projects standing in name of husband, he is member of undivided family whose financial status appears to be very affluent - Husband claiming that he is not part of family business - However, documents produced by him to show that he is separate from family business, pertains to post-separation of husband and wife - It shows that husband wants to hide his real income to avoid payment of maintenance to wife - Further, record shows that even after retirement from family business amount is credited to account of husband from construction company of his brother - Material on record showing that husband is part of family business - Held, income of husband should not be ascertained only on basis of income tax returns, it should be ascertained judicially considering attendant circumstances - Looking to circumstances grant of maintenance of Rs.25,000/- p.m. to wife, proper. 			(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Application by father for visitation rights - Parties divorced by mutual consent u/S.13B and custody of minor child given to wife - Minor son not willing to be with his father - Held, once the minor child, does not want to be with his father, application is nothing but an attempt to re-agitate matrimonial discord - Application not maintainable as custody given to wife and husband kept no stake. (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty and desertion - Wife claiming that husband was extremely cruel and of callus and indifferent attitude since initial years of marriage and left home without any reason - Husband did not give any financial or emotional support - He was not taking care of his daughter nor sharing responsibilities with wife - Events occurred in life of parties reflect one sided relationship where husband has taken everything for granted, with no sense of responsibility - Material on record showing that only wife made sincere efforts to salvage marriage and that she did more than what was her duty, to preserve it - Wife took good care of daughter despite adverse circumstances and gave her good education - There was no cohabitation between parties - Wife entitled to decree of divorce. (Paras 12, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Permission to waive statutory period of 6 months - Sought jointly by both husband and wife - Petition u/S.13B filed within 6 months from date of marriage - Almost 4 years have lapsed from date of marriage and 2 years have lapsed from date of their separation - Parties have agreed that both minor daughters shall remain with husband - In view of law laid down in 2014(3) ALL MR 60, period of six months can be waived, although there was no previous litigation between parties - Reason that husband desires to remarry is not germane to issue of such waiver - Permission granted. 2014(3) ALL MR 60 Foll. 	(Para 5)

heading: Annulment of marriage
Not permissible
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Sought on ground that wife was minor at time of marriage - Held, only minor spouse has right to seek annulment of marriage - Annulment sought by husband who was major at time of marriage - Not permissible - However, as annulment was sought mainly on ground of fraud and coercion caused by wife and her relatives on ground of age, matter remanded to High Court for fresh consideration. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Few isolated incidents of long past that too found to have been condoned due to compromising behavior of parties - Cannot constitute an act of cruelty within meaning of S.13(1)(i-a) - Incidents alleged should be of recurring nature or continuing one and in near proximity with filing of petition. (Paras 28, 29)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - On ground of cruelty - Petition by wife alleging that husband used to abuse her by saying she is characterless lady having affair with other persons - He was alleged to have physically abused wife - Wife was not cross-examined on these serious allegations - Those allegations therefore remained uncontroverted and in absence of cross-examination they are to be taken as proved - Husband in his evidence has not specifically denied allegations leveled by wife - Conduct of husband in suspecting character of wife, physically assaulting and harassing her as she was coming home late from work place due to nature of her job - It amounts to cruelty - Wife entitled to decree of divorce on ground of cruelty. 		(Paras 18, 19, 20, 24)

heading: Proceedings initiated at Family Court, Bandra
HeadNote.description:
Proceedings initiated at Family Court, Bandra - Respondent subsequently filing similar proceedings at Nasik - Proceedings at Nasik being subsequent in time are liable to the transferred at Bandra with liberty to respondent to claim travelling expenses for attending proceedings at Bandra. (Para 4)

(1997) 2 SCC 452 Rel. on.

heading: Application for divorce filed by husband alleging cruelty on the part of the wife and also that she left matrimonial house and she begot a child through another
HeadNote.description: Application for divorce filed by husband alleging cruelty on the part of the wife and also that she left matrimonial house and she begot a child through another - Family Court gave a decree for judicial separation instead of divorce - Wife denying the allegation of cruelty and asserting that the child was born to her through her husband - High Court setting aside the order of trial Court and dismissing the application of the husband finding that both the grounds of cruelty and desertion have not been proved - Plea of adultery not pressed - In the circumstances, held, the High Court was justified in dismissing the application for divorce. (Para 4)

heading: Right of illegitimate child
HeadNote.description: Right of illegitimate child - An illegitimate child is entitled to the estate of father only if marriage of parents was null and void u/S.11 of HM Act - If there is no marriage, even if it is proved that child is born out of relationship between a male and a female Hindu, the child is not entitled to legal heirship with respect to the property of father. 2007 (3) KLT 270, 2016 (2) KLT 81 Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Petitioner husband asked to pay Rs. 250/- as maintenance u/s 125 Cr. P.C. to respondent wife - Held, having regard to standard of living and position of parties interim maintenance at rate of Rs. 200/- was not excessive - Revision application dismissed. (Paras 4)

heading: Petition for divorce by husband on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Petition for divorce by husband on ground of cruelty - While dismissing petition court awarding maintenance to wife - Order of trial court granting maintenance is liable to be set aside in view of (1993) 3 SCC 406 - Decision of SC is binding under Art. 141 of Constitution.

(1993) 3 SCC 406 foll.

Constitution of India, Art. 141. (Paras 18, 19)

heading: Maintenance granted to wife under s. 125
HeadNote.description: Maintenance granted to wife under s. 125 - Matrimonial court granting amount to wife by way of permanent alimony - Such amount is in addition to amount awarded under S. 125. (Para 8)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - In an appeal filed by wife against decree of divorce u/S.13(1)(i-b) - Parties expressed their willingness to part on mutually agreed terms - No chance of their living together in future - Their marriage dissolved on agreed terms - Jurisdiction u/Art.142 of Constitution, exercised by Apex Court for said purpose - While quashing allegations/findings recorded against wife in decree of Court below, Apex Court directed husband to pay permanent alimony and medical expenses to wife - Ordered accordingly. 			(Paras 11, 12, 15, 16)

heading: Meaning of co-habitation
HeadNote.description:
Co-habitation after passing of decree for judicial separation - Meaning of co-habitation - Visiting juice bar, going to temple or to a friend's place will not amount to co-habitation.

Merely because on few occasions, the parties came together either in the juice bar or at the temple, will not amount to co-habitation. Co-habitation means to dwell to-gether as husband and wife or as if husband and wife.  [Para 7]

heading: Permanent alimony
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Entitlement to - Wife entitled to permanent alimony even if a decree of nullity of marriage has been passed against her. 2005 (1) RCR (Civil) 615 Foll.	(Para 8)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty and desertion by wife - Husband alleged that wife residing separately for continuous period of 2 years immediately preceding petition - Further, she also filed criminal case u/S.498A and S.494 IPC against husband and also petition u/S.125 for maintenance - Held, filing of criminal cases against husband cannot be said to be cruelty to husband - Moreover, petition for restitution of conjugal rights, filed by both husband and wife against each other - Same shows that they were interested in cohabitation - Vague pleading made by husband about harassment by wife - As regards ground of desertion, evidence of wife shows that husband had performed second marriage and he has son and daughter from that marriage - Therefore, she has just and sufficient ground to reside separate from husband - Therefore, dismissal of petition held, justified. 2005(5) ALL MR 1012 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 21, 22)

heading: Divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce on ground of cruelty - Sole incident of slapping by the wife in the bed room - No injury nor humiliation on part of husband proved - Such an incident cannot be branded as ill-treatment under S.13 - Husband not entitled to divorce on ground of cruelty.

(1994) 1 SCC 337 and AIR 1986 Raj 49 - Distinguished.	(Para 29)

heading: Condonation of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce by husband on ground of cruelty - Cruelty proved in trial court - Condonation of cruelty - Cannot be inferred from fact that till wife left marital home young couple was co-habiting and was having physical relations. (Para 10)

heading: Nullity of marriage
"Sapinda relationship"
Factum of custom
HeadNote.description: Nullity of marriage - "Sapinda relationship" - Factum of custom - Evidence led by wife to prove a custom allowing marriages among sapindas in their community - Evidence rightly found by trial court inadequate and insufficient - Decree of divorce declaring the marriage null and void - Decree of divorce upheld. AIR 1975 SC 733, AIR 1964 SC 118 and AIR 1968 SC 129 - Ref. to.	(Paras 20 to 22, 26, 31, 32)

heading: Maintenance
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Parties in consent terms agreeing not to initiate any proceeding against each other and claim alimony/maintenance in future - Effect - Held, both the clauses were against public policy and would not disentitle wife from claiming maintenance.

The language of Section 25 shows that it is a power conferred on the Court at the time of passing of the decree or at any time subsequent thereto on an application made to award alimony or maintenance.  This is a jurisdiction to be exercised by the Court.  The parties, therefore, cannot by an agreement between themselves, agree to oust the jurisdiction of the Court which otherwise Parliament has conferred.  The second aspect of the matter is that permanent alimony and maintenance are a larger part of the right to life.  These provisions have been included to enable a person unable to maintain herself to be protected.  Therefore, any clause in a contract or consent terms providing to the contrary would be against public policy. [Para 8]

In this case, clause 4 of the consent terms provided that both parties undertake not to initiate any proceedings against each other in future and clause 5 provided that wife will not claim any maintenance or alimony in future.  Held, Clause 5 of the consent terms is clearly severable from the other terms of the consent terms.  Clause 5 would be contrary to public policy and consequently that clause will have to be treated as nonest.  The only question is whether Clause 4 would bar the appellant herein from so applying.  The very fact that clause 5 was placed differently from clause 4 will indicate that it ought to cover situations other than those covered by clause 5.  Even otherwise clause 4 to the extent that prohibits a party from claiming maintenance would also suffer similar consequences as Clause 5 of being against public policy.  Hence the appellant was not barred from applying under S.25(1) for maintenance.  [Para 8]

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Order granting ad interim maintenance by District Judge at a place where Family Court was not established - Neither appeal under S.19(1) of Family Courts Act nor under S.28 of Hindu Marriage Act nor revision under S.115 would be maintainable - Order can, however, be challenged under Art.227 of Constitution of India.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Interim maintenance under S.24
HeadNote.description:
Interim maintenance under S.24 - Reimbursement of medical expenses incurred by dependant wife - Word "support" in S.24 can be given same meaning as is given to the word "maintenance" in S.3(b)(i) of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act - Hence wife would he entitled to reimbursement of medical expenses in an application under S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act.

Provisions of Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act provides for support to be nby the earning spouse in favour of non earning spouse during the pendency of proceedings before the Court. The question is as to whether medical expenses incurred by the claimant can form part of an application under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act. The word "support" has not been defined under the Hindu Marriage Act. We will have to only look at the definition as given in the dictionary or as understood in general parlance. However, we can draw inspiration from the word "maintenance" which has been defined under the provisions of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act. Section 3(b)(i) of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act defines maintenance to be inclusive of provision for food, clothing, residence, education and medical attendance and treatment. The definition here is also not an extensive definition, but inclusive one and nevertheless specifically mentions about medical attendance and, treatment. The meaning attributed to the word "maintenance" and as defined under Section 3(b)(i) can be taken to be the meaning even under the word "support" used under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act.  [Para 10,11]

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Encompasses a provision for residence.

Maintenance, necessarily must encompass a provision for residence. Maintenance is given so that the lady can live in the manner, more or less, to which she was accustomed. The concept of maintenance must, therefore, include provision for food and clothing and the like and take into account the basic need of a roof over the head. Provision for residence may be made either by giving a lump sum in money, or property in lieu thereof. It may also be made by providing, for the course of the lady's life, a residence and money for other necessary expenditure. Where provision is made in this manner, by giving a life interest in property for the purposes of residence, that provision is made in lieu of a pre-existing right to maintenance and the Hindu lady acquires far more than the vestige of title which is deemed sufficient to attract Section 14(1).  1995(6) SCC 88, 2005(2) SCALE 105 - Foll.   [Para 9]

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Agreement between parties regarding mutual divorce - A Marriage can never be said to be dissolved merely by entering into such an agreement by the spouses.

Simply because an agreement was produced along with the original application showing that the marriage has been dissolved by entering into an agreement in this behalf can never be said to be a ground for coming to the conclusion that the marriage was not subsisting on the date of the filing of the application. The spouses cannot dissolve the marriage on their own by entering into any sort of agreement and such type of agreement cannot be recognised by the court of law unless satisfactory evidence is led before the court, that by virtue of custom, a customary divorce has been obtained by them. In the instant case, the family court has not recorded any finding that the marriage was legally dissolved by entering into such an agreement on the basis of any custom. Unless there is any evidence in this behalf, an agreement produced before the court was nothing but a mere piece of paper which has no evidentiary value at all. By entering into such an agreement, a marriage can never be said to be dissolved in any manner. The Judge, therefore, committed an error in coming to the conclusion that in view of the agreement between the parties there was no subsisting marriage between the appellant and respondent at the time of filing of the application and that such marriage stood dissolved at the time of filing of this application. No weightage can be given to such an agreement by the court and therefore it can be said that the marriage was subsisting irrespective of such an agreement on the date of filing of the application. No marriage can be said to have been dissolved by entering into such type of agreement, unless an appropriate evidence is produced before the Court showing that a marriage can be dissolved between the parties by way of customary divorce, in view of prevailing custom in the community. In the instant case, no such evidence is produced and therefore the marriage can be said to be subsisting and it can on the date of the filing of the application and such marriage can be dissolved only by passing a decree by the competent court. A.I.R. 2005 SC 422 - Rel. on.  [Para 6]

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Wife wilfully denied co-habitation from the first night itself till she left the matrimonial home on the 6th day - Denial of sexual relationship to the other spouse who was anxious for it amounts to mental cruelty - Decree of divorce confirmed.

A normal and healthy sexual relationship is one of the basic ingredients of a happy and harmonious marriage. No doubt, if this is not possible due to ill-health on the part of one of the spouses, it may not amount to cruelty, depending on the circumstances of the case. But wilful denial of sexual relationship by a spouse, when the other spouse is anxious for it, would amount to mental cruelty, especially when the parties are young and newly married. The petitioner-husband has established the case that from the date of their marriage, i.e., 1.7.1993 till the date of their separation, i.e., the date of leaving his wife from the matrimonial home on 6.7.1993, she refused to cohabit with him and did not indulge in sexual intercourse; and thus he was deprived of a happy and harmonious marriage. Consequently, the petitioner-husband suffered mental cruelty and he has established and proved the same by acceptable evidence. The Family Court considered all these aspects and rightly granted decree for divorce; accordingly, there is no valid ground to take a different view. [Para 27]

heading: Transfer of case
Joint trial
Foll.	 [Para 6,8]
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of case - Joint trial - Parties same and would be leading common evidence - Order for joint trial by transfer of case is proper.

Where parties were same and would be leading a common evidence in both the proceedings and when both the proceedings were pending before the same Court, in the interest of justice both the cases be directed to be decided together.  2007(4) ALL MR 74 - Foll.	 [Para 6,8]

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Husband highly qualified as CA, ICWA, CIMA and well versed in Computer Information Technology - Had served in renowned and big companies before he started his own company - According to him he was getting only Rs.30,000/- per month from this company - High Court accepted this figure and fixed Rs.12,000/- as interim maintenance to the wife pending divorce petition - Held High Court was not justified in accepting claim of income of husband at Rs.30,000/- as gospel truth - Matter remanded for reconsideration.	(Para 9)

heading: Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - Parties cease to be husband and wife - Liability to pay alimony will not include liability to make arrangement for her stay by securing alternative accommodation for wife - Wife has no alternative but to quit from husband's premises.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Divorce
Desertion by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Desertion by wife - Wife was school teacher and was posted at different places - She, however, did not care to make any attempt to visit or live with her husband even during holidays or vacations of the school - Husband on his part made every effort to meet her but he failed and he filed suit for divorce after living separately for 26 years - Defendant wife filed written statement but did not care to appear in the case and cross-examination did not take place - Held from pleading of the parties and evidence of plaintiff it was clear that wife had deserted her husband and as such was entitled to decree of divorce.			(Paras 13-16)

heading: Interim maintenance
Claim by wife
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Claim by wife - To claim maintenance claimant should not have sufficient independent income for support - Wife employed in private concern and earning Rs.4500/-per month and staying with her brother - Husband earning only Rs.70/-per day - Held grant of maintenance to wife at for Rs.750/-p.m. is not justified.			(Para 5)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Marriage irretrievably broken down - Proceedings pending for about five years - No collusion while seeking divorce by mutual consent - Waiting period of six months can he dispensed with - Marriage dissolved by decree for divorce.	(Para 10)

heading: Divorce petition
Jurisdiction of Court
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Jurisdiction of Court - Not only the Court where the marriage was solemnized has jurisdiction to try the petition filed under the Act but also the court where the respondent resided or where the parties to matrimony last resided - It is the sweet will of the petitioner to file petition under any of the three clauses mentioned in S.19.	(Para 9)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Temperamental incompatibility between spouses - Living separately for last more than 4 years and 6 months - No chance of reconciliation - Agreed to dissolve marriage without any coercion or undue influence - Marriage dissolved by granting decree of divorce.	(Para 3)

heading: Dispute over property
Admission in pleadings
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Dispute over property - Admission in pleadings - Husband admitting in pleadings that wife was co-owner of flat in co-operative society obtained in exchange by surrendering tenancy rights to a builder - Title deed and share certificate both stood in the joint names of husband and wife - Held, there was 50:50 ownership in the flat and husband was estopped by his conduct from denying title of the wife - Family Court directed to appoint Commissioner to arrange inter se bids for 50% share of the other in the flat - Failing that to sell flat and distribute sale proceeds in the ratio of 50:50 after substracting sale expenses - Evidence Act (1872), S.56.	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Respondent-wife allegedly filed false complaint against appellant-husband - She also filed restitution petition u/S.9 subsequent to said complaint - However, did not disclose fact of filing of complaint by her in said petition - Even in her cross examination she admitted that had appellant not filed divorce petition she would not have filed complaint - Same shows ill-intention on part of respondent to put appellant behind bars and also humiliate and harass him - Such act on part of respondent comes within definition of 'cruelty' as defined under Hindu Marriage Act - Therefore, divorce petition, allowed. 2015(2) ALL MR 435 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 22)

heading: Maintenance pendente lite
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance pendente lite - Determination of - It cannot be said that as husband has no income, Court loses its power to award any maintenance pendente lite.

There is no fixed principle for determining the amount of maintenance pendente lite or expenses of the proceedings. The Court has to consider the status of the parties, their needs and the capacity of the husband to pay having regard to the reasonable expenses for the maintenance of the wife and the child, which he is obliged to meet under the law. The amount of maintenance pendente lite should be fixed for the wife and the child taking into consideration the cost of living index so that she does not feel handicapped. The husband was an employee of a private firm and he used to earn by undertaking private typing jobs. It is alleged by the husband that he has left his service voluntarily and presently he is unemployed and has no income at all to pay the maintenance pendente lite or expenses of the proceedings. The husband is an able-bodied person capable of earning. The husband voluntarily incapacitated himself from earning, but he cannot avoid his liability to maintain his wife and the child.		  [Para 9]

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Dissolution of marriage on ground of, scope - No specific pleading as regards acts which tantamount to cruelty - Acts of cruelty not mentioned by appellant-husband even in notice - Simply stating that respondents wife suffering with filarial disease at time of marriage, which fact was suppressed by respondent and her parents and that she is facing mental disorder would not constitute ground of cruelty - Cruelty must be of such nature that parties cannot reasonably be expected to live together - Appellant, held, miserably failed to establish cruelty alleged to have been meted out to him by respondent by adducing substantial evidence - No irregularity or illegality in impugned order passed by trial Court in dismissing divorce O.P. filed by appellant dismissed.	(Paras 16-19)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description:
Permanent alimony - Wife unsuccessful in defending suit for divorce - Even then she is entitled to permanent alimony.

The provision of grant or maintenance is a piece of social legislation therefore, the Courts are vested with wide discretion in the matter of grant of permanent alimony. So vast is the discretion that even where decree has been passed against the wife on the ground of her adultery or cruelty, the courts have allowed permanent alimony as she was found to be without means and no one to support. Section 25 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 is wide enough to enable the court to grant permanent alimony to the erring wife. There is nothing in law to prevent the court from making an order of permanent maintenance in favour of the wife even if she is unsuccessful in defending the suit for divorce. In view of the above the cruelty or desertion on part of the wife leading to the decree of divorce alone would not be a relevant criteria for refusing alimony to her. After all wife is entitle to maintain herself and there is no statutory prohibition for her from seeking maintenance from her husband or ex-husband.  						 [Para 6,8]

heading: Stay of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Stay of proceedings - Petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Petition filed by husband against wife - Wife seeking stay of petition on ground that her petition for divorce on ground of cruelty has been filed earlier - Application filed by wife dismissed by lower court - As evidence in both cases will be almost common and both petitions being before same Court, held, it would be in the interest of justice to try both petitions together.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Maintenance
Expression 'wife'
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Expression 'wife' - Law does not recognize a claim by an illegitimate wife though illegitimate child can claim maintenance - Marriage of a woman in accordance with Hindu rites with a man having a living spouse is a complete nullity and she is, therefore, not entitled to benefit of S.125 of Cr.P.C. or the Hindu Marriage Act. Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125.	(Paras 19-23)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Allegation of husband that wife terminated her pregnancy against his and his parent's wish - Allegation not proved by supporting evidence and found to be deliberate false hood - Levelling of such allegation in written statement itself would afford a ground for divorce.	(Paras 11, 16)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of the statutory period of six months - No possibility of re-union - Provision of six months waiting period being only directory can be waived.

There is an obligation on the part of the Courts to make last minute efforts to save the marriage at any cost.  It is only with that view in mind, the law makers have fixed the period of six months, so as to enable the parties to come together for mutual settlement instead of mutual divorce.  But, in case, where there is no possibility of re-union, especially after the divorce by mutual consent process has been adopted, which is by way of liberalised process, the facts of each and every case has to be considered and it is always open to the Court to decide about the waiver of the period of six months.  If this section viz. 13-B(2) of the Act is read as mandatory, then the very purpose of liberalised concept of divorce by mutual consent will be frustrated, especially when the parties have lived separately and there was no chance of re-union. AIR 1988 Guj 159, AIR 1994 Kar 12, AIR 1986 AP 167 - Rel.on.   [Para 7]

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Personal appearance of parties is not mandatory - Parties may be represented through duly constituted attorneys - In such a case Court will have to be more cautious and vigilant in recording its satisfaction about consent. Civil P.C. (1908), O.3, R.2.	(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Not a ground of divorce under S.13(1) - Court cannot add such a ground as that would be amending the Act, which is a function of legislature - It is for Parliament to enact or amend the law and not for the Courts - Cases granting divorce on ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage are not precedents to be followed.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Petition for divorce on ground of desertion by wife dismissed
HeadNote.description:
Petition for divorce on ground of desertion by wife dismissed - Second petition filed by husband - Fresh cause has to be shown - Mere separate living of wife because of litigation between spouses does not give cause of action - Wilful abandonment is essential.

What to required to be proved for a decree of divorce under Cl.(i-b) of S.3(1) is that other spouse "has deserted" and not that other spouse "is not living in the company." Therefore, desertion is not same as being away. It has to be shown that other spouse has deserted. Therefore, it would have to be shown that respondent had willfully abandoned the company of petitioner as a distinct event, subsequent to the filing of second petition. It may at least have to be shown that the appellant had made an attempt to seek return of respondent to matrimonial home after first petition was filed and that such attempt was thwarted, giving rise to a fresh cause of action. Mere continuance of separate residence since before the filing of first petition till second petition was filed would not constitute a separate cause of action for seeking decree on the ground of desertion.   [Para 8]

The appellant through out was litigating in the hierarchy of courts and there was no occasion for the respondent to take a conscious decision of withdrawing from the company of appellant, from the day the first petition was dismissed till the second petition was filed, the respondent must be held to have lacked the necessary animus deserendi and therefore, it can not be said that there is any fresh cause of action for filing petition.   [Para 9]

In the circumstances since the respondent wife could not have had any opportunity for resuming cohabitation during the period the appellant was fighting with the respondent in the hierarchy of courts, there is no question of the respondent bearing animus deserandi ruling out any cause for the appellant to seek divorce on the ground of desertion.   [Para 25]

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Substantive petition for divorce rejected - Court cannot pass order granting permanent alimony. AIR 1989 AP 8 held no longer good law in view of 1993 AIR SCW 2548.	(Para 8)

heading: Property rights of children
HeadNote.description: Property rights of children - Word "property" is not qualified with either self-acquired or ancestral property - It has been kept broad and general - Section does not impose any restriction on property right of illegitimate children except limiting it to property of their parents - Such interpretation is supported by Arts.39(f) and 300-A of the Constitution - However in view of contrary decisions in (2003)1 SCC 730, (2006)9 SCC 612 and AIR 2010 SC 2685 matter directed to be referred to a larger Bench.			(Paras 21, 22, 23, 36-42)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Wife establishing that though earlier she had married with Muslim after her divorce and before next marriage with a Hindu she became Full-fledged Hindu by performing Shudhikaran ceremonies - Dissolution of marriage by husband cannot be granted in aforesaid circumstances.	 2009(1) ALL MR 488 (S.C.) - Disting.	(Paras 10 to 12)

heading: Petition by husband for declaring marriage as void
HeadNote.description: Petition by husband for declaring marriage as void - Ground of subsisting earlier marriage of wife - Wife contending that earlier marriage was dissoluted by customary divorce - Burden of proving divorce by way of custom was on the wife and could not be shifted on to the respondent merely because he was informed of the dissolution - Moreover such a defence is not at all available under S.5(1) r.w. S.11.			(Paras 5, 6, 8)

heading: Maintenance pendente lite
Application for
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance pendente lite - Application for - Conduct of applicant is immaterial - It is not open to Court to pre-judge the issues and to hold that as the applicant is guilty of matrimonial offences applicant is not entitled to alimony pendent lite and expenses of proceedings.

For the purpose of awarding maintenance pendente lite and expenses of proceedings the conduct of the applicant is immaterial. The provisions of Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 do not authorise the Court to look into the conduct of the applicant at the time of consideration of an application for awarding maintenance pendente lite. This is apparent from the fact that the legislature has made provisions for consideration of the conduct of the parties at the time of awarding permanent alimony under Section 25 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. A proceeding for awarding alimony pendente lite and expenses of the proceedings is summary in nature and the Court is not authorised to go into the merits of the claim and the counter-claim of the parties. When an applicant applies for maintenance pendente lite and for expenses of the proceedings, it is not open to the Court to pre-judge the Issues and to hold that as the applicant is guilty of matrimonial offences, the applicant not entitled to alimony pendente lite and expenses of the proceedings inasmuch as such question is extraneous to the consideration.   [Para 8]

heading: Maintenance pendente lite
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance pendente lite - Lower Court granted interim maintenance of Rs.3,000 p.m., to wife and minor children and legal expenses of Rs.5,000 - Revision Petition by husband questioning quantum, being on higher side and disproportionate to his income, since he was only an agricultural coolie - Husband had not attended lower Court and had filed no counter - Held, Section 24 contemplates only summary enquiry - Keeping in view conduct of husband and object of section, lower Court was left with no option except to grant reliefs as prayed for - Finding of lower Court that despite adjournments, husband did not choose to file counter cannot be disturbed - However in light of nature of particulars furnished by wife, quantum of maintenance modified granting Rs.1500 p.m. to wife and Rs.500 p.m., each to minor children - Amount of legal expenses to prosecute litigation, confirmed - CRP partly allowed.

The object of Section 24 of the Act is to enable the child, wife or the husband who may not be having independent income sufficient to support herself or himself, as the case may be, and the necessary expenses of any proceeding under the said Act, to have maintenance and the expenses pendente lite so that the proceedings may be further proceeded with without any hardship on such parties.  It is no doubt true that while deciding the quantum to be awarded in this regard, the Court may have to assess the reasonable amount to be paid and it is also true that in this regard under Section 24 of the Act aforesaid, summary enquiry to be conducted though an enquiry in detail need not be conducted in this regard.  Keeping in view the object of the provision aforesaid and also taking the conduct of the husband into consideration, the learned Senior Civil Judge was left with no other option except to fix an amount of Rs.3,000/- to the wife and the minor children as well each and Rs.5,000/- towards legal expenses.  However, keeping the overall facts and circumstances in view, the Court is not inclined to disturb the finding recorded by the learned Senior Civil Judge to the effect that though several chances had been given to the husband, he had not filed any counter.  But however, in the light of the nature of the particulars which had been furnished by the wife in support of the application, the quantum of interim maintenance is hereby modified, granting Rs.1,500/- p.m. to the wife and Rs.500/- p.m. each to the minor children, i.e., in all Rs.2,500/- p.m., but however the quantum of legal expenses of Rs.5,000/- to prosecute the litigation as such is hereby confirmed.  To the said extent, the order impugned is modified.						   [Para 8]

heading: Divorce petition
Territorial jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Territorial jurisdiction - Parties resident of Lucknow residing together at Kanpur for sometime for providing medical treatment to petitioner - Divorce petition would not lie at Kanpur - Petition directed to be transferred to Family Court at Lucknow.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Petition for
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Petition for - Appellant's first marriage with elder sister of respondent was subsisting at time of marriage with respondent - Appellant had developed illicit relationship with younger sister of his first wife and had two children from her - His second marriage was null and void and as such he cannot maintain petition for restitution of conjugal rights on her leaving his company.	(Para 6)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Joint application seeking dissolution of marriage - Affidavits in support filed - Married on 16-2-2002, living separate from December, 2003 and application presented on 3-9-2004 - Affidavits clearly revealing that before staying physically separate they had stayed separately by mind and soul and there was no performance of marital obligations - Held, on perusal of pleadings and after having attempted reconciliation at appellate stage that parties are entitled to a decree of divorce though they were not staying separately for less than one year as stipulated in S.13-B(1). (1991)2 SCC 25 Foll.			(Para 14)

heading: Ex-parte decree
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Limitation Act (1963), S.5 - Ex-parte decree - Setting aside of - Delay of 75 days in presenting application - Ground of ill health and wife being out of station on relevant date pleaded - Annulment of marriage was sought under u/s.12(1)(c) and not under S.12(1)(a) on ground that wife was suffering from rheumatic heart disease and this fact was not known to him - Further Family Court proceeded on ground that her arguments were heard, while in fact, no such arguments were advanced - Held court was not justified in rejecting application for condonation of delay even after above glaring irregularities in the annulment decree were pointed out - Matter transferred from Hyderabad to Secunderabad to avoid embarrassment to learned Family Judge.			(Paras 5, 6, 9, 10)

heading: Matrimonial matters
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.142 - Matrimonial matters - In order to do complete justice in the matrimonial matters, the apex Court could be less hesitant in exercising its extraordinary jurisdiction under Art.142 of Constitution. (2004)10 SCC 505 & (1996)8 SCC 90 - Ref. to.	(Para 13)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description:
Restitution of conjugal rights - Wife seeking decree for restitution of conjugal rights against husband - However, number of cases filed by wife against husband showing that she did not have trust or any confidence in her husband and she was not desirous of cohabiting with him - Serious allegations also made against him - In the face of proceedings filed by wife against husband for the offence punishable under Ss.406 and 498-A of I.P.C., it is apparent that a feeling of threat and uncertainty would always remain at the back of his mind - Held, in such circumstances, it is not easy to digest that the respondent wife was desirous of cohabiting with the appellant husband - In the facts and circumstances, it is impossible for the appellant and respondent to stay together.

In the present case, the number of cases filed by the respondent wife against the appellant husband clearly show that the respondent did not have any confidence or trust in her husband and she was not desirous of cohabiting with him.  Where a party is desirous of cohabiting with the spouse, it is not expected of that party to institute proceedings for partitions and separate possession of the property, proceedings for an offence punishable under Section 406 of the Indian Penal Code and take steps to initiate proceedings for an offence punishable under Section 498-A of the Indian Penal Code.  It is not expected of a wife to launch all these proceedings against her husband and still desire to stay with him.  Moreover, the respondent wife has levelled several allegations against her husband about ill-treatment, demand for money from her parents and other several serious allegations are also made against him.  In such circumstances, it is not easy to digest that the respondent wife was desirous of cohabiting with the appellant husband.  In the face of the proceedings filed by the wife against the husband for the offence punishable under Section 406 and 498-A of the Indian Penal Code, it is apparent that a feeling of threat and uncertaintly would always remain at the back of his mind.	 [Para 12,13]

heading: Divorce
Petition by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband - Desertion and cruelty alleged - Wife soon after marriage leaving matrimonial house and living with her parents - She then applied for judicial separation and also filed complaint under S.498-A, IPC - Appellant husband and his parents were arrested and news of their arrest was published in local newspapers - Petition for judicial separation was dismissed and parents and appellant were acquitted in criminal case - Conduct of wife after abruptly leaving house without reasonable cause and her conduct before that in not participating in traditional customs such as Chulah ceremony disclosed her unco-operative and adamant attitude towards husband and his parents - If some minor quarrels or incidents took place because of her such attitude she was to blame herself and she cannot justify her conduct of leaving matrimonial house on that count - Dismissal of divorce petition quashed and set aside - Order for permanent alimony of Rs.1000/-; however, not interfered with.	(Paras 19-24)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Husband a professional architect of 25 years standing - Not disclosing his real income by producing balance sheet, profit and loss account which would show his real income - Income of Rs.5000/- disclosed by him was a gross underestimate - Wife carrying on some business at home - Same was not lucrative enough to support her and two sons pursuing studies in prestigious institutions - Maintenance granted to son of Rs.1500/- raised to Rs.3000/- p.m. - Wife granted Rs.1500/- p.m. and maintenance granted to second son maintained at Rs.2500/- p.m.	(Para 11)

heading: Petition for divorce
Divorce granted
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce - Petition was filed by husband on ground of cruelty and desertion - Divorce granted - Held, matrimonial disputes have to be decided by courts in a pragmatic manner keeping in view the ground realities - Court has to decide in the facts and circumstances of each case and it is not possible to lay down any fixed standards or even guideline.	(Para 10)

heading: Distinguished.	 [Para 30,31,32]
HeadNote.description:
Subjecting wife along with her child to DNA test - Husband contending that wife was pregnant at time of marriage and because there was no consummation of marriage he was not the father of the child - Wife contended that marriage was consummated on the day of marriage itself - DNA test may not discharge burden of proof placed on husband under S.112(1)(d), however, it was a piecce of evidence to establish case of husband - Hence order directing wife to subject herself to DNA test along with child could not be found fault with.

In the instant case, the contentious issue between the parties and the decision thereupon has a direct bearing on the legitimacy of the child born during the continuance of the marriage. Having regard to the nature of the proceedings in the main O.P., undoubtedly the issue of paternity of the child is also a necessary issue for effective adjudication of the controversy in between the parties. May be that the DNA test, even if reveals that the child was not born to the husband, would not decide the core question in the main O.P. whether the wife was pregnant by some other person at the time of marriage itself. It is also true that the DNA test by itself would not discharge the burden of proof placed on the husband under Section 12(1)(d) of the Hindu Marriage Act. However, undoubtedly, it is a piece of evidence to establish the case of the husband. Hence, it is a deserving case where the DNA test could be directed to be conducted. It is not contrary to the conclusive proof enjoined under Section 112 of the Evidence Act and does not suffer from any error of law or fact. For the aforesaid reasons, the order under Revision directing the revision petitioner/wife to subject herself to DNA test along with the child does not warrant interference by High Court under Art.227 of the Constitution of India. (2005)4 SCC 449 - Distinguished.	 [Para 30,31,32]

heading: Divorce on mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce on mutual consent - Parties to marriage filing various civil and criminal proceedings against each other - Transfer petition filed by wife in Supreme Court - Notice of hearing by S.C. - Parties agreeing to amicably put an end to all disputes - Accordingly compromise deed entered into and produced in court along with petition for divorce by mutual consent - Court having satisfied that marriage had irretrievably broken down allowing petition for divorce under S.13-B in exercise of its powers under Art.142 of Constitution and also directing dismissal of all pending cases as having become infructuous - Constitution of India, Art.142. (Paras 6,7,8)

heading: Divorce
Desertion
Proof of
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Desertion - Proof of - Wife leaving matrimonial house - Ill-treatment by husband and his family members - Husband and his family members arrested by police - Willingness shown by wife to return to to matrimonial house - Wife making efforts in that direction - Wife filed suit for restitution of conjugal rights - This shows wife never had any intention to desert husband or abandon conjugal domicile - Court below finding consistency in evidence of wife while husband's evidence inconsistent with regard to ill-treatment - Court below rightly refused decree for divorce - Second appeal dismissed.	(Para 6)

heading: Maintenance
Enhancement of
Inflation cost formula
Applicability
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Enhancement of - Inflation cost formula - Applicability - Rs.600/- as maintenance was fixed from 3-7-87 - Cost of living index has risen since then and maintenance would now be payable at Rs.2400/- p.m. - Maintenance fixed at Rs.2000/- p.m. - Held enhancement by taking cost inflation factor cannot be faulted with.	(Paras 3, 5)

heading: Irretrievable break down
HeadNote.description: Irretrievable break down - Marriage took place on 5-3-91 and wife deserted husband on 22-10-99 and started living with her parents - She did not return even after death of husband's father for his last rites and also did not attend marriage ceremony of brother-in-law - Parties were living separately for 14 years and there was no possibility of reunion even though wife was willing to join her husband if he stayed away from his parents - Wife had filed complaint after a lapse of 7 years from marriage complaining about torture by mother-in-law and brother-in-law during initial year of marriage - Complaint was filed after petition for divorce was filed by husband- Held both the parties had crossed the point of no return and hence family court was justified in granting decree for divorce - Husband directed to pay Rs.1 lakh by way of permanent alimony in addition to Rs.50,000/- already granted by Family Court.	(Paras 16,21,27)

heading: Cruelty
Rel.on. [Para 20]
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Expression "cruelty" would include mental harassment, torture and any conduct which would cause an apprehension to the life of the wife in matrimonial home as a result of behaviour of husband.

There cannot be duality of opinion that the expression "cruelty" would include mental harassment, torture and any conduct which would cause an apprehension to the life of the wife in the matrimonial home, as a result of behaviour of the husband. All said and done, finding on the question of cruelty can not be rendered without there being appropriate pleadings and required quantum of proof. The petitioner did not give specific instances regarding inhuman conduct of the husband. Indeed, he did not object for her further education and she completed graduation in Arts while in the matrimonial house. It is pleaded by the petitioner that all ornaments which were given by her parents were taken away by the respondent-husband. Not only that she failed to state the nature of ornaments and the period with reference to date and time of alleged incident regarding taking away of her ornaments by him but there is no whisper in her deposition regarding such incident. It appears that such allegations have been made without any substratum and just to carve out some incident regarding the ground of cruelty. It cannot be ignored that the statutory requirement of proof regarding alleged cruelty and necessity of pleading with required particulars can not be done away with, though some flexibility in this behalf is available in so far as matrimonial cases are concerned. 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 313 - Rel.on. [Para 20]

heading: Cruelty
Non-consumation of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Non-consumation of marriage - Husband suffering from paranoid Schizophrenia and had attempted to commit suicide - Wife was 24 years of age when got married and marriage lasted for four to five months only when she was compelled to live matrimonial home - Parties have since been living separately for 13 years - Both of them crossing the point of no return and wife's stay with respondent would be injurious to her health - Wife had done her Ph.D. and husband was not gainfully employed anywhere - Husband refused to submit to medical examination and left his deposition incomplete during trial and did not appear before trial court or High Court - Held, this was a fit case for interference and reversal of findings of courts below in order to relieve appellant from shackles and chain of respondent and let her live her own life, if nothing less but like a human being.

The legal concept of cruelty which is not defined by statute is generally described as conduct of such character as to have caused danger to life, limb or health (bodily and mental) or to give rise to reasonable apprehension of such danger. The general rule in all questions of cruelty is that the whole matrimonial relations must be considered, that rule is of a special value when the cruelty consists not of violent act but of injurious reproaches, complaints, accusations or taunts. It may be mental such as indifference and frigidity towards wife, denial of a company to her, hatred and abhorrence for wife or physical, like acts of violence and abstinence from sexual intercourse without reasonable cause. It must be proved that one partner in the marriage however mindless of the consequences has behaved in a way which the other spouse could not in the circumstances be called upon to endure, and that misconduct has caused injury to health or a reasonable apprehension of such injury. There are two sides to be considered in case of cruelty. From the appellant's side, ought this appellant to be called on to endure the conduct? From the respondent's side, was this conduct excusable? The court has then to decide whether the sum total of the reprehensible conduct was cruel. That depends on whether the cumulative conduct was sufficiently serious to say that from a reasonable person's point of view after a consideration of any excuse which the respondent might have in the circumstances, the conduct is such that the petitioner ought not be called upon to endure. As to what constitutes the required mental cruelty for purposes of the said provision, will not depend upon the numerical count of such incidents or only on the continuous course of such conduct but really go by the intensity, gravity and stigmatic impact of it when meted out even once and the deleterious effect of it on the mental attitude, necessary for maintaining a conducive matrimonial home.   [Para 37,38]

Where the parties are young and the mental disorder is of such a type that sexual act and procreation of children is not possible it may furnish a good ground for nullifying the marriage because to beget children from a Hindu wedlock is one of the principal aims of Hindu Marriage where sanskar of marriage is advised for progeny and offspring. Spouses owe rights and duties each to the other and in their relationship they must act reasonably. In every case where cruelty exists it is possible to say that the spouse at fault has been unreasonable. The list of cruelty, therefore, should be breach of the duty to act reasonably, whether in omission or commission, causing injury to health. Such a list avoids imputing an intention where in fact none may exist. Further all such matters are foresight, desires, wishes, intention, motives, perception, obtuseness, persistence and indifference would remain relevant but merely as matter of evidence bearing upon the requirement to act reasonably or as aggravation of the matters charged.					          [Para 43,45]

heading: Petition by husband for divorce on ground of cruelty and desertion
HeadNote.description: Petition by husband for divorce on ground of cruelty and desertion - Allegation that appellant wife often used to quarrel with him and his family members because she wanted to live separate from them - She also used to frequently visit her parents - Once 10-12 gundas came, they assaulted husband, and took away the wife forcibly to her parent's house - Husband made several efforts to bring her back but she refused - She admitted that if she and her child was paid maintenance she was agreeable to divorce - Divorce decree granted on ground of desertion upheld.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Application for - Such an application cannot be considered before expiry of statutory period of six months. 1997(11) SCC 490, II(2005) DMC 51 and (2002)10 SCC 194 - Ref. to.	(Para 10)

heading: Petition for divorce by husband
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce by husband - Cruelty and desertion alleged - Wife wanted to live separately and away from husband's joint family at Bhandup against her promise to live with joint family made before marriage - She denied physical relation with husband and caused him physical and mental torture - She left matrimonial home and went to her parents house at Borivali when she was seven months pregnant- From there in a couple of days she went to Pune to reside with her maternal uncle who was a divorcee - When husband called on her at Pune he was abused by her uncle - Husband ultimately purchased a separate premises to save matrimonial life but the wife refused to come back and demanded divorce - Counter allegations of wife were vague and not substantiated - Held husband was entitled to grant of divorce on ground of cruelty and desertion.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Maintenance
Claim for children
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Claim for children - Right to claim maintenance is conferred only on husband or wife - It is impermissible to grant maintenance to children of the parties - Their remedy is under S.125 of Cr.P.C. and Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act.	(Para 7)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - On ground of infidelity and loose moral character of wife - Further allegation that son was born though he had not visited wife for more than a year and was on duty in the Army - Behaviour of wife with in-laws was alleged to be rough and rude - All the allegations were denied by the wife - Held differences between the parties were so deep rooted that there was virtually no possibility of reconciliation and only remedy which was appropriate was to grant divorce.

It is not the policy of law to break up homes but a house which is torn as under by constant strifes and bickerings is a hell and must be broken up. It is in this perspective that the dispute should be visualized. Looked at, from this point of view, the only remedy which seems appropriate, is to grant divorce. In such matters, the paramount consideration should be the welfare of the family. The provisions of Hindu Marriage Act are wide enough to provide legal justification for the same. We can resort to principle of cruelty enunciated in sub-clause (1-a) of Clause 1 of Section 13 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 and it could be said that the conduct of the wife was cruel enough to give rise to such suspicions and misgivings on the part of the husband. We need not be categoric or specific about it, but the husband had, his own reasons to suspect the fidelity of his wife. He even denied the legitimacy of the son born to her with the allegations that he has not visited his wife for more than a year before the birth of the son.   [Para 12,13]

heading: Divorce
Petition by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband - Wife left matrimonial home seven months after marriage - Started living with her parents in Gujarat where she gave birth to a son - She was working as teacher in Govt. service and earning Rs.7,000/- p.m. - Her husband was staying in Bombay and earned Rs.1,400/- p.m. - She did not return to matrimonial home even during long vacations in summer month - Husband had denied her statement that he used to go and stay with her in vacations - Held, such a course of conduct over a long period indicates total abandonment of marriage and cannot be justified on ground of monetary consideration alone as a reasonable cause to desert - It also amounts to wilful neglect of the husband by the wife - Decree of divorce confirmed.	(Para 5)

heading: Divorce
Irretrievable breakdown
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable breakdown - Wife suffering from bronchial asthama - Husband was a citizen of USA and settled in New York which has extreme cold climate - Husband pursuing his career as a performing artist since 1981 - Marriage took place in November, 1989 and from 1991 they were living separately poles apart in New York and India - Both visited Nepal after marriage but wife had asthamatic attack in the acute winter at Nepal - Husband proceed to New York and she joined him later on - However she was unable to stay at New York or Los Angeles due to climate and had to return to India - There was no reunion between the parties since 1st week of January, 1991 - Held irretrievable breakdown can be inferred warranting dissolution of marriage.		(Para 20)

heading: Cruelty
What amounts to
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - What amounts to - Mismatch of personalities and friction that may occur on account thereof is not a cruelty.

Mismatch of personalities and friction that may occur on account thereof between the husband and wife is not essentially a cruelty.

Cruelty is not a term which could be fitted into specified yardsticks.  Some acts which are just routine or casual could be a grave act of cruelty to others.  It would depend upon facts of a given case whether these acts were 'cruel' to the subject person, and such person has to prove as to how he suffered due to said acts which were to him or her acts of mental cruelty.			 [Para 21,23]

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Wife not co-operating in consummation of marriage without any reasonable cause to do so inspite of attempts by petitioner during period of her stay with him - Amounts to both physical and mental torture - Petitioner losing all future hope of wife's coming back for leading conjugal life - Decree of divorce upheld.	(Para 5)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Husband producing income-tax returns - Computation of taxable income must be seen in its entirety and only net income cannot be considered.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Permanent alimony
Claim by wife
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Claim by wife - Fact that wife was suffering from epilepsy was not disclosed at time of Settlement of Marriage and till marriage was performed - Four days after marriage when both of them were allowed to stay with each other after "Satyanarayan Pooja" husband discovered that wife was suffering from epilepsy and hence marriage was not consumated - Next day wife's father was approached and father took away the daughter - Subsequently decree for nullity of marriage was passed ex parte - Held, in the facts and circumstances of the case order of permanent alimony in favour of appellant wife could not be passed.	(Para 4)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Validity
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Order of family Court as to rights of parties over joint property - Validity - Said property not given to couple at the time of marriage but was acquired by their own efforts - Could not be subject matter of an order of Family Court. (1997)7 SCC 500 Rel. On.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Mental cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Mental cruelty - Allegation that husband is keeping another lady as his wife - Proof - Father of wife deposed that he himself had visited and noticed presence of another lady at the flat where husband is residing - Evidence of interested witness, held, not reliable - Wife could have examined any of the neighbours to substantiate said allegation - Even otherwise, neither the source of information nor the date of alleged visit was stated in evidence - Unsubstantiated allegations by wife, amounts to mental cruelty - Husband entitled to divorce on that ground.

2003(3) ALL MR 777 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 38, 42, 45, 46)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
Enhancement
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Grant of - Wife and major children - Enhancement - Maintenance granted by Court below to wife and two children @ of Rs.1,000/-p.m. each - Application in 2002 for enhancement to Rs.2,000/- each p.m. - Allowed by Court below - Appeal by husband contending that children not entitled to maintenance - Held, admittedly children have crossed age of minority and become major - Major children do not fall within scope of S.26 of the Act and hence are not entitled to any maintenance - Maintenance granted earlier by trial Court has to be dispensed with automatically by necessary implication - Order of the Family Court modified accordingly - Children can work out their remedies in appropriate Court by appropriate proceedings as permissible under law.

Section 26 of the Act specifically ordains that interim maintenance can be granted to the minor children only. The object of the legislation is obvious to the effect that during the pendency of the litigation, either under Section 13 or under Section 9 of the Act between the spouses, the minor children shall not be subjected to destitution and neglect. In other words, there shall not be any hardship to the minor children, in any manner whatsoever, during the pendency of disputes between the parents. Therefore, contention of learned Counsel appearing for the husband that the husband, who is father and natural guardian of the children, need not maintain the children, since the same is not provided under Section 25 of the Act, cannot be accepted.	 [Para 17,19]

heading: Dissolution of marriage by custom
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage by custom - Custom must be specifically pleaded and established by person propounding such custom - Parties belonging to Hindu Vellala Gounder Community - Absence of pleading that marriage could be dissolved by executing a document in the form of an agreement - No satisfactory evidence let in to prove custom prevalent in the community or procedure to be followed for dissolving marriage - Agreement was signed only by the husband - Held in the circumstances marriage cannot be said to have been dissolved on the basis of the document executed. 2002(2) ALL MR 264 (S.C.) Rel. on.	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Can be dissolved only on grounds mentioned u/s.13 - Decree of divorce cannot be purchased for consideration with or without consent of other side - In appeal from order of restitution passed in a suit for dissolution on ground of cruelty and desertion Court dissolving marriage on husband agreeing to pay lump sum maintenance and expenses of marriage of the daughter - Such an order cannot be defended on ground that parties had barely lived together for four months and decree was passed with consent of parties.	(Paras 5-8)

heading: Divorce
Irretrievable break down
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable break down - Spouses living separately for over nine years - Criminal cases were instituted by wife against husband under Ss.498-A, 406, 420, IPC - Complaints were also made with employer of the husband where he was working - He had to resign - Held break down being irreparable divorce could not be withheld.			(Paras 24, 25, 27)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - Wife alleged to be suffering from schizophrenia - Team of doctors treating her stating that although she was suffering from "illness of schizophrenic type", did not show symptoms of psychotic illness and had responded well to treatment and can very well continue marital relationship with family support - Further she had not only completed MBBS but also a diploma in medicine and was continuously working as a Government Medical Officer - Held, High Court was justified in setting aside order and decree of divorce - Decree of restitution of conjugal rights granted in favour of wife.

Under Hindu law, marriage is an institution, a meeting of two hearts and minds and is something that cannot be taken lightly. Life is made up of good times and bad, and the bad times can bring with it terrible illnesses and extreme hardships. The partners in a marriage must weather these storms and embrace the sunshine with equanimity. Any person may have bad health, this is not their fault and most times, it is not within their control, as in the present case, the respondent was unwell and was taking treatment for the same. The illness had its fair share of problems. Can this be a reason for the appellant to abandon her and seek dissolution of marriage after the child is born out of their union? Since the child is now a grown up girl, her welfare must be the prime consideration for both the parties. The two parties in this case must reconcile and if the appellant so feels that the respondent is still suffering, then she must be given the right treatment. The respondent must stick to her treatment plan and make the best attempts to get better. It is not in the best interest of either the respondent or her daughter who is said to be of adolescent age for grant of a decree of dissolution of marriage as prayed for by the appellant. 	     [Para 23]

heading: Application for enhancement of maintenance
HeadNote.description: Application for enhancement of maintenance - Change of circumstances viz. promotion in service - Fit case for enhancement of maintenance. 			(Paras 5 to 7)

heading: Waiver of
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Statutory period of one year - Waiver of - For filing a petition u/S.13-B, parties cannot be allowed to invoke S.14.

The statutory period of one year required to be maintained by the parties for filing a petition under Section 13-B of the Act are independent of the provisions contained in Section 14 of the Act. Section 13-B when read is a complete Code in itself and, therefore, for filing a petition under Section 13-B of the Act, the parties cannot be allowed to invoke Section 14 seeking waiver of the statutory period of one year from separation for filing a petition under Section 13-B of the Act.   [Para 7]

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Allegations that wife expected husband to live away from his parents and created scenes in the house - She often used to leave house and stay with her parents and when husband went to bring her back he was humiliated - She did not come back from parent's house when her mother-in-law had chest pain - Held allegations made against her cannot be termed as physical or mental cruelty and single instance of assault on husband by his in-laws cannot be termed as cruelty - Divorce refused.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Allegation not proved
HeadNote.description: Cruelty and desertion by wife - Allegation by wife that her, husband had illicit relations with his brother's wife - Allegation not proved - Wife not allowing sexual access and left matrimonial home on her own - Efforts, to bring her back failed - Held husband was entitled to grant of divorce on ground of cruelty and desertion.			(Paras 7, 10, 11, 14)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Wife lodging FIR against husband and his family members under Ss.498-A, 506, 406/34, IPC - Further she filed petition under S.125, Cr.P.C. for maintenance - Husband and his parents had to surrender and get themselves bailed out - Case of cruelty at the hands of wife made out - However considering the fact that her daughter aged 8 years was living with wife and economic status of the husband, conditional decree of divorce granted by directing husband to pay a lump sum alimony of Rs.10 lac to the respondent wife.		(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Cruelty - Both trial and appellate Court finding that husband has failed to establish cruelty on part of wife - However, in view of serious allegations by both parties decree of judicial separation was passed - No appeal filed by husband - In application by wife decree of divorce granted to husband by Division Bench of High Court - Supreme Court observed that on the basis of the proven facts Trial Court was more inclined to believe wife, whereas learned Single Judge of High Court found both parties to be at fault - Hence middle path of judicial separation had been accepted - Consequently, there was no compelling necessity, independently placed before Division Bench to justify reversal, of the decree of judicial separation - In such circumstances it was wholly inappropriate for the Division of High Court to have granted a decree of divorce to the husband - Appeal allowed and order passed by single judge of High Court restored.			(Paras 21, 24, 27 to 30)

heading: DNA Test
Appeal pending
HeadNote.description: DNA Test - Dismissal of petition for divorce by husband - Appeal pending - Child born out of wedlock during pendency of petition for divorce - Paternity of child not disputed by husband - He, however, during pendency of appeal applying for DNA test by making it a prestige issue - Held there was presumption in favour of legitimacy and belated application for DNA test during pendency of appeal could not be allowed.			(Para 9)

heading: Divorce
Desertion and cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Desertion and cruelty - Appellant failed to prove either - However marriage is, both emotionally and practically dead - Both parties living apart for 14 years making acrimonious allegations against each other in the litigation embarked upon by both the parties - No possibility of retrieval of marriage - Held, continuance of such marriage would itself amount to cruelty - Court in exercise of its powers under Art.142 disolving marriage subject to appellant paying a sum of Rupees two lakhs by way of permanent alimony and Rs.25,000/- as costs of appeal. (1995)2 SCC 7 - Rel. on.			(Paras 7, 10-12)

heading: Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - No reconciliation was possible as relations were damaged seriously - Lost faith in each other - After decision by Family Court wife had converted to Islam, had married and was having a male child - Held it was not advisable to direct parties to stay together and no interference with judgment of trial court was called for. 			(Paras 18, 23)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Application for enhancement of maintenance - Application pending before Court which decides the suit for divorce - Held, when application for enhancement of maintenance amount filed by wife was pending in the Court it was its duty to go into that question and dispose of the said application before the suit for divorce is disposed of by it.	(Para 8)

heading: Dissloution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissloution of marriage - On ground of mental cruelty - Husband abandoning his wife and son - He did not bother about his wife for nearly 18 years - Wife was working as staff nurse from much prior to marriage - Husband was working as a worker in a cotton mill - Twelve days after birth of male child father of husband died - Wife was unable to attend funeral - Ill-will started from this incident - Husband was more interested in her salary and when she refused to hand-over salary he deserted her - He did not look after either his wife or child - Marriage was both emotionally and practically dead - Held wife was entitled to decree of divorce. (1998)1 SCC 105, (1993)4 SCC 232, (1994)1 SCC 337 - Rel. on.			(Paras 12, 17, 19)

heading: Maintenance
Income of wife
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Income of wife - Rival contentions as to income of wife - Lower court granted maintenance considering nature of employment of wife as Shikshan Sevak and salary certificate - No interference required in writ jurisdiction - No need to go into rival contentions more so in the light of interim order granted in the matter - With a view to affording opportunity to the husband to move trial court for modification, variation or setting aside the order under challenge, matter remanded to the trial court.	(Para 11)

heading: Divorce petition
Dismissal of
Appeal against
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Dismissal of - Appeal against - Respondent wife made several attempts to comply with decree of restitution of conjugal rights - Ample evidence to show that appellant husband not just showing disinclination to resume cohabitation, but blocking every attempt of respondent at cohabitation - These acts can be called positive wrongs amounting to misconduct within mischief of S.23(1)(a) of the Act - Dismissal of husband's divorce petition on said ground, held, proper. 
1981 Mh.L.J. 917,AIR 1984 P & H 161, AIR 1977 SC 2218 Ref. to.(Para 10)

heading: Cruelty and desertion
Mental cruelty
