HeadNote.description: Cruelty and desertion - Mental cruelty - Cumulative effect of facts and circumstances emerging from evidence on record is to be taken into consideration - On facts held, conduct of wife complained of was not so serious but could be treated as ordinary wear and tear of married life - Marriage could not be said to have been irretrievably broken down. (Paras 15, 17)

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Petition for nullity of marriage - With Alternative prayer for divorce on ground of cruelty - Filed within one year of marriage - Maintainability - Held, said alternative prayer is neither contrary nor inconsistent hence, can be entertained by the Court - However, practice to file a petition for nullity and put an alternative prayer for divorce giving a go-bye to the statutory provision of S.14, should be deprecated.

The petition was not filed for divorce under S.13(1) (ia) of the Hindu Marriage Act on the ground of cruelty. S.14 is applicable to a petition for divorce which is filed under Section 13 of the Hindu Marriage Act and not a petition for nullity under S.11 or 12. Nullity of marriage is altogether of different status than divorce. Therefore, if there is a prayer for nullity of marriage, the petition is to be presented within one year as sub-Section 2 of S.12 lays down that no petition for annuling a marriage on the ground specified in Clause (c) of Sub-Section 1 shall be entertained if (i) petition is presented more than one year after the force has ceased to operate or as the case may be, the fraud has been discovered. Thus, the petition was filed not under Section 13 for divorce but, for nullity under S.12. Filing of the petition within one year from the discovery of the fraud or after the force has been ceased to operate is mandatory and, therefore, the petition was rightly filed within time under Section 12. However, in the said petition, there is an alternative prayer for divorce on the ground of cruelty. In the petition, there are averments in respect of the instances of cruelty and, therefore, alternative relief of divorce is prayed as the marriage was consummated between the parties. Alternative prayer of divorce in the petition for nullity is neither contrary nor inconsistent and can be entertained by the Court. In the instant case, Family Court is not found at fault taking view that the Court when heard the matter and the evidence of the parties was recorded found that the parties were residing separately since March-2007, i.e. for more than four years so bar under Section 14 will not come in the way, though petition was presented within one year from the date of the marriage. One important point is also to be noted that if a party wants to seek an alternative relief for grant of decree of divorce in a petition for nullity of marriage filed within one year, then it will be cumborsome for the party to file another petition for divorce after one year. This leads to multiplicity of the proceedings. Hence, the prayer for divorce can be made alternatively in the petition for nullity if filed within one year. If nullity prayed, itself makes an exceptional hardship. Needless to mention that after all it is left to the Judge, Family Court to consider whether the parties have an exceptional hardship and primafacie the petition can be entertained for nullity under Section 12(1)(c). There should not be routine practice to file a petition for nullity and put an alternative prayer for divorce under Section 13 giving a go-bye to the statutory provision under S.14 of the Hindu Marriage Act.
AIR 1992 Karnataka 372 Disting.  [Para 16]

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - Husband alleging that wife failed to discharge marital obligations as she was mentally ill - Proof - Husband producing consent letters written by wife wherein she had consented to second marriage by Husband as she was incapable of discharging marital obligations because of her mental illness - No medical treatment provided by husband - Held letters did not appear to be genuine and were written at instance of appellant and disentitled him for dissolution of marriage by a decree of divorce.

If one person is mentally ill, then it is beyond expectation that she will write something voluntarily and if the person is not mentally ill, then letter written by her shows that they are not genuine and they have been written at the instance of the appellant or some other person and such person has succeeded in taking the documents in favour of the appellant with a view to take benefit of those documents. The respondent is legally wedded wife, of the appellant and the appellant was under obligation to provide better treatment to her in case of her illness instead of taking the same as a ground for dissolution of marriage by a decree of divorce, but the present appellant has not adduced any evidence to show that he has provided adequate medical treatment to her. This fact itself shows the cruelty committed by the appellant upon the respondent, disentitling him for dissolution of marriage by a decree of divorce.   [Para 9,10]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Wife suffering from mental disorder - Used to cry in the night and beat her husband and son - Also made attempts to commit suicide - She herself admitted in her examination-in-chief that she was suffering from mental disorder - Medication prescriptions brought on record supporting her mental disorder - Decree of divorce granted.	(Para 7)

heading: Decree of divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Decree of divorce - On ground of mental cruelty to husband - Challenge - Appellant wife entered into compromise for receiving permanent alimony and dissolution of marriage by mutual consent - She received half of the agreed amount and also filed a divorce petition - But back out of compromise and also withdrew divorce petition subsequently - she however did not return the money - Thus, she dishonestly induced respondent to part with huge sum of money - She was also having relations with another man - She even involved respondent and his family in criminal cases u/Ss.406, 498A IPC - Appellant left no stone unturned to make respondent's life miserable - Held, appellant misused her right and subjected respondent to mental cruelty - Hence, decree of divorce in favour of respondent, held, proper. 
(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Marriage
Proof
HeadNote.description: Marriage - Proof - Certificate of Sarpanch showing that the Respondent is the first wife of the deceased, held, cannot be accepted in the absence of any evidence from public record.		(Para 10)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description:
Custody of children - Two daughters aged 17 and 11 years preferring to stay with father and not even willing to meet mother - They even refused to attend mediation centre - Held, in the circumstances visitation cannot be made possible by order of the court. 

An order of custody of minor children either under the provisions of The Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 or Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956 is required to be made by the Court treating the interest and welfare of the minor to be of paramount importance. It is not the better right of the either parent that would require adjudication while deciding their entitlement to custody. The desire of the child coupled with the availability of a conducive and appropriate environment for proper upbringing together with the ability and means of the concerned parent to take care of the child are some of the relevant factors that have to be taken into account by the Court while deciding the issue of custody of a minor. What must be emphasized is that while all other factors are undoubtedly relevant, it is the desire, interest and welfare of the minor which is the crucial and ultimate consideration that must guide the determination required to be made by the Court.     [Para 14]

The children having expressed their reluctance to go with the mother, even for a short duration of time, we are left with no option but to hold that any visitation right to the mother would be adverse to the interest of the children. Besides, in view of the reluctance of the children to even meet their mother, leave alone spending time with her, we do not see how such an arrangement, i.e., visitation can be made possible by an order of the court.     [Para 15]

heading: Passed against wife
HeadNote.description: Ex parte decree of divorce - Passed against wife - In application for setting aside ex parte decree, wife stating various reasons including illness of her child - No prejudice is caused to either party by setting aside decree - Various reliefs prayed by respondent wife can be considered in main petition - Respondent wife would suffer grave, irreparable loss if ex parte decree is not set aside - It may lead to infringing wife's right to be heard in main petition - Order to set aside ex parte decree, held proper. 			(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Parties arrived at settlement - No application u/S.13B was filed to convert divorce petition - No clarification as to access to child is there in order - Order passed on application of husband praying for honouring settlement term and ending matrimonial disputes is liable to be set aside - Matter remanded back. 	(Para 12)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Grant of instant decree - During pendency of appeal petition for divorce by mutual consent filed - Statutory waiting period of six months can be waived by appellate court in suitable case.

In the instant case as per terms of the Consent Terms, both the parties had agreed to dissolve their marriage by mutual consent as contemplated under section 13B of the Hindu Marriage Act. It was agreed between the parties that both the children would be in the custody of respondent/wife. It was also recorded that it was difficult for them to cohabit as husband and wife since they were living separately for more than 5-6 years.

Held that in the aforesaid circumstances, petition filed for divorce by consent under S.13-B need not be kept in abeyance for a minimum period of six months. The said period of six months can be waived when an application for divorce by mutual consent is filed during the pendency of the appeal. The intention of the Legislature was to provide minimum period of six months for re-thinking of the parties. If the said provision is made applicable to the appellate court, it would be powerless to grant that relief on the basis of the application filed in the lower court because 18 months must have elapsed by the time the matter reached the appellate forum although the parties are still fighting relentlessly in the appellate Court and, therefore, the said waiting period of six months can be waived in a suitable case by the appellate court because it could not have been the intention of section 13-B(2) that the appellate court should, in each case, insist that the parties should go through the futile and meaningless ceremony of again waiting for completion of six months.

Consequently, when the appellate court is fully satisfied on the proved facts that marriage tie should be severed by mutual consent immediately since the parties have been living separately for more than the time prescribed under section 13B and that they have been fighting for sufficiently long period and, in such a case, section 13B does not impose any fetter on the powers of the court to grant instant decree of divorce.

AIR 1986 A.P. 167 Foll.

2008 (4) Bom. C.R. 539 Disting. 					    [Para 3,4,6,7,12,15]

heading: Matrimonial matters
HeadNote.description:
Matrimonial matters - Both parties to marriage are minors - While setting aside marriage High Court observing that wife can proceed against appellant under S.376 of Penal Code in criminal proceedings - Held, High Court was not justified in making such observation - Duty of courts in such matters, stated.

The only relief sought by the respondent was for restitution of conjugal rights and maintenance for the child. The High Court had rightly observed that even an illegitimate child would be entitled to maintenance. The High Court failed to appreciate that essentially it was seized of a matrimonial dispute between the parties. The attitude of the Court in such matters should be to encourage and persuade the parties to reconcile. It was an ideal case to be referred to conciliation/mediation. Paramount duty of the Court in matrimonial matters should be to restore peace in the family. The attitude should not be to further encourage the parties to litigate. Only as a last resort the Court ought to decide the suit/proceeding on merits.						      [Para 8]

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Proof
Wife opposing
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - Adulterous conduct of wife alleged out of which son was born - Proof - Husband insisting on DNA test of himself and son - Wife opposing - High Court ordering test - Held, High Court was fully justified in ordering DNA test.

In the instant case the respondent-husband had made clear and categorical assertions in the petition filed by him under Section 13 of the Hindu Marriage Act, alleging infidelity. He has gone to the extent of naming the person, who was the father of the male child born to the appellant-wife. It is in the process of substantiating his allegation of infidelity, that the respondent husband had made an application before the Family Court for conducting a DNA test, which would establish whether or not, he had fathered the male child born to the appellant-wife. The respondent feels that it is only possible for him to substantiate the allegations levelled by him through a DNA test. But for the DNA test, it would be impossible for the respondent-husband to establish and confirm the assertions made in the pleadings. The direction issued by the High Court, was fully justified. DNA testing is the most legitimate and scientifically perfect means, which the husband could use, to establish his assertion of infidelity. This should simultaneously be taken as the most authentic, rightful and correct means also with the wife, for her to rebut the assertions made by the respondent-husband, and to establish that she had not been unfaithful, adulterous or disloyal. If the appellant-wife is right, she shall be proved to be so. In case, she declines to comply with the direction issued by the High Court, the allegation would be determined by the concerned Court, by drawing a presumption of the nature contemplated in Section 114 of the Indian Evidence Act, especially, in terms of illustration (h) thereof. This course has been adopted to preserve the right of individual privacy to the extent possible. Of course, without sacrificing the cause of justice. By adopting the above course, the issue of infidelity alone would be determined, without expressly disturbing the presumption contemplated under Section 112 of the Indian Evidence Act. Even though, undoubtedly the issue of legitimacy would also be incidentally involved.            [Para 11,12]

heading: Condonation
HeadNote.description:
Appeal against decree of nullity - Delay of 338 days - Condonation - Respondent husband re-married after expiry of period of limitation for filing appeal - Keeping in view that decree of nullity was passed on ground of impotency which may affect prospects of appellant wife's second marriage, held, in such situation appeal to be decided on merits and to be maintained. 

If the appeal is not decided on merits and if the decree is confirmed only because the husband has performed the second marriage, it will affect not only status of appellant as wife, but as the decree is on the ground of impotency, such decree will also affect upon the prospects of her second marriage and in such situation, there will be irreparable loss to the respondent-wife if the appeal is not decided on merits.
AIR 1985 Kerala 220, 2007 (1) BCJ 582, AIR 1988 SC 839 Ref. to.     [Para 8]

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Divorce application by husband - Dismissed by family court - Appeal - Wife applying for restitution of conjugal right - Court granting restitution while rejecting relief for decree of divorce - Inspite of repeated attempts husband refusing wife to enter matrimonial house for co-habitation - He thus disentitled himself for a decree of divorce - He also neglecting to pay interim maintenance - Held his appeal against order of family court denying divorce was liable to be dismissed - Husband directed to provide suitable accommodation or a lumpsum of Rs.15 lakhs with interest thereon and pay Rs.10 lakhs as a lumpsum amount for maintenance. (Paras 18, 24, 25, 48, 50)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Petition on ground of cruelty pending - Therein husband also had prayed for dissolution of marriage - Pending this petition compromise arrived at - Wife fully complying with consent terms to her detriment - Parties filing petition for divorce by mutual consent - Subsequently husband withdrawing consent on ground that he was not allowed access to children as agreed upon - Real reason, however, was his inability to meet children as he was in jail and children were not willing to meet him - Held, in such a situation Family Court was right in not allowing husband to unilaterally withdraw consent and granting decree of divorce by mutual consent.			(Paras 16, 17, 20)

heading: Decree of divorce
Appeal against
HeadNote.description:
Decree of divorce - Appeal against - Appellant wife submitting that uncorroborated evidence of respondents ought not have been believed - Held, there is no rule that divorce cannot be granted on evidence of party alone - That apart, false allegation against husband in regard to demand of dowry amounting to cruelty - Entitles him to decree of divorce. 
2007 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 65  Ref. to.
2008(6) ALL MR 937 (S.C.), AIR 2004 Culcutta 161 Disting. (Para 15)

heading: Transfer of case
HeadNote.description: Transfer of case - Divorce petition filed by husband at Palghar, Thane - Wife now staying with her parents at Lucknow - Wife seeking transfer of case to Lucknow - In facts and circumstances of case, petition pending at Palghar, Thane, directed to be transferred to Family Court at Lucknow.	(Paras 2, 3)

heading: Claim of maintenance
HeadNote.description: Claim of maintenance - Respondent wife would be entitled to the same standard which she enjoyed while she was in the matrimonial home. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Interim Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim Maintenance - Family Court on basis of entries of deposits in husband's bank account awarded maintenance to wife - Explanations of those entries was given in this writ petition and same was not available before Family Court - Matter is liable to be remanded for de novo consideration on basis of explanation.	(Para 3)

heading: Transfer of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Transfer of proceedings - Divorce petition filed by husband before Court at one place - Wife seeking for transfer of proceeding to Court having jurisdiction in another place - Request for transfer, granted by Court after looking into convenience of the wife. AIR 2002 SC 396 - Rel. on.	(Paras 8 to 10)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Between husband and wife, occasionally there may be some exchanges of wits/anger/ jokes or satire, that itself may not be treated as an act of cruelty - On some occasion even if respondent-wife has said to appellant-husband that he is mentally ill, that itself cannot be treated as a ground for dissolution of marriage - Uttering of some words here and there should not have been taken so seriously by appellant-husband - Held, in a matrimonial life, little adjustment from both sides is the need of the hour.			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Second wife claiming maintenance from estate of her deceased husband - Second wife contracting marriage fully conscious of fact that first wife was living - Spouse of such bigamous marriage cannot seek maintenance by invoking S.25.		(Para 6)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Six months waiting period - Provision is directory and not mandatory - Period of six months can be waived and hearing preponed. AIR 1986 AP 167 - Rel. on.	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Interim maintenance
Grant of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of - Validity - Husband was directed to pay consolidated sum of Rs.3,00,000/- per month to wife - Admittedly while passing impugned order Court has not considered or scrutinized all material adduced - Order of Court hence set aside - Matter remitted back to Court to decide application for interim maintenance afresh in accordance with law. (Paras 4 to 6)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of six months' waiting period sought on ground that respondent wife has to move to New York for seeking a job and resettlement in life - Having regard to educational background of parties and entire facts and circumstances, court invoked jurisdiction u/Art.142 - Statutory period of six months waived, marriage dissolved.	(Paras 3, 8, 9)

heading: Annulment of marriage
Leading of evidence
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Leading of evidence - Respondent seeking annulment of marriage on ground of alleged unsoundness of mind of the petitioner - Report from Civil Surgeon awaited - Therefore, Petitioner did not lead evidence - Petitioner applying for being permitted to lead her evidence only after the said report was placed on record - Held, the petitioner would be entitled to adduce her evidence.                (Para 4)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Husband seeking divorce on ground of cruelty - Wife's complaint u/s.498A dismissed by Criminal Court - Held, filling of a false complaint itself amounts to cruelty within meaning of S.13(i)(a) - Hence, a decree of divorce to be granted to husband.        (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Cruelty can be of both kinds, physical and mental - Making wild and baseless allegations against respondent/opponent in writing itself amounts to a mental cruelty - Mental cruelty may be far more damaging than the physical cruelty.

Making wild and baseless allegations against respondent/opponent in writing itself amount to a mental cruelty. Cruelty can be of both kinds, physical and mental. It is physical when the body is injured and it is mental when feelings and sentiments are wounded. It causes mental pain, agony, emotional stress, frustration, suffering or fear of such a magnitude that it severs the bond of love and affection between the wife and the husband as a result of which it becomes impossible for the party, which has suffered, to live with the other party. In other words, the party who has committed the wrong, is considered by the other party as not worthy of living with. Mental cruelty may be far more damaging than the physical cruelty. 2006(4) ALL MR (S.C.) 190 - Ref. to.  (2002)2 S.C.C. 296 - Rel. on.  [Para 8,10]

heading: Divorce
Alleged against wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of mental cruelty - Alleged against wife - Husband expected wife to wear saree and to stay in joint family, attend domestic work, even when he resides away at distance of 450 km from his house - No wife would prefer to stay in absence of her husband with in-laws at such long distant place at cost of her matrimonial life - Days have gone when expectation of husband and in-laws to wear only saree and not Punjabi dress were fulfilled by wife - Considering present scenario, husband was expected to change his mind and not to allow such unreasonable expectations to intervene in smooth sailing of matrimonial life - Further, if wife finds photograph of lady in pocket of her husband, she is bound to know reason for keeping such photograph by husband - Nothing was wrong if wife countered husband for such act - Divorce cannot be granted. 	(Para 21)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Dismissal of petition for - Challenge - Parties entered into agreement for dissolution of marriage by obtaining decree from court - Respondent-wife never denied her signature on agreement nor its execution or contents - Both parties pursuant to agreement filed application u/S.13B - No submission by wife before Family Court during cooling period of six months that she wants to wriggle out of application u/S.13B and does not want to give consent for mutual divorce - Parties living separately for last four years - Their marriage has become irretrievable - Wife did not appear for hearing on any of dates despite service of notice nor filed any affidavit before Court - It shows wife was also not interested in keeping marital relations with husband - Therefore, dismissal of divorce petition held not proper - Decree of divorce granted. 		(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - On ground of non resumption of cohabitation even after passing of decree of restitution of conjugal rights - Husband is residing in USA for job purpose since last more than 10 years - Decree for restitution of conjugal rights was obtained by wife by making counter claim in divorce petition filed by husband - However, no efforts were taken by her for execution of said decree though she has filed proceedings for execution of maintenance order - Whereas husband had written several letters and also sent e-mails to convince wife to resume cohabitation at USA, but she had not responded - Only excuse offered by wife for not resuming cohabitation is that she cannot be expected to join husband at USA - Not acceptable - Since beginning, even prior to his marriage, husband is residing in USA and accordingly after marriage, wife had joined his company in USA - Even at time of filing counter claim, wife was aware that husband is residing at USA - No such condition put up by wife in her counter claim nor any discussion or evidence led on that aspect - Therefore, finding of Family Court that wife was since beginning knowing that if she had desire to resume cohabitation then it was to be at USA, proper - Divorce was granted. (Paras 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Sought on ground of events subsequent to dismissal of restitution application - Parties living separately since 1997 i.e. sometime after their marriage - Restitution petition filed by husband decided on 27/3/2001 and finally got dismissed by High court as withdrawn on 26/3/2009 - Divorce petition filed by husband on 17/3/2011 as he had lost hope for restitution - Wife had filed criminal case against husband and in laws in 1998 of which they got acquitted on 12/12/2008 - Acquittal of husband from criminal case, itself is a ground to presume cruelty at instance of wife - Even if act of wife presumed to be condoned, subsequent events of filing appeal, revision and SLP against judgment of acquittal, would amount to continued cruelty by wife - Hence, husband entitled to decree of divorce based on subsequent acts.			(Paras 18, 19, 21, 23, 24)

heading: Divorce
Dismissal of petition
Challenge
Hence, appeal allowed
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Dismissal of petition - On ground that as parties had already taken customary divorce, they should have approached the court u/S.13B - Challenge - Appellant wife sought divorce on ground of cruelty and evidence led by her also remained uncontroverted - Merely because proceedings were not contested in right earnest by respondent-husband and plea taken in written statement that customary divorce already taken place - It cannot be said that allegations made in petition were not established and divorce cannot be granted on alleged grounds - Only responsibility of court u/S.23 is to ensure that petition is not presented or prosecuted in collusion with respondent - No such findings recorded by trial court while dismissing divorce petition - Hence, appeal allowed - Decree of divorce granted. 			(Paras 4, 5, 8, 9, 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty and desertion allegedly caused by wife - Wife had abortion without consent of husband and stayed for long time with her parents - However, she lived with husband thereafter for 2 years - Held, even if husband suffered cruelty, same stood condoned by him by his own act and conduct - Husband cannot seek divorce on said grounds. (Para 11)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Trial court accepting husband's case of cruelty and granting divorce - High Court rejecting divorce treating instances of cruelty cited as normal wear and tear of married life - Held, if wife abuses husband as being born from a prostitute, summons police on false and flimsy grounds, makes it impossible for any close relatives to visit house - It cannot be termed as normal wear and tear of married life - Divorce granted. 	(Para 7)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Wife living separately from her husband - Started suffering from breast cancer - Approached husband for divorce by mutual consent on receiving Rs.12,50,000/- as full and final settlement - Held, it is duty of husband to take care of health and safety of wife - Husband directed to pay immediately rupees five lakhs and pending petition to be heard after wife is cured or within six months whichever is earlier. 

In the peculiar facts of the present case settlement, was nothing but a contract to dissolve the marriage, the Court has to satisfy itself that the contract is legal and valid in the eye of law. It seems that the petitioner-wife agreed for divorce by mutual consent on the condition that the respondent-husband will pay her Rs.12,50,000/- as full and final settlement. The petitioner-wife is suffering from such a disease which has compelled her to agree for the mutual consent divorce. The fact that petitioner-wife is ready for the mutual consent divorce after knowing about her medical condition raises a suspicion as to whether the consent obtained from the petitioner-wife is free as required by law for granting the decree of divorce by mutual consent. The Contract Act provides that consent is said to be free when it is not caused by "undue influence" as defined in Section 16 of the Act. The contract is said to be induced by "undue influence" where the relations subsisting between the parties are such that one of the parties is in a position to dominate the will of the other and uses that position to obtain an unfair advantage over the other. The principle of pre-exiting duty states that if a party to a contract is under a pre-existing duty to perform, then no consideration is given for any modification of the contract and the modification is therefore voidable. After the petitioner is fully cured from the disease or within six months whichever is earlier, the Family Court at Hyderabad, where the divorce petition is ordered to be transferred, shall take up the case along with a fresh application that may be filed by the parties under Section 13B for divorce by mutual consent. [Para 18,19,21]

heading: Enhancement
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance of minor child being in custody of mother - Enhancement - Father earning an income of Rs.10,000/- p.m. - Income of mother Rs.3,500/- p.m. - Contribution of spouses towards maintenance of child need not be equal - Rather, should be proportionate to their earnings and according to needs of child - Maintenance amount of Rs.800/- p.m. payable by father found insufficient to meet needs of child aging 3 yrs. - Enhanced to Rs.1,500/- p.m..

S.26 of Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 gives the Court power to make such provisions for custody, maintenance and education of child as it may deem "just and proper".  The settled position of law on the matter is that the welfare of child is the paramount consideration for the Court, though other matters such as income of both parents, needs of child and the like may also be considered.  [Para 3,4]

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description: Desertion - It is not necessary for the deserting spouse to leave the home in order to constitute desertion - If one spouse by his or her words compels the other side to leave the matrimonial home or stay away therefrom, without reasonable cause, the former would be guilty of desertion, though it is the latter who is seemingly separated from the other - The ejection of the other spouse from the home with the intention not to co-habit equally constitutes desertion - This is the principle of 'Constructive Desertion'. AIR 1957 SC 176 - Rel. on.			(Para 4)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Petition for enhancement of amount - Respondent husband having significant assets - He had a quite unusual number of bank accounts - Some of those were at premier multinational banks requiring high minimum balances to be maintained - He also subscribed to various services such as holiday time share - Though respondent suppressed evidence and information of his true income, considering his spending patterns, the holdings in his bank accounts and life style he maintained, his income considered much higher - And held, wife is entitled to be maintained in a life style consistent with that of her husband - Amount of maintenance enhanced from Rs.10,000/- to Rs.25,000/- p.m. 	(Para 25)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Irretrievable break down of marriage - Living apart for nine years - No hope for reconciliation - Decree of divorce can be passed without further waiting for statutory period of six months as per S.13-B(2).	(Para 13)

heading: Declaration of Marriage to be null and void
HeadNote.description: Declaration of Marriage to be null and void - Petition under S.12(1)(c) filed within 2 weeks of alleged marriage by husband - Wife having no menstruation regularly and concealed her marriage with other person - No consummation of marriage - Consent of husband obtained by force and fraud at time of marriage - Marriage between the parties, held, rightly declared by Family Court to be null and void. 2006(2) ALL MR (S.C.) 102 - Ref. to.	(Paras 26 to 30)

heading: DNA test
Revision
HeadNote.description: DNA test - For determination of paternity of child born during marriage, on ground of possibility of removal of misunderstanding between parties and bring them to terms, scope - O.P. filed by husband for divorce on alleged ground of petitioner-wife leading adulterous life - Dispute between parties in relation to identity of child allegedly born out of adulterous life of petitioner - Petition filed by husband under Section 45 Evidence Act read with Section 151, CPC to subject petitioner and her son including himself to undergo DNA test, allowed - Revision - Held, absence of express provision empowering Court in this regard, does not preclude a Court from invoking its inherent jurisdiction to pass such order so as to secure ends of justice - Such medical examination may not only lead to truth of the matter but may also lead to removal of misunderstanding between parties and perhaps may bring them to terms - Further, in her cross-examination, petitioner expressed no objection for subjecting herself to DNA test - No illegality or irregularity in impugned order. Evidence Act (1872), Ss.45, 112, 4. Civil P.C. (1908), S.51.	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Nullity of marriage
HeadNote.description: Nullity of marriage - Concealment of material fact while entering marriage - Husband alleged that wife had love affair with a Muslim boy prior to marriage which fact was concealed - Apart from oral evidence, husband also produced diary of wife wherein some love messages in Urdu language were written - Notebook of wife wherein she wrote "sorry" to husband out of her guilt, also an evidence against her - Counter allegations made by wife that husband had prior love affair with a colleague, that he is of suspecting nature and that he had written in Urdu to create false evidence - Same is not substantiated even by taking name of girl - Her allegations are in fact inconsistent - If husband is infidel, he would not care about character of wife - Wife initially denied but later on admitted that diary belongs to her - She is not trustworthy - She never filed petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Case of husband cannot be disbelieved merely because said Muslim boy was not examined - Case of husband more reliable than wife - Husband entitled to decree of nullity. 			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - Conduct of wife not inviting husband on their son's marriage - Also falsely complaining the Superior Officers of husband about his character leading to inquiries against husband and his posting to another place - Amounts to cruelty on part of wife.

Cruelty under Hindu Marriage Act is advisedly undefined. However, the 'Cruelty' can either be physical or mental or both. Physical cruelty is easy to prove but the mental cruelty depends on various factors. It is the total behavior, which is to be taken into account. If one spouse's consistent behavior shows lack of respect, understanding, faith and also reveals acts intended to- and which have caused pain, discomfort or brought disrespect or disrepute, to the other spouse, such behavior would constitute cruelty. Trust, mutual respect, understanding and commitment sustain marriages. A certain level of tolerance and accommodation to each other's propensities, preferences and habits is expected. One cannot and should not expect one's spouse to possess identical tastes, temperament and behavioral traits as oneself or one is used to with one's family members. Over sensitivities to innocent behavior, attitudes of having one's way only cannot but result in mismatch and matrimonial discord. Spouses are expected to be supportive to each other and pillars of strength in adversities.  [Para 21,23]

The respondent was posted to Kashmir, at the time when that state bristled with terrorism. The husband as a senior officer of CRPF was expected to shoulder his official responsibilities. In this context the wife's letters to his seniors telling them that he had an inclination towards a Kashmiri family, leading to inquiries and his transfer to Assam, caused him serious trouble and embarrassment. It could be reasonably assumed that it affected his standing in the eyes of his staff and colleagues, and this bound to cause him humiliation and anguish, as there was no truth in the complaint. Beside this the undertaking given by appellant in police station that "she will not fight" is the admission of the appellant of her conduct.  [Para 24]

In this case the contemporaneous evidence on record is thus important to ascertain the conduct of the appellant towards the husband. The false complaints leading to enquiries, transfers, face loss in front of seniors and staff and subordinates, clearly show that this behavior of the appellant had lowered the husband's reputation and professional standing. There was absence of trust, faith and respect for respondent. Appellant has been persistently cruel towards her husband not only during their stay together but also during the divorce proceedings which is apparent from the fact that she had leveled the unsubstantiated charges of adultery against him. 2000(1) ALL MR 83 (S.C.), 2002(1) ALL MR 953 (S.C.) Rel. on.   [Para 26]

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Waiting period of 6 months - Petition for divorce u/S.13 remained pending for 3 years - Thereafter parties withdrew their allegations against each other and filed a petition u/S.13-B for divorce by mutual consent - Respite period of 6 months as contemplated in S.13-B(2) already undergone by parties - Therefore Family Court is to pass necessary orders u/S.13-B without waiting for expiry of 6 months.

Section 13-B was by the Amendment Act 68 of 1976 enacted to allow the parties to file Petitions for divorce by mutual consent upon the grounds stated therein which are that they are living separately and are not able to live together. Section 13-B contemplates a Petition initially filed by the parties. It would be filed upon the premise that the parties have decided that they could not and hence have not lived together but have lived separately.

The provision under Section 13-B(2) is the respite period granted to such parties to reconsider their decision to dissolve their marriage. The provision lays down what a Judge is required to do if the Petition is not withdrawn before 6 months to 18 months statutory period when it remains on the file of the Court. If a Petition under Section 13 has remained on the file of the Court for as long as 3 years as in this case, the parties require no respite period to reconsider their decision to dissolve a broken marriage in which various allegations based upon the grounds under Section 13 have been made and later withdrawn upon seeing reason.

The parties, who settle their dispute, are not required to be penalised for settling their disputes. They have gone through the process of divorce in the Court for more than 6 months when the Petition remained  pending. They have only modified their views upon settlement of the dispute. Hence such a Petition, though for divorce by mutual consent which would be granted to both parties and not for divorce upon the  grounds under Section 13 of the Hindu Marriage Act, has lived through 6 months period in the Family Court already. Consequently, that period of 6 months, which the law requires the parties to undergo while the Petition remains pending, is undergone; only the acrimonious allegations are withdrawn so that the divorce can be granted amicably to both rather than to  one of the spouses. 		 [Para 6,7,11]

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty - Maintenance - After having filed a divorce petition on ground of cruelty, it is not open for the husband to say that wife should come back to him and stay with him and that because she refuses, she cannot be granted maintenance - Husband getting salary Rs.21,170/- per month - Held, he could easily shell out at least the sum of Rs.10,000/- per month for his wife and daughter - Grant of maintenance to wife, therefore, cannot be held to be improper.	(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Divorce
Validity of
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grant of, on ground of cruelty - Validity of - Evidence on record proved that wife treated husband with cruelty by making wild allegations that he is having relationship with some lady - Wife failed to prove said allegation - Also accused the husband of having HIV and she refused to keep physical relationship with him and also caused injury on his head by assaulting him with rolling pin and abused him and his parents - When wife makes allegations against her husband that he is having extramarital relationship and if she is not able to prove same, it causes cruelty to husband - Grant of divorce on ground of cruelty, proper. 	(Paras 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
Petition by wife
Rejection
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by wife - Rejection - Appeal and prayer for maintenance pendente lite - Non-payment by husband despite several opportunities granted - No issue of financial constraints, rather he did not want to pay the same - Such conduct of husband amounts to cruelty - Wife entitled to decree of divorce.			(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Petition by wife
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Petition by wife - Marriage between husband and wife was second marriage for both of them - It was solemnized merely with a view to have company - Pleading and evidence of parties show that said experiment failed miserably and it was not possible for both parties to live happily under one roof - Wife leveled several allegations against husband and painted very dark picture of her husband - If husband was so bad, there was no reason for wife to file petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Also most of statement made by wife in petition had been falsified by her evidence in cross-examination - Decree for restitution of conjugal rights cannot be granted. (Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Petition by alleged wife - Respondent was already divorced and residing with her ex-husband for betterment of her children - She failed to prove that she was subsequently married with appellant - No one attended said marriage nor celebrated with proper ceremonies - There was no cohabitation between parties - They were never recognized as husband and wife by society - Even there was no live-in relationship between parties - Merely because there was exchange of calls between parties, that does not mean they were husband and wife - They never stayed under one roof as husband and wife - There was no iota of evidence on record about valid marriage between parties - Respondent not entitled for restitution of conjugal rights. 2015(3) ALL MR 365 Rel. on.	(Paras 15, 16, 17, 20, 22, 23, 24, 26, 30, 31, 33)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Wife used to give repeated threats to commit suicide and once tried to jump from terrace - Once she pushed her husband from staircase resulting in fracture of forearm - Used to slap and assault him - Misbehaving with colleagues, relatives, landlord and husband's parents - Not attending to household chores and not serving food to husband - Not taking care of baby - Forced husband to live separately is rented house - Repeated fits of insanity, abnormal behaviour - Held High Court was not justified in admitting wife's appeal in the face of the above factual details culled out from pleadings of both parties - Decree of divorce granted.  (Paras 17, 23, 24)

heading: Void marriage
Ancestral coparcenary property
HeadNote.description: Void marriage - Right of children of void marriage - Ancestral coparcenary property - Children of void marriage are not entitled to share in ancestral coparcenary property of family of father - They can claim share only in ancestral property falling to share of their father and that too only after his death. (2003)1 SCC 730 - Rel. on.	(Para 6)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Fixed at Rs.40,000/- p.m. - Husband depositing Rs.40 lakhs - Wife pleading that Rs.40 lakhs will not invariably fetch interest of Rs.40,000/- p.m. - Court directed husband to pay further amount of Rs.15 lakhs to the wife to ensure return of Rs.40,000/- p.m. 	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Conversion of petition under S.13(1)(ia) into S.13B for divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Conversion of petition under S.13(1)(ia) into S.13B for divorce by mutual consent - Wife living in USA and husband in Mumbai - As counselling had not taken place representation of wife by her father as power of attorney holder not allowed by Family Court - Held Family Court ought to arrange for E-counselling and E-verification by video conference. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Petition filed on 1.6.2011 - Parties living  separately from date of their marriage on 26.3.2011 - Residing separately for more than a year and respondent wife was working in Canada - Parties agreed to file dissolution petition in mediation proceedings - Marriage subsisting on a tenuous thread because of six months cooling period out of which four months had already expired - Decree of divorce by mutual consent granted by invoking power under Art.142 of the Constitution - Constitution of India, Art.142. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - Wife has been unreasonably giving threats to the husband of committing suicide and attempting to commit suicide - It amounts to cruelty - Husband entitled to decree of divorce.

Where a wife every time gives a threat of committing suicide, such conduct has to be held to be amounting to cruelty and a conduct which is annoying. This is not a dispute of a normal nature between husband and wife and can not be treated as a normal wear and tear. 2010(2) Mh.L.J. 891 - Disting.  [Para 10]

Also, in the instant case, the wife was living with her parents, there was no occasion of her being subjected to cruelty and in spite of that she filed a complaint after eight years that she was harassed. It is, therefore, apparent that the said complaint could be in all circumstances be said to be false one and such filing of a false complaint under Section 498-A of I.P.C. has to be treated as one more act of cruelty. Since respondent/wife has subjected the husband to cruelty, a decree for divorce must, therefore, follow.  [Para 11,13]

heading: Decree of restitution
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Decree of restitution - Challenge - On ground that respondent-wife was suffering from mental disorder - No evidence produced to prove such mental disorder - Rather, respondent's degree of post graduation in sociology and PGDCA, showing that she was capable to do any work or study as a normal person - Appellant did not establish that mental disturbance of respondent is not curable - Held, if respondent is under mental depression or under medical illness, it is duty of her husband to protect his wife and treat her mental condition in discharge of his matrimonial obligations - Appellant is completely negligent on his part towards wife and declined to cohabit with her - Therefore, decree of restitution held proper. 	(Paras 17, 18, 19)

heading: Divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Challenge - Appellant-wife had lodged complaint against respondents-husband and in-laws within 3 months of marriage in September, 2006 alleging dowry demand - Whereas at same time undivided share of husband's family property was transferred in her name - Said complaint not taken further by her - Second complaint lodged with same allegations at Agra in April-May, 2007, much after filing of divorce petition by husband - Father of wife obtained warrant, as result, her father-in-law and brothers-in-law taken in private jeep from Pune to Agra and were detained in police custody for 2-3 days - Mother could not be arrested for want of lady constable - No reason to implicate brothers of husband who were students and residing at college campus - Husband was required to obtain protective order from High Court in proceeding u/S.498A - She also broke open lock of matrimonial house with prior intimation to police - On another occassion she had raised hue and cry in Society on finding the door locked - Considering totality of circumstances, wife and her father in most calculative manner humiliated husband and his family with intention to disrepute to his family - Conduct of wife affected physical and mental health of husband and his family - Decree of divorce, held, proper - Moreso becasue parties living separately nearly for 11 years and no efforts taken by wife to restore matrimonial bond which is now beyond repair. 1994 (1) SCC 337 Ref. to. (Paras 19, 20, 21, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29)

heading: Divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce on ground of cruelty - Fact before marriage show that appellant had refused to marry respondent - Respondent filed false cases under provisions of Dowry Prohibition Act and u/Ss.323, 504, 506 of IPC - He was pressurized to marry and was threatened that on his refusal to marry he will be killed - Appellant consented and cases instituted were withdrawn - Two years after wife again filed criminal case u/S.498A r.w. S.34 IPC against appellant, his parents and sisters - They were released on bail - Appellant filed divorce petition against wife and during pendency of petition complaint u/S.498A came to be disposed of and appellant and his parents and sisters were acquitted on merits - Held, appellant was entitled to seek divorce on ground of cruelty u/S.13(1)(i-a).

If the complaint filed by the wife against the husband under section 498-A of IPC and other related provisions was dismissed on merits and the husband and his family members are acquitted, it was clear that the complaint filed by the wife against the husband was a false complaint. In my opinion, filing of such complaint itself which create mental trauma on the husband and the complaint which was seriously prosecuted by the wife by leading evidence of several persons and bringing the said complaint to its logical conclusion which ultimately resulted in acquittal of the husband and his family members clearly amounted to the cruelty committed by the wife upon the husband. The respondent having filed a false complaint alleging offence under section 498-A and other provisions of IPC in which the appellant and his family members were acquitted and thus the appellant was entitled to seek divorce on the ground of cruelty under section 13(1)(i-a) of the Hindu Marriage Act.

2002(1) ALL MR 953 (S.C.), 2015(2) ALL MR 435 (S.C.), 2015(1) ALL MR 95 Rel. on.  [Para 41,43,51]

heading: Interim maintenance
Claim by husband
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Claim by husband - In a suit for divorce filed by wife - Medical evidence show that husband met with accident and suffered permanent disability - However, it does not show that husband is totally disabled from doing any work or that he has to only take bed rest - On one hand medical certificates produced by husband suggest that he is advised strict bed rest and on other hand he is regularly attending Court proceedings - Husband appeared to have exaggerated his position to avail maintenance from wife - Husband does have earning capacity by way of taking computer classes or tuitions - Wife is directed to pay interim maintenance till final disposal of suit only. (Paras 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty, claimed by husband - Evidence on record shows that wife thrown utensils on husband and threatened him of committing suicide - It further shows that wife was not happy with meager income of husband and not willing to do daily household duties on ground that she was more educated than husband - Wife failed to cross-examine husband on said grounds of cruelty and evidence of husband was unchallenged - Wife admitted in cross-examination that parties did not cohabit happily in matrimonial home - No communication from wife after separation that she desired to live with husband - Also wife played fraud on husband by depicting false date of birth - Husband proved that wife treated him with cruelty - Husband entitled for divorce.	(Paras 12, 18, 19)

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of statutory period of six months - Application for - Parties have been residing separately after solemnization of their marriage - Their marriage is dissolved by customary divorce and they applied for decree of divorce in Court - Parties contended to have arranged for their respective second marriages and that passage of six months would cause undue hardship to petitioners - However, no such particulars are given in application - Moreover, neither Civil Court nor even High Courts can pass orders before statuary period given in S.13B - Application rejected. 2014(3) ALL MR 60, 2008(1) ALL MR 227 Disting.	(Paras 16, 23)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Without referring parties to family Court to wait for mandatory period prescribed u/S.13B of H.M. Act - There was an irretrievable breakdown of marriage between parties - Parties do not have issues - In such situation, requiring parties to go to family court to seek decree of divorce would be lengthy process - By invoking jurisdiction u/A.142, marriage between parties is dissolved so as to enable them to commence their respective life afresh. 	(Para 3)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of statutory period - Parties lived as husband and wife only for few days and living separately for more than 5 Years - All the other litigations put to an end - Husband has to go to his work place in USA and wife has to think of her future - Therefore, statutory period waived by invoking jurisdiction u/Art.142.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Divorce petition
Settlement between parties
Divorce petition dismissed
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Settlement between parties - During pendency of petition, parties settled their disputes and undertook to withdraw allegations made against each other - Divorce petition dismissed - Parties are allowed to take recourse by filing petition u/S.13B for decree of divorce by mutual consent - As parties are not residing together for more than six months, they allowed to apply for waiver of period of six months and for immediate disposal of petition. 			(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Maintenance
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Enhancement of - Considering increase in net salary of husband from Rs.63,842/- to Rs.95,527/-, Court enhanced amount of maintenance from Rs.16,000/- p.m. to Rs.23,000/- p.m. - S.25(2) of Hindu Marriage Act empowers Court to vary, modify or discharge order of permanent maintenance made u/S.25(1), considering change in circumstances of parties - Therefore, enhancement of maintenance held proper - However, since husband has child from second marriage, amount of maintenance of Rs.23,000/- p.m. reduced to Rs.20,000/- p.m. 	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), S.13
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), S.13 - Divorce order passed by Foreign Court - Writ petition for quashing of divorce order - On ground that order is without jurisdiction, having been obtained by fraud and being violative of rules of natural justice and provisions of Hindu Marriage Act - Held, adjudication of rights of petitioner and validity of foreign judgment, would involve disputed question of facts - As such petition not maintainable for enforcement of legal rights of petitioner against private respondent - It will be open to Court of competent jurisdiction to adjudicate upon validity of foreign judgment in the light of provisions of S.13 CPC.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Second marriage
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Second marriage - Declaration of illegality by interim order - Permissibility - Husband performed second marriage after decree of dissolution of marriage - Interim application filed in appeal against decree of dissolution of marriage - While considering application at interlocutory stage High Court should not pass final order declaring second marriage of husband illegal - Moreover, when appeal against decree of dissolution of marriage was pending - Interim order liable to be set aside.	(Paras 4, 5, 7)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husbund on ground of cruelty - Severe allegation of ill-treatment for dowry made against husband and his family members by wife in written statement - She also filed complaint u/S.498A IPC against them - However, said complaint was filed two days before filing of divorce petition by husband - Further, said complaint was also made against her sister in law who was not married in husband's family at relevant time - On one hand she filed complaint against husband and on other hand she filed petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Such unproved allegations leveled against husband and his family members, itself amount to cruelty - Decree of divorce passed. 	(Para 8)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of cooling period - In view of long separation of seven years between parties and several rounds of litigation the parties have gone throw, period of 6 months provided u/S.13B, waived off by exercise of jurisdiction u/Art.142.	(Para 3)

heading: Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - On ground of desertion by wife - Challenge by wife on ground that she could not comply with decree of restitution of conjugal rights passed in favour of husband due to non-co-operation by husband - No evidence produced to prove the same - No lack of bonafide reflected on the part of husband due to this reason - Moreover, husband proved that wife has left his company without any reasonable cause - Therefore, S.23 not applicable to the factual matrix of the case - Grant of decree of divorce, held proper.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Prayer for issuing direction to trial court to expedite disposal of divorce petition - Wife put her appearance only after she was ordered to be served by way of publication and thereafter about 13 adjournments taken for filing written statement - Even counsel on one occasion had been changed - Held, Statute itself mandatorily requires disposal of divorce petition preferably within 6 months - No prejudice would be caused to respondent wife if such directions are issued - Hence, directions issued accordingly. 2012 (8) RCR (Civil) 89 Rel. on. 			(Paras 2, 4, 6)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of unchastity of wife - Husband only pleaded that some of his tenants had seen wife with respondents in compromising position - No pleading in petition that wife had illicit relationship with three respondents nor as to who are tenants or persons that had witnessed same - Also, no mention as to time and period during which wife had maintained illicit relationship - Admission of respondent in written statement about his illicit relation with wife - Said respondent, working as electrician in printing press of husband - It is unbelievable that man would come forward to admit in legal proceedings that he has illicit relationship with wife of another man - Other witnesses also stated against wife but same was also not believable - Witnesses examined by husband are got up witnesses - Husband tried to make out concocted case against wife - Petition dismissed. (Paras 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of wife having been afflicted with disease of epilepsy - Held, epilepsy cannot be equated with unsoundness of mind or mental disorder as contemplated u/S.13(1)(iii) of Hindu Marriage Act - Decree of divorce cannot be granted on said ground.  (Para 10)

heading: Divorce
Ground of illness
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of illness - Spouse suffering from Hepatitis B which could be communicated by sexual access, is not a ground for divorce available u/S.13 of Act.

Cruelty which is contemplated under Section 13 as ground for divorce is that after the solemnization of the marriage, the respondent has treated the petitioner with cruelty. Cruelty must be a voluntary act of person who visits cruelty on the other. If a woman refuses sexual access, there are authorities to the effect that such a voluntary refual would itself constitute a cruelty and afford a ground for divorce. This is not a case where the woman is complained of as having denied sexual access to the husband. On the other hand, the apprehension of the petitioner is that if he has access to the wife, he will get infected with Hepatitis B. Section 13 provides for certain forms of illnesses in a spouse as affording a ground for divorce which include under Clause (iv) where the person has been suffering from a virulent and incurable form of leprosy and clause (v) states that a person has been suffering from venereal disease in communicable form. Both could be illnesses which could be transmitted by sexual access. These are the only two instances of illnesses, apart from mental illness, which afford a ground for a spouse to seek for divorce. A person suffering from Hepatitis B which could be communicated by sexual access is not a ground which is available under Section 13. 	 [Para 3]

heading: Permanent alimony
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Grant of - Family Court directed husband to pay permanent alimony of Rs. 15 lakhs to wife, while allowing his divorce petition - There was no finding on material issues like financial earning capacity of husband to pay alimony and also financial earning capacity of wife - No reason given for fixing permanent alimony - High Court also dismissed appeal against said order in limine - Order of Family Court and High Court set aside - Matter remanded to Family Court to decide quantum of payment of permanent alimony.			(Paras 15, 17, 19, 21)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of desertion - Parties were living separately for more than decade - All attempts of reconciliation through mediation have failed - There is absolutely no chance of both living together to continue marital life - To do substantial justice to parties, dissolution of marriage directed subject to payment of Rs. 10 lakhs by husband to wife and his daughter as permanent alimony and maintenance.	(Paras 11, 14, 15)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Rejection on ground that marriage involving a minor is void - Petition filed by wife on ground of cruelty and parties having 2 children - Held, presumption of marriage may arise even on proof of prolonged cohabitation - Impugned order set aside - Direction issued to Family Court to proceed further in accordance with law.			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Limitation Act (1963), Arts.136, 137 - Execution of decree/order of family court - Applicability of Arts.136, 137 of Limitation Act - Determination - As per S.28A of HM Act and S.18 of Family Courts Act, decree or order passed under HM Act or under FC Act are having same force and effect for its execution at par with decree or order passed by Civil Court itself -Therefore decree or order is allowed to be executed in same mode and manner as provided for execution of decree or order passed by Civil Court - Period of limitation for execution of decree or order made by Civil Court is 12 years as provided under Art.136 of Limitation Act - Art.136 is applicable to execution of decree/order of family court. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Wife not willing to reside in matrimonial home - Asking husband to send mother-in-law to old aged home - Held, insisting upon husband to live separate from his mother who is old aged and suffering from cardiac problem is by itself a cruelty - Petition of husband, allowed. 2016 ALL SCR 2113 Rel. on. 			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Petition u/s.13B
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Petition u/s.13B - Rejection on ground that parties have not mentioned reasons for their separation - Challenge - Held, whatever be the reason, it stands established that parties living separately and mutually agreed to dissolve their marriage - Ingredient u/S.13B stands satisfied - It is not for the court to probe into such reasons and decide as to whether parties were justified in living separately - Hence, impugned order set aside - Decree of divorce granted. 	(Paras 7, 9, 10)

heading: Divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Dismissal of petition and grant of decree of restitution in favour of husband - Challenge - Cross-examination of appellant-wife making it clear that appellant-wife is working at Jabalpur and her husband is working at Delhi - Husband wanted her to live with his parents and serve them which is not acceptable to appellant - Parties residing separately and never tried to live together or to maintain their relation as husband and wife - In such circumstances, grant of decree of divorce in favour of appellant, held just and proper. 2005(5) ALL MR 1012 (S.C.), 2008(5) ALL MR 963 (S.C.), 2014(6) ALL MR 400 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 8, 12)

heading: Divorce
Impermissible
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition on ground of cruelty u/S.13(1)(i-a) - Grant of decree on mutual consent u/S.13B - By merely treating an answer of husband in cross-examination as consent for divorce - Impermissible - There cannot be any decree for mutual divorce u/S.13B without considering three essential ingredients, namely, (i) spouses living separately for one year (ii) Cooling period of six months as provided u/S.13B(2) and (iii) joint petition by both parties - Impugned decree liable to be quashed and set aside.  2008(3) ALL MR 507, 2009(6) ALL MR 515 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 4, 5, 6)

heading: Annulment of marriage
Application for
Same falling u/S.12(i)(c)
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Application for - On ground of consent of petitioner being obtained by suppression of fact of mental illness of respondent-wife - Same falling u/S.12(i)(c) - Held, it is not necessary for petitioner to prove that mental disorder alleged is of incurable nature and it is difficult for him to live with respondent on account of the same - He needs only to allege and prove that certain material fact relating to mental illness of respondent has been suppressed and his consent was obtained fraudulently - And if the same had been disclosed earlier, he would not have given consent for marriage. 	(Paras 11, 16, 17)

heading: Interim maintenance
Grant of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of - Challenge - Petitioner-husband contending that he has lost his potentiality and earning capacity therefore removed from his job - However, evidence on record showing that he has worked in corporate world for 30 years - He is having better prospects than he was having in the job - His facebook profile showing that he is not sitting idly but working in Jhon Maxwell Team - Respondent-wife is not qualified as him and having no source of income - Merely because one time in her life about 20 yrs. back she was doing some job of stenographer, she cannot be denied her lawful claim for interim maintenance - Looking to status of parties and approximate earning of husband, amount of Rs.30,000/- p.m. granted by Trial Court, held not exorbitant or unreasonable. 			(Paras 10, 11, 22, 23)

heading: Decree of divorce
Necessity
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - On ground of wife suffering from mental disorder - Compliance with O.32 R.15 CPC - Necessity - Medical evidence showing that wife was taking treatment for mental disorder - In such circumstances, both Courts below were bound to hold enquiry as to whether wife was capable of defending herself or not - And if not, Courts were bound to provide assistance of Guardian-at-litem who can take care of defence of wife - If those provisions are not followed and decree is passed against person having mental disorder, it would be nullity - Both Courts below erred in completely overlooking mandates of O.32 R.15 while passing decree of annulment of marriage - Decree set aside and matter remitted back.  1972 ALLMR ONLINE 648, 1985 ALLMR ONLINE 66, 2003(3) ALL MR 1178 (S.C.), 2013(2) ALL MR 296, AIR 1957 Kerala 51, AIR 1954 Madras 810, 1999(2) ALL MR 404 (S.C.) Ref.to.	(Paras 8, 15, 17, 19)

heading: Interim maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of - Salary certificate of wife shows net income of Rs.28,335/- - Two children are taking education who were looked after by wife - Wife is required to maintain herself as well as take care of education of both children - It is also responsibility of father of children to ensure education of children is not affected due to financial constraints - Amount of Rs.5000/- granted as interim maintenance.	(Para 6)

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Application for - Filed by parties after they went through mediation and have decided to amicably settle matter - As per settlement, husband agreed to pay Rs.10 lakhs to wife in full and final settlement of all her claims and Rs.3 lakhs by way of FDR in name of daughter - Husband also agreed to contribute Rs.1 lakh at time of solemnization of marriage of daughter - In exercise of power u/Art.142 marriage between parties was dissolved. 	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Petition for divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce on ground of cruelty - Variance between facts alleged in petition and averments in court - Petition not stating anything about grounds of cruelty pleaded in the petition - What he stated in court was altogether different story - Held what was sought to the proved ought to be  first pleaded and in its absence petition must fail. (Para 8)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty and incurable unsoundness of mind of wife - Husband claiming that his wife was suffering from Schizophrenia which is incurable - Husband has not mentioned specific instances of abnormal behavior of wife - No certificate given by doctor that wife was suffering from incurable unsoundness of mind - Further parties entered into compromise in which husband admitted that he can cohabit with wife - Decree of divorce cannot be granted. 2008(5) ALL MR 963 (S.C.), 2012(1) ALL MR 473 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Restitution of conjugal right
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal right - Petition filed by husband after inordinate delay of 7 years - Held decree of restitution was misconceived.	(Para 8)

heading: Waiver
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiting period of 6 months - Waiver - Period of 6 months as contemplated in S.13B(2) is directory and not mandatory - It can be waived when there is no likelihood of reconciliation - Petitioner's marriage fixed with another man, so there is no chance of resumption - Waiver is necessary because date of marriage is fixed and prospective bridegroom would leave the country before 15 days of completion of 6 months - Waiver allowed. 2017 ALL SCR 1858 Rel.on.			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Nullity of marriage
HeadNote.description: Nullity of marriage - Petition on ground that consent of wife was obtained by force - Marriage was solemnized on 2.4.2012 - Wife claimed to have obtained customary divorce on 27.6.2012 - However, petition for nullity filed only on 27.3.2015 - Time limit of one year, lapsed - Wife also complained of cruelty but failed to prove it - Besides, plea of cruelty is inconsistent with plea of nullity of marriage - As against this, husband produced marriage certificate issued by Gurdwara in support of his plea that it was a runaway marriage in absence of parents - He had also obtained order of civil Court restraining wife from contracting second marriage - In said order also, customary divorce was disbelieved - No appeal or revision filed against said order - If at all any force was used against wife for marriage, she would have approached police authorities - Petition dismissed. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty by wife - Respondent wife had not disclosed about the two children borne prior to the marriage - FIR lodged by wife against petitioner and his parents for offence punishable u/S.498-A of IPC was quashed - Allegations by wife that the petitioner is a womanizer, drunkard and harassing her on the count of money borrowed from one moneylender, without supporting any evidence - Wife made complaint against petitioner to the Government hospital, where petitioner was serving in order to defame him - Acts of wife amounts to mental cruelty to husband - Grant of decree of divorce in favour of husband, proper. 2013 ALL SCR 993, 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1833 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 881, 2014(1) ALL MR 854, 2015(2) ALL MR 435 (S.C.), 2016(2) ALL MR 14, 2013(1) ALL MR 409 (S.C.), 2016(2) ALL MR 551 Rel.on. 			(Para 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Wife alleged to be hot tempered lady used to pick up quarrel on petty matters and used to torture husband by not preparing food - She also alleged to be torturing her father-in-law and husband by giving threats that she will commit suicide if ownership of ground floor of house is not transferred in her name - However, no specific instances quoted by husband in pleadings to show cruelty by wife - On contrary, allegation made by wife against husband of having illicit relations with tenant are proved by evidence of doctor of nursing home where tenant's child was born - Birth extract of tenant's child issued by Municipal Corporation shows name of petitioner as father of child corroborates evidence of doctor as well as wife - Wife proved illicit relationship of husband, whereas husband failed to prove cruelty by wife - Husband, not entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Para 12)

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description: Desertion - Marriage taking place on 11-03-1993 - On 12-04-1993 at the request of wife petitioner leaving her at residence of her aged uncle and aunt as they were not well - When he tried after a week to bring her back she refused to come back for no reason - Petitioner again tried after 2/3 weeks to pursuade her but she refused - Petitioner also informed Legal Aid & Advice Committee of his willingness to receive the wife but she showed her reluctance again - Since she refused to accept summons from the Bailiff case was decided ex-parte - Held pleadings along with evidence on record showed that Petitioner had made out case within meaning of S.13(1)(ib) and Family Court was not justified in assuming that wife could not think of living separate from her husband.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Ex-parte decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Ex-parte decree of divorce - Setting aside of in appeal u/O.41 with directions to parties to live as husband and wife - Appeal against, by second wife - High Court despite knowledge of marriage of husband with appellant-second wife, has not adverted to consequences thereof and has given directions in question, which may not be capable of due performance - Further, appellant-second wife was not party to appeal before High Court and said order was passed without hearing appellant - Order passed by High Court being without jurisdiction, liable to be set aside - Matter remanded to High Court for deciding appeal afresh after impleading appellant as party respondent. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12, 14)

headline:
Hindu Marriage Act (1955)S.13 - Civil P.C. (1908) O.41 R.1(d) O.9 R.13 - Ex-parte decree of divorce - Setting aside of in appeal u/O.41 with directions to parties to live as husband and wife - Appeal against by 2nd wife
Despite knowledge of marriage of husband with 2nd wife, HC not adverted to consequences thereof - Appellant-second wife not party to appeal before HC and said order was passed without hearing appellant - Set aside

heading: Divorce
By mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce - By mutual consent - Presumption of consent for divorce cannot be attributed to the party absent before trial court - As consent needs to continue till the date of decree of divorce u/S.13B(2) - Court has statutory obligation to hear the parties to ascertain their consent.  2009 ALL SCR 1804 Rel. on.	(Para 16)

heading: Territorial Jurisdiction of Family Court
