HeadNote.description: Territorial Jurisdiction of Family Court - Last residence together of spouses - After marriage couple residing in Nagpur in husband's parents' house - Husband proceeding to USA to pursue his career and wife following him to USA - Both after returning from USA residing in husband's parents' house in Nagpur - They can be said to have last resided in Nagpur and family court had jurisdiction to decide petition for restitution of conjugal rights filed by husband.	(Para 5)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Parties contracted love marriage against wishes of their parents - Wife asserted that she lived in matrimonial home for one month and then turned out for demand of dowry - Whereas husband contended that they did not stay together even for a single day - He alleged that, when parents of wife came to know of marriage, they confined her in their house and did not allow to meet her husband - Finding of court below that in a love marriage there is no occasion for demand of dowry, not based on sound reasoning - When marriage is against wishes of parents, chances of friction are galore - Going by assertions of husband, it is unnatural for him to sit quietly when wife was confined - Neither he reported matter to any authority nor filed petition for habeas corpus or restitution of conjugal rights - Allegations of wife rather appear to be true - Instead of ensuring comfort for wife in matrimonial home, husband joined in greed of his family to extract money from family of wife - This would qualify as "cruelty" - Wife entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Paras 11, 12, 13)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Wife allegedly assaulted husband and caused injuries to him - Proof - Uncorroborated evidence of petitioner-husband not sufficient - Copy of FIR filed against wife, not proved - NC case registered in police station against wife, also not proved - Incident of assault by wife, cannot be said to be proved - Vague evidence by petitioner regarding threat given to him and his parents by wife about sending them in jail, found unbelievable - Said threat does not amount to cruelty to him - Therefore, it cannot be said that wife had caused physical or mental cruelty to petitioner - Moreover, she cohabited with him, begotten a son and still willing to resume cohabitation - Husband held, not entitled to decree of divorce on ground of cruelty u/S.13(i)(i-a). 	(Paras 17, 20, 21, 22, 24)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty and desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty and desertion - Husband alleged that after marriage wife repeatedly used to visit parental house and with malafide intention to get separate maintenance allowance, refused to stay with him in spite of repeated request - General and vague allegations made without mentioning manner in which wife had ill-treated husband - Whereas as per wife, due to ill-treatment given by family members of husband, she started residing separately - In petition filed for maintenance, Court granted allowances to wife by holding that wife treated with cruelty and therefore, she has justifiable ground to reside separate from husband - Decree of divorce cannot be granted. 2008(5) ALL MR 963 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - Allegation in written statement branding the wife as unchaste woman having extra marital relations - Enumeration of instances and incidents - Is a grave assault on educated wife sufficient itself to constitute mental cruelty - Her claim is liable to be allowed - Subsequent offer to withdraw allegations from W.S. cannot absolve husband from being held liable for worst form of cruelty.

The position of law in this regard has come to be well settled and declared that levelling disgusting accusations of unchastity and indecent familiarity with a person outside wedlock and allegations of extra marital relationship is a grave assault on the character, honour, reputation, status as well as the health of the wife. Such aspersions of perfidiousness attributed to the wife, viewed in the context of an educated Indian wife and judged by Indian conditions and standards would amount to worst form of insult and cruelty, sufficient by itself to substantiate cruelty in law, warranting the claim of the wife being allowed. That such allegations made in the written statement or suggested in the course of examination and by way of cross examination satisfy the requirement of law has also come to be firmly laid down by Apex Court. 		 [Para 7]

It is futile to claim on behalf of the appellant that the withdrawal of allegations unilaterally by the husband, by filing an application for amendment of the written statement wiped out completely all those allegations for all purposes.	  [Para 10]

That apart, even the fact that the application for amendment seeking for deletion of the accusations made in the written statement was ordered and amendments carried out subsequently does not absolve the husband in this case, from being held liable for having treated the wife with cruelty by making earlier such injurious reproaches and statements, due to their impact when made and continued to remain on record. To satisfy the requirement of clause (i-a) of sub-section (1) of Section 13 of the Act, it is not as though the cruel treatment for any particular duration or period has been statutorily stipulated to be necessary. As to what constitutes the required mental cruelty for purposes of the said provision will not depend upon the numerical count of such incidents or only on the continuous course of such conduct, but really go by the intensity, gravity and stigmatic impact of it when meted out even once and the deleterious effect of it on the mental attitude, necessary for maintaining a conducive matrimonial home. If the taunts, complaints and reproaches are of ordinary nature only, the Courts perhaps need consider the further question as to whether their continuance or persistence over a period of time render, what normally would, otherwise, not be a so serious an act to be so injurious and painful as to make the spouse charged with them genuinely and reasonably conclude that the maintenance of matrimonial home is not possible any longer. A conscious and deliberate statement levelled with pungency and that too placed on record, through the written statement, cannot so lightly be ignored or brushed aside, to be of no consequence merely because it came to be removed from the record only. The allegations levelled and the incidents enumerated in the case on hand, apart from they being per se cruel in nature, on their own also constitute an admission of the fact that for quite some time past the husband had been persistently indulging in them, unrelented and unmindful of its impact. That the husband in this case has treated the wife with intense cruelty is a fact, which became a fait accompli the day they were made in the written statement. [Para 11]

heading: Maintenance
Claim not maintainable
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Claim for, by "illegitimate wife" - Claim not maintainable - Held, decisions of Bombay High Court upholding right of maintenance to "illegitimate wife" "faithful mistress" by liberal construction of word "wife" as contained in S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act cannot be said to be a good law and are required to be overruled to that extent.

It is fundamental principle of law that in order to claim a relief from the Court of law, there must be a legal right based on a legal status.  When the status of a woman as "wife" is not recognized by provisions of the Act, which confers the right for permanent alimony, she can not be entertained for grant of relief in the absence of recognition of her status by the Act.

If the construction of word "wife" is not accepted uniformly, for the purpose of same remedy provided in special legislation [Section 125 of Cr.P.C., 1973] and personal law, anomalous position may occur.  A woman who has been denied maintenance in a petition under Section 125 of Cr.P.C., 1973, for the reason that she is not "legally wedded wife", would successfully pray and obtain permanent alimony in total disregard of earlier judicial pronouncement, as also, provisions regarding legitimacy of marriage as contained in personal law.

Even while considering Section to be a "welfare legislation", it cannot be ignored that such a liberal construction, although may benefit the second wives, who are drawn into the form of marriage by keeping them ignorant about illegitimacy of the same, may encourage bigamous marriages with full knowledge and inspite of existence of a legislation in the field, preventing bigamous marriages.

For the reasons discussed above, with due respect, it is held that the decisions of the Bombay High Court, upholding right of maintenance to "illegitimate wife" [or "faithful mistress"] by liberal construction of word "wife" as contained in Section 25 of H.M. Act, cannot be said to be a good law and are required to be overruled to that extent. AIR 1988 SC 644 - Followed.  1987 Mh.L.J. 179 and AIR 1999 Bom. 127 Overruled.  [Para 21,24]

heading: Divorce
Dismissal of petition
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Dismissal of petition - Appeal - Appellant-husband seeking divorce on ground of desertion and cruelty - Cruelty alleged, for wife filing criminal case against husband in which he was acquitted - Couple lived together only for 86 days after marriage - Evidence showing that after December, 2002 appellant or his parents never met respondent in her father's house and despite having been informed about her child's birth they did not return to ask well being of both mother and child - Letter of respondent produced by appellant himself, also showing her urge to return to family of appellant with her girl child - Thus, desertion not proved - As regards criminal case launched by respondent, acquittal itself is no ground for decreeing suit on ground of cruelty - More particularly admission on part of appellant that his love for respondent was lost immediately after marriage inclines court to hold that respondent was forced to launch criminal proceedings to somehow force him to take her and her child back - And not for painting a bad picture of him before society - Held, a husband who leaves his newly wedded wife and even did not care to have a look at new born child, is himself guilty of cruelty - He does not deserve any relief - Appeal dismissed. 	(Paras 19, 20, 23, 24, 40, 42)

heading: Divorce
Ground of adultery
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of adultery - Application for conduct of DNA test - All three children are major by age - Not made parties to divorce proceedings - Not willing to give blood sample on ground of privacy - Denial by children cannot result in adverse inference against wife - Contesting parties are husband and wife and not children - Further, DNA test is not a direct evidence but a fact from which inference can be drawn - Children who are not parties to proceedings, cannot be ordered to undergo DNA test which may affect their reputation in society - Application of husband liable to be rejected. 2010(5) ALL MR 895 (S.C.), 2014(6) ALL MR 983 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 5, 6, 8)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of, to wife - Challenged by husband on ground that she has sufficient income and he is already paying maintenance granted u/S.125 Cr.P.C. - No material to show that wife is actually having permanent source of income - Husband has also failed to produce his salary slip or income tax returns to prove that his income is less than that claimed by wife - Interim maintenance granted u/S.125 Cr. P.C. of Rs. 2,000/- is not sufficient to satisfy bare necessities of wife - Grant of interim maintenance of Rs.3,000/- in proceedings u/S.24 of HM Act, proper. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11, 13)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of - To major unmarried daughter in proceedings u/S.26 - Validity - As per S.20 of Act, 1956 unmarried daughter who is unable to maintain herself can claim maintenance - Daughter was taking education and had no income of her own to sustain herself - Maintenance was granted to daughter in absence of application u/S.20 just to avoid multiplicity of proceedings - Grant of maintenance to major daughter, proper. 2006(1) ALL MR 211 Rel.on. 			(Paras 8, 9, 11, 13)

heading: Divorce petition
Dismissal
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - On ground of desertion - Dismissal - On ground that separation was at instance of husband and wife was always ready to cohabit - Parties living separately since last 20 years - Though wife claiming that she was always ready to cohabit with husband, not even a single attempt was made by her to recommence cohabitation nor any intention harboured to do so - No proceedings for restitution of conjugal rights filed by wife - Last communication between parties was 12 years back that too over phone - Conduct of wife shows that she has intention to bring cohabitation permanently to end - No hope of revival of marriage - Order dismissing divorce petition set aside. 			(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable breakdown of marriage by itself is not a ground under Hindu Marriage Act on which alone a decree of divorce can be passed - Irretrievable breakdown of marriage can only be a circumstance which the Court can take into account when cruelty is proved and blend them together. 	(Para 21)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Husband and wife staying separately for more than 2 years and there is no hope of reunion - Settlement has arrived between parties and husband agreed to pay Rs.18 lakhs towards full and final settlement of claim of wife - In exercise of inherent powers, divorce by mutual consent granted and criminal proceedings against husband and his family members, quashed - Transfer petition disposed of accordingly. 	(Para 4)

heading: Divorce
Legality
Accusations not proved
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Petition filed by husband on ground of cruelty - Decree however granted of judicial separation - Legality - Wife accusing husband of having illicit relationship with his widowed sister-in-law - Accusations not proved - Leveling of such false allegations amounts to cruelty - No evidence that husband had condoned act of wife or started cohabiting with her - Not a case that husband is taking advantage of his own wrong - Husband entitled to decree of divorce on ground of cruelty - Decree of judicial separation liable to be set aside.

218 (2015) DLT 729 Ref. to. 			(Paras 24, 25, 28, 29)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Claim for by wife - Wife alleging ill-treatment by her husband and his relatives and also that her father-in-law made advances towards her with ill-intention and when she told said fact to husband and relatives they drove her out of matrimonial home - Husband in his evidence stated that wife had love affair with another person and she had eloped with him while she was in her parents' house - Mother of wife had filed missing report and said fact proved by evidence of police officer - Husband also exhibited photograph of wife with said person - No evidence given by wife to show that photographs were manipulated - She also failed to examine her sister to prove that she was residing with her during said period as claimed by her - Further, after wife was traced husband gave notice informing that he was still ready to accept her back in matrimonial home - Wife however did not return to matrimonial house - Wife failed to prove that husband has withdrawn from her company without sufficient reasons - Wife not entitled to decree of restitution. 		 	(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Grant of maintenance to wife - Challenge to - Decree of restitution of conjugal rights against wife - Held, when the husband has succeeded in obtaining a decree of restitution of conjugal rights against the wife, it is implied that wife was required to join the company of the husband at her matrimonial home and therefore, there is no question of maintenance at least from the date of the said order - Order to that extent is required to be set aside - However, Court refused to interfere in the maintenance granted to daughter.

When the husband has succeeded in obtaining a decree of restitution of conjugal rights against the wife, it is implied that the wife was required to join the company of the husband at her matrimonial home and therefore, there is no question of maintenance at least from the date of the said order. If the wife is directed to be paid maintenance despite the said decree, reluctance of the wife to join the husband would be further strengthened and she would be encouraged to stay away from the husband despite the decree passed by the Court. The decree for restitution of conjugal rights would be rendered inoperative and for such an act of the wife, the husband would be penalized to pay the maintenance to the wife, who does not subject to the decree passed by the Court. Such a direction would be incentive to frustrate the decree passed under Section 9 of the Act. If such a decree is passed at the instance of the wife and against the husband, the Court would be justified in directing the husband to pay maintenance to the wife till he resumes co-habitation with her or calls upon her to join him at the matrimonial home pursuant to the decree passed by the Court in her favour. Such is not a case before Court. Court is, therefore, satisfied that the Family Court acted without jurisdiction in directing the husband to pay maintenance at least from the date when the impugned order was passed and therefore, the impugned order to that extent is required to be set aside. However, the Court refused to interfere in the maintenance granted to the daughter. AIR 2005 SC 986 - Ref. to.  [Para 12]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty by wife - Husband alleging wife to be forgetful and having hardly any knowledge of cooking - Also alleged that she used to obstruct him from performing his duties when being Electrical Engineer he was required to attend emergency services - Even she was in habit of making scene in the colony and also threatening to commit suicide - Evidence of other witnesses fully corroborative with evidence of husband and inspires confidence of Court - While wife failed to falsify said evidence and only stating that she was ready to go with her husband - Alleged conduct of wife sufficient to prove cruelty against husband - Husband entitled to decree of divorce on said ground.            (Paras 11, 16, 20)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Husband established that during their honeymoon wife resisted consummation of marriage and even thereafter caused embarrassment and humiliation to him - She made unfounded allegation of molestation against husband's elder brother by way of serving a legal notice - She also filed complaints implicating not only husband but also his entire family including his married sister and even the advocate of her husband - Neighbour of husband who gave evidence in court, was also dragged in litigation - Her projection as a victim of cruelty, was disbelieved in all judicial proceedings - Held, proceeding by wife was nothing but a ruthless act to cause harassment to her husband and in-laws - Same amounts to worst kind of cruelty - Hence, divorce petition allowed. 2015(2) ALL MR 435 (S.C.) Ref. to.			(Paras 29, 30, 31)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Wife creating an atmosphere of animocity between herself and husband's mother and daughter - Her allegation of extra marital relationship with some lady found to be totally false and unfounded - Held, husband was entitled to decree of divorce.	(Para 16)

heading: Validity of marriage
HeadNote.description: Validity of marriage - Seven pheras around bundle of burning agarbattis, whether amounts to Saptpadi - What is "Sacred Fire" has not been defined in Hindu Marriage Act - Fact that respondent put Sindur on appellant and garlanded her, proved by evidence - Even fact of taking seven pheras in said manner also proved - Merely because seven pheras were taken around burning aggarbattis, does not mean that no seven pheras were taken around sacred fire as contemplated in S.7 of the Act - Same does not render marriage between parties invalid. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Petition for divorce
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce - On ground of cruelty - Husband alleged that wife used to abuse his parents, constantly telling husband to ask them to leave their house and also was not doing household work - Throughout day husband and wife were not at house, but were working in bank and school respectively - Therefore, no occasion for major friction during day time between wife and husband's parents - Also, that husband could not have witnessed incidents during day time on working days - On weekend, as per husband wife was never at home - Allegation that wife did not look after needs of husband when he used to return home late - Does not amount to cruelty - Apart from attending her job, wife was cooking in morning and in evening and also used to purchase vegetables on her way - Obvious that she herself used to get tired and still she was cooking for family and doing other household work - Specific instances given by husband are uncorroborated - As per husband, there was no physical relation after March 2006, which would mean that till March 2006, they were having normal relations and majority of instances mentioned by husband were before March 2006 stood condoned - Non Cognizable complaint lodged by husband against wife was only for creating evidence against her as petition for divorce was lodged within couple of days - Dismissal of petition proper. 2017(5) ALL MR 42, 2010 ALL SCR 1860 Ref. to. 	(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Permanent alimony/maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony/maintenance - Grant of - Salary slip of husband shows that he is serving in Western Coalfields Limited on post of security guard and earning net salary of Rs. 28,361/- p.m. - Said evidence not discarded by husband - Wife entitled to maintenance of Rs. 7,000/- p.m. (Paras 8, 9, 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Allegation that wife had slapped husband in presence of his colleagues - Not believable in absence of any corroboration - General allegation made that wife's mother used to instigate her to behave indifferently with husband thereby interfered in their married life - No specific incident shown to prove the same - Further, husband stated that he saw wife going in car with gentleman and when he tried to stop her, she did not listen and drove away car - No evidence to corroborate same or that husband had ever questioned wife after her arrival at home - Though husband alleged that his father was once assaulted by wife, his father or mother could not depose in support thereof - Only one incident of visiting and creating scene in office of husband by wife, supported by one of his colleagues - It was because wife was interested to know income of husband for claiming maintenance - Allegations and similar counter allegations including allegation of adultery made by parties against each other - Both of them were in habit of socialising and it is possible that they misunderstood each other - No concrete evidence to prove mental and physical cruelty - Hence, husband not entitled to divorce. 			(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 22, 26)

heading: Decree of divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce by mutual consent - Cannot be annulled except on a plea of insanity or the statement made in state of utter stupor when the mental faculties are dimmed.	(Para 2)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Sought on ground of cruelty and desertion - Trial Court did not frame issue of desertion and decided entire matter only on ground of cruelty - No objection was raised by appellant husband nor he made any application u/O.14 R.5 for framing additional issues on desertion - In proceedings filed by respondent wife for restitution of conjugal rights u/S.9, it was held that wife had not deserted appellant - Such finding was not challenged by appellant though same was decided during pendency of divorce petition - Since additional issue was not framed, no question of applicability of O. 20 R.5 - Even if Court would have framed additional issue on issue of desertion, it could not have taken a different view than view already taken in parallel proceedings filed u/S.9 - Principle of Res-judicata would be applicable - No error committed by Trial Court in not framing issue on ground of desertion - No interference. 	(Paras 13, 14, 17, 16)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Direction to wait for period of 18 months to secure divorce - Validity - As per S.13B(2), there is bar to both parties making motion for disposal of petition for divorce by mutual consent for period of 6 months from date of presentation of petition - Similarly, there is bar to disposal of petition after period of 18 months from date of presentation petition - Order directing to wait for period of 18 months modified to period of 6 months. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of mental cruelty - Husband alleging that he and his parents have suffered physical and mental harassment due to demand of separate residence by wife - No mention in legal notice sent by husband regarding such demand by wife and resultant harassment to husband and his parents - Said ground is afterthought - Further, evidence regarding alleged quarrelsome nature of wife is of very general nature - No specific instances of violence or unacceptable behaviour of wife, brought on record - Wife alleged to have given threats to initiate criminal proceedings u/S. 498A IPC - However, no such complaint filed by her - Evidence of independent witness shows that husband has not suffered any harassment and he simply wanted divorce - Husband failed to show that conduct of wife is so abnormal and below acceptable norms that husband cannot reasonably be expected to put up with it - Husband failed to prove specific case of mental cruelty inflicted by wife - Divorce petition liable to be dismissed.			(Paras 19, 20, 21, 22, 24, 27)

headline: Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S. 25 – Maintenance – To wife and daughter – Cancellation of – Ground that wife has suppressed source of income, daughter also started getting stipend after completion of medical course – Stipend is paid to student to meet her educational and other requirements and cannot be substitute to husband’s liability to maintain wife – There was no evidence of wife’s independent income – Order of cancellation of maintenance, improper.

heading: Maintenance
Cancellation of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - To wife and daughter - Cancellation of - Ground that wife has suppressed source of income, daughter also started getting stipend after completion of medical course and husband has retired from service - Stipend is paid to student to meet her educational and other requirements - Same cannot be a substitute to husband's liability to maintain wife - There was no evidence of wife's independent income - Wife and daughter receiving total maintenance of Rs.9,000/-, not sufficient for their sustenance and as daughter was taking medical education, relatives of wife were supporting them - Some movement of amount in wife's bank account could not establish that such amounts represent wife's income - Order of cancellation of maintenance, improper. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Grant of decree
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Grant of decree - In favour of husband - Challenge - Record showing that no evidence was led by husband to substantiate averments made in petition u/S.9 - Even issues were not framed by trial court, though wife had not admitted claim of husband in her written reply before court - Evidence of father of wife set aside on ground that he could not have deposed on behalf of his daughter - Order granting decree in favour of husband, improper, liable to be set aside.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Void marriage
HeadNote.description:
Void marriage - Respondent had a spouse living at time of her marriage with appellant on 20.12.2009 - Her previous marriage stood dissolved on 4.8.2010 by mutual consent decree - Held, her subsequent marriage when first marriage was subsisting was void u/S.11 and once marriage was found to be void family court ought to have declared it to be so - Recourse to S.23 of Hindu Marriage Act, was not proper.

When marriage is void under Section 11, decree or declaration under Section 11 cannot be refused by taking recourse to Section 23 of "the Act". A marriage void in law can not be legalized by reading S.23 in mode & manner as done by the Family Court.

Section 23 envisages marriages which are voidable and, therefore, speak of those breaches or violation which can be waived legally by parties. Interpreting Section 23 in any other way would defeat the legislative mandate under Section 11 and mean that marriage declared void by law will not be presumed to be so by courts of law.   [Para 15,16]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty by wife - Wife was suffering from epilepsy since childhood - Husband claiming that this fact was suppressed from him at time of marriage - Wife is suffering from epilepsy is not ground for granting decree of divorce - Husband not entitled to divorce. 	(Para 4)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Acquittal of husband in private complaint filed by wife - Husband had sent divorce notice to wife making serious allegations against her character on basis of an anonymous letter received by him - Therefore, private complaint filed by wife for defamation, wherein husband was acquitted - Earlier proceeding for divorce filed by husband, dismissed by trial court and remanded by appellate court for fresh trial - Ground of acquittal raised in subsequent proceeding - Though husband acquitted, it cannot be said that wife had filed false complaint against him - When case filed by wife cannot be called as false case, husband cannot use decision of said case as ground of cruelty for getting divorce. 	(Paras 8, 11, 12, 14, 17)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Claim for by wife - Wife alleging ill-treatment by her husband and his relatives and also that her father-in-law made advances towards her with ill-intention and when she told said fact to husband and relatives they drove her out of matrimonial home - Husband in his evidence stated that wife had love affair with another person and she had eloped with him while she was in her parents' house - Mother of wife had filed missing report and said fact proved by evidence of police officer - Husband also exhibited photograph of wife with said person - No evidence given by wife to show that photographs were manipulated - She also failed to examine her sister to prove that she was residing with her during said period as claimed by her - Further, after wife was traced husband gave notice informing that he was still ready to accept her back in matrimonial home - Wife however did not return to matrimonial house - Wife failed to prove that husband has withdrawn from her company without sufficient reasons - Wife not entitled to decree of restitution. 			(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Passport of child
HeadNote.description: Passport of child - Direction to handover, sought against respondent-husband in divorce proceedings - Passport of child required for travelling to Singapore due to relocation of appellant-wife to Singapore by her employer - Since respondent and appellant started living apart, child was in custody of appellant and after her relocation to Singapore child was in custody of parents of appellant - No sufficient material before Court to indicate that respondent is in position to look after child on his own by disturbing position which has held since both parties started living apart - Further, after appellant sought return of passport, respondent filed application for grant of custody of child and visitation rights - Child has also desire to reside with his mother in Singapore - Material on record indicate that purpose of appellant seeking passport of child, was not to place child outside jurisdiction of Court - Considering welfare of child, respondent directed to handover passport of child to appellant and appellant is permitted to take child with her to Singapore. (Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 20)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Decree of nullity of marriage - Grant of - Appellant-wife performed second marriage with respondent-husband during subsistence of first marriage - Wife claiming that first marriage was dissolved by panchayati divorce-customary divorce - Wife in her written statement not pleaded that such type of divorce was prevalent in her community - No mention in panchayati divorce deed that it was based on custom prevalent in community - Said divorce deed is of no legal consequence - It shows wife performed second marriage during subsistence of first marriage - Grant of decree of nullity of marriage, proper. 	(Paras 17, 18, 19)

heading: Interim maintenance
Legality
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Legality - Salary certificates of husband shows his annual salary of Rs.11,72,000/- - These certificates are of years of 2013, 2014 and 2015, showing consistent increase in quantum of income of husband - No error in granting interim maintenance at rate of Rs.15,000/- p.m. to wife. (Paras 3, 4)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Cruelty - Filling of letter containing defamatory allegation by wife to employer of husband - Amounts to actionable cruelty - Therefore, marriage between parties allowed to be dissolved. (Para 43)

heading: Appeal
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), S.96(3), O.23 R.3 - Appeal - Against decree of divorce by mutual consent - Maintainability - Appeal filed on ground that consent for dissolution of marriage obtained by fraud when appellant was ill - S.96(3) of CPC provides that no appeal shall lie from decree passed by Court with consent of parties - S.19(2) of Family Courts Act also bars any appeal from decree or order passed by Family Court with consent of parties - Further, facts on which appeal is filed is not in domain of Appellate Court to enter into inquiry into said facts and if same is done, would also deprive parties of an important right of appeal, by converting Appellate Court into fact finding Court - Only Court which passed consent decree is capable of going into facts of fraud - Appeal not maintainable. 	(Paras 10, 13, 14, 22, 23)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Allegations made by wife in her written statement as to impotency of husband and also regarding mistreatment, torture and dowry demand by husband - Wife failed to produce any medical evidence to show that husband is medically unfit to consummate marriage - Husband examined doctor who opined that husband is fit and suffered no medical infirmity - Allegations in written statement were grave and serious, which are likely to impact husband's self image and adversely affect his mental well being - Cross-examination of husband and his expert witness clearly establishes that wife endeavoured to attribute non-consumption of marriage to husband’s impotency - Allegations levelled by wife remained unsubstantiated and unproven - False allegations caused mental pain and suffering to husband - Husband and wife living separately for more than 8 years - It can be presumed that marriage has irretrievably broken down - Order granting divorce, proper. 			(Paras 17, 22, 23, 25, 26)

heading: Judicial separation or divorce
HeadNote.description: Judicial separation or divorce - Ground of cruelty and desertion - Allegations by husband that he was cheated by wife and her family members by telling that she was mangalik and giving her incorrect birth date - However, marriage between parties proved to have been performed after verifying the background, houses and all details of both families - Admission in evidence belie the case of husband that there was cheating on part of wife and her parents at time of settlement of marriage - Husband also failed to prove that he was mangalik and intended to marry the girl having mangalik yog - Cruelty on part of wife not proved - Material on record showing that wife left matrimonial home on being beaten and threatened with life - She also lodged police complaint - Except bare words, husband made no attempt to bring back wife for cohabitation - He had not sent notice calling upon wife to join for cohabitation - Thus, husband cannot take advantage of his own wrong - Not entitled to decree for judicial separation or in alternative for divorce. (Paras 13, 14, 18, 19, 20, 23, 24, 25)

heading: Interim alimony
HeadNote.description: Interim alimony - Entitlement of earning wife - Earning of wife is no ground to refuse alimony u/S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act. 			(Para 10)

heading: Maintenance pendente lite
Grant of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Maintenance pendente lite - Grant of - Challenge - Husband claiming that award of maintenance of Rs.40,000/- p.m. is beyond his known source of income - Husband is into steel business - Parties living luxurious life after marriage - Lifestyle before marriage as has been spent by wife with husband cannot be lost sight of - Nature of life spent by husband after marriage and after initiation of proceedings for divorce has evidential value which is considered by Family Court - After break up, wife started residing with her parents and she has no independent source of income and is dependent on her parents to meet her day to day requirements - Grant of maintenance of Rs.40,000/- pendente lite, proper. 	(Paras 8, 10)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Dismissal of petition for - Challenge - Appellants, husband and wife moved petition for divorce with their free consent - There is no collusion inter-se - Appellants living separately for a period of one year next before presentation of petition - Not able to live together - Mutually agreed that their marriage should be dissolved - Hair-splitting observations by Judge of Family Court to dismiss petition run counter to pleadings and oral evidence of parties, not proper - Parties entitled for dissolution of marriage. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of cooling period of six months - Application for - Parties were referred to mediation by Court - Both parties and their respective lawyers appeared before mediator and after mediation, parties decided to get separated - Parties have entered and executed consent terms, which were placed on record - No possibility of resuming cohabitation - Cooling period of six months, waived. (Paras 6, 7, 8, 9)

heading: Divorce
Claim by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Claim by husband - On ground of cruelty and desertion - Allegation that wife was insisting husband to reside separately from his parents and misbehaved with her in-laws and frequently leaving matrimonial home - Wife stated that adultery by husband was reason for her moving out of matrimonial home - Wife though insisted that she intends to live with husband, no meaningful effort made by her for reconciliation - Parties living separately since 16 years - Marriage between parties is emotionally dead and there is no point in persuading them to live together any more - Marriage between parties is liable to be dissolved - Husband directed to pay to wife Rs.25 lakhs as full and final settlement of her claims. (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Divorce
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grant of - On ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Challenge by wife on ground that High Court or Trial Court has no power to grant divorce on ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Husband sought divorce on ground of cruelty - Allegation that wife left marriage hall late at night and did not come back to live with husband despite efforts made by relatives of husband - Marriage was never consummated - Parties living separately from date of marriage for almost 20 years - Husband remarried after 6 years of marriage, 5 years of which were spent in Trial Court’s proceedings - Marriage took place soon after decree of divorce was granted - Such conduct of husband cannot be held against him - All mediation efforts have failed - Further, wife has filed multiple cases in Courts against husband - She has filed complaint seeking removal of husband from job - Wife has harassed husband at work place by insulting him in front of students and professors - Such continuous acts of wife amounts to cruelty - Such conduct shows disintegration of marital unity and marriage - However, there was no initial integration itself which would allow disintegration afterwards - Considering conduct of wife, decree of divorce can be granted not only in exercise of powers u/Art.142 on account of irretrievable breakdown of marriage but also on ground of cruelty. (Paras 15, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22)

headline: Divorce – Grant of by trial court and High Court on ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage – Challenge by wife – Cruelty by wife also proved – Decree can be granted not only in exercise of powers u/Art.142 on ground of irretrievable breakdown but also on ground of cruelty.

heading: Divorce petition
Transfer of
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Transfer of - Petition filed at Nagpur - Wife staying at mercy of her parents at Akola and finding it very difficult to attend Court proceedings at Nagpur from Akola - Also, she is required to take care of her 5 years old child and her old parents - Considering wife’s convenience, it would be just and proper to transfer petition pending on file of Family Court, Nagpur to Family Court at Akola. 	(Para 8)

heading: Divorce
Petition by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband - For alleged mental cruelty, mental disorder and wife’s suffering from diseases Rheumatoid arthritis and hypothyroidism - Firstly, said diseases are not venereal diseases - Informed to husband well before marriage - Three instances of wife’s insulting behaviour referred - Wife however showed that it was husband who used to drink heavily and abused her in public - Her version is more specific and reliable - Even otherwise, alleged insulting behaviour by itself is not so grave and weighty - Not filing any petition by husband for restitution or for custody of child, shows he has no interest in family and wants divorce anyhow - Husband failed to prove his case - Petition dismissed. 2006(5) ALL MR 67 (S.C.) Ref. to. 2012(1) ALL MR 267, 2003(3) ALL MR 777 (S.C.), 1990 ALLMR ONLINE 1438 Disting. 		(Paras 21, 22, 23, 25, 27, 28, 29, 33, 34)

heading: Judicial separation
Grant of
Illegal
HeadNote.description:
Judicial separation - Grant of - Merely giving false date of birth by wife before marriage does not establish cruelty - Plea by husband in respect of his abstinence from sexual relations for six months on medical advice, not substantiated - Insistence on part of wife for sexual relations cannot be termed as cruelty - Since prior to marriage, wife being Doctor her duty hours were not fixed and many times she was required to stay at hospital beyond duty hours for attending emergency cases - Does not make out cruelty on part of wife - Other allegations are of general nature and not making out cruelty - Mere lodging complaints by wife u/S.498A IPC by itself would not be ground of cruelty - Husband failed to prove his case for divorce - Therefore, judicial separation could also not have granted - Family Court however held that it was difficult for parties to cohabit together and therefore decree of judicial separation was required to be passed to avoid complications - Illegal - Moreso when wife is staying in matrimonial home.
	The Court would be entitled to exercise discretion in favour of the petitioner by granting him a decree for judicial separation only in the event, the petitioner proves his case for decree of divorce and the Court finds him entitled for the decree of divorce on the grounds mentioned in Section 13. Conjoint reading of Sections 10, 13 and 13-A , makes it clear that a discretion is given to the Court to grant alternate relief of judicial separation in the event, the petitioner makes out a case for grant of decree of dissolution of marriage/divorce in his favour. It is only then that the Court can exercise discretion taking into consideration the circumstances of the case and instead of passing a decree of divorce, pass a decree of judicial separation.
	The issue in the present case is of propriety on the part of the Family Court in granting such alternate relief in absence of any material to justify the grant of such relief. Coming to the facts of the case in hand, the Family Court rejected the prayer of the respondent for grant of decree of divorce on the ground of cruelty, by coming to the conclusion that he has failed to prove the cruelty. In the Family Court, the parties did not lead any evidence in respect of judicial separation. Thus in absence of any material on record, the Family Court granted a decree of judicial separation in favour of the respondent, merely for asking. The Family Court has misread and misconstrued the provisions of Sections 10, 13 and 13-A of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 and has erred in granting decree of judicial separation particularly in the light of the finding that the respondent failed to prove his case for divorce on the ground of cruelty. The material on record indicates that the allegations made by the respondent against the appellant were vague and general and at the most they can be termed as normal wear and tear of married life. Admittedly, the appellant is staying in the matrimonial home. In these circumstances, there was no occasion for the Family Court to abruptly come to a conclusion that it was difficult for the parties to cohabit together and therefore the decree of judicial separation was required to be passed to avoid complications. The said findings of the Family Court are based on wrong interpretation of relevant provisions as well as wrong appreciation of evidence on record. The Family Court has drawn unwarranted inferences.
AIR 2008 Bombay 129 Foll.	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of desertion - Wife at her own, in absence of husband left his company in 2008 - Parties living separate since then - Admissions by wife reveal her willful and deliberate intention not to resume cohabitation with husband - Husband was ready to cohabit with her, but she refused - Many criminal cases lodged against husband by her and her father - Allegation by wife that husband having illicit relationship with one lady, not proved - Held, in view of facts husband proved that wife has deserted him without any reasonable cause and without his consent since more than two years - Relations between parties have gone to stage of irreparation and beyond hope of salvage - Therefore, grant of decree of divorce in favour of husband, proper.(Paras 9, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Grant of maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.47, R.1(1) - Grant of maintenance - Alteration of interim maintenance amount - Provisions of S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act, cannot be given restricted meaning - If in a given case, an application is made for alteration of the interim maintenance amount already granted, such an application will have to be entertained as an application for review under order 47 of R.1(1) of Civil P.C. or in the alternative an application u/s. 127 of Criminal P.C.

The provisions of Section 24 cannot be given restricted meaning and if in a given case, an application is made for alteration of the interim maintenance amount already granted, such an application will have to be entertained as an application for review under Order XLVII Rule 1(1) of Civil Procedure Code or in the alternative an application under Section 127 of Code of Criminal Procedure before the Family Court.  In the instant case, in the application at Exh.5, the wife had claimed that the husband was working with a Company called Bindview Pvt. Ltd. at Pune as a Senior Technical Lead and was drawing a monthly salary of Rs.62,000/-.  In the application at Exhibit-50, the husband came out with a case that he lost the said job and the subsequent job due to the acts of the wife and he remained unemployed for ten months.  Thereafter, he came to be employed with S.I. Services (I) Pvt. Ltd.  He joined the said company on 01-08-2004 and the Salary Certificate placed on record reflected that his gross salary was Rs.15,528/- per month with the said Company.  His net pay came to Rs.14,697/- per month.  When the application at Exh.40 was rejected, his employment with Vmoksha Technoligies Pvt. Ltd. on a gross salary of Rs.25,454/- for December, 2003 was taken into consideration by the Family Court.  Thus, the husband had made out a case for alteration of the maintenance amount on the basis of the subsequent change in employment and his monthly salary with M/s. S. I. Services (I) Pvt. Ltd.  The Family Court rightly entertained the application at Exh.50 and it cannot be accepted that the order passed below Exh.50 was without jurisdiction or powers.  If the circumstances change in the future in respect of either of the parties i.e. if the husband gets more salary or the wife starts earning, either of them may apply for alteration of the interim maintenance amount.  AIR 1997 SC 3397 - Referred to.  [Para 6]

heading: Petition for divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce by mutual consent - Can be presented through power of attorney holder - As per S.10 of Family Courts Act, Family Court has to follow procedure under Code - And O.3 Rr.1 and 2 of Code permits recognised agent to act on behalf of party - Power of attorney holder is recognised agent and in absence of any provision in S.13B, abrogating power under Code of power of attorney holder he can very well present petition under S.13B on behalf of his Principal. 2012(3) ALL MR 521, 2010(4) ALL MR (JOURNAL) 49, 2004(5) ALL MR 396 (S.C.), 2013 ALL MR (Cri) 4048 (S.C.), 2012(3) ALL MR 521 Rel.on. 	(Paras 7, 10, 12)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125 - Maintenance - Right of second wife - Second marriage during subsistence of first one is void ipso jure being in contravention of S.5(i) of Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 - A woman entering into such Marriage is not a "wife" within the meaning of either Hindu Marriage Act or Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act or S.125 of Cr.P.C. - Hence cannot claim maintenance under any of these statutes.

A marriage contravening S.5(i) of Hindu Marriage Act is void ipso jure and the woman entering into such a marriage is not a "wife" within the meaning of either Hindu Marriage Act or S.125 of Cr.P.C.  The expression "wife" used in both statutes means only a legally wedded wife.  The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act cannot be treated differently for the meaning to the expression "wife" used therein.  The expression must be given the meaning in which it is understood in law applicable to the parties.  Since the institution of Marriage and the very relationship of husband and wife originates from personal law applicable to the parties, there can be no escape from reference to personal law while understanding the expression "husband" and "wife" used in different statutes.  As far as Hindus are concerned, the law relating to Marriage amongst Hindus is codified by Hindu Marriage Act and therefore unless the marriage is valid under the provisions of Hindu Marriage Act the parties entering into such a Marriage cannot describe themselves as "husband" and "wife" for the purposes of application of different statutes or for deriving the benefits available under different statutes.

As regards the argument based on S.18(2)(d) of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act (which enables a wife to live separately and claim maintenance if her husband has any other wife living) is concerned, such a provision can obviously exist only in case of Marriages solemnized before Hindu Marriage Act came into operation.  Had the Hindu Marriage Act not laid down monogamy as a rule of law and that Hindu husband cannot marry another wife after the commencement of that Act, clause (d) could not have been included in S.18(2) of Hindu Adoption & Maintenance Act.  Further, a bigamous marriage contracted after coming into force of Hindu Marriage Act being null and void, question of having another wife cannot arise after the Hindu Marriage Act came into operation.  Therefore, it can be applicable only in cases where a husband has entered into two Marriages prior to coming into operation of Hindu Marriage Act.

Therefore, the expression "Hindu wife" used in S.18 of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act, means legally wedded Hindu wife and no less. A second wife not being the legally wedded wife cannot resort to S.18 to claim maintenance.  AIR 1999 AP 19 - Rel. on.  AIR 2008 Delhi 7 - Dissented from.   2004(3) Mh.L.J. 487, I(2002) DMC 136 (DB) Distinguished.		 [Para 22,23,28]

heading: Matrimonial proceedings
Right of privacy
HeadNote.description: Matrimonial proceedings - Right of privacy - Medical examination of woman to prove her verginity - Allowing such a test would amount to violation of her right to privacy and personal liberty - Moreover verginity test cannot constitute a sole basis to prove consummation of marriage - It would be a roving enquiry which is not permissible - Constitution of India, Art.21. (2003)3 JT (SC) 399 Rel. on.	(Paras 4,6)

heading: Order of maintenance pendente lite
HeadNote.description:
Order of maintenance pendente lite - Can always be passed without first making an attempt at reconciliation under S.23(2) - S.23(2) is not mandatory.

An order under Section 24 can always be passed without taking steps for bringing about reconciliation under Section 23(2) of the Act for the timing to make efforts for reconciliation is in the discretion of the Court. Section 24 of the Act fundamentally deals with an ancillary or incidentally relief and is an enabling provision to empower either of the spouses to put forth the defences in the main proceeding. Section 23(2) and Section 24 co-exist in harmony and in fact if the context and subject-matter are appreciated in proper perspective, there is no anomaly in between the two provisions. Section 23(2) is not mandatory and does not operate in absolute terms. Any order passed without compliance under Section 23(2) as has been held in the case of Dharmendra Kumar would be an irregularity and not an illegality. Grant of pendente lite maintenance under Section 24 of the Act is not to be construed in a narrow compass. The jurisdiction of the Court to pass the order arises at the stage of institution of proceedings and continues till the proceeding is concluded.		The maintenance and the entitlement under section 24 of the Act can be made available even in a proceeding pertaining to setting aside of an ex parte decree and restoration of the main suit. 'Any relief that has been used in Section 23(2) would not cover an incidental and ancillary relief during the proceeding as that has to be construed in broader canvass and would include only substantive relief and further if there is non-compliance of the same, it would amount to an irregularity and not an illegality and such irregularity is rectifiable at the appellate stage and would not render the judgment or an order a nullity. 1995 MPLJ 555 Approved. 2003(1) MPHT 5 (NOC) Overruled.	 [Para 27]

heading: Evidence Act (1872), S.112
HeadNote.description:
Evidence Act (1872), S.112 - Divorce and maintenance proceedings - Necessity of DNA test - Explained. 
	The position of law is different in the case of S.13 of Hindu Marriage Act and the application filed under S.125 of Cr.P.C. “Adultery” is a ground for “Divorce” under S. of 13 of Hindu Marriage Act. For proving adultery, the DNA test will definitely be useful as per the established law discussed above. If the wife is refusing for DNA test, then her refusal may be considered as a ground for drawing adverse inference against her. But the position under S.125 of Cr.P.C is different. S.125(1)(b) of Cr.P.C. provides that person is also liable to grant the maintenance to his illegitimate minor child. In the case filed under S.125 of Cr.P.C the DNA test is not mandatory in each and every case.	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Incidents representing normal wear and tear of matrimonial life - Not an act of cruelty.

All that the evidence disclosed was that as a result of some quarrels, the wife used to leave the house for a short-while - say a day or two, go to her parents in the city and come back. This happened in June 1980 and January 1981 when the wife left with her child, stayed with her parents for 2-3 days and returned. There did not appear to be any serious dispute between the spouses. It may be that some minor dis-agreement took place between the spouses provoking the wife to go to her parent's place since they were very much in the same city and she returned to the matrimonial home after a short gap of 2-3 days. Held the two incidents were not such as to amount to cruelty in matrimonial law. This represented the normal wear and tear of matrimonial life.  [Para 12,13]

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description:
Desertion - Wife leaving matrimonial house over a small controversy about price to be paid for a silver trinket with her father-in-law. Next day wife handing over custody of her three year old son but refusing to return home - Held wife was guilty of desertion within meaning of S.13(1)(ib).

It may be that in the absence of the husband, the father in law of the wife ought not to have found fault with her paying Rs.110/- for a silver trinket if the father-in-law thought that the price was excessive. But this, did not justify the wife deserting the matrimonial home. Such differences of opinion, and perhaps insults, are a part of day today wear and tear of matrimonial life. The father in law might have honestly believed that the price paid was excessive. But this did not provide her a justification to leave matrimonial home and to quietly hand over custody of the child the next day when the husband met her.  [Para 20]

For the offence of desertion so far as the deserting spouse is concerned, two essential conditions must be there. (i) the factum of separation and (ii) the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end (animus deserendi). Looking to the evidence of the two spouses and the father of the husband there is clear evidence of factum of separation and of the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end. Conduct of the wife as also the conduct of her parents in not bothering to bring about any reconciliation leaves us with no choice but to conclude that the wife had deserted the matrimonial home with an intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end. She willingly parted company of her son though the child was of a tender age of just 3 years and needed the mother's care most. The offence of desertion commences when the fact of separation and the animus deserendi co-exist. But it is not necessary that they should commence at the same time. The de facto separation may have commenced without the necessary animus or it may be that the separation and the animus deserendi coincide in point of time. In the present case both the conditions existed namely the factum of separation and the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end. Hence, the appellant-wife is guilty of desertion and this would be ground for the husband to obtain divorce under clause (ib) of sub-sec. (1) of sec.13 of the Hindu Marriage Act.  [Para 22]

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - It cannot be assumed that a particular conduct will, under all circumstances, amount to cruelty, vis-à-vis the other party - Mere trivial irritations, quarrels, normal wear and tear of married life would not be adequate for grant of divorce on the ground of cruelty.			(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Only instance highlighted by appellant was that the respondent wife abused his parents on the day of festival in the presence of relatives and neighbours - No other instance mentioned in the petition about cruelty by the respondent - Married life should be assessed as a whole and a few isolated instances over certain period will not amount to cruelty - Making certain statements on the spur of moment and expressing displeasure about behaviour of elders may not be characterized as cruelty.		 (Paras 11, 12)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Allegations of cruelty not truthful - Appellant not interested to keep respondent as his wife and he wanted divorce by any means - Both spouses were living separately from 2002 and their re-union was impossible - Court requested to grant relief in exercise of powers under Art.142 of the Constitution - Court was, however, not inclined to accede to the request also in view of fact that issue was pending before larger Bench.	(Para 15)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable break down of marriage - Not a ground for passing a decree of divorce.	(Para 9)

heading: Divorce
Jurisdiction of Court
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Jurisdiction of Court - Merely because both the parties have prayed for the same relief of divorce, the Court does not get jurisdiction to pass a decree under O.12, R.6 - Held, the Court will have to follow the mandatory provision of S.23(1)(a) and record satisfaction which is a condition precedent for passing a decree of divorce. (1997)11 SCC 701 and AIR 1965 SC 364 - Rel. on.	(Paras 7, 8, 10)

heading: Divorce
Petition by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband - Allegation that she attended Appellant's brother's marriage against his advice and suffered miscarriage - Held if respondent had failed to go to attend the marriage of her husband's brother, then also she would have been liable to be blamed - This showed not the cruelty of respondent but utter insensitivity on the part of appellant husband.	(Para 8)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Allegation that wife did not attend to husband when he was injured and was in hospital - This did not form part of pleadings and was introduced in evidence without any supporting evidence - In any event one single instance in isolation was hardly sufficient to claim dissolution of marriage.	(Para 9)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Allegation that wife did not go to attend and serve the mother of appellant when she underwent eye surgery - Neither the mother not attending doctor examined to prove surgery - Held it cannot be a ground for granting divorce.	(Para 9)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grounds for not sustainable - Nothing to indicate that wife had contributed in any way for breakdown of marriage - Moreover allowing divorce on ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage would amount to legislation by Court - Hence denial of divorce by High Court cannot be interfered with.	(Para 13)

heading: Maintenance/ Permanent alimony
Enhancement
HeadNote.description: Maintenance/ Permanent alimony - Enhancement - After marriage wife resigned from post of Air Hostess - Husband's salary as Sr. Commander in Air India was Rs.83,19,031 even a after income-tax deductions for a period of one year and he was also receiving rental income between Rs.7,20,000 or Rs.10,80,000 - He had huge bank deposits and investments in shares and mutual funds - He owns one acre of land in Pune - Husband aged 42 years, had remarried and was having one child - wife had earned only Rs.1.5 lakhs from casual assignments during five years period - She was staying with her sister - Held she was entitle to Rs. 40000/- p.m. instead of Rs.20000/- fixed by courts below or in the alternative a lump sum of Rs. 40 lakhs.	(Para 15)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Consideration to be kept in mind while fixing the amount.

The court has to consider while deciding maintainace payable the status of the parties, their respective needs, the capacity of the husband to pay, having regard to reasonable expenses for his own maintenance and others whom he is obliged to maintain under the law and statute. The courts also have to take note of the fact that the amount of maintenance fixed for the wife should be such as she can live in reasonable comfort considering her status and mode of life she was used to live when she lived with her husband. At the same time, the amount so fixed cannot be excessive or affect the living condition of the other party. These are all the broad principles courts have to keep in mind while determining maintenance or permanent alimony.	 [Para 12]

heading: Petition for divorce
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce - Non-payment of alimony pendente lite by husband alleged - Husband objecting saying that actually there was over payment - Wife thereafter did not press her objection and did not file application for stay - Decree passed on merits cannot be set aside.	(Para 14)

heading: Divorce
Grounds
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grounds - Husband alleging mental cruelty - Wife alleging bad moral character and illicit relations with girl whom she could not name or identify - This ground was also not taken in written statement - Husband was in jail custody after complaint under S.498-A and allegations made by wife were only meant to humiliate husband who was working in a nationalised bank - Such false allegation was itself a ground of divorce.	(Paras 18, 20)

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - Refusal of conjugal rights by wife - Wife refusing sexual relations after the birth of fourth child - Husband at that time was only 33 years old and even according to wife he had extra sexual urge - Even unintentional act of such cruelty of denying sex when devices of birth control are known and easily available would amount to mental cruelty.	(Para 22)

heading: Interim maintenance
Children alone, excluded
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of, in favour of children, not permissible - Section 24 confers right upon spouses alone, to claim maintenance - Children alone, excluded - Lower Court order granting interim maintenance to two minor children also, held, bad.	(Para 3)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of, under Section 24, insistence on payment of, beyond date of disposal of main proceedings, not valid.	(Para 15)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Grant of litigation expenses - Application filed under S.24 by wife for grant of litigation expenses - Wife cannot be compelled to file a written statement unless an order is passed in favour of the wife directing the petitioner husband to pay litigation expenses - Wife is expected to file written statement only after the amount is paid to her.(Para 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of mental disorder - Found to be incorrect in subsequent custody proceedings - Finding likely to have ill effect on minor child - Finding held rightly rejected by Family Court.	(Para 10)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Decree of divorce in favour of husband - Wife claiming lump sum of Rs.75 lakhs as maintenance to her and her daughter - List of assets set out indicating that husband was sufficiently well-off to provide suitable lump sum towards permanent alimony - Family Court directed to ascertain estimated income of husband to enable the Court to pass final orders.	(Para 11)

heading: Appeal pending
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty - Appeal pending - Parties arriving at a compromise and praying for dissolution of marriage by mutual consent - Held original petition can be amended, entertained in appeal and decree for divorce can be granted. AIR 2001 Kant. 300 - Dissented from.	(Para 17)

heading: Withdrawal of consent
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal of consent - On divorce petition Court directing parties to place on record terms of compromise by way of separate application - Such application not filed - No decree for divorce passed - Wife can be allowed to withdraw her consent.			(Para 19)

heading: Divorce
Petition by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband - On ground of cruelty - Wife had filed complaint u/S. 498A IPC from which husband and his relatives were acquitted - It was alleged that wife started harassing husband mentally and treating him with cruelty on financial matters and for separate accommodation - She is also alleged to have refused to reside in rented premises and deserted husband - Wife used to make allegations against husband on his character in society - In written statement also wife made several allegations against husband - It amounts to mental cruelty - Wife in her affidavit commented on character of husband's sister and also made insinuation regarding legitimacy of birth of husband's niece - Such allegations amount to cruelty - Further, both parties were residing separately for more than 10-12 years - Husband entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Paras 33, 38, 39)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of - Husband was orthopedic doctor earning more than Rs.2 lakhs p.m. - Husband claiming that he has already paid Rs.1 crore towards maintenance charges of his daughter therefore he is not liable to pay any further maintenance - It is duty of father to take care of his minor daughter - Amount already paid by husband to wife, shall be treated as for welfare of daughter - Considering income of husband and wife, husband directed to pay Rs.40,000/- p.m. to minor daughter and Rs.25,000/- p.m. to wife as maintenance - Husband also directed to make fixed deposit of Rs.5 lakhs in name of daughter. 			(Paras 43, 44)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Expression 'cruelty' includes both physical and mental - Wife a well-educated young scientist - More interested in her career even at the cost of marital life - Underwent termination of two pregnancies without the knowledge and consent of husband and his parents as per the husband - High Court found that apart from this wife was not interested in continuing marital tie and best efforts of husband failed to pursuade her about maintaining marital relations and need and necessity of child in their life - Held finding of mental cruelty was rightly arrived at by trial Court and High Court and needed no interference.	(Paras 45, 47)

heading: Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - Divorce decree confirmed by High Court - Husband remarrying without waiting for 90 days for wife to approach Apex Court under 136 - In view of this precipitate action creating a situation of fait accompli Apex Court while confirming decree directing husband to pay an amount of Rs.Five Lakhs to the appellant wife.			(Para 48)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Statutory waiting period of six months u/s.13-B(2) - Specified periods not optional for the parties to be complied with - Statutory period, held, mandatory and not directory.

The period specified by Legislature as pre-requisite to filing and grant of a decree for divorce on mutual consent is expected to be complied with and its observance is not discretionary at the whim of the court. The legislative scheme clearly shows that the specified periods are not optional for the parties to be complied with because the cause of action is completed only upon conclusion of the period and clearly mandates the court to satisfy the requirements of law before passing a decree.

Section 13-B is a complete code in itself. It provides for cause of action, grounds and reasons which are required to be satisfied by the parties, the procedure to be followed by the court and the premise which ought to be taken into consideration by the court before it passes a decree of divorce on the ground of mutual consent. The Act contemplates different remedies which are available to a spouse to a marriage under different circumstances. For availing of that relief, it is mandatory for the parties to satisfy the requirement and grounds specified under that provision. For example, seeking a decree for judicial separation, the parties must satisfy the grounds spelt out by the legislature under section 10 of the Act wherefrom, the parties seek a decree of divorce. They are expected to comply with the statutory requirements and establish and prove by due and cogent evidence either of the grounds stated in sub-clauses 13(1)(i) to (vii) and the other provisions of that section. Unless the court is satisfied that either of the grounds stated under section 13 of the Act is satisfied, the court obviously cannot pass a decree dissolving the marriage between the parties by passing a decree of divorce. In other words, the jurisdiction of the court to grant a relief under the provisions of the Act is controlled by legislative limitation of the respective provisions. To enact law is a matter in the domain of the legislature.  2005(1) DMC 571 - Not agreed.   [Para 10,13]

heading: Divorce petition
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Burden of proof - Rule of reasonable proof is applicable to the divorce proceedings.

The rule of reasonable proof is applicable to the proceedings before the court of competent jurisdiction either under section 10 or under section 13 of the Act, as the case may be. In other words, burden of proof shall lie upon that party to establish and prove the grounds pleaded by it for seeking such a relief from the court. There is clear distinction between the provisions of sections 10 and 13 on one hand and section 13-B of the Act on the other. In terms of section 13-B, there is hardly any burden of proof on either of parties as the foundation thereof is by mutual consent. The court is granted power to dissolve the marriage between the parties by a decree of divorce on the ground of mutual consent. In fact, it is an exception to the proceedings under any other provision before the court of competent jurisdiction for dissolving the marriage between the parties.  						 [Para 14]

heading: Statutory waiting period
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Statutory waiting period - Power of court to waive statutory period - Held, the court has not been vested with any specific or even general power to condone the delay or waive the period stipulated either under S.13-B(1) and for that matter u/s.13-B(2).

Section 13-B does not provide omnibus jurisdiction to the court but grants such specific and/or special jurisdiction. The court can pass decree for divorce on mutual consent only upon satisfaction of the grounds stated therein and subject to the satisfaction of the period specified in law. The court has not been vested with any specific or even general power to condone the delay or waive the period stipulated either under section 13-B(1) and for that matter, under section 13-B(2). The legislature in its wisdom allowed the parties a limited right to seek divorce by mutual consent provided the parties present the petition in the court of competent jurisdiction on the ground that they have been living separately for a period of one year or more, they have not been able to live together and that they have mutually agreed that the marriage should be dissolved. Once such a petition is filed, the court has to satisfy itself of these requirements and thereafter, the parties are expected to take out a second motion which again has to be a joint motion but not earlier than six months and later than 18 months. Still the parties have to satisfy the court that the said petition was not withdrawn and the court is expected to record its satisfaction after hearing the parties and on making such enquiry as it thinks fit that the averments in the petition are true, court may pass a decree declaring the marriage to be dissolved on the ground of mutual consent. Apparently, the decree for divorce by mutual consent is dependent on fulfillment of the requirements afore-noticed and due satisfaction of the court. This cannot be termed as merely directory as the statute does not even impliedly indicate such intent of the legislature. The provision of a statute must be given its plain meaning and requirement of law stated under those provisions should be satisfied before the relief under the specific provision can be granted to the parties.   [Para 14]

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Mutual consent ought to continue from the date of institution of first motion till passing of the decree.

The mutual consent ought to continue from the date of institution of first motion till passing of the decree. This is the significance of the provisions of section 13-B(2) of the Act. It will not only be unjust but would be impermissible on accepted norms of statutory interpretation that this period of six months is treated as optional, condonable or could be waived at the request of the parties. The law must be given a meaning that would be applicable and acceptable generally and not to a particular case. Firstly, the legislature has not provided any power of relaxation to the court in regard to the stated period of six months under section 13-B(2). Secondly, if this procedure is adopted at the behest of the parties by the court, it will amount to denial of a statutory benefit of rethinking. The period of six months is the product of the legislature and the courts have always upheld its validity. To waive or abolish by judicial dictum a specific provision of the legislature would amount to negating a statutory provision which is otherwise constitutional and cannot easily be dropped in reality. No prejudice is caused to the parties by merely waiting for a short period of six months before they take a vital and pertinent decision in regard to their marriage which is a social sacrament coupled with civil rights and obligations and which they had entered upon voluntarily and happily. Impulsive and impatient decisions rarely guide the parties to the logical and correct decision. They must have time to ponder over their decision and reassure themselves that the decision of dissolving their marriage is correct and needs to be implemented. For arriving at such a vital decision, the period of six months is to be held as mandatory and in conformity with the legislative intent expressed in no uncertain terms in the relevant provisions.  AIR 1992 SC 1904 - Rel. on.   [Para 15]

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
