HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiting period of six months - It is mandatory for granting divorce by mutual consent and not directory - Court also has no power to relax the period. 2002(2) HLR 45 - Rel. on.	(Para 17)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Consent given by parties for filing petition for divorce on mutual consent - Held, it is not an irrevocable consent - Parties can withdraw such consent of course, for appropriate reasons - Even second motion has to be presented by both parties by filing a joint petition.

The consent given by the parties for filing petition for divorce on mutual consent is not an irrevocable consent. The parties can withdraw such consent of course, for appropriate reasons. Even second motion has to be presented by both parties by filing a joint petition. The provisions of section 13-B do not in any way, encroach upon the jurisdiction of the court of competent jurisdiction under the provisions of sections 10 and 13 of the Act. This itself indicates that section 13-B is certainly a special provision but has to operate upon satisfaction of the conditions and grounds specified in that section. In any other cases of serious nature, the parties are not left without remedy and they can always approach the court under different provisions but if they wish to seek dissolution of marriage by mutual consent, it essentially must be in compliance and in conformity to the provisions of this special section.

Section 13-B of the Act states the grounds on which and the period of limitations which shall constitute a complete cause of action for the parties to file a petition for divorce by mutual consent. Wherever any of the ingredients are missing or are not satisfied, the petition itself cannot be presented, as it would affect the very jurisdiction of the court to entertain such a petition. Legislature has not granted any power to waive or condone the periods of limitation specified under that provision. Ex turpi causa non oritur actio. Absence of complete cause of action would be a legal impediment in institution and continuation of such proceedings. Thus, the parties have to satisfy the court that ingredients of section 13-B(2) are satisfied and the averments made in the petition are correct to enable the court to pass a decree.  [Para 18,19]

heading: Interpretation of statute
Term "waiver"
Meaning of
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of statute - Term "waiver" - Meaning of - Term "waiver" means abandonment of a right which is express or implied from conduct - In proceedings u/s.13-B, held, either the concept of waiver or condonation as understood in strict legal parlance is not applicable.

heading: Interpretation of statute
Statutory provisions
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of statute - Statutory provisions - Liberalized process for dissolving marriage - Process has to operate within the frame work of the provisions which provide for such remedy - It can hardly be permissible that the statutory provisions should be moulded to suit the facts of each case and that too only on the ground of convenience of parties.	(Para 24)

heading: Divorce and judicial separation
HeadNote.description:
Divorce and judicial separation - Alarming increase in number of cases - Court expressed its deep concern over the situation.

It is a disturbing phenomenon that large number of cases are flooding the courts relating to divorce or judicial separation. An apprehension is gaining ground that the provisions relating to divorce in the Hindu Marriage Act, 1950 has led to such a situation. In other words, the feeling is that the statute is facilitating breaking of homes rather than saving them. This may be too wide a view because actions are suspect. But that does not make the section invalid. Actions may be bad, but not the Section. The provisions relating to divorce categorise situations in which a decree for divorce can be sought for. Merely because such a course is available to be adopted, should not normally provide incentive to persons to seek divorce, unless the marriage has irretrievably broken. Effort should be to bring about conciliation to bridge the communication gap which lead to such undesirable proceedings. People rushing to courts for breaking up of marriage should come as a last resort, and unless it has an inevitable result, courts should try to bring about conciliation. The emphasis should be on saving marriage and not breaking it. As noted above, this is more important in cases where the children bear the brunt of dissolution of marriage. One must not lose faith in humanity. It is an ocean; if a few drops of the ocean are dirty, the ocean does not become dirty. If nothing ever went wrong in one's life, he or she would never have a chance to grow stronger. One should never forget that today well lived makes every yesterday a dream of happiness and tomorrow a vision of hope. Marital happiness depends upon mutual trust, respect and understanding. A home should not be an arena for ego clashes and misunderstandings. There should be physical and mental union. Marriage is something, Ibsen said in "The League of Youth" you have to give your whole mind to. If marriages are made in Heaven as Tennyson said in Ayloner's Field, why make matrimonial home hell is a big question.   [Para 50,51]

heading: Divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of desertion - Dispute arising out of certain incident of misbehaviour by one person with wife during husband's absence - Husband raising quarrels on that count and reaching wife to her parent's home - No intention of the wife to bring to an end permanently the matrimonial relations - Husband had failed to prove ground of desertion - Wife had reason to live separate - Therefore, held, the husband is not entitled to a decree for dissolution of marriage on the ground of desertion.

In the present case, mere suspicion about the character of his wife is the cause for the wife to leave his house.  There was no intention of the wife to bring to an end permanently the matrimonial relations.  So the husband is not entitled to a decree for dissolution of marriage on the ground of desertion.

Held, as the husband failed to establish the ground of desertion, he cannot claim a decree for dissolution of marriage because of irretrievable breakdown of the marriage.  His act itself was found a compelling circumstance for the wife to live separate and her separate residence was not found to be an act of wife to reside separate with an intention to desert the husband permanently.  Under these circumstances, husband cannot take benefit of his own wrong and claim a decree for divorce alleging irretrievable breakdown of the marriage.					  [Para 15,18]

heading: Irretrievable breakdown
Petition for divorce
Ground of
HeadNote.description: Irretrievable breakdown - Petition for divorce - Ground of - During conciliation, Husband not willing to resume marital life but wife showing willingness - Submission during arguments for granting divorce on ground of irretrievable break down of marriage - Held, it is not a ground u/s.13 for divorce - Prayer rejected.	(Para 18)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
Petition by husband
Set aside
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Petition by husband - Most of incidents/conduct relied upon by husband insignificant or trifling and could not be said that it touched a certain pitch of severity - Alleged incidents or conduct could not be said to be other than ordinary wear and tear of married life - Findings recorded by trial Court on point of cruelty - Set aside - Husband-Petitioner held not entitled to divorce on said ground.			(Paras 11, 13, 15, 18, 19, 20)

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description:
Desertion - Is a matter of inference to be drawn from facts and circumstances of each case - Essence of desertion means intentional permanent abandonment of one spouse by other without that other's consent and without reasonable cause.

Desertion is a matter of inference to be drawn from the facts and circumstances of each case. What amounts to desertion in a particular case depends upon the circumstances and mode of life of the parties. In any case mere physical separation between spouses for a continuous period of not less than two years immediately preceding the presentation of the petition would not constitute desertion. The factum of desertion and the intention of a party to bring cohabitation permanently to an end are the essential ingredients of legal desertion. In other words, the essence of desertion means the intentional permanent abandonment of one spouse by other without that other's consent and without reasonable cause. Insofar as burden is concerned it is always on the petitioner in proving the factum of desertion as well as animus deserendi, which the petitioner has to establish to the satisfaction of the court. Even if the wife, where she is a deserting spouse, does not prove just cause for her living apart, the petitioner-husband has still to satisfy the court that the desertion was without cause. Therefore, in a petition for divorce by the husband on the ground of desertion, it is not enough if it is established that the wife left the matrimonial home without reasonable excuse and against wishes of husband but indeed, it must further be shown that the intention was to bring cohabitation permanently to an end.  In the present case, it was apparent from the overall facts and circumstances of the case that the petitioner did not care for the respondent wife and his daughter or care to maintain his daughter after 11.7.1997. He never made any attempt to bring them back. There was no material on record to show that he made any attempts to meet his daughter either through mediator or through court or through his sister and her husband who were known to be the friends of the respondent. This conduct of the petitioner speaks volumes. If he genuinely wanted to patch up and bring the respondent and daughter back home, he could have done so either through the mediator or by giving her notice or by filing a petition for restitution of conjugal rights. He did none.  It is not sufficient for a husband to show that his wife had left him without an intention to return and that he is willing to keep the wife but she without any reasonable cause was avoiding his company. In order to support his case or to shift the burden, he must further show that the attempts were made by him to get back the wife to the matrimonial home. Further not only he should make attempts but the attempts should seem to be honest and genuine. This is exactly what is lacking in the present case. None of the attempts made by the petitioner, were honest and genuine.  Though the petitioner and the respondents are living separately from 11.7.1998 but essential parameter of the act of desertion, that is, animus deserendi is not proved by the petitioner against the respondent. On the other hand it seems from the material on record that the petitioner, who felt "relieved" when the respondent left on 11.7.1998, never wanted the respondent to come back and was waiting for two years period to get over to seek divorce on the ground of desertion. No inference on the basis of material on record can be drawn that the respondent ever intended to bring cohabitation permanently to an end. Thus, the ground of desertion has not been proved by the petitioner in the present case. The trial Court has not considered the evidence in proper perspective and as a result of which wrong conclusions on the point of desertion have been drawn. The finding of the trial Court that the respondent deserted the petitioner without any reasonable cause for two years preceding the presentation is, therefore, liable to be set aside as it is not supported from the evidence on record.	 [Para 29,30,31]

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Marriage cannot be annulled on the ground of HIV infection or any other disease - On ground of disease except mental disease no marriage can be declared as null and void under Ss.5 and 12 of the Act - This is so even assuming that wife was HIV positive before her marriage.		(Paras 8, 11, 12)

heading: Suitfor annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Suitfor annulment of marriage - Locus standi -Either party or even third party canmaintain a suit - Suit filed by father-in-lawcontained no ground for annulment ofmarriage - Proceedings in matrimonial suitquashed in writ petition filed by wife. (Paras 13, 14)

heading: Enhanced maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Enhanced maintenance - A substantive right conferred under statute - Cannot be denied merely on ground of an agreement contra between parties - Such agreement being contrary to public policy, not a valid contract and cannot operate as a bar to exercise jurisdiction under Section 25(2) - Only criteria, while considering application u/S.25(2), should be whether there is any change in circumstances justifying enhancement of compensation - Earlier order u/S.25(1) of Act granting maintenance, whether an agreed order or order on contest, immaterial.

While considering an application under Section 25(2) of the Act, the only criteria should be whether there is any change in the circumstances justifying the enhancement of compensation. Whether the earlier order under Section 25(1) of the Act granting maintenance was an agreed order or an order on contest is immaterial since the right to maintenance under Section 25 of the Act is a continuing right variable from time to time. Such discretion conferred on the Court under sub-section (2) of Section 25 to vary the maintenance awarded under sub-section (1) of Section 25 in the changed circumstances cannot be restricted and the substantive right conferred under the statute cannot be denied to a party merely on the ground of an agreement contra between the parties. As a matter of fact, such agreement defeating the right of maintenance provided under a statute being contrary to public policy is not a valid contract and therefore cannot operate as a bar to exercise the jurisdiction conferred under Section 25(2) of the Act.   [Para 28]

heading: Order on contest and an agreed order
HeadNote.description: Order on contest and an agreed order - Order, passed recording terms of settlement, becomes decree of Court - Section 25(2), either expressly or by necessary implication, does not draw any distinction between an order on contest and an agreed order - Order declining to exercise jurisdiction under Section 25(2) merely on basis of Memorandum of settlement between parties, erroneous - Dismissal of O.P. filed for further maintenance at the threshold without making enquiry into correctness of Appellant-wife's plea as to change of circumstances on ground that she was paid maintenance by virtue of an order passed by Court in terms of Memorandum of settlement, cannot be sustained - Impugned order set aside - Matter remanded to Court below for consideration afresh in accordance with law - Appeal allowed.	(Paras 29, 30, 32, 33)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Time limit for withdrawing consent - Observation in AIR 1992 SC 1904 to the effect that mutual consent should continue till the divorce decree is passed, even if the petition is not withdrawn by one of the parties within the period of 18 months is too wide and does not logically accord with S.13B (2) - Decision requires reconsideration. (Para 15)

heading: Irretrievable break down of marriage
HeadNote.description: Irretrievable break down of marriage - Petition for divorce by mutual consent - Pending for long time - Husband marrying again and begetting a child during pendency of divorce proceedings -In view of irretrievable break down, court in exercise of its powers under Art.142 of the Constitution granted a decree of divorce subject to the condition that husband payes a lump sum of Rupees Ten lakhs to the wife within a period of nine months.  (Para 21)

heading: Null and void marriage
HeadNote.description: Null and void marriage - Wife relying on a registered document of "Chhor Chithhi" from her husband - Existence of such customary divorce in Vaish Community of Maheshwaris not established - Held, in absence of decree of divorce from Court, it had to be held that in law first marriage subsisted when she went through the second marriage with the present husband and as such decree declaring second marriage as null and void could not be interfered with.		(Para 12)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Expression "at the time of passing of any decree" in S.25 - Cannot be restricted only to decree of judicial separation or divorce under the Act - It encompasses all kinds of decrees under Ss.9 to 13 of the Act - Court can, however, grant maintenance to a spouse financially weak and economically dependant.

The expression used in the opening part of Section 25 enabling the 'Court exercising jurisdiction under the Act' 'at the time of passing any decree or at any time subsequent thereto' to grant alimony or maintenance cannot be restricted only to, as contended, decree of judicial separation under Section 10 or divorce under Section 13. When the legislature has used such wide expression as 'at the time of passing of any decree,' it encompasses within the expression all kinds of decrees such as restitution of conjugal rights under Section 9, judicial separation under Section 10, declaring marriage as null and void under Section 11, annulment of marriage as voidable under Section 12 and Divorce under Section 13.  [Para 18]

It is well known and recognized legal position that customary Hindu Law like Mohammedan Law permitted bigamous marriages which were prevalent in all Hindu families and more so in royal Hindu families. It is only after the Hindu Law was codified by enactments including the present Act that bar against bigamous marriages was created by Section 5(i) of the Act. Keeping into consideration the present state of the statutory Hindu Law, a bigamous marriage may be declared illegal being in contravention of the provisions of the Act but it cannot be said to be immoral so as to deny even the right of alimony or maintenance to a spouse financially weak and economically dependant. It is with the purpose of not rendering a financially dependant spouse destitute that Section 25 enables the court to award maintenance at the time of passing any type of decree resulting in breach in marriage relationship.  [Para 20]

Section 25 is an enabling provision. It empowers the Court in a matrimonial case to consider facts and circumstances of the spouse applying and decide whether or not to grant permanent alimony or maintenance.  [Para 21]

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Second marriage of wife declared as null and void - Fact of first marriage was made known to husband and "Chhor Chithhi" obtained by wife from previous husband was shown to second husband - Second husband was an Advocate - He denied second marriage and claimed that wife was only a governess for children from the first wife - He even denied parentage of his daughter from second wife - Both of them were living as husband and wife for over nine years - Held, in such circumstances both the Family Court and High Court were fully justified in granting maintenance under S.25.	(Para 22)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Petition by husband on some ground - Wife not only defending it but making serious allegations against husband amounting to cruelty, in her written statement - Failing to prove them - Allegations found to be false and baseless - Amendment of petition not necessary - Husband entitled to decree for divorce.

Making wild, reckless and baseless allegations in the written statement itself constitutes cruelty.   [Para 17]

It cannot be permitted to defendant to make charges and then get away by saying that the petitioner must prove that those charges are false.  That apart, the court is not concerned in such cases so much with the strict construction of the definitions of the concept "proved", "not proved" and "disproved". It is concerned with a matrimonial dispute where one party has already come to the court and alleged that the other party has indulged in a cruel behaviour and thereby caused agony to him and that the petitioner can no longer live with the other party. The defence of such a respondent cannot be to make further allegations against the petitioner and then to tell him that he or she must prove that those allegations are false. The moment such serious allegations are made in a written statement, the problem gets compounded.  It is undoubtedly true that when the petitioner approaches the court seeking divorce on certain grounds, the court has to consider as to what is the substance in his grievances and the burden of proving the allegations made by him in his petition is on him or her, but in a situation where the respondent comes not merely with a defence to the allegations made in the petition so as to continue the marriage but makes counter allegations against the petitioner, it would certainly be open to the petitioner to contend that those further allegations have caused cruelty to him or her and that the respondent must prove those allegations. That apart, it would also be open to him to contend that the moment such false allegations are made, one must look at them in the context of the matrimonial harmony and the question of continuation of marriage. The problem cannot be merely looked at as a problem of making allegations and counter-allegations and as to whose allegations are true or false. The moment such allegations are made in a written statement, it becomes clear that there is an irretrievable break down of the marriage. That would certainly be a factor to be considered while deciding the plea of cruelty raised by the petitioner.   [Para 28]

It is no use making allegations if one is not in a position to prove them and, the court is concerned with the consequence of such allegations on the other party whether they are proved or not.   [Para 28]

When the petitioner husband as well as his mother both have deposed that the allegations of cruelty against them are/were false and they have caused them a severe agony it could not be said that they have taken those allegations in strides.  They could not be driven to amend the petition and then lead evidence thereafter. This will only mean prolonging the agony which both the parties are already undergoing.  It is no doubt true that as provided under section 23(1)(a) of the Hindu Marriage Act, one is not to be permitted to take advantage of his or her wrong, but that has got to be established, and unless established it cannot be contended that the petitioner is trying to take advantage of his own wrong.   [Para 28]

When one party to the petition has sought divorce on some ground and the respondent to that petition does not merely defend it to get it defeated, but makes further serious allegations against the Petitioner, it becomes a clear step towards the dissolution of the marriage.As a normal rule whether cruelty as a matrimonial wrong has been established is a question of fact and in which case it will have to be determined by taking into account the particular individual's conduct and the circumstances of the case and there cannot be any general rule. At the same time, where the Petitioner makes the grievance of cruelty on the basis of some instances and fails to establish the same, but the respondent comes up with serious allegations (such as adultery, insanity or unchastity), and fails to prove the same, it will amount by itself to cruelty by the respondent. It will not be necessary in such case for the Petitioner to amend his petition in view of those allegations in the written statement and send him back to the Trial Court when on the face of it those allegations constitute cruelty and particularly when the respondent produces no credible evidence in support thereof.  [Para 28]

In the instant petition for divorce by husband, the respondent wife made serious allegations against the husband such as adultery in her written statement but failed to prove the same, though the onus lay upon her, the allegations were found to be false, baseless and constituted cruelty. Therefore, the petitioner husband was entitled to decree for divorce.			 [Para 31,32]

heading: Alimony
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Alimony - Grant of - Divorced wife having better income than that of her husband - Not entitled to alimony.	(Para 32)

heading: Wife's petition for restitution
HeadNote.description:
Wife's petition for restitution - Wife testifying that she was ill-treated as demand for gold articles and money was not fulfilled - Circumstances made her unable to cohabit with husband inspite of her repeated attempts - Held her evidence though uncorroborated had to be taken into consideration and given due weight.

Evidence Act (1872), S.3. (Para 19)

heading: Wife's petition for restitution
HeadNote.description: Wife's petition for restitution - Husband denying marriage and then giving notice to petitioner that as per custom he was giving divorce, similar notice also published in newspaper - Held conduct of husband clearly showed that he was not ready and willing to cohabit. (Para 23)

heading: Delay in filing restitution petition
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing restitution petition - Wife living with parents since July 1988 - Stand taken by both sides that they made attempts at reconciliation but failed - Husband giving notice of divorce on 15.11.89 - Notice replied on 30.11.89 - After some more efforts wife filing petition on 31.1.91 - Held it could not be said that there was delay or that there was no explanation for delay. (Para 26)

heading: Child/minor marriage
Not void
HeadNote.description:
Child/minor marriage - Not void - Marriage solemnized in contravention of Section 5(iii) of Act, not a void marriage, although it is an offence under Section 18 of said Act - Marriage contracted by a minor either under H. M. Act or under Child Marriage Restraint Act, not illegal or void. Child Marriage Restraint Act (1929), Ss.2(a), (b), 3-6, 12. Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act (1956), Ss.6(c), 5.

Section 18 of the Act makes marriage, in contravention of the conditions specified in clauses (iii), (iv) and (v) of Section 5, of an offence and in case of contravention of condition (iii) of Section 5 the person who procures a marriage can be punished with imprisonment of fifteen days or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees or with both. Going by these provisions of law, a marriage solemnized in contravention of Section 5(iii) of the Act is not a void marriage. Therefore there is nothing in the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 which would make a marriage illegal if it is solemnized if the bride has not completed the age of 18 years. Although it is an offence under Section 18 of the Act, but, it does not make the marriage an illegal marriage.	 [Para 5,6]

heading: Application for maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Application for maintenance - Applicant second wife of her husband - Second marriage null and void when solemnised on account of subsistence of the first marriage of husband - Divorce of first wife - Parties to second marriage continue to live as husband and wife even after divorce of first marriage - Second wife entitled to the status of a wife and consequently has a right to claim maintenance. Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125.

In the present case, the evidence adduced by the wife shows that although on the date of her marriage with the husband on 2-6-1978 the first marriage of the husband was subsisting, the first marriage of the husband had come to an end with the execution of Deed of Divorce dated 7-4-1980.  It was contended on behalf of the wife that since the husband has not led any evidence to establish the subsistence of his first marriage, her testimony as well as her tendering xerox copy of the divorce deed does neither conclusively establish the validity of the first marriage of the husband nor its dissolution.  Before the Family Court, no such issue was framed and there is no finding to that effect.  Moreover, the husband instead of rebutting the above contentions, has in fact chosen to make capital out of it.  Therefore, court proceeded on the footing that the first marriage of the husband was subsisting on 2-6-1978.  If the first marriage of the husband was subsisting on the date of the second marriage, then as per law and as per the judicial decisions of the Apex Court the second marriage is null and void.  But the question in the present case is, if the first marriage has come to an end by a Divorce deed dated 7-4-1980 and both the parties to the second marriage continue to live together as husband and wife after the dissolution of the first marriage, whether the second wife can be deprived of the status of a wife ? Even though the second marriage of the husband during the subsistence of the first marriage was null and void, on the dissolution of the first marriage, if the parties to the second marriage continued to live together as husband and wife, then there is no impediment in conferring the status of 'wife' to the second wife. In other words, even if the second marriage was null and void when solemnised on account of the subsistence of the first marriage of the husband, if the parties to the second marriage continue to live as husband and wife even after the divorce of the first marriage then the second wife would be entitled to the status of a wife and consequently has a right to claim maintenance.   [Para 16]

With the ever increasing matrimonial offences, time has come for the Parliament to have a fresh look and see whether the existing laws strike a balance in the matter of rights and obligations cast upon the husband and wife in preserving the sanctity of the sacred institution of marriage.  Luckily in the present case, the first marriage of the husband ended in a divorce, as a result whereof maintenance could be granted to the wife.  But in a given case, if the wife is an innocent victim and it is only after the marriage, she realises that the husband has cheated her by not disclosing the existence of a living spouse, should the wife be at the mercy of the husband and stay with him as a concubine ? Should there be no legislation granting some protection for her to live independently in a dignified way by seeking maintenance from the husband ? In a society where the marriage between a man and woman is considered to be sacred and supposed to last beyond the existence of the physical body and extend for generations, whether the existing legislations strike a balance in the matter of matrimonial offences committed by man or a woman?  It is for the legislature to consider and take appropriate measures.  AIR 1965 SC 1564 and AIR 1975 SC 83 - Referred to.	 [Para 18]

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - Proof - Concept of proof beyond the shadow of doubt - Not to be applied to matters of delicate personal relationship as that of husband and wife.

Legal cruelty has to be found out, not merely as a matter of fact, but as the effect on the mind of the complainant spouse because of the acts or omissions of the other. Cruelty may be physical or corporeal or may be mental. In physical cruelty, there can be tangible and direct evidence, but in the case of mental cruelty there may not at the same time be direct evidence. In cases where there is no direct evidence, Courts are required to probe into the mental process and mental effect of incidents that are brought out in evidence. It is in this view that one has to consider the evidence in matrimonial disputes.   [Para 9]

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - There may be a case where conduct complained of itself is bad enough and per se unlawful or illegal - Impact or injurious effect need not then be inquired into or considered.	(Para 10)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Conduct complained of must be something more serious than "ordinary wear and tear of married life" - Before the conduct can be called "cruelty", it must touch a certain pitch of severity - It may be words, gestures or by mere silence, violent or non-violent.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - Courts should guard against hyper sensitive approach.

A too technical and hyper-sensitive approach would be counter-productive to the institution of marriage. The Courts do not have to deal with ideal husbands and ideal wives. It has to deal with particular man and woman before it. The ideal couple or a mere ideal one will probably have no occasion to go to Matrimonial Court. (See Dastane Vs. Dastane, 2007 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 13).   [Para 13]

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Wife used to frequently borrow money at the behest of her parents - If money was denied used to quarrel and threaten husband to falsely implicate him in dowry demand and kill children - She often used to keep children tied by rope and once she attempted to throw them down from rooftop - She often tortured them and threatened that she will destroy the whole family - Held, instances clearly proved that husband was subjected to mental and physical cruelty.	(Para 14)

heading: Petition by husband seeking decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Petition by husband seeking decree of divorce - Can be declined on ground that he has failed to pay maintenance to his wife and daughter despite order of the court. AIR 1988 Cal. 192 Overruled.	(Para 21)

heading:
Effect of introducing Sub-Section (1-A).

Whereas prior to the amendment a petition for divorce could be filed only by a party which had obtained a decree for judicial separation or for restitution of conjugal rights, this right is now available to either party to the marriage irrespective of whether the party presenting the petition for divorce is a decree holder or a judgment debtor under the decree for judicial separation or the decree for restitution of conjugal rights, as the case may be. This position is incontrovertible.  [Para 10]
HeadNote.description:
Effect of introducing Sub-Section (1-A).

Whereas prior to the amendment a petition for divorce could be filed only by a party which had obtained a decree for judicial separation or for restitution of conjugal rights, this right is now available to either party to the marriage irrespective of whether the party presenting the petition for divorce is a decree holder or a judgment debtor under the decree for judicial separation or the decree for restitution of conjugal rights, as the case may be. This position is incontrovertible.  [Para 10]

heading: Petition under S.13(1-A)
HeadNote.description:
Petition under S.13(1-A) - Provisions of S.3(1) are attracted - To say that right under S.13(1-A) is absolute and unqualified and that it is not subject to S.23 is fallacious.

The object of sub-section (1-A) was merely to enlarge the right to apply for divorce and not to make it compulsive that a petition for divorce presented under sub-section (1-A) must be allowed on a mere proof that there was no cohabitation or restitution for the requisite period. The very language of Section 23 shows that it governs every proceeding under the Act and a duty is cast on the Court to decree the relief sought only if the conditions mentioned in the sub-section are satisfied, and not otherwise. Therefore, the contention raised by the learned Counsel for the appellant that the provisions of Section 23(1) are not relevant in deciding a petition filed under sub-section (1-A) of Section 13 of the Act, cannot be accepted.				 [Para 12]

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.23 -Expression "taking advantage of his or her own wrong"
heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Meaning of - Failure to pay maintenance as directed by court - Is a "wrong" within meaning of S.23.

After the decree for judicial separation was passed on the petition filed by the wife it was the duty of both the spouses to do their part for cohabitation. The husband was expected to act as a dutiful husband towards the wife and the wife was to act as a devoted wife towards the husband. If this concept of both the spouses making sincere contribution for the purpose of successful cohabitation after a judicial separation is ordered then it can reasonably be said that in the facts and circumstances of the case the husband in refusing to pay maintenance to the wife failed to act as a husband. Thereby he committed a 'wrong' within the meaning of Section 23 of the Act.				 [Para 14]

heading: Relief of decree of divorce
HeadNote.description:
Relief of decree of divorce - Ground for divorce made out - Does not entitle him to a decree as of right.

If the provisions in Section 13(1-A) and Section 23(1)(a) are read together the position that emerges is that the petitioner does not have a vested right for getting the relief of a decree of divorce against the other party merely on showing that the ground in support of the relief sought as stated in the petition exists. It has to be kept in mind that relationship between the spouses is a matter concerning human life. Human life does not run on dotted lines or charted course laid down by statute. It has also to be kept in mind that before granting the prayer of the petitioner to permanently snap the relationship between the parties to the marriage every attempt should be made to maintain the sanctity of the relationship which is of importance not only for the individuals or their children but also for the society. Whether the relief of dissolution of the marriage by a decree of divorce is to be granted or not depends on the facts and circumstances of the case. In such a matter it will be too hazardous to lay down a general principle of universal application.

1977(4) SCC 12 Explained.  [Para 15,16]

heading: Decree for judicial separation
HeadNote.description:
Decree for judicial separation - Granted at the instance of wife - It does not vest any absolute right in either of them not to make any attempt for co-habitation with the other party.

On a fair reading of the sub-section (2) of S.10 it is clear that the provision applies to the petitioner on whose application the decree for judicial separation has been passed. Even assuming that the provision extends to both petitioner as well as the respondent it does not vest any absolute right in the petitioner or the respondent not to make any attempt for cohabitation with the other party after the decree for judicial separation has been passed. As the provision clearly provides the decree for judicial separation is not final in the sense that it is irreversible; power is vested in the Court to rescind the decree if it considers it just and reasonable to do so on an application by either party. The effect of the decree is that certain mutual rights and obligations arising from the marriage are as it were suspended and the rights and duties prescribed in the decree are substituted therefor. The decree for judicial separation does not sever or dissolve the marriage tie which continues to subsist. It affords an opportunity to the spouse for reconciliation and readjustment. The decree may fall by a conciliation of the parties in which case the rights of respective parties which float from the marriage and were suspended are restored. Therefore the impression that Section 10(2) vests a right in the petitioner to get the decree of divorce notwithstanding the fact that he has not made any attempt for cohabitation with the respondent and has even acted in a manner to thwart any move for cohabitation does not flow from a reasonable interpretation of the statutory provisions.		 [Para 17]

heading: Effect
HeadNote.description:
Grant of decree for judicial separation - Effect - Offence of living in adultery does not get frozen or wiped out.

Living in adultery on the part of the husband is a continuing matrimonial offence. The offence does not get frozen or wiped out merely on passing of a decree for judicial separation which as noted earlier merely suspends certain duties and obligations of the spouses in connection with their marriage and does not snap the matrimonial tie. In that view of the matter accepting the contention raised on behalf of the appellant would, defeat the very purpose of passing the decree for judicial separation. The decision of the Gujarat High Court in AIR 1979 Guj. 209 does not lay down the correct position of law. On the other hand the decision of the Madras High Court in the case of Soundarammal v. Sundara Mahalinga Nadar, AIR 1980 Madras 294, in which a single Judge took the view that the husband who continued to live in adultery even after decree at the instance of wife could not succeed in petition seeking decree for divorce and that Section 23(1)(a) barred the relief, has our approval. Therein the learned Judge held and rightly that illegality and immorality cannot be countenanced as aids for a person to secure relief in matrimonial matters.  AIR 1980 Mad. 294 Approved of AIR 1979 Guj 209 Overruled.			 [Para 20]

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Mental cruelty - Wife removing Mangalsutra and bangles in privacy to please husband and at his instance - Husband cannot complain of mental cruelty on him by wife.

It is no doubt true that Mangalsutra around the neck of a wife is a sacred thing for a Hindu wife as it symbolises continuance of Married life. A Hindu wife removes her Mangalsutra only after the death of her husband. But here we are not concerned with a case where a wife after tearing her Mangalsutra threw at her husband and walked out of her husband's house. Here is a case where a wife while in privacy, occasionally has been removing her Mangalsutra and bangles on asking of her husband with a view to please him. If the removal of Mangalsutra was something wrong amounting to mental cruelty, as submitted by learned counsel for the appellant, it was the husband who instigated his wife to commit that wrong and thus was an abettor. Under such circumstances the appellant cannot be allowed to take advantage of a wrong done by his wife for which he himself was responsible. In such a case the appellant cannot be allowed to complain that his wife is guilty of committing an act of mental cruelty upon him, and further by such an act, has suffered mental pain and agony as a result of which married life has broken down, and he is not expected to live with his wife. It also appears to us that, whenever the appellant asked her wife for removal of her Mangalsutra, the respondent never comprehended that her husband at any point of time would react to such occurrences in the way he did. Under such circumstances, the appellant was not expected to have made an issue out of it. We are, therefore, of the view that removal of Mangalsutra by the respondent would not constitute mental cruelty within the meaning of Section 13(1)(ia) of the Act.  [Para 8]

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Mental cruelty - Wife preserving and maintaining copies of letters written by her to her husband - Cannot be termed as an act of cruelty.

The view taken by the High Court was that mere retention of copies of the letters would not amount to mental cruelty. We also find that if the wife had any intention to use copies of those letters she would have filed the same before the trial Court. Excepting filing a counter-affidavit the respondent-wife did not file any copy of the letters sent to her husband, whereas the husband has filed all the letters sent to him by his wife in the Court which were exhibited. The respondent-wife in her testimony stated that she wrote several letters to her husband, but her husband did not reply any of them and as such she started preserving the copies of the letters sent by her to her husband. This act of the respondent, according to us, is a most natural behaviour of human being placed in such circumstances. Thus, we find mere preserving the copies of the letters by the wife does not constitute an act which amounts to mental cruelty, and as a result of which it becomes impossible for the husband to live with his wife.  [Para 10]

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Mental cruelty - Parents of wife making representation to Women's Protection cell - Neither husband nor his relatives in any way harassed by the Cell - Mental cruelty is not made out. (Para 11)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Wild and reckless allegations made in bulky written statement containing 46 paragraphs - Contents of the allegations would cause mental agony and torture and would make it impossible for wife to live with the husband - Husband withdrawing unconditionally all the allegations but repeating same allegations in a subsequent application - Held it could not be said that allegations were genuinely given up and that they were very much there on record and would cause mental cruelty and suffering making it impossible for her to live with the husband. AIR 1986 Raj. 13 and AIR 1994 SC 710 Rel. on. 	(Paras 24, 47)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Wild and reckless allegations - Wife showing her willingness to reconcile after unconditional withdrawal of allegations by husband - But husband repeating same allegations in subsequent application - Held even assuming that wife had condoned cruelty husband had revived cruelty by repeating allegations that were withdrawn - Hence there was no condonation of cruelty.

AIR 1975 SC 1534 Rel. on. (Para 49)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Cruelty by making wild and reckless allegations against character of wife proved - Spouses living apart for several years - Efforts of Court to persuade them to reconcile yielding no result - Held case of mental cruelty was made out and since there was an irretrievable break down of marriage decree of divorce has to be affirmed. (Para 50)

heading: Challenge by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Challenge by wife - Wife claiming that statutory requirement of living separately for period of one year prior to filing of petition u/S.13B not fulfilled - First and second motion statement showing that parties living separately for more than one year - Further, plea of wife that she was forced and threatened to sign on motion statements and decree was obtained by misrepresentation of facts and coercion - Wife was represented by counsel throughout proceedings - But she never brought to notice of Court that she was under any coercion - Record showing that after recording first motion statement, wife went to U.K., therefore there was no question of threat or coercion to her to return to India and record second statement - Plea of wife not tenable - Marriage between parties dissolved after following due procedure - Court has recorded its satisfaction, after making inquiry into correctness of terms and conditions of compromise deed arrived between parties and in presence of wife - Decree of divorce, proper. (Paras 9, 10, 12)

heading:
Concept of marriage.

Marriage as a social institution is an affirmance of civilized social order where two individuals, capable of entering into wedlock, have pledged themselves to the institutional norms and values and promised to each other a cemented bond to sustain and maintain the marital obligation. It stands as an embodiment for continuance of the human race. Despite the pledge and promises, on certain occasions, individual incompatibilities, attitudinal differences based upon egocentric perception of situations, maladjustment phenomenon or propensity for non-adjustment or refusal for adjustment gets eminently projected that compels both the spouses to take intolerable positions abandoning individual responsibility, proclivity of asserting superiority complex, betrayal of trust which is the cornerstone of life, and sometimes a pervert sense of revenge, a dreadful diet, or sheer sense of envy bring the cracks in the relationship when either both the spouses or one of the spouses crave for dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Concept of marriage.

Marriage as a social institution is an affirmance of civilized social order where two individuals, capable of entering into wedlock, have pledged themselves to the institutional norms and values and promised to each other a cemented bond to sustain and maintain the marital obligation. It stands as an embodiment for continuance of the human race. Despite the pledge and promises, on certain occasions, individual incompatibilities, attitudinal differences based upon egocentric perception of situations, maladjustment phenomenon or propensity for non-adjustment or refusal for adjustment gets eminently projected that compels both the spouses to take intolerable positions abandoning individual responsibility, proclivity of asserting superiority complex, betrayal of trust which is the cornerstone of life, and sometimes a pervert sense of revenge, a dreadful diet, or sheer sense of envy bring the cracks in the relationship when either both the spouses or one of the spouses crave for dissolution of marriage - freedom from the institutional and individual bond.        [Para 2]

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description:
Desertion - As a ground of divorce.

A husband or wife would be entitled to a dissolution of marriage by decree of divorce if the other party has deserted the party seeking the divorce for a continuous period of not less than two years immediately preceding the presentation of the petition. Desertion, as a ground for divorce, was inserted to Section 13 by Act 68/1976. Prior to the amendment it was only a ground for judicial separation.

For the offence of desertion so far as the deserting spouse is concerned, two essential conditions must be there (1) the factum of separation, and (2) the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end (animus deserendi). Similarly two elements are essential so far as the deserted spouse is concerned: (1) the absence of consent, and (2) absence of conduct giving reasonable cause to the spouse leaving the matrimonial home to form the necessary intention aforesaid. For holding desertion as proved the inference may be drawn from certain facts which may not in another case be capable of leading to the same inference; that is to say the facts have to be viewed as to the purpose which is revealed by those acts or by conduct and expression of intention, both anterior and subsequent to the actual acts of separation.         [Para 15,16]

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Subsequent conduct of wife - Can be noted to show pattern of behaviour and conduct on basis of non-disputed material brought on record - Divorce petition on ground of desertion - Subsequent events of mental cruelty - Apex court can in its power under Art.142 take notice of and decide case itself without asking respondent husband to amend petition and direct family court to consider issue of mental cruelty - It would be logical to do so and illogical to refrain from doing so. (Para 23)

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Mental cruelty - What constitutes.

Mental cruelty and its effect cannot be stated with arithmetical exactitude. It varies from individual to individual, from society to society and also depends on the status of the persons. What would be a mental cruelty in the life of two individuals belonging to particular strata of the society may not amount to mental cruelty in respect of another couple belonging to a different stratum of society. The agonized feeling or for that matter a sense of disappointment can take place by certain acts causing a grievous dent at the mental level. The inference has to be drawn from the attending circumstances. In this case allegations were made against him which were not correct; his relatives were dragged into the matrimonial controversy, the assertions in the written statement depict him as if he had tacitly conceded to have harboured notions of gender insensitivity or some kind of male chauvinism, his parents and he are ignored in the naming ceremony of the son, and he come to learn from others that the wife had gone to Gulbarga to prosecute her studies. That apart, the communications, after the decree for restitution of conjugal rights, indicate the attitude of the wife as if she is playing a game of Chess. The launching of criminal prosecution can be perceived from the spectrum of conduct. The learned Magistrate has recorded the judgment of acquittal. The wife had preferred an appeal before the High Court after obtaining leave. After the State Government prefers an appeal in the Court of Session, she chooses to withdraw the appeal. But she intends, as the pleadings would show, that the case should reach the logical conclusion. The sanguine concept of marriage presumably has become illusory and it would not be inapposite to say that the wife has shown anaemic emotional disposition to the husband. Therefore, the decree of divorce granted by the High Court deserves to be affirmed singularly on the ground of mental cruelty.           [Para 37,38]

heading: Desertion
Animus deserendi
HeadNote.description:
Desertion - Animus deserendi - Facts that respondent stayed away without consent of petitioner and that there is no readiness and willingness of respondent to return to matrimonial home without any reasonable cause - Leads to conclusion that there is animus deserendi - Burden lies on petitioner to prove such facts.

For matrimonial offence of desertion, so far as the deserting spouse is concerned, there are two essential conditions, namely,

(i) the factum of separation; and

(ii) the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end (animus deserendi).

Similarly two elements are essential so far as the deserted spouse is concerned, namely,

(i) the absence of consent; and

(ii) the absence of conduct giving reasonable cause to the spouse leaving the matrimonial home to form the necessary intention referred to above.

No doubt it is the petitioner for divorce who bears the burden of proving these elements in both the spouses respectively. But all these elements are questions of fact. The circumstances that the deserting spouse has physically stayed away from the matrimonial home; that there is absence of consent for such stay from the deserted spouse; that there is a failure to substantiate any reason for such stay; and that there is a clear omission to demonstrate readiness and willingness to discharge the continuing obligation to return to the matrimonial home, taken together, may be sufficient to draw a conclusion that there was an animus deserendi and the same was without a reasonable cause. Once such desertion is established, there is no obligation on the deserted spouse to appeal to the deserting spouse to change his or her mind or actually take steps to effect a reconciliation or bring the deserting spouse back to the matrimonial home.      [Para 16]

heading: Divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of desertion - Respondent wife left matrimonial home on her own - When she left, there was no animus deserendi - But she continued to stay away and did not return - No justification given except that husband did not come to take wife back - Even after filing of divorce petition, wife filed several matrimonial petitions and criminal proceedings - It shows that not only animus deseredi has continued but also matrimonial bond is beyond repair - It would be grave injustice if marital tie is not severed - Divorce granted.(Paras 17, 20, 22, 23)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband alleging cruelty and desertion - Similar allegations by wife against husband - Fact that petitioner was a divorcee neither revealed in the matrimonial advertisement nor disclosed to the respondent before solemnization of present marriage - Divorce in both the marriages sought on almost identical allegations - Even pending the appeal husband came out with a fresh matrimonial advertisement for third marriage - Further, facts show that husband was not only cruel but made the wife to leave matrimonial home - Divorce cannot be granted to him. 	(Paras 10 to 14)

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description: Desertion - Husband with his conduct brought a situation where the wife had no other option but to leave matrimonial home - In such a case husband cannot seek divorce on ground of desertion - He cannot take advantage of his own wrong. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Nullity of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Nullity of marriage - Petition filed by husband - Husband is 'Parsi', wife is 'Hindu' - Both practiced their own religion even after getting married - Provisions of Hindu Marriage Act cannot be availed - Order of Family Court dismissing petition as barred by law, upheld. 
2014(5) ALL MR 292, AIR 2010 Gujarat 3, 1997(4) ALL MR 20 Ref. to.(Para 17)

heading: Nullity of marriage
HeadNote.description: Nullity of marriage - Husband filed petition for nullity after 12 years of marriage - During this period baby was born out of said wedlock - No reason pointed out showing what compelled him to suddenly realise that wife belonged to different religion - Husband is taking advantage of his own wrong - No cause of action to the husband to file petition - Same is barred by law - Hence, dismissed.(Para 18)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Respondent alleging that wife used to throw away medicines brought by him during the pregnancy - Allegation not established by evidence - Ever assuming that it was proved it was too trivial in nature to cause any cruelty within meaning of S.13(1)(ia). (Para 9)

heading: Condonation of Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Condonation of Cruelty - Wife throwing away medicines brought by husband during her pregnancy - After normal delivery spouses leading normal sexual life - Held ever if it is assumed that incident of throwing medicines amounted to cruelty it was condoned by the husband. (Para 10)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - After receiving notice of petition for divorce wife filing criminal complaint under S.498-A and 506 with the police against the husband and his family members - All of them acquitted after trial - Evidence by wife in divorce case showing that case made out by her about harassment for getting more money from her father was not totally false - Similarly her complaint under Ss. 498-A and 506 was not totally false, baseless and vexatious - No averment by husband that it was not possible for him to live with her because of her conduct - On the contrary evidence showing that he was trying to contact second marriage and was demanding Rs.40,000 as dowry by misrepresenting that he has already secured divorce - Held in the circumstances trial court was not right in granting decree of divorce to the husband. (Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Claim for by husband on ground of cruelty - Husband claiming that wife is short tempered and used to pick up quarrel - She  allegedly used to break utensils by throwing them away whenever quarrel took place - Further, she has habit of leaving for her parental home immediately after creating such scenes and without consent of husband - On many occasions husband had to follow her even at odd night hours - Wife used to rise late in morning and also refused to cook food for husband in time - She used to humiliate husband in presence of strangers and guests in house - Husband gave specific details of incidents - Wife claiming that husband is drunkard and used to ill-treat her for demand of dowry - If wife was really ill-treated, she would have complained to authorities against such domestic violence - No evidence of such complaint was ever adduced - Further, stand of wife that she is prepared to live with husband improbablises her allegations as to domestic violence - None of allegations of mental cruelty were specifically denied by wife in her counter statement - It must be deemed to be admission in proof of allegations of cruelty by virtue of principle as to evasive denial incorporated u/O.8 R.5 - There is enough material from testimony of husband and circumstances of case to prove that wife treated husband with cruelty - Husband entitled to decree of divorce on ground of mental cruelty. 			(Paras 17, 19, 20, 22, 26, 27)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Claim for by husband - Ground of desertion - S.13(1)(i-b) does not permit spouse to sue for divorce on ground of desertion before continuous period of desertion completes two years - Alleged desertion was in month of December 2008 - Petition filed in month of January 2009 - Order refusing claim of husband, proper. (Para 11)

heading: Matrimonial cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description: Matrimonial cruelty - Proof - In proof of matrimonial cruelties both mental and physical, it is quite insensible and impractical for Courts to insist on adduction of independent evidence - As in most of matrimonial cases, such cruelties usually take place only within four walls of one’s own house - It gives no opportunity to outsiders of house to witness alleged acts of cruelties - Family Courts, therefore will have to proceed with inquiry into truth of allegations, confined to sole testimonies of spouses before them, rather than rejecting them as being interested. 	(Para 14)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Claim for
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - Claim for - Will not be defeated on ground of alleged condonation of cruelty, when relationship between spouses is again estranged. 

	Condonation of cruelty is a benevolent and generous act of an offended spouse forgiving the misdeeds of the offending spouse and restoring the latter to the original company. In every condonation there is an implied condition that the excused spouse will not repeat or commit matrimonial wrongs in future. No wrong is permanently wiped out by condonation; but is only hibernated. The reunion of spouses for a temporary period during the pendency of the proceeding for divorce pursuant to settlement of matrimonial issues will not defeat the claim for dissolution of marriage on the ground of alleged condonation of cruelty nor will it bar continuance of the proceeding when their relationship is again estranged. The alleged condonation can put an end to the proceeding only when the complaining spouse has led a normal and intimate life uninfluenced by the conduct of the offending spouse, in such a manner that the wronged spouse has pardoned and restored the offending spouse to the original status. Nothing of that sort happened in present case. The reunion lasted only for a temporary period and the spouses failed to carry on a normal and harmonious life. Therefore, the plea raised by the learned counsel for the respondent for dismissal of the original petition on the ground of alleged condonation of cruelty is liable only to be refused.	(Paras 24, 25)

heading: Cruelty
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Mental cruelty - High Court holding that no question of mental cruelty to each other can arise when parties were not living together - Held, conclusion drawn by High Court was erroneous.

The High Court wrongly held that because the appellant-husband and the respondent-wife did not stay together there is no question of the parties causing cruelty to each other. Staying together under the same roof is not a pre-condition for mental cruelty. Spouse can cause mental cruelty by his or her conduct even while he or she is not staying under the same roof. In a given case, while staying away, a spouse can cause mental cruelty to the other spouse by sending vulgar and defamatory letters or notices or filing complaints containing indecent allegations or by initiating number of judicial proceedings making the other spouse's life miserable. This is what has happened in this case. 	 [Para 9,24]

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Mental cruelty - Wife complaining to Women Protection Cell that mother of husband asked her to sleep with husband's father - Mother of wife in her cross-examination deposing that her daughter lodged such complaint with a hope that under pressure husband may take her back - Such statements cause mental cruelty and it is not the way to win husband back. 	 (Para 22)

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Mental cruelty - Wife making unfounded, indecent and defamatory allegation against her mother-in-law, filing revision seeking enhancement of sentence awarded to husband, filing appeal questioning acquittal of husband and his parents shows that she made all efforts to see that her husband and his parents are put in jail and he is removed from his job - Held all this amounts to causing mental cruelty to husband. 	(Para 23)

heading: Irretrievable breakdown of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Is a very weighty circumstance amongst others necessitating severance of marital tie.

Irretrievable breakdown of marriage is not a ground for divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. But, where marriage is beyond repair on account of bitterness created by the acts of the husband or the wife or of both, the courts have always taken irretrievable breakdown of marriage as a very weighty circumstance amongst others necessitating severance of marital tie. A marriage which is dead for all purposes cannot be revived by the court's verdict, if the parties are not willing. This is because marriage involves human sentiments and emotions and if they are dried-up there is hardly any chance of their springing back to life on account of artificial reunion created by the court's decree. 	    [Para 26]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Both husband and wife were living apart for more than ten years - Wife caused extreme mental cruelty to husband making marriage beyond repair - Wife, however, was not earning and was entirely dependent on her parents and brother - Husband directed to pay Rupees fifteen lakhs as and by way of permanent alimony, in matrimonial cases one spouse is never entirely at fault. 	(Paras 30, 31)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Whether husband withdrew himself from wife's company and society without just and reasonable cause - Wife filed petition u/s.9 on various grounds - That husband was indifferent, never in matrimonial home with her - That he never visited her or returned her calls - That he did not pay for abortion and never enquired about it - Also, never gave her any gift - These grounds not sufficient evidence - Physical separation between them was fact owing to different places of work - Which was also known before marriage - Wife before marriage agreed to seek transfer - Whenever they were together in each other's cities or travelling together, they lived as man and wife - They had conjugal relations - Husband was not in city when she visited is only isolated incident - Not course of conduct to be called as withdrawal by husband from her society - Restitution of conjugal rights rightly denied. 			(Paras 2, 4, 12)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - Husband alleges wife has extra marital affair - Trial court dismissed petition holding that allegation is unsupported by evidence - Husband's allegation that marriage was never consummated is against his own evidence - Issue is of wife's failure and refusal to abide by her commitment to seek transfer - To term this as cruelty is unreasonable - Allegations are conceived in anger and malice - Divorce cannot be granted.

Cruelty as a matrimonial wrong, has an inseparable nexus with human conduct. The social strata or milieu to which the parties belong, their chosen way of life, respective temperaments and emotions, are all factors that must be weighed while assessing the act of 'cruelty' alleged in support of a petition for divorce. To find for the husband, we must have evidence of a course of conduct beyond ordinary trials and tribulations of any marriage, something of sufficient gravity and weight. This conduct need not be physical. A consistent pattern of indifference or neglect would, in a given case, suffice. This is not such a case.             [Para 13,14,16,18]

heading: Irretrievable breakdown of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Doctrine of ex debito justitiae - Husband re-married and sought divorce on ground of "irretrievable breakdown of marriage" - Also, seeking following up of doctrine of ex debito justitiae - Held, relief sought by husband cannot be granted since first appellate court is not vested with plenary jurisdiction - That can be done only by Supreme Court under Art.142 - Even otherwise "irretrievable breakdown of marriage" is no ground of divorce.
2006(4) ALL MR 190 (S.C.), 2005(5) ALL MR 1012 (S.C.) Ref. to.
2009(6) ALL MR 515 (S.C.), 2010 ALL SCR 1196, 2010 ALL SCR 1860, 2013 ALL SCR 993 Rel. on. 	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Matrimonial proceedings pending
HeadNote.description:
Matrimonial proceedings pending - Application for interim maintenance need not necessarily be only to family court under S.24 of Hindu Marriage Act.

(1993) 3 SCC 406 Rel.on. (Para 5)

heading: Family Courts Act (1984), S.9(1)
HeadNote.description: Family Courts Act (1984), S.9(1) - Divorce by mutual consent - Duty of court to endeavour for a settlement - Where parties living separately for a long period, extent of which is beyond period stipulated in the Act - And parties mutually agreed for divorce by verdict of court - In such cases, 'settlement' need not invariably be that of reunion of spouses - But it can be by way of facilitating an easy legal dissolution. 	(Para 4)

heading: Considerations
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of mental cruelty - Considerations - Concept of cruelty varies from time to time, place to place and from individual to individual in its application according to social status, economic conditions and various other considerations - Each case is to be judged on its facts. 	(Para 24)

heading: Divorce petition
Plea of desertion
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Plea of desertion - Proof - Petitioner has to prove that apart from factum of physical separation for a continuous period of more than two years before institution of proceedings, the guilty spouse had been residing separately with an intent to put marital ties to an end.	(Para 31)

heading: Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - When the validity of marriage is not established, it would not be appropriate to grant maintenance under S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act - However, in view of cohabitation, maintenance can be granted under S.20 of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act. (1993) 3 SCC 406, (2006) 5 SCC 461 Ref. to. 	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Proof - Respondent alleging that on the very first night of the marriage the appellant wife told him that his mother is over-wise - Allegation denied by appellant wife - Held it was unlikely that a woman would on the very first night would say so. (Para 13)

heading: Mental cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description: Mental cruelty - Proof - Wife during seventh month of her pregnancy left respondent's house and went to her parents in the city itself without anybody's consent or without performing customary ceremonies - Held this would, at the most, amount to irresponsible behaviour but would not cause any mental cruelty. (Para 13)

heading: Cruelty
Proof of
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Proof of - Appellant wife alleged to be taking contraceptive pills without respondent's consent, alleged to have left for parents home in the city without consent during her pregnancy, alleged to have shaved off her daughter's hair without his consent, alleged to have bitten his finger very badly and threw the child from the bed, alleged to have pulled his hair after insulting his parents - Held all these incidents even assuming to be true would only amount to normal wear and tear of matrimonial life and would not amount to 'cruelty' within meaning of S.13(1)(ia). (Para 14)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Wife giving interview to the press much after the petition was filed - Interview was about problems suffered by women whose houses are broken - From interview intention to defame respondent or his family members could not be inferred because she narrated her sufferings - Held case of mental cruelty could not thereby be established. (Para 18)

heading: Petition for divorce
Petition dismissed
HeadNote.description:
Petition for divorce - Petition dismissed - Permanent maintenance for wife or children could not be granted - Remedy is to apply under S.18 of Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act (1956)

1993 Crl.L.J. 2930 Referred. (Para 21)

heading: Second marriage
HeadNote.description: Second marriage - During pendency of appeal - Held, restriction placed by S.15 of HM Act on second marriage till dismissal of appeal, would not apply to a case where parties have settled and decided not to pursue appeal. 	(Para 19)

heading: Second marriage
Legality
HeadNote.description: Second marriage - During pendency of appeal - Legality - Pending appeal, settlement arrived between appellant and his first wife - Pursuant to settlement, appellant applied for withdrawal of appeal - However, before order of Court on said application, appellant entered second marriage - In such circumstances, held, second marriage cannot be said to be illegal - Firstly, withdrawal has effect from date of application and not from date of order - Secondly, S.15 is enacted for protection of person who files appeal against decree of divorce - If purposive interpretation of S.15 is made, restriction under said provision would not apply if appellant himself is not willing to pursue appeal - Appellant's first marriage was not subsisting when he married again - Second marriage not illegal. (1978) 3 SCC 258, (1975) 1 SCC 405, 2003(2) ALL MR 24, (1962) 2 SCR 538 Rel. on. 		(Paras 10, 12, 18, 19, 24)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Decree in favour of wife - Challenge - Son born to parties within 8 ½ months of marriage - Allegation that wife refused to have physical relationship, baseless - No bill produced by husband to show that medical expenses on birth of son were paid by him - Child born at wife's maternal place and expenses born by that side only - Though appellant visited there on next day of birth, he was annoyed that he was not properly informed - Thereafter, he never took back his wife and son - Even when family members of wife took her to matrimonial home, she was not allowed to enter - Appellant clearly stated that he did not want to keep her - Other evidence shows that appellant always wanted to save his money and shift burden on wife's parents - He denied paternity of child only at stage of arguments, which also reveal his intention to avoid liability - He never maintained wife and never tried to reconcile dispute but only blamed wife for living separately - On contrary, evidence shows that wife tried many times to resume matrimonial cohabitation - Impugned decree not to be interfered with.	(Paras 11, 12, 15, 17, 18, 26)

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Reasonable cause for living apart - To be shown by spouse who has withdrawn from society of other spouse - However, in this regard, S.9 must be read with S.23 which imposes on Court the duty to enquire into and pass a decree after satisfying itself about certain matters - Petitioner must show his bonafide desire to resume matrimonial cohabitation and to render rights and duties of matrimonial relation. 		(Para 19)

heading: Husband's application for dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Husband's application for dissolution of marriage - Decree for restitution of conjugal rights passed in favour of husband - Evidence showing that husband and his mother gave threats to the wife and made it impossible for her to resume co-habitation - She had to file police complaint which fact husband tried to suppress - Held husband has failed to discharge the burden which lay upon him to prove that he was not taking advantage of his own wrong - He was not entitled to decree of dissolution of marriage. (Para 23)

heading: "wrong" and 'advantage' of his or her own wrong
HeadNote.description:
"wrong" and 'advantage' of his or her own wrong - Wrong means something more than mere disinclination - It has to be serious or grave misconduct on the part of the party seeking dissolution of marriage.
1981 Mah. L.J. 917 Overruled. (Para 22)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Not complying with decree of restitution of conjugal rights - Cannot by itself provide a cause for granting dissolution of marriage.
AIR 1968  Puj. & Har.    287 held rightly dissented from in 1981 Mah.L.J. 917. (Para 22)

heading: Not proper
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance to wife - Declined, on count that her previous marriage is not yet dissolved by Court and that she has obtained lump sum amount of Rs.1 lac from her first husband - Not proper - Interim maintenance u/S.24 cannot be denied to wife during pendency of petition for declaration of nullity of marriage, as issue of legality of marriage is yet to be decided - Marriage between parties had taken place in 2009 and up to 2014, they resided together and also having one daughter born out of wed-lock - Husband cannot mix up with his liability of providing interim maintenance to wife with whatever lump-sum amount she might have received from her first husband - Wife entitled to interim maintenance.  1996(1) ALL MR 136, 2008 SCC On Line P&H 1036 Rel. on. 	(Paras 16, 26)

heading: Refusal to grant
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance to wife - Refusal to grant - Challenge - Admission of wife that she was working earlier and that she was compelled to work even after birth of her daughter, though she did not want to do so - Husband contended that wife is still working - However, neither salary certificate nor income tax return is produced to that effect - In absence of any documentary evidence, wife entitled to get interim maintenance, especially considering fact that she is having liability to look after her small school going daughter.	(Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Application under
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Application under - Maintainability - U/S.18 wife entitled to seek maintenance only if marriage is subsisting - A divorced wife can seek maintenance only U/S.25 of Marriage Act.1993 Mh.L.J. 1731 - Rel. on.	(Para 23)

heading: Period of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Appeal in matrimonial cases - Period of limitation - S.19(3) of Family Courts Act provides for limiting period of 30 days - Whereas by virtue of 2003 Amendment, limiting period in Hindu Marriage Act raised to 90 days - Held, limitation of 90 days would apply considering object of 2003 Amendment - No need to invoke non obstante provision under Family Courts Act as there is no direct conflict between two statutes.

The provisions of Section 28 (4) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 came to be amended in the year 2003 consequent to the suggestion given by the Apex Court in Savitri Pandey's case [AIR 2002 SC 591].
