If the requirement of domicile in India is omitted altogether, the Act shall have no nexus with India which shall render the Act vulnerable on the ground that extra-territorial operation has no nexus with India. This extra-territorial operation of law is saved not because of nexus with Hindus but Hindus domiciled in India.

2005 (3) Raj 1791, AIR 2006 Kerala 275, AIR 1973 Cal 425 Overruled.		     [Para 14]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Act will apply to Hindu outside the territory of India only if such a Hindu is domiciled in the territory of India.		(Para 20)

heading: Applicability of Act
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Petition by wife for judicial separation and custody of child - Husband and wife having domicile of origin in India - At time of marriage husband had acquired domicile of Sweden as domicile of choice - Subsequently both husband and wife receiving citizenship in Sweden - After- wards both husband and wife went to Australia they had not acquired citizenship of Australia and husband's claim of being domiciled in Australia was not proved by sufficient material - Held, husband had not abandoned domicile of origin in India and as such petition for separation and custody of child was maintainable by wife in India. 		(Paras 26, 27, 28)

heading: Petition for divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce - Ground of desertion - Evidence of petitioner and respondent - Merely because the Trial Court could not decide which evidence should be believed, held, that is no reason to allow the petition for divorce. 1992 Mh.L.J. 1098 and 2008 (5) ALL MR 702 : 2008(5) Bom.C.R. 1 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Evidence of petitioner-husband that respondent-wife attempted to commit suicide or ran to river to commit suicide and the petitioner brought her back and such happening more than once, held, shows that life of the respondent was miserable.			(Para 12)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Held, what is cruel treatment is to a large extent is a question of fact. (Para 5)

heading: Interference with
HeadNote.description: Petition for dissolution of marriage - Leave to present the petition before expiry of one year from the date of marriage - Grant of leave by trial Court - Interference with - Held, the Appellate Court will not interfere with the trial Judge's discretion unless he has proceeded on a wrong principle of law, or failed to have regard to some material consideration or some gross injustice has occurred. AIR 1957 Mad. 423 - Ref. to. (Para 6)

heading: Divorce petition
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Maintainability - One of the parties is not Hindu, which is a formal defect - Petition not maintainable under Hindu Marriage Act on that count. (Para 8)

heading: Divorce petition
Dismissal
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Dismissal - Appeal against - One of the parties is not Hindu, therefore petition was not maintainable - However, trial court dismissed petition on a different ground - Though petition in favour of respondent is not permitted to be withdrawn, respondent did not appear and was ex-parte before trial court - Therefore, appellant granted liberty to file fresh petition or suit for same subject matter. (Para 8)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (1966), Art.23
HeadNote.description: International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (1966), Art.23 - Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948), Art.16 - Marriage and marital relationship - Marriage involves contract to be married, living together as husband and wife and publicity that they are married - Various obligations and duties flow from marital relationship unlike the cases of live-in- relationship or marriage-like relationship.	(Paras 23, 24, 30, 31, 32)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - In a given case it may be no more than persistent attitude wholly inimical to relationship.

The "cruelty" in matrimonial law is undefined, and lends itself to myriad interpretations, each dependent on its factual context, is now well-settled. It must be seen if there is evidence of some course of conduct sufficiently grave, beyond the vicissitudes of daily life, as would make it impossible reasonably to expect the complaining spouse to live with the other. There is no longer any legal requirement of proof of apprehension of harm, injury or physical violence. Much of the evidentiary material is, of necessity, inferential. One party's inability to fully compromise and adjust may not, per se, constitute cruelty. It is true that cruelty sometimes walks in silence. It may, in a given case, be no more than a persistent attitude wholly inimical to the relationship.

In the instant case, a little short of three years after their marriage, S and Y had a son. The trajectory of this marriage does not, therefore, indicate that S's wanting a separate residence was seen by either Y or his parents as fatal to the marriage. Demanding privacy and there is evidence that this was admittedly lacking in the confined spaces of the matrimonial home and a separate residence is not, per se, an act of cruelty, even mental cruelty or emotional trauma. How the parties responded to this must be gauged. In the instant case, contention that on the pleadings and evidence and looking to the conduct of the parties, it is not possible to hold in favour of the husband on ground of cruelty on this ground, is correct.

2010(3) ALL MR 977, 2010(2) ALL MR 925 (S.C.), 2005(5) ALL MR 313 (S.C.) Rel. on. 				           [Para 9,10]

heading: Divorce
Desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Desertion - Factum of separation, deserting spouse's intention to cease co-habitation permanently, lack of other spouse's consent and absence of evidence that other spouse's conduct forced deserting spouse out of matrimonial home must be in existence to prove desertion - Wife leaving home when the son was seven months old - Son in custody of husband since then - Attempt at co-habitation not made by wife - No proof that wife was forcibly driven out of house - Husband, held, was entitled to divorce on ground of desertion. 	(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty - Alleged acts of cruelty, whether condoned - Husband had filed a petition u/s.9 for restitution of conjugal rights prior to divorce petition - Filing of such petition u/s.9 was nothing but a clear act of condonation of alleged cruelty - In terms of S.23(1)(b), husband cannot seek divorce on ground of cruelty. 	(Para 12)

heading: Divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of desertion - Husband and wife not cohabiting prior to 3 years of filing of divorce petition - Wife declined to resume cohabitation on ground that there was a threat to her life and limb - But, no attempt made to substantiate said plea in her evidence - Even in maintenance proceedings she declined to resume cohabitation - Only inference that can be drawn is of intention of wife to desert husband - Husband entitled to decree of divorce on ground of desertion. 			(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Maintenance and permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Maintenance and permanent alimony - Husband claiming his income to be approximately Rs.10,000/- p.m. - Offering to pay maintenance of Rs.7000/- p.m. to daughter - Offer accepted with a direction that maintenance will be payable to daughter till her marriage and expenditure for her education shall also be reimbursed - Wife would be entitled to permanent alimony of Rs.3000/- p.m. - Liberty also given to wife to approach Family Court for enhancement in view of her claim that husband earns more and possessed of large immovable property. 	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Refusal to consummate marriage during honeymoon period of four days - Refusal because wife was undergoing menstrual cycle - No allegation that she continued refusal after that period - Marriage cannot be dissolved on this ground.		(Paras 8, 18)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Vague and general allegations about quarrel with parents of husband - Wife went to Nashik for office work for three days after one month of marriage despite husband's advice not to do so - That she occasionally used to wear shirt and pant while going to office which was not liked by husband - Such trivial instances are not sufficient to grant divorce on ground of mental cruelty. 			(Paras 11, 12, 14)

heading: Cruelty
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Mental cruelty - Mere trivial irritations, quarrels, normal wear and tear of married life would not be adequate for grant of divorce on ground of cruelty. 

The married life should be assessed as a whole and a few isolated instances over certain period will not amount to cruelty. The ill-conduct must be preceded for a fairly lengthy period where the relationship has deteriorated to an extent that because of the acts and behaviour of a spouse, one party finds it extremely difficult to live with the other party no longer may amount to mental cruelty. Mere trivial irritations, quarrels, normal wear and tear of married life which happens in day to day life in all families would not be adequate for grant of divorce on the ground of cruelty. Only sustained unjustified and reprehensible conduct affecting physical and mental health of the other spouse may lead to mental cruelty. There is no evidence to that effect in the present case.  [Para 7]

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of cruelty - False criminal prosecution by spouse - May amount to cruelty even if criminal court does not record a finding that prosecution is false.

 Whether a particular act will constitute cruelty or not will depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. Whether an order of acquittal in criminal prosecution lodged at the instance of the spouse amounts to cruelty will depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. Whether the criminal Court has recorded a finding that the prosecution case was false is again not a clinching factor. Considering the evidence on record, the Matrimonial Court will have to decide whether the prosecution which resulted into acquittal will amount to an act of cruelty. In a given case, depending upon the evidence on record, even if the acquittal is on the ground that the charge could not be substantiated and even if there is no finding recorded by the Criminal Court that the prosecution case was false, there can be a case of cruelty. It depends on the manner in which the complaint is filed and prosecuted. 			     [Para 27]

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Husband seeking divorce on ground that wife had initiated false criminal prosecution against him and his family - Said prosecution resulted in acquittal after four years of agony, trauma and humiliation - Even in divorce proceeding wife alleged cruelty - She alleged that due to ill-treatment and harassment by husband, she started suffering from arthritis and her father suffered shock which led to his death - However, she did not examine any doctor to substantiate said allegations - Held, said defamatory allegations are very serious in nature - It amounts to cruelty on husband - Husband entitled to decree of divorce u/s.13(1). 			(Paras 21, 22, 28, 34)

heading: Permanent alimony
Entitlement of wife
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Entitlement of wife - To be decided in a separate application u/s.25 - It will be unjust to deal with said aspect in an appeal filed by husband challenging denial of divorce - Court before which application u/s.25 is to be filed, directed to decide the application while considering the findings recorded in decree of divorce. 	(Paras 33, 34)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Question as to whether cooling period can be waived - Parties living separately for 17 years - Possibility of reconciliation is non existent - Moreover, parties reached settlement and wife reasonably provided for by way of permanent alimony vis-à-vis a monthly maintenance - Held, looking to circumstances and in the interest of justice cooling period of six months allowed to be waived.	(Para 1)

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description:
Decree in divorce petition - Appeal against - Application for conversion of the appeal into an application u/s.13-B and grant of divorce by mutual consent - Parties had filed joint petition on ground that they have been living separately for a long period and not able to live together - Also that they are mutually agreed for dissolution of marriage - Thus, requirement of S.13-B(1) satisfied - Further, looking to circumstances procedural requirements of S.13-B(2) particularly as to cooling period can be waived - Application allowed.
(2010) 15 SCC 316, (2002) 10 SCC 194 Foll. 		(Para 1)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Appeal against dismissal of divorce petition by husband - No date, particulars of how wife treated him with cruelty are stated by husband - No person is examined to show that husband was harassed at his workplace by wife - No material on record showing conduct of wife amounts to cruelty - Petition liable to be dismissed. 
1998 (1) SCC 105 Ref. to. 	(Para 11)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Appeal against dismissal of divorce petition by husband - Husband produced inland letter written to his wife calling upon her to join his company when she left home - There is nothing on record showing that it was really issued to wife - Further, nothing shows that it was received by wife - Vague pleadings as to ground relating to desertion - Petition liable to be dismissed. 	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Cruelty
Mental cruelty
Scope
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Mental cruelty - Scope - Husband Staying in hotels without paying money - Bills being paid by his father-in-law - Said conduct not only to disliking of wife but also to society as a whole - This kind if conduct has to be essentially termed as mental cruelty to wife, inasmuch as, the social denigration of husband would have its serious impact on family life, particularly on wife - Wife naturally expects not always an excellent status from husband, but, at least, a responsible and disciplined life in society and to her as well.	(Paras 14, 23)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Decree of, on ground of husband being addicted to vices like alcoholism, abusing wife and staying in hotels without paying bill and the same being paid by father-in-law, etc., justification for - Staying of husband in hotels and not paying bills admitted by husband - Further, instead of supporting his case by adducing evidence or making his statements in counter, husband resorted to making of some serious allegations against his wife - This shows ill-will, dislike and despising attitude of husband to wife - Dissolution of marriage and consequential decree of divorce - No reason calling for interference with impugned order - Appeal dismissed.			(Paras 15, 18, 19, 23-25)

heading: Practice and procedure
HeadNote.description: Practice and procedure - Averments as to conduct of parties - Need not always be made only during course of evidence - Conduct of parties some times will be spoken to by parties themselves and some times could be perceived from statements made in petition or counter filed before the Court - Such allegations made in written statement or counter, as the case may be, shall be treated as additional particulars for granting relief sought for.	(Para 16)

heading: Practice and procedure
HeadNote.description: Practice and procedure - Divorce proceedings, initial responsibility on petitioner seeking divorce to make allegations - It is equally the responsibility of opposite party/spouse to repel such allegations and substantiate same through oral and documentary evidence.	(Para 20)

heading: Nullity of marriage
Impotency of wife
Distinct from infertility
HeadNote.description: Nullity of marriage - Impotency of wife - Distinct from infertility - Evidence of husband merely substantiated infertility of wife - No pleadings nor any proof that marriage infact was not consummated for impotency of wife - Family Court however equated infertility to impotency and passed impugned decree of nullity - Acceptance of case on alleged ground for nullity held, erroneous - Decree of nullity, quashed and set aside. 	(Paras 16, 18, 27)

heading: Matrimonial offence/fault theory
HeadNote.description:
Matrimonial offence/fault theory - Party suffering "guilt" or "fault" disentitles himself/herself from consideration.

A perusal of the grounds on which divorce can be sought under Section 13(1) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, would reveal, that the same are grounds based on the 'fault' of the party against whom dissolution of marriage is sought. In matrimonial jurisprudence, such provisions are founded on the 'matrimonial offence theory' or the 'fault theory'. Under this jurisprudential principle, it is only on the ground of an opponent's fault, that a party may approach a Court for seeking annulment of his/her matrimonial alliance. In other words, if either of the parties is guilty of committing a matrimonial offence, the aggrieved party alone is entitled to divorce. The party seeking divorce under the "matrimonial offence theory" / the "fault theory" must be innocent. A party suffering "guilt" or "fault" disentitles himself/herself from consideration. Illustratively, desertion for a specified continuous period, is one of the grounds for annulment of marriage. But the aforesaid ground for annulment is available only, if the desertion is on account of the fault of the opposite party, and not fault of the party which has approached the Court. Therefore, if a husband's act of cruelty, compels a wife to leave her matrimonial home, whereupon, she remains away from the husband for the stipulated duration, it would not be open to a husband to seek dissolution of marriage, on the ground of desertion. The reason being, that it is the husband himself who was at fault, and not the wife. This is exactly what the respondent has contended. Her claim is, that in actuality the appellant is making out a claim for a decree of divorce, on the basis of allegations for which he himself is singularly responsible. On the said allegations, it is the husband, who deserves to be castigated. Therefore, he cannot be allowed to raise an accusing finger at the respondent on the basis of the said allegations, or to seek dissolution of marriage, thereon.

There is no dispute between the rival parties, that after wife's first conception was aborted in June, 1999, the attending gynecologist had cautioned the couple against any further conception for at least two years. The couple had been advised, that pregnancy during this period could lead to serious medical complications. Wife alleges, that her husband had proceeded with unsafe cohabitation, leading to her second pregnancy, within a short period of eight months (after the abortion in June, 1999), i.e. well within the risk period. Clearly contrary to the medical advisory. The truth of the second conception, cannot be disputed, in view of the overwhelming supporting evidence on the record of the case. The conception could have only occurred because of, unprotected sexual indulgence by husband. The medical condition of wife, was for one and only one reason, namely, the second conception, during the unsafe period. Clearly, the blame thereof, rests squarely on the shoulders of appellant. It is in this view of the matter, that the submissions advanced at the hands of the learned counsel for appellant, have been vehemently opposed. The grounds/facts on which divorce is sought by the appellant, are not at all available to him under the "fault theory" on which Section 13(1) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, is founded.	         [Para 35,36]

heading: Irretrievable breakdown of marriage and doing complete justice between the parties
HeadNote.description:
Irretrievable breakdown of marriage and doing complete justice between the parties - Wife not consenting to severance of ties though she had suffered for no fault on her part - Court cannot grant divorce under S.13 or by invoking Art.142.

In this case court cannot grant a decree of divorce on the ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage, for the simple reason that the breakdown is only from the side of the husband. The wife has consistently maintained, that she was intensely concerned with her future relationship with her husband, and that, her greatest and paramount desire was to rejoin her husband, and to live with him normally in a matrimonial relationship, once again. Since in the present case, the respondent wife does not consent to the severance of matrimonial ties, it is not possible to accede to the instant prayer, made by the appellant. Doing justice between the parties is clearly a constitutional obligation. This Court has been bestowed with the discretion ". to make such order as is necessary for doing complete justice in any cause or matter pending before it.". The concept of justice, however, varies depending on the interest of the party. On most occasions, it is advisable to adjudicate matters in consonance with law. Whenever it is possible to do so, on the touchstone of the courts conscience, the determination rendered would simultaneously result in doing justice between the parties. The matter will be examined as if, the wife had approached the Family Court seeking divorce, on the ground that her husband had suffered brain damage leading to cognitive deficiencies. Yet, despite the said deficiencies, his working memory had returned to "near normal" after treatment. And his mental condition was such, that it would not have any effect on his matrimonial obligations. And the wife's family is agreeable to pay an amount to be determined by this Court (just as the husband, has offered), so as to enable their daughter to break away, and find a more suitable match. Should she have been granted freedom from her matrimonial ties, in the given facts, in order to do complete justice to the parties? We would ask ourselves, whether the husband would have accepted such a plea, in the facts denoted above? In such situation, if this Court had, in exercise of its jurisdiction under Article 142 of the Constitution granted compensation to the husband, and had dissolved his marriage on the pretext of doing complete justice between the parties, would the same be acceptable to the husband? We have no doubt that on a reversal of roles, the husband, without any fault of his own, would have never accepted as just, the dissolution of his matrimonial ties, even if the couple had been separated for a duration, as is the case in hand. Specially, if the husband had, right from the beginning, fervently expressed the desire to restore his matrimonial relationship with his wife, and to live a normal life with her. If the same sequence of facts cannot be viewed as doing justice to the husband, they have to be likewise viewed for the wife as well. 				           [Para 39,40,41,42]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Wife making reckless, frivolous, unsubstantiated allegations against husband in her oral evidence and in letters written to him causing mental cruelty - She alleged that husband had illicit relations with his two real sisters - Held, this was bound to cause not only mental cruelty to him but also to his sisters and this itself was a good ground to dissolve marriage and grant decree under S.13(1)(ia).             (Para 8)

heading: Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - Wife leaving matrimonial home and took her minor daughter with her - Admitted daughter to another school - Persuasion by husband and his family members to no avail - She intended to bring co-habitation to end - Decree under S.13(1)(ib), justified.           (Para 10)

heading: Petition for divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce by mutual consent - Rejection on ground that marriage between parties already dissolved by deed of divorce as per custom and usage prevailing in the caste and community - Parties did not plead customary divorce at all - But specifically pleaded their ignorance with regard to procedure recognized under the law for dissolution of marriage - Trial court on its own inferred case of customary divorce - Hence, rejection on said ground held, not sustainable. 	(Para 8)

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce by mutual consent - Maintainability - Parties dissolved their marriage by executing a deed of divorce believing it to be a valid procedure - Wife remarried after such execution of deed - However, legally the marriage between parties still subsisting - Hence, petition u/s.13B held, maintainable. 	(Para 9)

heading: Petition for divorce by mutual consent
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of statutory period of six months - Permissibility - Where marriage has been irretrievably broken and there are no chances of reconciliation between the parties - Court may take recourse to its inherent powers u/s.151 CPC and permit the waiver of statutory period of six months. (Paras 10, 13)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Statutory period of six months - Main object of the provision is to liberalize divorce - Same cannot be read in rigidity - Waiver of such period though not specifically provided, same can be read in provision with the main object of it. 	(Para 10)

heading: Jurisdiction of Family Court
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Family Court - In proceedings filed in a Court governed by provision of CPC., party thereto, regardless of his / her domicile, is bound to and must invoke provisions of the same Code for appropriate relief or direction in those proceedings. 	(Para 6)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Marriage may have been performed within or outside territories to which the Act extends - It is enough that marriage is valid Hindu marriage as stipulated in Ss.5, 7 and nothing more. 			(Paras 12, 15)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - Respondent wife, Hindu by religion, staying in Mumbai married with appellant, Hindu by religion staying in Jammu and Kashmir - Respondent wife's petition for dissolution of marriage under central Act cannot be rejected in exercise of powers under O.7 R.11 as she was living in Mumbai on date of presentation of the petition. 	(Paras 18, 20)

heading: Decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - Failure of court to frame issue as regards original prayer of restitution of conjugal rights - Whether vitiates decree of divorce - Facts of the case show that petition was originally filed for restitution of conjugal rights - By subsequent amendment, husband alternatively sought decree of divorce - Both parties led evidence only on aspect of divorce - Non-framing of issue as regards restitution, was not challenged by wife before commencement of evidence - Held, though failure to frame issue amounts to error committed by trial court, that itself will not vitiate decree of divorce.  (Para 9)

heading: Permissibility
HeadNote.description:
Petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Alternative relief of divorce - Permissibility - Held, if the other party refuses to cohabit and on account of such conduct, petitioner seeks alternative relief of divorce that may be granted - If separate proceeding is permissible, there is no reason to deny such relief in same proceedings - Concept like changing nature of suit may not be applicable in such cases - In any case, a party refusing to cohabit cannot be permitted to oppose alternative relief of dissolution of marriage.

AIR 2012 Raj 8 Ref. to. AIR 1992 MP 105 Rel. on. (Paras 11, 12, 13)

heading: Divorce on ground of desertion
HeadNote.description:
Divorce on ground of desertion - Sought by way of amendment in petition originally filed u/s.9 - Held, amendment would take effect from the date it was allowed - It would not relate back to date of original petition u/s.9 - Hence, period of 2 years desertion would be required to be proved prior to date of amendment.
II (1985) DMC 329 Approved. II (1991) DMC 326 Ref. to. (Para 14)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Not a ground mentioned in S.13 for divorce - Fact that parties are living separately for 20 years, cannot lead the court to pass a decree of divorce without examining if any ground of divorce is made out. 	(Para 15)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty on account of desertion - Wife left matrimonial house in absence of husband - She assigned reasons of ill-treatment and dowry demand for her desertion - However, she produced no evidence in the form of letter written to her father in this regard - No witness gave evidence on said aspect - At no point of time, she or her father lodged any police report - False and unsubstantiated allegations amounts to cruelty - Wife gave no positive response to notices of husband for rejoining his company - Even before Marriage counsellor, wife refused to return to husband without any justification - Wife is neither interested in cohabitation nor in dissolution of marriage - This is nothing but cruelty and desertion - Parties lived together only for 10 months and living separately since 20 years - Husband entitled to decree of divorce. (Paras 17, 18, 19, 20, 25)

heading: Condonation of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of cruelty - Whether petition for restitution u/s.9 amounts to condonation and whether it bars decree of divorce - Held, to constitute condonation, there must be forgiveness and restoration - To ascertain the same, conduct of both parties need to be seen - If offer of cohabitation is declined by other party, condonation never occurred - As such, if the petition for restitution of conjugal rights u/s.9 fails, it does not amount to condonation of acts of cruelty done by other party - Decree of divorce would not be barred.

To constitute condonation in terms of Section 23(1)(b) of the said Act, there must be forgiveness and restoration. The question, however, is whether for constituting condonation, the conduct of only one of the parties is to be considered or whether the conduct of both parties is to be taken into account. In other words, whether the unilateral act of one of the parties is to be considered or whether the bilateral acts of both parties are to be considered. If for constituting condonation, there must be forgiveness and restoration, it is obvious that bilateral acts of both parties will be required to be taken into account while considering the aspect of condonation. Forgiveness and restoration cannot be unilateral and for it to be effective and fruitful, it has to be bilateral. One party to the marital tie may be ready to forgive and restore the same. One of the modes could be by filing proceedings for restitution of conjugal rights. The other party may, however, not be ready to forgive and restore said tie. The proceedings filed by one party for restitution could be opposed by the other by refusing to rejoin the marital tie. The same would not result in condonation in as much as there would be no consensus between the parties for the purposes of forgiveness and restoration. It would remain onesided. Hence, the aspect of condonation will have to be adjudicated after taking into account the bilateral acts of both parties. The offer made by one party and the reciprocal conduct of the other will have to be viewed together while determining codonation in terms of Section 23(1)(b) of the said Act.

In matter like one at hand, where the desertion continues without even a day's break, the conditional forgiveness offered by the husband is not reciprocated by the respondent wife. On the contrary, she refuses to take advantage of the opportunity available and persists in desertion. As such, condonation which technically is a bilateral act or decision, never occurred and therefore the wife cannot resist the decree of divorce on the ground that husband has condoned her acts.

AIR 2006 HP 33, AIR 1993 HP 1, AIR 2012 Raj 8 Dissented from.  [Para 22]

heading: Divorce
Petitioner for
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petitioner for - Ground of mental cruelty - Mere trivial irritations, quarrels, normal wear and tear of married life would not be adequate for grant of divorce on ground of mental cruelty. 2007 ALL SCR 881 - Rel. on	(Para 24)

heading: Divorce
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition for - Ground of mental cruelty - Husband and wife living in USA for seven months - Husband, the petitioner alleging misrepresentation about educational qualification of wife and her incapacity to adjust to life in USA - Wife had failed in one subject but she took supplementary examination and completed her B.Sc examination - She had also joined MBA course, she was very good in music and while in USA she had also obtained International Driving Licence - Husband had never made any complaint about her with parents - Pending petition he had lost his job in USA and was living in Bangalore - Wife was also living in Bangalore - Held divorce could not be granted on the ground of mental cruelty or on the ground that wife was unable to adjust to life in USA.			(Paras 15, 16, 26)

heading: Void marriage
No evidence led
HeadNote.description: Void marriage - Wife claiming divorce by custom, from her previous husband - No particulars as to when and how divorce had taken place or about existence of custom of divorce by mutual consent in the community - No evidence led - In absence of such proof, subsequent marriage held to be void. 2002(2) ALL MR 264 (S.C.) - Disting.			(Paras 13 to 16)

heading: Divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce on ground of cruelty - Wife and husband did not live together for more than five days after marriage and have been living separately since 2002 - Wife failed to prove her case before criminal court u/Ss.498A, 323, 504 and 506 which was filed after delay of one month - No reasons for delay stated - By filing false complaint she got husband and his family members arrested - Deposition of her witnesses and her own was unreliable - Husband and his family members gave gifts to relatives of wife - Alleged demand of dowry and goods was an afterthought - Held, in view of these findings and acquittal in criminal case husband was entitled to seek divorce on ground of cruelty u/S.13(1)(i-a). 

A perusal of the record clearly indicates that the appellant husband and the respondent wife did not stay together for more than five days after their marriage and have been staying separately since 2002. The respondent could not prove her case before the Criminal Court though the prosecution had examined six witnesses, including the respondent herein and the appellant and his family members were arrested and were subsequently released. The finding rendered by the learned Magistrate First Class acquitting the appellant and his family members has attained finality. There was a complete irretrievable break down of the marriage of the appellant and the respondent within a short span of time. 	   [Para 35]

It was clear that the complaint filed by the wife against the husband was a false complaint. In my opinion, filing of such complaint itself which create mental trauma on the husband and the complaint which was seriously prosecuted by the wife by leading evidence of several persons and bringing the said complaint to its logical conclusion which ultimately resulted in acquittal of the husband and his family members clearly amounted to the cruelty committed by the wife upon the husband.	  [Para 36]

heading: Restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description:
Restitution of conjugal rights - Cruelty committed by wife proved by husband - She cannot maintain application for restitution of conjugal rights.

The respondent wife having treated the appellant with cruelty and such allegations having been proved, the respondent at the same time could not maintain her application for restitution of conjugal rights by filing an application under section 9 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. The husband, who had suffered mentally in view of such false criminal case filed by the wife and admittedly in which he and his family members were acquitted, cannot be compelled by the Court by passing an order of restitution of conjugal rights under section 9 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 and to co-habit with the wife. Once the husband has made out a case of divorce and had proved the cruelty committed by the wife under section 13(1) (i-a) of the Hindu Marriage Act, the wife could not maintain her application for restitution of conjugal rights under section 9 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. 

The appellant husband had proved before both the Courts below that he had withdrawn from the society of the respondent due to the respondent having committed cruelty upon the appellant and such withdrawal from the society of the respondent was not without a reasonable excuse. Both the reliefs are counter point to each other. Once the cruelty committed by the wife is proved by the husband, no relief for restitution of conjugal rights can be granted by the Court. Both the reliefs cannot be granted together at the same time.			 [Para 44,45]

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Child is not a chattel nor is he/she an article of personal property to be shared in equal half - Custody orders are capable of being altered and moulded keeping in mind needs of the child. (1973)1 SCC 840, (1998)1 SCC 112, 2009(1) ALL MR 925 (S.C.), AIR 1982 SC 1276 - Rel. on.(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Variation in visiting rights of the father - Custody of 7 years old son with the mother - Mother intending to go to Australia where she was getting a better job opportunity - Her autonomy on her personhood cannot be curtailed by Court on ground of prior order of custody of child with visitation rights to father - Right to development is a basic human right - Separating child who wanted to live with his mother in Australia will be disastrous to both.	(Para 23)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Visitation rights of father - Mother intending to take child to Australia with her - High Court restructuring visitation rights of father keeping in mind educational career of child - Mother agreeing to furnish undertaking/bond in order to ensure her return to India twice in a year and allow father to visit child - Order of High Court needs no interference.(Paras 25, 26)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiting period of six months - Is not mandatory but directory. 	(Para 21)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Waiver of waiting period - Power of Court under Art.142 - Cannot be exercised contrary to statutory provisions u/S.13B(2) of Act 1955 to waive waiting period of six months - Especially when no proceedings are pending before Court and Court is approached only for purpose of waiver of statutory period.  2010 ALL SCR 1196 Ref. to. 	(Para 9)

heading: Evidence Act (1872), S.108
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.108 - Civil death of husband - Succession rights of wife after second marriage - Husband got missing in year 1989 and not heard of thereafter - Wife entered second marriage in 1991 which was dissolved in 1994 - Second marriage contracted even before the husband declared civilly dead i.e. within 7 years of date of his missing - Therefore, second marriage would be null and void - Wife entitled to claim her share in property of her husband. 1980 AIR (Punjab) 274 Rel. on. 			(Paras 33, 39, 40)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by husband - Mere coldness or lack of affection cannot amount to cruelty. 2007 ALL SCR 881 Ref. to.	(Para 14)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Determination of fact of cruelty - Held, cruelty varies from individual to individual, depending upon social and economic status of spouses - It is not necessary that cruelty is committed physically, rather mental torture or abnormal behavior may amount to cruelty to a spouse in a given scenario.  	(Para 13)

heading: Divorce
Allegations of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Allegations of cruelty - Should be specific with regard to time, place and manner of committing such cruelty - Cruelty should be such in which it is not reasonably expected to live together.

	In the instant case the appellant-wife has sought divorce on the ground of cruelty. Cruelty has not been defined exactly anywhere. The allegations of cruelty cannot be considered on trivial issues, rather the allegations should have the origin with reference to time, place and manner of committing such cruelty. General allegations of cruelty do not constitute cruelty in the eyes of law so as to grant decree on that premise. Mere annoyance or irritation may not constitute cruelty, rather it is a spontaneous change in human behavior which restricts the other side to live with the spouse under the fear of endangering life or bodily injuries. Though, the word 'cruelty' has not been defined strictly, but it has to be gathered from attending circumstances of each case. The allegations should be specific with regard to time, place and manner of committing such cruelty. The cruelty should be such in which it is not reasonably expected to live together. It has a wider connotation as it should be willful and unjustifiable conduct of the spouse of such intensity which may endanger the life of other spouse and even may cause bodily injuries to the spouse. The spouse has a reasonable apprehension of such danger.				 [Para 12]

heading: Decree of divorce
Reversal
Challenge by husband
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - Reversal - Challenge by husband - Husband's case was that despite all alleged previous cruel acts perpetrated by wife, he wanted to resume co-habitation, same did not allegedly fructify due to attitude of wife - He however, did not file restitution application at first instance - Nor did he come forward to resume cohabitation during conciliation proceedings - On the other hand wife in her reply notice and also in the counter showed her willingness to resume co-habitation - Circumstances proved the husband to be bent upon to get divorce on unsubstantiated ground of alleged cruelty - Reversal held, proper. 			(Paras 68, 69, 70)

heading: Cruelty
Condonation of
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Condonation of - Meaning stated.

Condonation means forgiveness of the matrimonial offence and the restoration of offending spouse to the same position as he or she occupied before the offence was committed. To constitute condonation there must be, therefore, two things: forgiveness and restoration. The evidence of condonation in the instant case is, as strong and satisfactory as the evidence of cruelty. But that evidence does not consist in the mere fact that the spouses continued to share a common home during or for some time after the spell of cruelty. Cruelty, generally, does not consist of a single, isolated act but consists in most cases of a series of acts spread over a period of time. Law does not require that at the first appearance of a cruel act, the other spouse must leave the matrimonial home lest the continued cohabitation be construed as condonation. Such a construction will hinder reconciliation and thereby frustrate the benign purpose of marriage laws.
2007 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 65 Ref. to.   [Para 55]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty and desertion raised by husband - Allegations made against wife that she was a psychiatric patient, unwilling to cook food for him and his parents, unwilling to have sexual intercourse and also that she perpetrated physical cruelty on him - Unwillingness to cook, food is no ground for divorce - No evidence to establish other grounds - On the contrary, pre-suit notice and petition reveal conduct of husband to stretch the things to get divorce - That apart, parties lived together for 2 years - Within that period wife got conceived and delivered child subsequently - Though she alleged demand of dowry against husband, never filed complaint against him - She also showed willingness to resume cohabitation - Theory of irretrievable breakdown of marriage cannot be applied in view of facts and circumstances - Divorce petition liable to be dismissed.	   (Paras 24, 26, 33, 59, 60)

heading: Ground of venereal disease
HeadNote.description:
Ground of venereal disease - Infection of HIV Virus leading to AIDS is covered by ground of divorce at S.13(1)(v) of the Act.

The term "venereal disease" is not defined anywhere and that is rightly so thereby removing the rigours of rigidity. It loosely describes a class of diseases that are transmitted not "exclusively" by sexual contact but "chiefly" by sexual contact. Some decades back the existence of HIV virus, it's means of transmission, it's infection and consequences thereof were unknown. Had the term been defined by specifying the diseases falling therein, it would have been impossible to consider the infection by HIV virus as a venereal disease. That being not the position, Court will have to look for the common factors between the diseases that are accepted to be venereal diseases and the infection of HIV virus. The main common factor is the means of transmission. Like other venereal diseases of syphilis, gonorrhea, Hepatitis B etc., the infection of HIV virus is chiefly transmitted sexually. The other means of transmission are less common. Merely because there are other means of transmission, it is not possible to restrict the meaning of "venereal disease" and omit infection of HIV virus therefrom.							 [Para 12]

Infection of HIV virus leading to AIDS is covered by ground of divorce at Section 13(1)(v) of the Act. The learned trial Judge was right in passing decree of divorce under the provision. 				 [Para 15]

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Held, whether a particular act or conduct complained of is covered under the ground of cruelty or not is to be decided on facts and circumstances of each case.

The question of cruelty is to be judged on the totality of the circumstances. Under Clause (ia) of Sub-section (1) of Section 13 and under sub-section (1) of Section 10 of the Act, cruelty is a ground of divorce as well as judicial separation respectively. Whether a particular act or conduct complained of, is covered under the ground of cruelty or not, is to be decided on the facts and circumstances of each of the case. The question as to whether a particular act or behaviour would amount to cruelty or not depends upon the character, way of life of the parties, their social and economic conditions, their status, customs and traditions. Each case is to be decided on the facts of its own. Cruelty is classified into two heads i.e. physical cruelty and mental cruelty. Unending accusations and imputations can cause more pain and misery than a physical beating. Mental cruelty can be inflicted in various ways. In the instant case, the trial Judge after considering the evidence on record has passed decree of divorce and, in our view, it cannot be said that no case of cruelty has been made by the respondent wife. The respondent wife has already narrated the incident in her affidavit which she had tendered in lieu of examination-in-chief and nothing substantial has been brought on record on behalf of the appellant in the cross-examination of the respondent-wife. Considering the same, it cannot be said that the allegations made by the respondent against the appellant are false. Considering the evidence on record the decree passed by the trial Court regarding dissolution of marriage, therefore, is required to be upheld.  [Para 17]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of irretrievable break down of marriage - Though followed at one point of time, cannot be appreciated now - As, no such ground available under HM Act - Said ground can only be appreciated by Apex Court exercising powers under Art.142 of the Constitution. 2005(5) ALL MR 1012 (S.C.), 2006 (2) RCR (Civil) 290, 2002(1) ALL MR 953 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Para 31)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of desertion by wife - Wife was prevented sufficiently from company of husband as she was shunted out from matrimonial house and was not kept properly - Testimony of wife in that context, never sought to be refuted by husband by way of cross-examination - Thus, living separately from matrimonial house was not on account of any animus deserendi at instance of wife - Therefore, merely living separately cannot be considered to be a ground to seek divorce on ground of desertion. 	(Para 30)

heading: Divorce
Allegation of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Allegation of cruelty - Without specific particulars with regard to time, date and manner of committing cruelty - Cannot form cruelty in strict sense.

	The allegation of cruelty should not be based on trivial matters, rather such allegations should have the origin in the context of time, place and manner of occurrence. General allegations of cruelty cannot constitute cruelty in the eyes of law so as to part ways in matrimonial house.  [Para 23]

	Cruelty has not been defined strictly anywhere, and it has to be gathered from attending circumstances of each case. The allegations of cruelty without specific particulars with regard to time, date and manner of committing cruelty cannot form cruelty in strict sense. 	 [Para 24]

	Cruelty has a wider connotation in the context of its root and configuration. It should be wilful and unjustifiably conduct of the spouse of such degree which may endanger the life of other spouse and may cause bodily injury to the spouse and the spouse has a reasonable apprehension of such danger. 2005(5) ALL MR 313 (S.C.), 2014 (1) HLR 197, (2002) 2 SCC 619 Ref.to.	 [Para 25]

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
What constitutes
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - What constitutes - Mental pain, agony and suffering as would not make possible for parties to live with each other - Could come within broad parameters of mental cruelty - Mere coldness or lack of affection cannot amount to cruelty. AIR 1994 SC 710 Ref. to. 	(Para 27)

heading: Divorce petition
Draft of
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Draft of - Parties are required to make specific pleadings so as to enable opposite party to specifically meet, verify and if necessary, challenge the allegations - However, with regard to general conduct and behavior of opposite party, it may not be possible to give specific dates, time and place of occurrence.

The parties are required to make specific pleadings for the reason that it enables the opposite party to specifically meet, verify, and if necessary, challenge/deny the averments/ allegations. Otherwise, the opposite party would remain in the dark and would not be able to effectively deal with the accusations, allegations and averments made against him/her. Apart from making the aforesaid specific allegations, the respondent also made general allegations in his petition with regard to the alleged general conduct and behaviour of the appellant. However, it may not always be possible for a party to make specific allegations with regard to the date, time, place of occurrence in relation to a generalized conduct, act or omission - where such conduct is repeated continuously over a period of time. Thus, the allegations in the instant case that the appellant used to call the respondent 'Hathi' or 'Mota Hathi', cannot be given a particular date, time or place of utterance as, according to the respondent, such an utterance was repeatedly made by the appellant. Similarly, it may not be possible to give specific dates and times in relation to the allegations that the appellant denied sex to the respondent consistently. When two parties are in a marital relationship, neither is expected to maintain a logbook and note down therein each and every instance of matrimonial offence committed by the other. When the allegation is that a party showed uncooperative attitude towards his/her spouse and family members; did not show respect to the other spouse and his family members; misbehaved and abused with the opposite party and his family members - in respect of such allegations, it may not be possible to plead a specific date, time or place of occurrence. However, when intolerable conduct/matrimonial offence manifests itself into an incident which has larger proportions, the aggrieved party would be able to pin pointedly - with particulars and details, recite and establish such matrimonial offence. 				 [Para 29,30]

heading: Divorce on ground of cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty by wife - Wife allegedly used to call husband 'Hathi' and 'Mota Hathi' - No defence of wife that the taunts were made jokingly, or out of love and affection and without malice - Held, calling of names and hurling of abuses such as 'Hathi' 'Mota Hathi' by wife in respect of her husband, even if he was overweight, is bound to strike at his self respect and self esteem - Further, wife also taunted husband for not being able to satisfy her sexual desire - She also threatened him to immolate herself and implicate him and his family in a dowry case - Such events are clearly destructive of matrimonial bond and constitute mental cruelty - Divorce petition decreed. 	(Para 49)

heading: Legitimacy of children of void or voidable marriage
HeadNote.description:
Legitimacy of children of void or voidable marriage - Marriage is condition precedent to acquire status of legitimacy.

The benefit of legitimacy as contemplated under section 16 is restricted to and controlled by the word 'marriage'. Marriage is a condition precedent to decide the legitimacy of a child. In other words, the benefit of section 16 of the Act is available to an illegitimate child who is born to parents who have undergone the rituals/formalities of performance of marriage, maybe void or voidable.In converse, if there is no marriage may be void or voidable, then, this benefit of 'deeming legitimacy' is not available for the children, who are begotten out of any physical relationship of a man and a woman. 2011 ALL SCR 1209 Rel. on.  [Para 19,20,21]

heading: Divorce
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Principles of appreciation of evidence - Applicability - In dispute between husband and wife, it is not possible to bring documentary evidence on record - Case has to be decided on word of wife against word of husband.

Principles of appreciation of evidence are quite well settled. In a dispute between the husband and wife, it is not possible to bring documentary evidence on record and, very often, the case has to be decided on the word of the wife against the word of the husband. A judicial trained mind, however, can very well examine the facts and circumstances of the case and then draw its own inference from the material on record. Most of the time acts of cruelty take place in close room or bedroom of the couple where neither the parents nor children are privy to what happens inside the four walls of the bedroom. It is also quite well established that the women in India normally do not like to bring the dispute between the husband and wife in open and very often do not disclose to their parents extreme cruelty at the hands of the husband because she feels that if such a disclosure is made, it would make her parents unhappy. The situation in India is therefore such that the husband plays a dominating role in the house despite the fact that wife is educated, working and belongs to affluent family.  [Para 16]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Alleged mental and physical cruelty by husband - Wife was maternal cousin of husband - Both had love affair when wife was 18 years of age and husband was 35 years of age - Husband was not ready to give divorce though consent terms were filed and wife had almost agreed to all terms and conditions of husband including not to claim custody of son, any past, present and future maintenance and interest in property of husband - Police complaint filed by wife was withdrawn only because husband promised her that he would give her divorce by mutual consent - Husband made several scandalous allegations against wife in written statement and also in petition u/S.9 filed by him - That would also amount to cruelty and would be treated as instances of cruelty - On one hand husband wants to stay with wife and on other hand, he made scandalous allegations against wife - Inference can be drawn that husband only wishes to harass wife and is really not interested in happily residing with her - Wife is entitled to decree of divorce. (2005) 4 SCC 649 Disting. AIR 1994 SC 710 Ref. to. 	(Paras 15, 16, 17, 18, 23, 24, 25)

heading: Word 'wrong'
HeadNote.description:
Word 'wrong' - Meaning of.

The word "wrong" envisaged under Section 23(1)(a) of the Act has to be a "wrong" of a kind different from a mere conduct of refusing to resume conjugal relationship after passing the decree of restitution of conjugal rights.   [Para 11]

heading: Petition for divorce
HeadNote.description: Petition for divorce - Husband proved that there was no resumption and co habitation after decree for restitution of conjugal rights was passed in his favour - Wife was not inclined to live together and remained absent when matter was referred for mediation - Decree of divorce passed. (Paras 15, 16)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Persistent effort of wife to constrain husband to be separated from his parents, without any justifiable reason, would be torturous for husband - Same constitutes an act of 'cruelty' on husband.	(Para 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Wife giving threats and attempting to commit suicide - She locked herself in bathroom and poured kerosene on herself so as to commit suicide - Was saved with the help of neighbours - Had she been successful in her attempt, husband would have suffered for entire life due to legal provisions - Held, only this one event was sufficient for husband to get decree of divorce on ground of cruelty. 2012(1) ALL MR 473 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Para 10)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty by wife - Levelling unsubstantiated allegations against husband with regard to an extra marital life, being quite serious - Amounts to mental cruelty. 2003(3) ALL MR 777 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 12, 14)

heading: Consent decree
Appeal against
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Consent decree - Appeal against - Maintainability - Held, there are several formalities and requirements u/S.13B - When there is violation of those requirements of law or there is allegation of fraud, undue influence, coercion, deception, deceit in passing a decree u/S.13B, appeal can be made - Further, S.28(1) is very clear that all decrees including consent decree u/S.13B, is appealable.	(Para 27)

heading: Decree of divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce by mutual consent - Appeal against, whether abuse of process of law - Joint petition filed by parties - Their statement signifying their willingness for divorce was recorded and signed by both before trial court - Matter adjourned from time to time - Husband appeared thereafter but wife did not appear despite notice - Decree passed in such circumstances - Held, consent decree passed u/S.13B is appealable u/S.28(1) - Therefore, appeal is not an abuse of process of court.	(Paras 18, 29)

heading: Valid Marriage
HeadNote.description: Valid Marriage - Non-performance of saptpadi ceremony - Does not affect the marriage performed by the parties unless it is established that saptpadi ceremony was part of the ceremonies to be performed by one of the parties as per their customs. (Para 21)

heading: Age of parties to a marriage
HeadNote.description:
Age of parties to a marriage - Even if the marriage has been solemnized between a bride who is less than 18 years and a bridegroom aged less than 21 years - It cannot be held to be void under Hindu Marriage Act - Such child marriage as per S.3 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, is voidable at the option of one of the contracting parties, being a child at the time of marriage.

For a valid marriage of course, the bridegroom should have completed the age of 21 years as per the requirements contemplated under Section 5 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. But in a case where there is a violation of such a condition, the question arises whether it can be construed as a void marriage or a voidable marriage at the instance of one of the parties under Section 11 and 12 respectively of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. On a careful reading of Section 11 and 12 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, it is found that the Legislature has purposely omitted to include the requirement of Section 5 (iii) to attract the provisions under Section 11 and 12 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. In other words, even if the marriage has been solemnized between a bride who is less than 18 years and a bridegroom aged less than 21 years, it cannot be held to be void under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. Referring to the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 to analyze the ultimate consequences of a child marriage. 'Child' as per the definition found under Section 2(a) means 'a person who, if a male, has not completed 21 years of age and, if a female, has not completed 18 years of age'. Of course, such a child marriage as per Section 3 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 is voidable at the option of one of the contracting parties, being a child at the time of marriage. It is very important to refer to Section 3(b) of the said Act which would read that the petition under Section 3 of the said Act can be filed beforever the child filing the petition completes 2 years of attaining majority. Therefore, at the distance of time, the appellant cannot contend that the marriage performed when he was below 21 years of age is void and, therefore, he cannot be directed to take his wife to the matrimonial home.  [Para 26,27]

heading: Cruelty in matrimonial matters
HeadNote.description: Cruelty in matrimonial matters - If not admitted, requires to be proved on preponderance of probabilities - And not beyond a reasonable doubt as in criminal cases. 	(Para 10)

heading: Cruelty in matrimonial matters
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty in matrimonial matters - Intention is not necessary element in such cruelty.

Cruelty may be of any kind and any variety. It may be different in different cases. It is in relation to the conduct of parties to a marriage. That conduct which is complained of as cruelty by one spouse may not be so for the other spouse. There may be instances of cruelty by the unintentional but inexcusable conduct of any party. The cruel treatment may also result by the cultural conflict of the spouses. In such cases, even if the act of cruelty is established, the intention to commit cannot be established. The aggrieved party may not get relief. The context and the set up in which the word 'cruelty' has been used in the section that intention is not a necessary element in cruelty. That word has to be understood in the ordinary sense of the term in matrimonial affairs. If the intention to harm, harass or hurt could be inferred by the nature of the conduct or brutal act complained of, cruelty could be easily established. But the absence of intention should not make any difference in the case, if by ordinary sense in human affairs, that act complained of could otherwise be regarded as cruelty. The relief to the party cannot be denied on the ground that there has been no deliberate or wilful ill-treatment.

(1963) 2 All ER 966 Ref. to.      [Para 17]

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Statutory period of 18 months contemplated u/s.13B(2) - Is the time limit for withdrawal of first motion - And not outer limit for filing of motion for grant of decree by mutual consent - Therefore, duration of 18 months should not be taken to be period of limitation fixed for filing of second motion. 
119 (2005) DLT 278 Rel. on. 	(Para 7)

heading: Second motion for
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Second motion for - Rejection on ground of limitation - Challenge - Parties filed second motion along with first motion - First motion was allowed subject to conditions mutually agreed between parties - However, they could not appear together for recording of their joint statement due to some unavoidable circumstances - Held, once the petition is filed, the date of second motion has to be reckoned from date of filing of motion and not from the date of recording of statements - Hence, order setting aside second motion on ground of limitation, held, illegal. 	(Para 7)

heading: Mandates of law
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Mandates of law - Mere filing of petition u/S.13B is not good enough - Family Court is required to hear parties so as to examine whether consent is free and not obtained by fraud or undue influence - Non adherence to these basic mandates renders decree of divorce by mutual consent invalid.	(Paras 19, 23, 24)

heading: Impugned decree quashed
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - On basis of consent terms - Joint application made by parties to convert divorce petition into petition for divorce by mutual consent - Although application was allowed, no amendment was made in petition nor even in prayer clause - On next date after application was allowed, decree was passed in absence of wife - No opportunity of being heard given to wife nor any enquiry was held as to whether her consent was free - As per consent terms filed by husband, parties agreed to divorce by mutual consent on payment of one time alimony of Rs.3 Lacs to wife by husband - Whereas wife contended that they agreed for Rs.12 Lacs as one time alimony - As husband was working as Commissioner in Sales Tax Department, Rs.12 Lacs was not shown on record to avoid technical difficulties and accordingly, Rs.3 Lacs was shown in consent terms - Entire approach of Family Court was defective and oblivious to S.13B read with S.23(1)(bb) - Impugned decree quashed - Petition restored for fresh consideration.		(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
What constitutes
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Cruelty - What constitutes - Held, conduct complained of should be 'grave and weighty' so as to come to conclusion that spouse cannot be reasonably expected to live with the other spouse - It must be something more serious than ordinary wear and tear of married life - Factors on bases of which conduct has to be considered, stated.

To constitute cruelty, the conduct complained of should be 'grave and weighty' so as to come to the conclusion that the petitioner spouse cannot be reasonably expected to live with the other spouse. It must be something more serious than ordinary wear and tear of married life. Equally true is that the conduct has to be considered in the background of several factors such as social status of parties, their education, physical and mental conditions, customs and traditions etc. Cruelty must be of the type as to satisfy the conscience of the Court that the relationship between the parties has deteriorated to such an extent due to the conduct of the other spouse that it would be impossible for them to live together without mental agony, torture or distress, to entitle the complaining spouse to secure divorce.   [Para 14]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Husband taking plea that wife coaxing him to leave his army service and start a karyana shop - However, no particulars much less the date, time, year and person in whose presence such a demand was raised by wife, has been elicited - Therefore, plea of husband held, not sustainable. (Para 15)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Wife allegedly withdrew Rs.2.50 lacs from joint account of her husband and misappropriated it - FIR also lodged against wife u/Ss.406, 420 IPC which was cancelled - No evidence adduced to prove that wife mis-utilized the amount - On the contrary conduct of husband in lodging FIR in the circumstances, amounts to cruelty - Said allegation not sustainable, more so because it was a joint account and wife also had authority to operate it and make withdrawal from it. (Para 16)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Plea taken that wife misbehaved with husband's old aged parents - No specific date, month and year of such misconduct on the part of wife has been incorporated in petition in compliance with provisions of Rule 4 of Punjab and Haryana Rules and orders volume II, chap. I Part E - Plea not established, hence not sustainable. (Para 17)

heading: Divorce
Assessment of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of mental cruelty - Assessment of cruelty - Mental cruelty can be assessed from the continuous unprovoked conduct of a spouse which causes embarrassment, humiliation, and anguish so as to render the other spouse's life miserable and unendurable - This conduct should be of such gravity that the wronged party cannot be reasonably asked to put up with such conduct and continue to live with the other party.	(Para 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of mental cruelty by wife - Petitioner-husband alleging that respondent-wife wanted to stay in a separate accommodation - Petitioner along with his 8 adult family members living in a house consisting of 2 or 3 rooms - When a woman enters into matrimony, it is duty of family members of her matrimonial home to provide her some privacy - Therefore, respondent's demand for separate accommodation in such circumstances, held not unreasonable and did not constitute cruelty - Divorce cannot be granted on said ground.			(Para 13, 14)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Contention that parties not living together for almost 12 years - Yet a decree of divorce cannot be passed on this ground alone - High Court has no power to exercise jurisdiction similar to Supreme Court u/Art.142 to dissolve a marriage on doctrine of "irretrievable breakdown". (2006) 4 SCC 558, 2009 ALL SCR 600, 2009(6) ALL MR 515 (S.C.) Rel. on.			(Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Marriage
Presumption as to
HeadNote.description:
Marriage - Presumption as to - Voters list and Ration card prepared during life time of deceased father of plaintiffs describing defendant as his wife - Her name entered in Gram Panchayat record as owner of suit house after his death - Oral evidence of plaintiff to rebut presumption denying that she was legally wedded wife - Held, electrol roll, public document is relevant u/S.35 - Defendant is a legally wedded wife.
1978 (3) SCC 527, 1985 (1) SCC 637, 1994 (1) SCC 460 Rel. on.
2014(5) ALL MR 894 (S.C.), 1965 DGLS (Soft) 15 Disting. (Para 21)

heading: Appeal
Limitation
Applicable provision
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Limitation - Applicable provision - Stipulations in Hindu Marriage Act deal with substantive right of parties and substantive right of appeal - Whereas stipulations in Family Courts Act deal with procedural matters - Substantive provision must get precedence over a procedural provision - Hence, period of limitation stipulated u/S.28(4) of HM Act, must be preferred.

Under Section 19 of the Family Courts Act, appeal can be preferred against any decision of the Family Court not being an interlocutory order. Under Section 28(4) of the Hindu Marriage Act the period of limitation is prescribed for orders passed under the Hindu Marriage Act. In this view of the matter, the stipulation of Section 19(3) are more general in nature inasmuch as they cover not only orders passed by the Family Court under the Hindu Marriage Act but cover all appealable orders passed in proceedings before the Family Court. The stipulations of Section 19(3) of the Family Courts Act being general in nature and Section 28(4) of the Hindu Marriage Act as amended being special in nature (in that they refer to one class of cases which fall under Section 19 of the Family Courts Act.) Stipulation of Section 28 of the Hindu Marriage Act in which the relevant sub-section (4) appears must be reckoned to be special more appropriate and specific, inasmuch as the said provision confers substantive right of appeal. Section 19(3) assumes a more general character. A substantive provision must get precedence over a procedural provision. The Hindu Marriage Act is the piece of substantive law which confers the power to pass the order in question and the right to prefer appeals. The Family Courts Act does not deal with substantive rights of the parties but only deals with the manner in which the matters coming within Section 7 of the Family Courts Act have to be dealt with and disposed of by the Family Courts. To this extent, it has to be held that the stipulations in the Hindu Marriage Act deal with substantive right of the parties and the substantive right of appeal whereas the stipulations in the Family Courts Act deal with procedural matters. On the principle that prominence and predominance must be given to the statutes dealing with substantive rights in preference to those dealing with procedural stipulations, the stipulation of the period of limitation in Section 28(4), must be preferred.   [Para 16]

heading: Appeal
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Limitation - When two interpretations are possible about the period of limitation, one stipulating a larger period of limitation is to be preferred. (Paras 18, 19, 22)

heading: Appeal u/S.28
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Appeal u/S.28 - Limitation - Non obstante clause u/Ss.19, 20 of Family Courts Act cannot override applicability of period of limitation prescribed for appeal u/S.28 of Hindu Marriage Act - A non obstante clause cannot be read mechanically - Totality of circumstances have to be taken into account. 	(Para 21)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Court exercises a wide discretion in matter of granting alimony pendente lite - But that discretion is judicial and neither arbitrary nor capricious - It is to be guided, on sound principles of matrimonial law and to be exercised within ambit of provisions of Act and having regard to object of Act. 		(Para 11)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance and costs of proceedings - Grant of - Order u/S.24 is conditional on circumstance that applicant has no independent income - Wife is educated and could support herself, is no answer - Likewise, financial position of wife's parents is also immaterial. 	(Para 15)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Power of court to mould claim - Husband ordered to pay Rs.60,000/- p.m. to wife in addition to Rs.10,000/- ordered under provisions of Domestic Violence Act - At time of application, wife was unemployed - Later on she started working, but got no permanent source of income - Whereas husband belongs to a rich family - He is a partner in family business which is flourishing - Nevertheless, amount of Rs.60,000/- p.m. is on higher side - Same is ordered to be reduced to Rs.25,000/- p.m. in addition to above said Rs.10,000/-. 			(Paras 12, 13, 16)

heading: Nullity of marriage
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Nullity of marriage - Petition for - Wife is Hindu and Husband is Christian - Both parties continued to profess their religion after marriage and till filing of petition - Hindu Marriage Act not applicable to parties - Jurisdiction of court is barred to entertain the petition u/s.11 - No cause of action - Rejection of petition under O.7 R.11, justified. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Nullity of marriage
Petition for
Tenability
HeadNote.description:
Nullity of marriage - Petition for - Ground that consent of wife for marriage was obtained by fraud - Tenability - Wife is Hindu and husband is Christian by religion - Their marriage was love marriage and they knew each other since childhood - Husband did not convert as Hindu - Not a case of wife that she came to know about religion of husband just before filing of petition - Religion of husband is evident even from his surname 'Pinto' - Hence, contention of wife that her consent to the marriage was obtained by fraud, not tenable - Rejection of petition under O.7 R.11 for want of cause of action - Proper.
2009(1) ALL MR 488 (S.C.) Disting. (Paras 11, 12)

heading: Maintenance to wife
Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Maintenance to wife - Interim maintenance - Wife having income sufficient to maintain herself - Merely because the husband starts earning additional amount, she cannot be taken not to have income sufficient to maintain herself ipso facto.	(Para 5)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description:
Permanent alimony - Wife would be entitled to alimony, depending upon the income of the husband and his assets and properties at the final hearing of the petition for divorce.

The wife would be entitled to alimony, depending upon the income of the husband and his assets and properties at the final hearing of the Petition for divorce when the permanent alimony and maintenance would be considered under Section 25 of the Hindu Marriage Act.

For determination of the permanent alimony and maintenance, the Petitioner's other income and other properties as also the Respondent's income and other properties as also conduct of the parties and other circumstances would be seen by the Court upon the entire evidence led in that behalf. It is at that time that the wife's equal right to the property of the husband would be adjudicated upon. It is at that time that the status the parties enjoyed whilst their marriage continued would also be seen from the evidence which is led. AIR 1979 Bombay 173 (D.B.).  [Para 7]

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Maintenance - Grant of - Distinction between law laid down under Ss.24 and 25 - For considering application under S.24 for interim maintenance which is decided upon affidavits of the parties alone, the Court cannot and would not consider the precise income, standard of living, conduct of the parties, other properties and other circumstances of the case.

The distinction between the law laid down under Sections 24 and 25 of the Hindu Marriage Act is distinct and clear. It is so because of the specific circumstances that the Court would require to see at the time of each of these applications.
