It may be clarified that for considering the application for interim maintenance under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act, which is decided upon affidavits of the parties alone, the Court cannot and would not consider the precise income, standard of living, conduct of the parties, other properties and other circumstances of the case. The amount that would have to be granted for the maintenance of the wife would be for her support and necessary expenses of the proceedings. That amount would be granted if she does not have income sufficient for her support and necessary expenses of the proceedings. The ambit for grant of interim maintenance under Section 24 is, therefore, far narrower than the ambit under Section 25. It is the distinction between the two sections which is required to be understood for the Court to grant the maintenance amounts thereunder. Under Section 25 of the Hindu Marriage Act as aforesaid, the entire evidence relating to the income, properties of both the parties and their conduct and circumstances would be and can be seen. That is because the evidence is led in that behalf at the time of final hearing.						 [Para 10,11]

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - While exercising its powers High Court as the first Court of Appeal is both a Court of law and also of facts.	(Para 14)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Wife refusing to stay at matrimonial house - Husband filing application under S.9 for restitution of conjugal rights - High Court was justified in concluding that he had condoned all earlier acts of cruelty - Condonation in basically a question of fact.	(Para 7)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty and desertion
Desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty and desertion - No specific allegation of cruelty by wife - Desertion - Daughter stating that father used to beat her mother - That was a sufficient reason for wife to stay apart - Hence wife was neither guilty of cruelty or desertion.	(Para 17)

heading: Cruelty
Rel. on.	(Paras 18)
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Defies any definition and its category can never be closed - It may be subtle or even brutal and may be by gestures and words or even silence may amount to cruelty is some situations. 1975(2) SCC 326 - Rel. on.	(Paras 18)

heading: Proof of marriage
HeadNote.description: Proof of marriage - Absence of long co-habitation - Certificate from trustees of temple did not mention anything about marriage ceremony or conduct and solemnization of marriage - Birth certificate of two children not produced before court - Held, High Court was right in holding that marriage was not proved. (Para 14)

heading: Offence of bigamy
HeadNote.description:
Offence of bigamy - Hindu contracting second marriage after converting himself to Islam - It would be an offence under S. 17 inspite of his conversion to Islam. - Apostacy does not bring to an end civil obligations or matrimonial bond but it is a ground for divorce and judicial separation under Ss. 13 and 10 respectively.

Religion is a matter of faith stemming from the depth of the heart and mind. Religion is a belief which binds the spiritual nature of man to a supernatural being; it is an object of conscientious devotion, faith and pietism. Devotion in its fullest sense is a consecration and denotes an act of worship. Faith in the strict sense constitutes firm reliance on the truth of religious doctrines in every system of religion. Religion, faith or devotion are not easily interchangeable. If the person feigns to have adopted another religion just for some wordly gain or benefit, it would be religious bigotry. Looked at from this angle, a person who mockingly adopts another religion where plurality of marriage is permitted so as to renounce the previous marriage and desert the wife, he cannot be permitted to take advantage of his exploitation as religion is not a commodity to be exploited. The institution of marriage under every personal law is a sacred institution. Under Hindu Law, Marriage is a sacrament. Both have to be preserved.  [Para 38]

heading: Applicability of Act
Domicile of parties
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Domicile of parties - Parties living in U.S. since prior to their marriage - Came to India only to be married as per Hindu rites and returned back to U.S. - Remained in U.S. until filing of divorce petition - Facts and documents including Green Card of husband show intention of parties to make U.S. their permanent home - Domicile of parties therefore is U.S. and not India - Hindu Marriage Act not applicable to parties.	(Paras 17 to 19)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Territorial jurisdiction of Court - Last residence of parties together - Determination - Facts show that parties to the marriage last resided together in U.S. for about 7 months - Even prior to that they stayed in Pune, India only for a single night - Last residence of parties together is therefore U.S. - Court in U.S. alone has territorial jurisdiction to decide divorce dispute.	(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Territorial applicability of the Act - Both parties are Hindus - Marriage between parties solemnized in India as per Hindu rites - Held, once it is established that marriage between the parties was performed as per Hindu rites, Hindu Marriage Act would apply by virtue of S.2(1)(a) - Mere fact that appellant was domiciled at the time of marriage in the USA, does not take away applicability of the Act. 	(Paras 30, 31, 32)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction - Doctrine of intended domicile - Parties residing in USA - Wife filed divorce petition in Family Court - Respondent wife moved to India - Child was admitted to school here - Appellant-husband's domicile of origin was India, his domicile of choice was USA - He owns and continues to own property in India - He cannot be deemed to have given up his domicile of origin - Respondent's conduct showed that her intention is not to continue to be domiciled in USA - Concept of intended domicile is not applicable here - Initiation of proceedings in India is not prevented.
AIR 1974 SC 1764 Ref. to. (Paras 34, 43, 44)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cannot be granted relying on consent letter - Only a competent court can grant decree of divorce. (Para 12)

heading: Legal heirship certificate
HeadNote.description: Legal heirship certificate - Deceased had married during subsistence of first marriage - Marriage is void and second wife cannot claim to be heir of deceased - Children out of this marriage would, however, inherit properties of deceased, he being their father - Mother of deceased is also legal heir and can inherit a share in properties of her son.(Para 12)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - On ground of cruelty - Petition by husband alleging that wife used to get up in middle of night, shouting in filthy language and going out of room - Husband stated that it caused bad impression in minds of neighbours and tremendous mental harassment to him and his family members - Evidence of husband that once wife created rowdy scene gathering people of entire building - However, husband failed to examine any independent witness comprising of neighbours to prove said incident - Husband also failed to prove his plea that wife was suffering from mental disorder, to such extent that he could not live with her - Further, once Family Court discarded evidence as to mental disorder and unsoundness of wife - Subsequent finding of Family Court that instead of treating herself, wife by having resort to police machinery foisted herself in matrimonial home cannot be accepted - Decree of divorce on ground of cruelty liable to be set aside.			(Paras 16, 17, 20, 21, 23)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of marriage - On ground of cruelty - Matrimonial cruelty is cruelty of such degree and nature that other spouse cannot be reasonably expected to live with erring spouse. 	(Para 16)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Held, when cruelty is alleged as a ground for divorce, petitioner must have specific pleadings with reference to instances of cruelty meted out by respondent and those have to be established by cogent and reliable evidence. 	(Para 11)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Proof - Held, normal wear and tear of family life is not cruelty as contemplated in S.13(1)(i-a) - It is something more than that and party opting it as a ground has to establish that on account of cruel treatment of opposite party his life has become miserable and he found it impossible to continue with spouse. 	(Para 12)

heading: Divorce
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged desertion by wife - Proof - Wife stated that she was constrained to leave matrimonial home on account of ill-treatment of petitioner after consumption of liquor - Further, after sending her to her parental home he did not turn up to take her back to matrimonial home - No case of petitioner that despite efforts taken by him wife did not turn back to join him - Except testimony of husband no other witness to say that wife quitted matrimonial home wilfully - Wife clearly stated that she is willing to join husband but he is not - Thus, plea of desertion not proved.			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Wife had filed complaint under DV Act and also under IPC - However, same was filed only after husband's filing divorce petition - Held, on account of taking recourse to law for availing the remedies available to her, wife cannot be held guilty of acts of cruelty - Husband not entitled to decree of divorce on that count.	(Para 21)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Wife filed complaint under DV Act and also under IPC - Acquittal of husband and in-laws on account of allegations not being proved beyond a shadow of doubt - Does not dilute or falsify averments made by wife - In divorce proceeding preponderance of probabilities have to be taken into account - Dismissal of wife's complaint does not translate into act of cruelty entitling husband to decree of divorce.	(Para 21)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Evidence of husband that wife used to lose her temper on petty matters and used to shout on husband and her in laws and always threatened them that she would commit suicide - Husband further stated incident of wife standing on skirting of well to threaten husband to commit suicide or injure minor child for insisting him to stay away from his old parents - Same supported by evidence of his father and doctor and remained unchallenged - No evidence produced by wife to prove that she was ill-treated including physical violence by husband and in laws though she alleged same - In fact, wife admitted that her in laws had never demanded dowry and admitted aforesaid facts stated by husband - Same clearly shows that she was extremely short tempered and she used to make big issue of trifle matters - Husband proved his case hence, held entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Para 10)

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Marriage between Hindu girl and converted Hindu boy - Husband converted to Hinduism from Muslim religion by adoption, only for purpose of marriage - No proof that adoption was validly taken - Nothing to show that alleged conversion was voluntary with any faith in Hinduism - Nor any evidence to show that he was accepted as Hindu by nearby Hindu community - Held, once there was no voluntary conversion and its recognition as a Hindu, the marriage is ab initio void by bar of Ss.2 and 5 - Same is material fact and circumstances u/S.12(1)(c) to annul the marriage. 	(Paras 38, 39)

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - On ground of petitioner-wife being minor at the time of marriage - Marriage performed on 15-08-2008 - Petitioner born on 28-11-1991 according to her and on 25-08-1991 according to respondent-husband - Even taking 28-11-1991, by 15-08-2008 petitioner did not complete 18 years - By the time petition for annulment filed she did not attain 21 years - Application filed by petitioner for annulment of marriage u/S.12(1)(c) was on 15-07-2010, squarely within one year - Therefore, decree for annulment of marriage, held proper. 			(Paras 38, 39, 40, 41, 42)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Ex parte decree for - Challenge - Petition for restitution was filed by husband - Wife though filed objection, could not appear on subsequent posting dates - Court passed ex parte decree merely accepting the proof affidavit filed by husband and without recording its satisfaction in terms of S.23(1)(a) - Therefore, decree held not sustainable in law - However, since wife has not offered specific reason for her non-appearance, she was held liable to deposit cost of Rs. 3000/- before Family Court.			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Enforcement of
HeadNote.description: Decree for restitution of conjugal rights - Enforcement of - On the strength of decree spouse cannot be compelled to restore conjugal rights or to resume cohabitation unless and untill he/she is willing for such restoration - Provisions under Rr.32,33 of O.21 provides for enforcement of a decree for restitution of conjugal rights only to the extent indicated therein. 	(Para 10)

heading: Necessity
HeadNote.description: Petition for restitution of conjugal rights - Recording of satisfaction by court - Necessity - One can maintain a divorce petition on ground that despite a decree of restitution, there was no resumption of cohabitation between parties - Therefore, provision of S.9 cannot be allowed to be misused by either party whose petition u/S.9 was merely a pretence and was for securing decree of divorce - Therefore, it is incumbent on petitioning party to satisfy court about his/her sincerity in wanting to resume cohabitation.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Void marriage
HeadNote.description: Void marriage - First wife of deceased proving that her marriage was prior in time - Evidence of her witnesses could not be dislodged during cross examination - First wife and deceased having five children out of wedlock - Marriage of second wife was subsequent in time - Witnesses of second wife stating that deceased had two marriages - First wife was legally wedded wife - Second marriage was void. (Paras 11, 12, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Divorce
Rejection of petition
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Rejection of petition - For non-examination of witness - Challenge - Alleged cruelty by husband and in-laws on account of demand of dowry - Wife left matrimonial home within a fortnight of solemnization of marriage due to alleged ill-treatment - Husband demanding a flat in Delhi and torturing wife for not receiving car of his choice in marriage - Husband admitted of receiving a santro car which he used even after separation and even till his evidence was recorded - He also admitted that wife's father had showed him a flat in Nagpur - Conduct of husband speaks volumes - No allegation that wife was not desirous of marrying him - Infact her application for taking transfer to matrimonial city, even after returning to parental home, showing her desire to live with husband - It was subsequent conduct of husband abusing wife and her father and threatening them by emails and phone which compelled her to change her decision - Held, no girl who has happily married with her consent and whose parents have spent lakhs of rupees on marriage, would leave matrimonial home and decide to take divorce without any reason - Rejection of petition merely on ground that no other witness examined by wife, held erroneous - Divorce petition deserves to be allowed. 2016(1) ALL MR 605 Disting. 			(Paras 10, 14, 15)

heading: Divorce petition
Acceptability of evidence
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Acceptability of evidence - Is not based on number of witnesses that are examined - It is not always necessary for a party to examine several witnesses in support of the case in respect of demand of articles or dowry - If demand made from wife alone, no question of examining any witness to prove the same.		(Paras 11)

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Mental cruelty - May consist of verbal abuses and insults by using filthy and abusive language, leading to constant disturbance of mental peace of other party. AIR 2005 SC 534 Rel. on.	(Para 27)

heading: Decree of divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - On ground of mental cruelty - Challenge - Wife in written statement making disparaging, derogatory remarks about husband and his close relations about their character - She even did not spare chastity of his mother and sister - In view of such unfounded allegations, decree of divorce on ground of mental cruelty held justified. AIR 1994 SC 710, AIR 1990 Calcutta 867 Rel. on.	(Paras 34, 35, 36, 37)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grant of, on ground of mental disorder - Husband suffering from "paranoid schizophrenia" - Merely  branding a spouse as a schizophrenic is not sufficient - For  purpose of S.13(1)(iii) "schizophrenia" is what schizophrenia does - Two elements necessary to get decree - Party must be suffering from schizophrenia - At the same time disease of such kind that other party cannot reasonably expected to live with him - Only one element is insufficient to grant decree. 	(Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of mental cruelty - Appellant wife alleged that husband used to have attacks of mental disorder - He gave abuses and assaulted her - Also gave abuses in filthy language and assaulted her father and brother - Appellant has not adduced evidence of her father or brother - Nor they filed any complaint against husband - Appellant did not examine best witnesses who were easily available - Reasons for beating her, not stated - No medical certificate produced - Appellant did not state on what issues husband used to argue - Allegations are vague in nature - Held, married life should be reviewed as whole, few isolated instances over a period of years will not amount to cruelty.(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Unless decree of divorce is passed, Matrimonial Court has no jurisdiction to grant relief u/S.25 - Therefore, once decree rejecting prayer for divorce confirmed, wife cannot be granted permanent alimony. (1993) 3 SCC 406 Rel. on. 	(Para 20)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Husband alleged that wife was suspecting character of husband by alleging that husband used to frequently talk to particular lady on phone - He further alleged that wife was threatening husband and his parent that she shall put them in trouble by committing suicide and poisoning children - However, no police complaint filed - On contrary, husband fraudulently obtained exparte decree of divorce by assuring wife that he would withdraw case and due to which she did not attend Court - His subsequent marriage with same lady, showing that allegation levelled by wife was not unsubstantiated - Remarriage of husband would not give him any advantage - Divorce, not granted.			(Paras 15, 16, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Maintenance
To minor children
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - To minor children - Parties have three minor children - Elder son being taken care by parent of husband and other two children taking education in boarding school - School fees of both minors were Rs.65000/- p.a. and Rs.75000/- p.a. respectively - Both husband and wife have admitted that they have income, no document produced showing their respective income - Wife produced certain receipts of amount which she claimed to have paid towards fees of school - However, no attempt made to examine appropriate witnesses from school - Wife is running business of beautician and therefore, she has to contribute towards education and maintenance of children - No fault in directing husband to pay Rs.2000/- p.m. each to children. 	(Para 26)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
What amounts to
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - What amounts to - Held, mere filing of complaints is not cruelty, if there are justifiable reasons to file complaints - Merely because no action is taken on complaint or after trial accused is acquitted, may not be a ground to treat such accusation of wife as cruelty - However, if it is found that allegations are patently false, there can be no manner of doubt that said conduct of spouse would be an act of cruelty. (Para 10)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Wife made reckless, defamatory and false accusations against her husband, his family members and colleagues - Thus, lowering his reputation in eyes of his peers - Proceedings u/S.182 IPC also launched against wife - Such conduct of wife amounts to cruelty - Hence, husband held entitled to decree of divorce - However, looking to fact that wife is living with her son and daughter-in-law in house belonging to husband's mother - Her requirement to have a decent house, considered - Looking to status of parties, husband directed to pay Rs.50 lakh as permanent alimony to wife and ensure her of purchase of a flat of value up to 1 crore in her name.  (Para 11, 12, 13)

heading: Foreign decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Foreign decree of divorce - On ground of desertion - Whether enforceable in India - Ground of divorce stated to be covered by Art.117/1 of Dubai law which deals with 'divorce due to the damage with which marital life becomes impossible' - No such ground recognized in Hindu Marriage Act - Further, factum of separation and animus to desert (intention to bring cohabitation to end) are two essential requisites of Sec. 13(1)(i-b) - Dubai Court granted divorce merely on factum of separation without considering animus deserendi - Real controversy having not been considered, foreign decree cannot be said to be rendered on merits - It will therefore be unenforceable under clause (f) of S.13 CPC.  (2001) 5 SCC 265 Rel. on. 			(Paras 30, 31, 33)

heading: Foreign decree of divorce
HeadNote.description: Foreign decree of divorce - Whether enforceable in India - While wife was domiciled in India, divorce petition filed in Dubai Court without making provisions for her costs of travel, residence and litigation - Effective contest of the matter by wife was thus not ensured - Proceedings in Dubai Court therefore in breach of principles of natural justice - Consequently, judgment is unenforceable in terms of clause (d) of Sec.13 of CPC.  (1991) 3 SCC 451 Ref. to. 	(Para 34)

heading: Effect
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty - Delay in instituting proceeding - Effect - Petition filed by husband - Alleged last act of cruelty occurred in 1996 - Long cohabitation of parties i.e. about 12 years thereafter - Would suffice to conclude that petitioner has condoned acts of cruelty - Petition dismissed. 	(Para 18)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Filed by husband alleging mental cruelty and adultery by wife - Failure of husband to lead any cogent and convincing evidence to substantiate his plea - Moreover, parties having a grown up son suffering from mental disorder and needs joint efforts of his parents to move further in life - That being so, mere fact that parties living separately for past 7 years, would not persuade court to put an end to marital ties. 	(Para 18)

heading: What constiutes cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce on ground of cruelty - What constiutes cruelty - Held, to constitute cruelty, there must be such willful treatment of party which caused suffering of body and mind either as an actual fact or by way of apprehension in such a manner as to render the continued living together of spouses harmful or injurious having regard to the circumstances of the case. 	(Para 12)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of adultery - Serious charge casting aspersion on one's character, needs to be proved either by direct evidence or by evidence of independent witnesses or documents. 			(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Divorce
Burden of proof
Erroneous approach
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of adultery - Burden of proof - Lies only on party who casts allegation - It never shifts on other party to prove negative fact - In support of husband's allegation against wife, sister-in-law of wife gave statement on affidavit - At that time, said sister-in-law was in cross terms - However, later on dispute resolved and she did not enter witness box - In circumstances, Family court accepted affidavit of sister-in-law and insisted wife to secure presence of her sister-in-law, if she wants to prove her innocence - Erroneous approach - From commencement till conclusion of proceedings, burden is only of husband to prove adultery - Shifting it on wife, is against principles of law. 	(Paras 20, 25)

heading: Divorce
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of adultery - Evidence and proof - Husband alleged that wife had sexual relations with one 'K' - Allegation based only on information given by others - Nothing objectionable seen by husband himself - Out of two witnesses of adultery, first one was sister-in-law of wife - At time of giving affidavit, said witness had separated from her husband i.e. brother of wife - However, later on she joined her husband and did not enter witness box - In absence of examination, mere affidavit cannot be relied upon - Recourse to S.14 of Family Courts Act, would be of no use - Insistence on wife to secure presence of her sister-in-law, also not justified - Burden is only of husband to prove adultery - Second witness of adultery stated to be colleague of said 'K' - However, he too had strained relations with said 'K' - Evidence of such witnesses not acceptable - Other witnesses of fact that wife lived with said 'K' in one room, were also not specific - Though call detail records (CDRs) produced, it was not proved by examining any officer of Cellular Company - In fact, there is no proof that given mobile number was in use of wife only - Charge of adultery not proved - It rather amounted to cruelty on wife - Husband not entitled to decree of divorce. AIR 1958 SC 441, 2003(3) ALL MR 696 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of mental cruelty - Held, behaviour of a spouse might cause anguish, disappointment, frustration or agitation to wronged spouse - But that by itself not sufficient - Party who approaches court is expected to furnish particular facts which according to him/her are of such nature that would have caused mental cruelty of such intensity that it is impossible for him/her to live with other spouse.

	The settled proposition of law is that the normal behaviour and conduct of a spouse is not sufficient to constitute cruelty. It must be something more than that. The behavior and conduct of the spouse is guided by their social status, educational qualifications, physical and mental condition and the cultural and social background. The behavior of a spouse might cause anguish, disappointment, frustration or agitation to the wronged spouse, but that by itself, is not sufficient. The party who approaches the court is expected to furnish the particular facts which according to him/her are of such a nature that would have caused mental cruelty of such an intensity that it is impossible for him/her to continue to live with the other spouse. It is legal cruelty which is required to be proved in order to succeed. The behavior and conduct of response should be so acute and of such a grave nature and magnitude that would make it difficult for the wronged spouse to continue in the relationship. The court should be able to deduce therefrom that it is not in his/her welfare to continue with such a relationship. The wronged spouse needs to prove all these facts which creates such a apprehension in his/her mind. An inference must be drawn by the court from the attending facts and circumstances which need to be pleaded elaborately and specifically in the petition. 

2014 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 148, (1994) 1 SCC 337, 2002(3) ALL MR 945 (S.C.), 2005(5) ALL MR 313 (S.C.), AIR 2006 SC 1675 Rel. on.		 [Para 14]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Husband pleaded that wife never respected his family members and she extended threats to them, used filthy and abusive language and threatened him of dire consequences - Also that she is quarrelsome lady who neglected their child and did not allow husband to play with him and failed to perform her domestic duties - However, no time and place disclosed when such quarrel took place or threat extended or abuse hurled - Said pleas are devoid of any specific act of cruelty - Hence, husband not entitled to decree of divorce on ground of cruelty.		(Para 16)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Contention that due to a tense and vitiated atmosphere created by wife, father of appellant-husband suffered heart attack within three months of his marriage and angiography had to be done on him - No specific incident however pleaded which had so vitiated atmosphere of house that led to his father suffering heart attack - Moreover, angiography is generally done for addressing heart blockages - It cannot be said that appellant's father developed blockages of such magnitude within 3 months of his marriage - Held, simply because one of family members developed some medical problem, cause of same cannot be attributed to others - Alleged cruelty not proved. 	(Para 21)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged fraud on part of parents of wife and mediator in concealing correct age of wife that she is 10 years elder than husband - However, same was condoned by husband by continuing relationship - Held, act of alleged cruelty once condoned, cannot be taken as ground for seeking divorce - Hence, petition cannot be allowed on said ground.	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty by wife - Plea as to frequent visits of wife to her parental house - No specific date, time or circumstance in which wife left for her parental home without seeking permission or intimating him - Held, a wife is entitled to visit her parents' home - Such visit per se cannot be reason for a husband to complain.	(Para 22)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Filing of criminal complaint by wife against husband - Cannot be construed as cruelty for grant of divorce - Specially when differences between parties had been sorted out later on and wife had joined company of husband and they had started living together.	(Para 22)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged desertion by wife - Ground of desertion added by amendment - No case of husband that though wife was called upon by him to resume co-habitation, she did not resume it - On the contrary, in original petition which was filed on ground of cruelty, prayer made for eviction of wife from premises which she was claiming to be her matrimonial house - Same itself coming in the way of husband claiming decree on ground of desertion - No finding of court also that wife had intention to desert husband - Therefore, decree of divorce on ground of desertion, held not sustainable. 			(Para 18)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty by wife - Wife in her additional written statement made allegations as regards husband's relationship with another woman - However, did not attempt to prove the same - Unsubstantiated allegations made by wife affecting character and reputation of husband causing mental agony and cruelty to him - Hence, decree of divorce on ground of cruelty, held proper. 	(Paras 30, 34)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Prayer for mandatory injunction directing wife to vacate suit premises - No claim for exclusive right, title and interest made by husband - Rather suit premises stands in joint names of parties - Therefore, husband not entitled to seek relief of mandatory injunction. 	 (Para 35)

heading: Decree of divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce - Grant of permanent injunction restraining wife from harassing husband in any manner - Challenge - Judgment is silent on scope and meaning of word harassment - There is serious doubt as to whether such a decree could have been passed - Also such decree is incapable of being enforced - No court or Tribunal can grant relief which is incapable of being enforced - Hence, said part of decree cannot be sustained. 			(Para 36)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Maintenance - Grant of - Challenge - On ground that wife has been employed - No evidence adduced to show that on date of decree wife had source of livelihood or she had any income - Moreover, husband was doing medical practice - Therefore, finding that wife entitled to maintenance of Rs.3000/-, cannot be faulted with. 			(Para 37)

heading: Annulment of marriage
Rejection
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Petition for, on ground of wife suffering from sickle cell anemia and which was not disclosed to husband prior to marriage - Rejection - Challenge - Said disease is incurable and its symptoms are general weakness and fatigue - Even it could be inherited by the offspring - Said condition would surely affect marital life to certain extent - Family Court however held that disease of wife would not affect marital life of husband and rejected petition - Held, while considering what is material fact Judge cannot look at the problem as a third person but should look at it as if he/she is concerned with problem or facing it - Such test not applied by Family Court - Moreover, case of husband is that had he been aware of wife suffering from such disease before marriage, he would not have consented for marriage - Same is also one of tests applied while considering material facts u/S.12(1)(c), which family court failed to do - Therefore, impugned order quashed and set aside - Petitioner entitled to decree of nullity.	(Para 12)

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - 'Material fact' within meaning of S.12(1)(c) - Held, it cannot be said that only facts and circumstances which would materially interfere with a happy marital life, would only be material facts - But a fact which may not seriously interfere with marital life of party but would be of such a nature which if disclosed, would result in either party not consenting for marriage, would also be a material fact. 	(Para 12)

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - On ground of concealment of some material fact before marriage - Burden of proof as to knowledge - Held, if one party alleges that other party has knowledge about some fact and tenders evidence stating so - It would be necessary for other party to enter into witness box, at least to state that he/she had not known it - As soon as that is said, onus would again shift on other party.	(Para 13)

heading: Cruelty by wife
What amounts to
HeadNote.description: Cruelty by wife - What amounts to - Held, leveling false allegations against husband specially in respect of demand of dowry and failing to prove the same - Would tantamount to cruelty.	(Para 14)

heading: Cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty - Distinguished from ordinary wear and tear of family life - Sensitivity of wife with respect to conduct of husband - Not a ground on which decree of divorce can be granted.

Treating the petitioner with cruelty is a ground for divorce under Section 13(1)(ia) of the Act. Cruelty has not been defined under the Act but In relation to matrimonial matters it is contemplated as a conduct of such type which endangers the living of the petitioner with the respondent. Cruelty consists of acts which are dangerous to life, limb or health. Cruelty for the purpose of the Act means where one spouse has so treated the other and manifested such feelings towards her or him as to have inflicted bodily injury, or to have caused reasonable apprehension of bodily injury, suffering or to have injured health. Cruelty may be physical or mental. Mental cruelty is the conduct of other spouse which causes mental suffering or fear to the matrimonial life of the other. "Cruelty", therefore, postulates a treatment of the petitioner with such cruelty as to cause a reasonable apprehension in his or her mind that it would be harmful or injurious for the petitioner to live with the other party. Cruelty, however, has to be distinguished from the ordinary wear and tear of family life. It cannot be decided on the basis of the sensitivity of the petitioner and has to be adjudged on the basis of the course of conduct which would, in general, be dangerous for a spouse to live with the other. In the instant case both the trial Court as well as the High Court have found on facts that the wife had failed to prove the allegations of cruelty attributed to the respondent. Concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the Courts cannot be disturbed by this Court in exercise of powers under Article 136 of the Constitution of India. Otherwise also the averments made in the petition and the evidence led in support thereof clearly shows that the allegations, even if held to have been proved, would only show the sensitivity of the appellant with respect to the conduct of the respondent which cannot be termed more than ordinary wear and tear of the family life. [Para 6]

heading: Desertion
HeadNote.description:
Desertion - There can be no desertion without previous cohabitation by parties - Wife cannot be permitted to take advantage of her own wrong after marriage.

"Desertion",, for the purpose of seeking divorce under the Act, means the intentional permanent forsaking and abandonment of one spouse by the other without that other's consent and without reasonable cause. In other words it is a total repudiation of the obligations of marriage. Desertion is not the withdrawal from a place but from a state of things. Desertion, therefore, means withdrawing from the matrimonial obligations, i.e. not permitting or allowing and facilitating the cohabitation between the parties. The proof of desertion has to be considered by taking into consideration the concept of marriage which in law legalizes the sexual relationship between man and woman in the society for the perpetuation of race, permitting lawful indulgence in passion to prevent licentiousness and for procreation of children. Desertion is not a single act complete in itself, it is a continuous course of conduct to be determined under the facts and circumstances of each case.  If a spouse abandons the other in a state of temporary passions, for example, anger or disgust without intending permanently to cease cohabitation, it will not amount to desertion.    [Para 7A]

For the offence of desertion so far as deserting spouse is concerned, two essential conditions must be there (1) the factum of separation and (2) the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end (animus deserendi). Similarly two elements are essential so far as the deserted spouse is concerned : (1) the absence of consent, and (2) absence of conduct giving reasonable cause to the spouse leaving the matrimonial home to form the necessary intention aforesaid. For holding desertion proved the inference may be drawn from certain facts which may not in another case be capable of leading to the same inference: that is to say the facts have to be viewed as to the purpose which is revealed by those acts or by conduct and expression of intention, both anterior and subsequent to the actual acts of separation. 	 [Para 8]

To prove desertion in matrimonial matter it is not always necessary that one of the spouse should have left the company of the other as desertion could be proved while living under the same roof.  Desertion cannot be equated with separate living by the parties to the marriage.  Desertion may also be constructive which can be inferred from the attending circumstances.  It has always to be kept in mind that the question of desertion is a matter of inference to be drawn from the facts and circumstances of each case.     [Para 9]

As desertion in matrimonial cases means the withdrawal of one party from a state of things, i.e., a marital status of the party, no party to the marriage can be permitted to allege desertion unless he or she admits that after the formal ceremonies of the marriage, the parties had recognized and discharged the common obligation of the married life which essentially requires the cohabitation between the parties for the purpose of consummating the marriage. Cohabitation by the parties is an essential of a valid marriage as the object of the marriage is to further the perpetuation of the race by permitting lawful indulgence in passions for procreation of children. In other words, there can be no desertion without previous cohabitation by the parties. The basis for this theory is built upon the recognized position of law in, matrimonial matters that no-one can desert who does not actively or willfully bring to an end the existing state of cohabitation. However, such a rule is subject to just exceptions which may be found in a case on the ground of mental or physical incapacity or other peculiar circumstances of the case. However, the party seeking divorce on the ground of desertion is required to show that she was not taking the advantage of his or her own. [Para 10]

In the instant case the appellant herself pleaded that there had not been cohabitation between the parties after the marriage. She neither assigned any reason nor attributed the non-resumption of cohabitation to the respondent. From the pleadings and evidence led in the case, it is apparent that the appellant did not permit the respondent to have cohabitation for consummating the marriage. In the absence of cohabitation between the parties, a particular state of matrimonial position was never permitted by the appellant to come into existence. In the present case, in the absence of cohabitation and consummation of marriage, the appellant was disentitled to claim divorce on the ground of desertion. [Para 11]

heading: Decree of divorce
Appeal against
HeadNote.description:
Decree of divorce - Appeal against - Limitation of 30 days is apparently inadequate - Government should consider raising it to 90 days.

The period of limitation prescribed for filing the appeal under Section 28(4) is apparently inadequate which facilitates the frustration of the marriages by the unscrupulous litigant spouses. In a vast country like ours, the powers under the Act are generally exercisable by the District Court and the first appeal has to be filed in the High Court. The distance, the geographical conditions, the financial position of the parties and the time required for filing a regular appeal, if kept in mind, would certainly show that the period of 30 days prescribed for filing the appeal is insufficient and inadequate. In the absence of appeal, the other party can solemnise the marriage and attempt to frustrate the appeal right of the other side as appears to have been done in the instant case. A minimum period of 90 days may be prescribed for filing the appeal against any judgment and decree under the Act and any marriage solemnized during the aforesaid period be deemed to be void. Appropriate legislation is required to be made in this regard. We direct the Registry that the copy of this judgment may be forwarded to the Ministry of Law & Justice for such action as it may deem fit to take in this behalf. [Para 18]

heading: Void marriage
Decree as to
HeadNote.description: Void marriage - Decree as to - Sought on ground that wife was already married to some other person - Wife though admitted fact of earlier marriage, stated to have taken customary divorce from her earlier husband - No evidence led to show existence of any customary divorce prevailing in her community - No document filed relating to period prior to passing of Act - No elderly person examined from the community who could depose in support of custom prevailing for obtaining customary divorce - Held, a custom cannot be created by an agreement between parties - Wife failed to prove any such custom to obtain customary divorce - Hence, declaration of marriage as null and void held, proper. 		(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Custom and usage
HeadNote.description: Custom and usage - Custom is a rule which in a particular family or a particular class of community or in a particular district has, from long usage, obtained the force of law - It must be ancient, certain and reasonable - Custom being in the derogation of general rule of law, must be construed strictly and should be established by evidence - Party relying on custom must allege and prove the custom on which he relies.	(Para 13)

heading: Interim maintenance
Grant of
Relevant considerations
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Grant of - Relevant considerations - Held, for grant of maintenance, Court has to consider status of the parties, their respective needs, capacity of husband to pay having regard to his reasonable expenses for his own maintenance and of those, he is obliged under the law and statute - Amount of maintenance fixed for the wife should be as much which is sufficient for her to lead comfortable life.			(Paras 10, 18)

heading: Grant of interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Grant of interim maintenance - Exercise of discretion by Court - Held, though wide discretion conferred on Court while making order of interim maintenance, same must be guided by criterion provided in S.24 - Namely, means of parties, incidental and other relevant factors like social status, back-ground from which both parties come from and also economical dependence of the claimant.	(Para 12)

heading: Approach of Court
HeadNote.description: Grant of interim maintenance - Approach of Court - Held, order of interim maintenance being temporary in nature, detailed and elaborate exercise by Court may not be necessary - However, Court has to take all relevant factors into account and arrive at proper amount having regard to factors mentioned in the Act.	(Para 12)

heading: Word 'support' u/S.24
Meaning of
HeadNote.description: Word 'support' u/S.24 - Meaning of - Held, word "support" u/S.24 should not be narrowly interpreted - It does not mean bare existence - It means that claimant spouse should have same comfort as that of other - Of course, the section is not intended to bring about arithmetical equality between the two. 		(Para 15)

heading: Grant of interim maintenance
HeadNote.description:
Grant of interim maintenance - Determination as to income of rival claimants - Held, capacity of other party to earn cannot be taken into consideration - It is only actual earning of opposite party on basis of which relief can be granted - Permanent income and not casual income, is relevant.

	The Court while considering the merits of an application for grant of an interim maintenance under Section 24 has to necessarily arrive at prima- facie determination about the earning capacity of the rival claimants. The determination cannot be made with exactitude; it is essentially interim in nature. The Court is called upon to make a summary consideration of amount which the applicant is to be awarded by way of maintenance pendente-lite and litigation expenses in accordance with the financial resources of the parties. The capacity of the other party to earn cannot be taken into consideration. It is only the actual earning of the opposite party on the basis of which relief can be granted. Permanent income and not casual income is relevant. For example if a husband brings on record that the non- applicant wife earns some amount by taking coaching classes for children, this cannot be termed as her permanent income or that the wife has independent permanent source of income. The proceedings being summary, the matter has to be decided on the basis of pleadings supported by affidavits and the documents that may be filed by the parties in support of their case. 	 [Para 16]

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Liability of husband to pay - Where there are sufficient means in family of husband on strength of which husband got married - He has to share burden to support his wife during course of annulment of such marriage. 	(Para 17)

heading: Grant of interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Grant of interim maintenance - Determination as to income of parties - Where parties do not come forward with exact income they have - Court would have no alternative but to apply guess-work.	(Para 18)

heading: Interim Maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim Maintenance - Liability of husband to pay - Held, it is obligation of husband to maintain his wife - He cannot be permitted to plead that he is unable to maintain wife due to financial constraints as long as he is capable of earning. AIR 1968 Delhi 174, 2015 ALL MR (Cri) 2046 (S.C.)Ref. to.	(Para 19)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition by husband on grounds of cruelty and desertion by wife - Wife left matrimonial home 10 yrs. back - Husband examined three witnesses to prove that he made genuine efforts to bring her back - No contra evidence produced by wife - She alleged that husband does not take care of son who is suffering from heart disease and that he tortured her for demand of Rs. 1 lakh - However, in cross-examination she admitted that medical expenses of son were borne by husband - As to allegation of torture, her criminal complaint was dismissed for want of evidence - Further allegation that husband intends to marry another woman hence not interested in cohabiting with her, not mentioned in written statement - Wife had admitted in maintenance proceedings that she does not want to cohabit with husband - Restitution petition filed by her only during pendency of divorce petition and not earlier - Fact that she deserted husband without sufficient cause, proved - Filing of false criminal complaint by her amounted to cruelty - Both alleged grounds of divorce, proved - Husband entitled to decree of divorce. 			(Paras 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 28, 31, 42)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Filing of false criminal case against husband, amounts to mental cruelty. 2015(2) ALL MR 435 (S.C.), 2012(4) ALL MR 506 (S.C.), 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1833 (S.C.), 2016(2) ALL MR 14 Rel. on. 		(Para 39)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Irretrievable breakdown of marriage - Parties living separately since last more than 20 yrs. - Relation became more strained after filing of criminal case by wife - Chances of reunion are very dim and bleak - It can be reasonably inferred that there is irretrievable breakdown of marriage. AIR 2006 SC 1675 Ref. to. 			(Paras 31, 40)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Mental cruelty may consist of verbal abuses and insults by using filthy and abusive language leading to constant disturbance of mental peace. 	(Para 22)

heading: Relief of
Improper exercise
HeadNote.description: Divorce and judicial separation - Relief of - Wife sought relief of divorce on ground of cruelty - Court also found husband guilty of committing cruelty - However, granted her decree of judicial separation and not decree of divorce - No justification recorded for granting a relief not sought for - Improper exercise - Decree of judicial separation converted to dissolution of marriage. 			(Paras 23, 24, 25)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - To seek relief u/S.13(1)(i-a), petitioner himself should be free of guilt or fault - Petitioner alleging cruelty by his wife on ground that wife suspects his fidelity and refused to cohabit - However, phone bills and call lists produced by wife showed that petitioner was in habit of making frequent calls and sending several messages to his cousin even during odd hours - Making of such calls admitted by petitioner - Petitioner's friend also admitted in cross-examination that he had advised petitioner to snap relationship with his cousin - Evidence made it clear that petitioner is wrongdoer - Wrongdoer not entitled to any relief - Dismissal of petition upheld. 2013(5) ALL MR 446 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Counterclaim for restitution of conjugal rights
HeadNote.description: Counterclaim for restitution of conjugal rights - Rejection of application for - Ground that petitioner has already filed written statement and limitation for filing counterclaim u/O.8 R.6A, had expired - Provisions of O.8 R.6A would not be applicable to S.23A of HM Act - Order rejecting counterclaim on ground of same being barred by limitation, improper. 			(Para 10)

heading: Counter claim
HeadNote.description: Counter claim - To claim reliefs under DV Act - Can be filed in divorce proceedings pending before Family Court - As per S.26 DV Act, in legal proceedings initiated before Family Court, any relief available u/Ss.18, 19, 20, 21, 22 of DV Act, can be claimed by aggrieved person. 			(Para 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of incurable unsoundness of mind and mental disorder - Two separate grounds given under provision of S.13(1)(iii)(a) and (b) - Scope under both the parts, stated.

	There are two separate grounds in the provision viz. (a) incurable unsound mind; and, (b) respondent spouse has been suffering continuously or intermittently from mental disorder and the disorder is of such kind and of such extent that the petitioner cannot reasonably be expected to live with the respondent.

	From the wording of the aforesaid provision it can be said that the mental condition like incurable unsound mind mentioned in the first part or the mental disorder mentioned in the second part needs to be proved by expert evidence and that evidence needs to satisfy the Court that such mental condition exists. From the wording of the provision it can be said that the second part of the provision has wide scope. For this part, it is not necessary that mental disorder is incurable. However, the mental disorder must be of such kind and extent that the Court needs to be satisfied that it is not advisable to ask the petitioner to live with the respondent. The scope shows that there is no limit to the kind of mental disorder as no specific kind is mentioned. However, the term "has been suffering" shows that the period of illness must not be too short or the petition should not be based on one or two instances showing such mental disorder. The term "intermittently" cannot be misread in this provision to infer that the mental illness returns after the treatment within few days. The term "extent" is also important and on that also the Court needs to be satisfied to come to the conclusion that the petitioner cannot be reasonably expected to live with the husband. Thus the relief is discretionary and while using discretion, the Court is expected to keep in mind the aforesaid things. 			 [Para 10,11]

heading: Divorce
Evidence of psychiatrist
Consideration
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of incurable unsoundness of mind and mental disorder - Evidence of psychiatrist - Consideration - Evidence of psychiatrist needs to be considered both for corroboration and contradiction purpose - In such case evidence of other witnesses or circumstances relating to behaviour of respondent can be considered by Court as that can help strengthening opinion or create probability that opinion has no justification and it is weak.

	Psychiatrist is an expert but in view of provision of section 45 of the Evidence Act, it is up to the Court to either rely on the opinion or to refuse to do so. Further, he being a witness, his credibility can be impeached like the credibility of any other witnesses and his veracity can be tested as provided in section 146 and other provisions of Evidence Act. As psychiatrist is expected to give evidence on the basis of the examination of the patient done by him, the symptoms noted by him, the treatment and the follow up treatment given by him and the record created by him needs to be considered both for corroboration and contradiction purpose. In such a case the evidence of other witnesses or the circumstances which relates to the behaviour of the respondent can be considered by the Court as that can help strengthening the opinion or create probability that the opinion has no justification and it is weak. 		 [Para 13]

heading: Divorce
Effect
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of incurable unsoundness of mind and mental disorder - Absence of expert evidence - Effect - Held, when there is no expert evidence for proving incurable unsoundness of mind or mental disorder, other evidence cannot help petitioner in any way to get divorce on said ground. 			(Para 21)

heading: Decree of restitution
Grant of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Decree of restitution - Grant of - Challenge - Divorce petition filed by husband on ground of mental disorder, dismissed for want of sufficient evidence - Looking to nature of allegation made by husband, it can be inferred that he has no intention to resume cohabitation - It can be said that he has withdrawn from company of wife without justifiable reason - Trial Court has no alternative but to grant decree of restitution in favour of wife - Hence, grant of impugned decree, held proper. 	(Para 24)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Has to be proved by giving specific instances - General allegations that wife used to avoid husband and his family members, was not preparing food for husband and she used to quarrel with husband and his parents, cannot constitute cruelty. 	(Para 21)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged adultery by wife - Husband alleging that wife has extra marital relations and that his second daughter was born out of such relations - Photographs produced in support, alleged to be fabricated by wife - Photographer examined by husband neither stating to have taken those nor vouchsafing that they are not fabricated - Allegation about paternity of second daughter - Not tenable as she was born during wed-lock and when both parties were living together - More so because husband in his restitution petition filed earlier has not doubted paternity of second daughter - Therefore, dismissal of divorce petition, held proper. 		(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Interpretation of Statute
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statute - Two kinds of mental illness given in clause (iii) of sub-sec.(1) of S.13 of HM Act, separated by word 'or' - Needs to be read separately in view of legislative intent attached to the Act - Meaning of word 'unsound mind' given.

	The statement of object and reasons of the Act shows that it was made to amend and codify the law relating to marriage amongst Hindus. The object of legislation was mainly (i) to liberalise the provisions relating to divorce. The amendment which introduced clause (iii) in the year 1976 was intended to remove certain anomalies and handicaps that had come to light after the passing of the Act of 1955. 		 [Para 31]

	In section 13 of the Act, the meaning of expression 'mental disorder' is given and meaning of expression 'psychopathic disorder' is also given. However, the meaning of 'unsound mind' is not given in this section. The meaning of 'unsound mind' or the definition of this term is available in other Acts like Indian Penal Code or Contract Act. But, the purpose behind inclusion of that term in the relevant provisions of that Act needs to be kept in mind. The same meaning cannot be attached to the term 'unsound mind' as used in clause (iii) of section 13 (1) of the Act as the term is not separately used, but it is affixed by the word 'incurably'. Thus, the mental illness mentioned in first part of section 13 (1) (iii) is incurably unsound mind. In view of the absence of meaning of this term in the Act itself, it needs to be presumed that the word needs to be understood in it's natural, ordinary or popular sense. In the law.com dictionary, the meaning of 'unsound mind' is given as '"a person of unsound mind is an adult who from infirmity of mind is incapable of managing himself or his affairs. The term, therefore, includes insane persons, idiots and imbeciles". This definition is also found in black;s law dictionary, 2nd Edition. This Court holds that the meaning given above to 'unsound mind' needs to be used in the present matter. If the word 'incurable' is prefixed to this term, one can find that this kind of illness is different from the mental illness mentioned after word 'or' in clause (iii) of section 13 (1). The explanation given to the clause shows that such mental illness mentioned after word 'or' includes schizophrenia. Though schizophrenia also can be called as incurable mental illness, that illness may not be of kind mentioned above viz. the patient is incapable of managing himself or his affairs. So, this Court has no hesitation to hold that the mental illness mentioned on two sides of word 'or' in aforesaid provision are of different kinds.

2010(5) ALL MR 934 (S.C.) Ref. to. 				 [Para 32]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Sought on ground of mental illness of wife - Illness described as schizophrenia - Evidence showing that illness can be kept under control by medicines - However, evidence like description of symptoms given in discharge card shows that during attack, wife shows irritability, disruptive behaviour and also hostility - Reading together evidence of husband and medical evidence, it can be said that probability as required by second part of S.13(1)(iii), created by husband - Matter needs to decided on preponderance of probability - In view of independent evidence of doctor who has given treatment to wife, husband cannot be reasonably expected to live with wife - Though evidence not sufficient to make out case of illness of first part of said clause, husband held entitled to decree of divorce.

	The question arises in the present matter as to whether the evidence given by the husband is sufficient to make out the case for first kind of illness or second kind of illness or whether the evidence is not sufficient to make out the case under both the grounds. Court has already quoted the evidence of the husband and the evidence given by doctor, who is giving treatment to the wife. The illness is described as schizophrenia and the evidence shows that the illness can be kept under control by medicines. However, the evidence like description of the symptoms given in discharge card shows that during attack, wife shows irritability, disruptive behaviour and also hostility. The husband has given evidence that in the month of June 2001 itself, he first noticed the illness of the wife. His evidence shows that even after that he continued cohabitation. Some record of giving treatment in Amravati is also produced though doctor from Amravati is not examined by the husband. The wife had admitted that circumstance. One incident of November 2004 is admitted by both the sides and the evidence of the doctor shows that few days prior to that incident, wife had come to him as patient for receiving treatment for the same illness. Though the defence is taken that her father had taken her to Aurangabad due to situation created by husband, the fact remains that father of the wife had informed to police that on his own he was taking the wife to Aurangabad due to her mental condition. After that the wife continued to receive treatment of doctor due to her mental illness. The evidence of husband shows that even after learning about mental illness, he continued cohabitation with the wife and he got female issue from her. He approached police first time in November 2014 and informed to police that due to illness of the wife and due to the incidents which are mentioned in the petition also like her suicidal tendency and tendency to cause harm even to daughter she was taken back to the parents house by her parents. He had expressed apprehension that there was possibility of his false implication from the side of his wife. Since then the parties are living separate. If the evidence of husband and the medical evidence is read together, it can be said that the probability as required by second part of section 13 (1) (iii) is created by the husband. The matter needs to be decided on preponderance of probability. Due to independent evidence of doctor, who has given treatment to the wife in Aurangabad, there is no reason to disbelieve the husband on his case that he cannot reasonably be expected to live with the wife. However, the evidence is not sufficient to make out the case of illness of first part of this clause. 				 [Para 35]

heading: Divorce proceeding
HeadNote.description: Divorce proceeding - In petition filed by husband provision of S.13(1)(ia) was mentioned - However, in pleadings ground of mental illness was mentioned - Trial court framed issue on provision of S.13(1)(iii) also - Thus, finding can be given on both issues - When court comes to conclusion that husband cannot be expected to live with wife due to stated mental illness, it cannot be said that he has deserted her without reasonable cause - Therefore, restitution petition filed by wife, dismissed - Husband entitled to decree of divorce. 	(Para 37)

heading: Divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of desertion - Marriage solemnized on 9.3.2015 and wife left matrimonial home on 13.5.2015 - Whereas appellant/husband filed divorce petition on 25.2.2016 - Statutory period of 2 yrs. as contemplated in S.13(1)(i-b) not completed - From evidence also, it appears that wife did not intend to desert husband - Rather, husband was instrumental in ensuring that wife stays away from matrimonial home - Divorce petition liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grounds of cruelty and adultery - Husband alleged that wife refused to do household work and even to share bed with him - That, she used to leave home without informing anybody and she also had illicit relations with another man - To prove illicit relation, hostel mate of wife (during studies) was examined - However, except stating about behaviour of respondent, witness provided no link about illicit relationship - In any case, matter of adultery cannot be considered without impleading alleged adulterer - As regards alleged behaviour of respondent, no cogent evidence produced - Mere aggressive behaviour or sadness of wife does not mean that she is spoiling matrimonial life - Nuptial knots cannot be broken on unfounded allegations - Petition dismissed. 2015 (2) R.C.R. (Civil) 871, 2007 ALL SCR 881 Ref.to.	(Paras 7, 14, 16, 17)

heading: Decree
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Decree - Is appealable, in view of judgement in 1986 (2) PLR 608. 1986 (2) PLR 608. 	(Para 5)

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Appeal against - Both parties categorically stating that because of unfounded emotions and momentary temperamental differences, they have committed serious mistake of obtaining decree of divorce and now repenting - Parties want to live together for themselves and also for their only daughter - In peculiar facts and circumstances of the case decree of divorce set aside. 	(Paras 6, 8, 9, 10)

heading: Educational expenses of minor children
HeadNote.description: Educational expenses of minor children - Claim for, by wife - On ground that minor son is in high school and is in her custody so she has to incur all educational expenses including co-curricular activities - Wife was already awarded Rs.5,000/- p.m. as maintenance - In said application for maintenance pleadings in respect of educational expenses of minor son were considered by Family Court - No change in circumstances for wife to file fresh application for grant of educational expenses of minor son - Further, wife was also awarded interim maintenance of Rs.15,000/- p.m. in proceedings under DV Act in addition to Rs.5,000/- already granted - Wife not entitled to educational expenses of minor son. 	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance to child - Stay, on ground that access of child was not given to father - Validity - Minor child of 12 years is not article which can be given forcefully to another - Mother of minor child has not denied access to father - Minor child himself does not wish to meet his father - Further, there is no connection between access to child and interim maintenance - Father cannot be absolved of his liability to maintain his dependent child - Order staying interim maintenance, improper. 	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Are illegitimate
HeadNote.description: Children of void marriage - Are illegitimate - They would not be entitled to any share in ancestral coparcenary joint family property of their parents - Can only claim share in separate property of father - But they cannot make any claim during lifetime of their father - Said right would accrue to them only on death of their father by way of succession. 		(Paras 33, 37)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - General allegations that wife used to avoid husband and his family members and that she used to often visit her parental house and was not preparing food for husband and was not opening door of house after his return to home - Cannot constitute cruelty. 	(Para 18)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Sought on ground of cruelty by wife - Earlier petition filed by husband on ground of cruelty, disposed of in terms of compromise arrived at between parties and parties started residing together - Same allegations made in subsequent petition without mentioning any specific instances - Such bald allegations cannot be believed - Husband cannot take benefit of earlier complaints filed by him and contents of previous petition - Defence of wife that husband having illicit relationship with another lady and also begotten one son from her, also proved - Hence, petition dismissed.		 	(Paras 16, 19)

heading: Divorce proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Lunacy Act (1912), S.41 - Divorce proceedings - Matrimonial court has power to order a person to undergo medical test - It can be ordered by court either suo motu or at instance of a party.

A Matrimonial court has the power to order a person to undergo medical test.	 [Para 85]

The Court, however, indisputably is empowered to satisfy itself as to whether a party before it suffers from mental illness or not either for the purpose of appointment of a guardian in terms of Order 32, Rule 15 of Code of Civil Procedure or Section 41 of the Indian Lunacy Act as also for the determination of his competence as a witness.	 [Para 27]

The Court has power to issue appropriate direction for protection of human rights of mentally ill persons and to see to it that a person suffering from mental illness gets adequate protection in terms of the Mental Health Act.	 [Para 29]

Yet again the primary duty of a Court is to see that truth is arrived at. A party to a civil litigation, it is axiomatic, is not entitled to constitutional protections under Art.20 of the Constitution of India. Thus, the Civil Court although may not have any specific provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure and the Evidence Act, has an inherent power in terms of Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure to pass all orders for doing complete justice to the parties to the suit.  Discretionary power under Section 151 of Code of Civil Procedure,it is trite, can be exercised also on an application filed by the party.	 [Para 32,33]

In certain cases medical examination by the experts in the field may not only found to be leading to truth of the matter but may also lead to removal of misunderstanding between the parties. It may bring the parties to terms. Having regard to development in medicinal technology, it is possible to find out that what was presumed to be a mental disorder of a spouse is not really so.  In matrimonial disputes, the Court has also a conciliatory role to play-even for the said purpose it may require expert advice.	 [Para 34,35,36]

The prime concern of the Court is to find out as to whether a person who is said to be mentally ill could defend himself properly or not. Determination of such an issue although may have some relevance with the determination of the issue in the lis, nonetheless, the Court cannot be said to be wholly powerless in this behalf. Furthermore, it is one thing to say that a person would be subjected to test which would invade his right of privacy and may in some case amount to battery; but it is another thing to say that a party may be asked to submit himself to a psychiatrist or a psychoanalyst so as to enable the Court to arrive at a just conclusion. Whether the party to the marriage requires a treatment or not  can be found out only in the event, he is examined by a properly qualified  Psychiatrist. For the said purpose, it may not be necessary to submit him self to any blood test or other pathological tests.	 [Para 50]

If the Court for the purpose envisaged under Order 32, Rule 15 of Code of Civil Procedure or Section 41 of the Indian Lunacy Act can do it suo motu, there is no reason why it cannot do so on an application filed by party to the marriage. Even otherwise the Court may issue an appropriate direction so as to satisfy himself as to whether apart from treatment he requires adequate protection inter alia by way of legal aid so that he may not be subject to an unjust order because of his incapacity. Keeping in view of the fact that in a case of mental illness the Court has adequate power to examine the party or get him examined by a qualified doctor, we are of the opinion that in an appropriate case the Court may take recourse to such a procedure even at the instance of the party to the lis. Furthermore, the Court must be held to have the requisite power even under Section 115 of Code of Civil Procedure to issue such direction either suo motu or otherwise which, according to him, would lead to the truth.	 [Para 51,52,53]

heading: Matrimonial proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Matrimonial proceedings - Order to undergo medical test - Not violative of Art 21 of the Constitution - Power is to be exercised only if there is prima facie case and there is sufficient material before the court.

A  Matrimonial court has the power to order a person to undergo medical test.  Passing of such an order by the court would not be in violation of the right to personal liberty under Act 21 of the Constitution.  [Para 85]

In all such matrimonial cases where divorce is sought, say on the ground of impotency, schizophrenia ...etc. normally without there being medical examination, it would be difficult to arrive at a conclusion as to whether the allegation made by his spouse against the other spouse seeking divorce on such a ground, is correct or not. In order to substantiate such allegation, the petitioner would always insist on medical examination. If respondent avoids such medical examination on the ground that it violates his/her right to privacy or for a matter right to personal liberty as enshrined under Article 21 of the Constitution of India, then it may in most of such cases become impossible to arrive at a conclusion. It may render the very grounds on which divorce is permissible nugatory. Therefore, when there is no right to privacy specifically conferred by Article 21 of the Constitution of India and with the extensive interpretation of the phrase "personal liberty" this right has been read into Article 21, it cannot be treated as absolute right. What is emphasized is that some limitations on this right have to be imposed and particularly where two competing interests clash. In matters of aforesaid nature where the legislature has conferred a right upon his spouse to seek divorce on such grounds, it would be the right of that spouse which comes in conflict with the so-called right to privacy of the respondent. Thus the Court has to reconcile these competing interests by balancing the interests involved.	 [Para 80]

If for arriving at the satisfaction of the Court and to protect the right of a party to the lis who may otherwise be found to be incapable of protecting his own interest, the Court passes an appropriate order, the question of such action being violative of Article 21 of the Constitution of India would not arise. The Court having regard to Article 21 of the Constitution of India must also see to it that the right of a person to defend himself must be adequately protected.	 [Para 81]

heading: Divorce
Sought by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Sought by husband - On ground of cruelty by wife - Wife allegedly used to give threats that she will commit suicide as marriage was against her wish - Not believable as she was pregnant and pregnant lady may not take extreme step to commit suicide unless there are constrained circumstances - No case of husband that when such threats were given by wife, he called her father or arranged meeting of elders to give advice to wife or to restrain her from doing such acts in future - Absence of such natural conduct on part of husband casts doubt over his bona fides - Husband stating that wife has filed application u/S.24 of Guardians and Wards Act even though child was in her custody - However, same cannot be said to be frivolous, as it may have been filed because she wanted to get herself declared as guardian of child - Litigation for maintenance was also initiated by wife as husband had not arranged for her maintenance - Mere filing of such proceedings ipso facto will not amount to cruelty u/S.13 - Husband not entitled to divorce on said ground.			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Claim for by husband - On ground of desertion by wife - Husband alleging that wife was not residing with him for more than 2 yrs. without any reason - Restitution petition filed by wife on ground of desertion by husband was decreed by Court and had attained finality - Even after said decree husband did not resume cohabitation with wife - In such circumstances husband cannot claim that wife has deserted him without any reasonable cause - Moreover, wife claiming that when she was driven out of house she was pregnant - Therefore, it is hard to believe that she would have left house of husband on her own accord, without any reason - Further, husband issued notice for divorce within few days of wife leaving house, without making any attempt for bringing her for cohabitation - Such action on part of husband shows that he would not have accepted anything less than divorce - Thus, husband himself keeping wife away - Not entitled to decree of divorce on ground of desertion. 			(Paras 11, 12, 14, 16)

heading: Divorce
