HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of mental cruelty - Wife admitting before husband that she conceived before marriage through another man - Quarrel between spouses reached to extent of suicide attempt by wife - Acts of wife constitute mental cruelty - Husband entitled to decree of divorce. 2014 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 148, 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1833 (S.C.), 2002(3) ALL MR 945 (S.C.), (2004) 4 SCC 511, 2012(1) ALL MR 473 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Para 15)

heading: Permanent alimony
Computation
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Computation - Husband has already paid Rs.93,100/- towards maintenance - During conciliation, he had offered permanent alimony of Rs.3 lakh but conciliation had failed - Considering salary of husband Rs.41,203/- and fact that wife is 47 yrs. old, held, grant of Rs.12,36,000/- [i.e. 25% of salary x 12 x 10 (yrs.)] would meet ends of justice. 	(Para 16)

heading: Annulment of marriage
Fraud and misrepresentation
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - Fraud and misrepresentation - Advertisement by husband in matrimonial columns of newspaper - Father of wife replying and clearly stating that his daughter was "legally divorced" - Mother of husband replying to letter stating that her son was "also legally divorced" - Word "also" clearly meant that mother knew that the wife was usually divorced before her son's marriage was settled - No evidence of suppression of facts or any fraud or misrepresentation on the part of parents in bringing about marriage - Marriage cannot be annulled on this ground.	(Para 8)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Allegation of cruelty and desertion by wife - No direct evidence of fact that respondent went to clinic of appellant and shouted slogans against appellant - Respondent wife had to go to an orphanage along with child which meant that she was driven out of the house by appellant - Appellant also failed to prove desertion by wife - Dismissal of petition for divorced is justified - No interference.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty and desertion
Erroneous
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty and desertion - Wife's employment and staying away - Issue as to whether fact of wife's employment was disclosed to husband at time of marriage - Finding of court below that there was no reason for wife to hide said fact - Erroneous - Matrimonial advertisement clearly projected wife as studying - Husband's job was transferable all over India - He would not want wife to stay away even after marriage and meet only on holidays - Initially wife's employment was on ad hoc basis which was regularized only after 4 yrs. of marriage - In said circumstances, allegation of husband that wife refused to cohabit with husband on day to day basis, appearing true - It constitutes both cruelty and desertion. 	(Para 31)

heading: Divorce petition
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - On ground of desertion - Maintainability - Initially, husband filed divorce petition on ground of cruelty - After 2 yrs. of alleged desertion, he filed second petition on ground of desertion - Maintainability of second petition challenged on ground that filing of earlier petition would prevent wife from resuming cohabitation - Held, there is no general rule that filing of one petition bars a subsequent petition alleging desertion - It would have to be pleaded and proved in each case - Not a case of wife that she wanted to resume cohabitation but failed to do so only because of earlier petition - On contrary, there is evidence to disclose that she was not even ready to talk to husband about their future - Second petition not barred. 		(Para 33)

heading: Divorce
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of adultery - Challenge - Husband alleged that in his absence, 2nd respondent/police constable used to visit his wife - Specific instance referred by him wherein he had seen his wife indulging in sexual intercourse with 2nd respondent - On his making hue and cry, neighbours had also gathered and seen 2nd respondent coming out - Allegation supported by testimony of a neighbour and son - Support also provided by order of disciplinary action against 2nd respondent - Decree of divorce, justified. 	(Para 4)

heading: Annulment of marriage
Petition by wife
HeadNote.description:
Annulment of marriage - Petition by wife - On ground of non-performance of 'saptapadi' ceremony - Marriage performed in absence of parents of parties by exchange of garlands in Mandir - Though photographs produced by husband shows that 'phera' was being taken, evidence not available of persons clicking those photographs - After two days of marriage, parties stated to have moved Human Right Commission seeking protection - However, affidavit of wife filed before said Commission within a week, states that she never agreed for marriage - This causes a dent in appellant's case - Marriage certificate produced by husband does not show date of marriage - 'Pujari' performing ceremonies also not examined - There being no proof of saptapadi, valid marriage cannot be said to have taken place - Decree of annulment, cannot be interfered with.

1994(4) SCC 363, 2016(1) L.A.R. 558 Ref. to. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10, 12)

heading: Validity of marriage
Proof
HeadNote.description: Validity of marriage - Proof - When factum of marriage is disputed, registration of marriage under Hindu Marriage Act or Special Marriage Act cannot constitute proof of a valid marriage. 2016(1) L.A.R. 558 Ref. to. 	(Para 10)

heading: Interim maintenance
Application by wife
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by wife - Alleged suppression of material facts - Interest if any in flat acquired by wife along with father and brother two months after filing of said application - And transfer of said interest to her brother was again much after filing of said application - Therefore, expecting wife to have disclosed such particulars in said application, not proper - Rejection of application on alleged suppression of said particulars - Illegal. 	(Paras 14, 25)

heading: Interim maintenance
Application by wife
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by wife - Wife allegedly acquired interest in flat along with her father and brother after filing application - Fact that notice of demand or notice for payment of taxes addressed only in name of wife - Not a ground to presume that wife is the sole owner of flat. 	(Para 17)

heading: Interim maintenance
Application by wife
Delay in disposal
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by wife - Delay in disposal - Application filed in year 2011 - Disposed of in year 2016 - Nothing on record that wife was responsible for said delay - Inference by Family Court that such delay is indicative of fact that wife was/is capable of earning sufficient for her needs and therefore was not in need of any interim maintenance - Not proper. 	(Paras 20, 25)

heading: Interim maintenance
Application by wife
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by wife - Wife has given sufficient indication as regards her own financial status and also of her husband - Life style to which parties accustomed also indicated - Capital and non capital assets owned by husband also stated broadly as to why she claimed interim maintenance of Rs.5 lakhs p.m. - Thus, in facts, rejection of claim of wife on basis that she had failed to give break up of expenses - Not proper. 			(Paras 21, 25)

heading: Interim maintenance
Application by wife
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by wife - Failure of Family Court to look into document produced by both parties - Mere observation that said documents can be looked into only after their veracity is tested in trial - Not correct approach for dealing with application for interim maintenance. 	(Paras 23, 25, 37)

heading: Interim maintenance
Application by wife
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by wife - Husband having considerable stakes in family concern, other companies and firms - His luxury life style reflected from material placed on record - Material on record not sufficient to infer that husband was having only Rs.4 to 5 lakhs per annum - Thus, husband easily being in position to pay interim maintenance of Rs.1 lakh p.m. to wife - However, since wife was earning Rs.25000 to 30000 p.m. as tutor in French, interim maintenance can reasonably be determined as Rs.75000 p.m. - Fact that wife has jewellery worth more than one crore, would be of no relevance - Further fact that parents of wife are rich and affluent or in position to maintain her, is also of no relevance. 			(Paras 39, 40, 43)

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - Proof - Vague allegations made that wife was not dutiful to household work and used to disrespect elders - Only two specific instances quoted - One, when wife allegedly refused to prepare tea for guests and insulted husband by calling him ‘impotent’ - Another, when she threw utensils in kitchen and called husband ‘bauna’ - Except these two instances which pertained to same month, no other instance quoted from rest of 5 yrs. of cohabitation - Even these two instances were not proved - Witness stated to have been in drawing room and not in kitchen where parties quarrelled - Witness also admitted to have been a regular visitor but never been insulted by wife - Isolated and unproved instances, cannot become ground of divorce - Impugned decree, set aside. 	(Paras 14, 15, 16, 19, 22, 25)

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - Proof - Evidence must be of contemporaneous nature - Bald statements made in petition, unsupported by such an evidence is not a sufficient proof. 	(Para 17)

heading: Condonation of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of cruelty - Wife allegedly insulted husband by calling him ‘impotent’ in year 2009 - Considering that parties lived together till year 2013, alleged misbehaviour can be taken to have been condoned - This cannot constitute ‘cruelty’. 
2017 ALL SCR 817, 2007 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 65 Ref. to. 	(Para 18)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Onus is of petitioner to prove cruelty and not for respondent to prove negative - When testimony of petitioner/husband itself was bereft of any material, finding by court that wife failed to rebut allegation of cruelty, was erroneous. 	(Para 24)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Alleged desertion by wife - Various complaints filed by wife with Women’s Cell wherein compromises too had been effected - No complaint filed with Police - Inference can be drawn that wife wanted to reconcile with husband - It was husband who did not adhere to compromise terms - From evidence, it appears that wife left matrimonial home due to situations created by husband - Husband is guilty of 'constructive desertion' - Dismissal of petition proper. 		(Para 10)

heading: Divorce petition
Proof
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Alleged cruelty by wife - Proof - Allegations of husband that wife is overly attached to her parents, not knowing basic cooking, being rude etc. - Not of such magnitude which would make it impossible for him to live with wife - Cruelty by wife, not proved - Her conduct in filing complaint only with Women’s Cell and not with Police, also goes in her favour - Whereas, husband’s conduct in levelling allegation of adultery against wife (though not pressed), amounts to cruelty - Dismissal of petition proper. 			(Para 12)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Filing of false complaint by wife against husband's brother alleging molestation - Accused discharged by Court as there was no evidence showing his involvement in offence - Such complaint by wife tarnished image of husband and his entire family - It would amount to cruelty u/S.13(i)(i-a) - On said ground alone husband would be entitled to decree of divorce.	(Paras 36, 38, 50)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty by wife - Wife filed complaint against husband's brother that he threatened to kidnap her child - However, made contradictory statement before police authorities - This incident would certainly amount to cruelty as contemplated u/S.13(i)(i-a) - Especially when no further action was taken on this complaint by investigating authorities as there appeared no substance in allegations. 	(Paras 39, 50)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Petition on ground of cruelty - Events occurred during pendency of petition - Can and should be looked into for considering whether a case of cruelty is made out as contemplated u/S.13(i)(i-a). 2012(4) ALL MR 506 (S.C.) Foll.			(Paras 40, 41)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Wife was out to harass husband by having him arrested time and again without bringing true and correct facts before Family Court and subverting process of law and justice - It would certainly amount to cruelty u/S.13(i)(i-a).	(Paras 42, 43, 50)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Wife hit her mother-in-law in abdomen with her elbow - Knowing fully well that mother in law was suffering from breast cancer and her abdomen muscles were removed and transplanted around chest along with fat and fascia and there were no nerve on left side of abdomen - Testimony of her husband and mother in law, not shattered - Act of wife amounts to cruelty.			(Paras 48, 49, 50)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Wife involved in number of incidents causing harassment and cruelty to husband and his family - Family Court examined each incident rather than looking at case in its entirety - Even some of major incidents have not been considered - Therefore order refusing to grant divorce to husband, suffers from perversity - Set aside.	(Para 51)

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - Is a state of mind - Feeling of deep anguish, disappointment, frustration in one spouse caused by the conduct of the other for a long time, may lead to mental cruelty. 			(Para 16)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged mental cruelty caused by wife - Contention that criminal case filed by wife against husband ended in acquittal - Appeal against acquittal still pending - No allegation that wife had levelled allegation assassinating his character or of any of his family members which could have adverse impact on his avocation - Held, mere fact that criminal case ended in acquittal by itself would not lead to a finding against wife that she is guilty of causing extreme mental cruelty to husband which could become basis for dissolution of marriage. 2013 ALL SCR 993 Disting. 			(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged mental cruelty caused by wife - Husband alleged that wife was habitual of taking intoxicant drugs and under influence of such drugs she had insulted and abused him time and again - However, except bald deposition no evidence produced to prove the same - Rather wife tendered her urine examination reports of that period when she was pregnant and was residing with husband - Thus, mental cruelty by wife not proved - Infact failure to prove such serious allegation shows that it was husband's conduct which comes out to be harsh and cruel towards wife.	(Para 14)

heading: Annulment of marriage
HeadNote.description: Annulment of marriage - On ground of fraud by wife by suppressing material facts - Consent of husband for marriage allegedly obtained by suppressing fact of skin disease and scar on chest of wife - Scar is on lower part below neck which can remain covered by normal clothes - Photographs of wife sent by e-mail to husband before marriage reveal scar on her chest - Even after seeing scar on first night, husband continued to cohabit with wife for one month - Nothing to show that husband cohabited with wife without full consent after alleged fraud discovered - Burden to show that after discovery of fraud, there was no physical relationship or then relationship was discontinued, not discharged by husband - Husband failed to prove alleged fraud or suppression - Not entitled to annulment of marriage.			(Paras 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 37)

heading: Prayer by wife
HeadNote.description: Restitution of conjugal rights - Prayer by wife - Husband deserted wife on ground that she suppressed fact of suffering from skin disease and having scar on her chest - However, he has cohabited with wife for one month even after noticing scar on chest of wife - Husband also failed to establish that wife or her family members played fraud or suppressed fact of scar - Withdrawal from society of wife by husband, improper - Grant of decree of restitution of conjugal rights and in default to maintenance of Rs.20,000/- p.m., proper.	(Paras 39, 40, 41, 42, 43)

heading: Challenge by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Challenge by wife - On ground that due to her not being in right frame of mind she was forced to accede to paltry amount of money offered to her as permanent alimony and as maintenance to daughter - Decree obtained u/S.13B by practicing fraud may be recalled by court in exceptional cases - But if from evidence and other material on record, there is no element of coercion or any undue influence, decree u/S.13B cannot be recalled or interfered with - No case of wife that she was forced to get her marriage dissolved on account of any fear or coercion - Plea of wife that terms and conditions were not settled at time of recording first motion statements - It will not take away substratum of decree - Any party seeking variation in terms and conditions of divorce can resort to provisions of S.25(2) or to any other remedy - Wife failed to prove fraud, coercion - Decree of divorce cannot be interfered with. 	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Appeal against - Is not maintainable in view of provisions of S.19(2) of Family Courts Act. (Para 13)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Ex-parte decree of divorce - Legality - Appellant-wife was proceeded ex-parte on basis of report of Process Server - Copy of said report does not bear even name of person in whose presence an attempt was made to serve appellant-wife - Even if it is presumed that appellant had refused to accept service, in said eventuality, provisions of O.5 R.17 will come into operation - No such exercise done by process server - Therefore, passing of ex-parte decree, held illegal.	(Paras 7, 8, 10)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Wife filing petition on ground of cruelty - Husband also seeking divorce in counter-claim on ground of cruelty and desertion - Wife admitted fact of desertion by her for more than 2 yrs. and applied for judgment on admission in terms of O.12 R.6 - Held, wife is taking advantage of her own wrong - Decree of divorce, declined. (Para 14)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Not permissible on mere admissions and without recording any evidence. 17 Bombay 624 (F.B.), AIR 1960 Bom. 117, 2010(5) ALL MR 405 Rel. on. (Para 20)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Divorce petition - Filed on ground of cruelty by wife - Wife allegedly filed false complaint against husband - Husband also did not leave any stone unturned in taking help of Police to harass wife and filed false complaint against her - In such circumstances decree of divorce granted on ground of wife lodging false FIR, held not sustainable. 	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Wife allegedly levelled false allegation of adultery against husband - Wife neither took up plea of involvement of husband with another woman nor did make any such allegation in her examination in chief - It was only with an objective to extract said allegation she was asked questions pertaining to said woman - In such circumstances it cannot be said that any prejudice caused to husband by alleged allegation by wife - Wife cannot be held guilty of making such allegation.			(Para 19)

heading: Divorce
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Alleged cruelty by wife - Condonation of - Husband's mother committed suicide allegedly due to harassment given by wife - However, after incident of suicide husband took his wife to Canada - Same tantamounts to condonation of cruelty as per provisions of S.23(1)(b) of HM Act.	(Para 19)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of break down of marriage - Parties living separately since long - There differences seem to have kept them apart giving indication that marriage has broken down - However, broken marriage is no ground for grant of divorce - Child born out of their wedlock being maintained by wife - She cannot be attributed desertion warranting grant of divorce - As husband failed to establish that wife ever had intention to desert him or she had actually deserted him - Divorce petition rejected. 		(Para 20)

heading: Second divorce petition
HeadNote.description: Second divorce petition - Whether barred by res-judicata - Earlier petition (HMP 1) was filed on ground of cruelty by wife during period of cohabitation - Same was decided on merits and dismissed - Subsequent petition also based on acts of cruelty allegedly inflicted by wife during same period of cohabitation, though with a slight variation in acts alleged to be constituting cruelty - Held, in any contingency, if husband had omitted to mention some of acts in HMP-1, which were available to him but he chooses not to rely on those instances which he referred to and mentioned in HMP-2 - Same does not give him distinct cause of action - HMP-2 based on same set of facts, barred by res-judicata. 	(Paras 12, 20)

heading: Divorce
Cruelty
Ground of
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Cruelty - Ground of - Wife alleging that husband demanded Rs.25 lacs to extend his consent for dissolving marriage by mutual consent and also spread damaging rumours about her in society making her difficult to stay in society - Testimony of witnesses of wife and her own testimony not found reliable - Also no other evidence adduced by wife - Husband examined himself refuting allegations and stood well in cross-examination - Held, in circumstances, trial court's view that wife failed to prove her allegations proper.	(Para 14)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Not a single allegation by wife found to be worthy of acceptance - Years spent in litigation cannot be relied on to say that marriage is dead - Divorce cannot be granted on this solitary ground.	(Para 16)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Complaint under S.498-A of I.P.C. filed by wife against husband - No action taken by police - No other follow up action on it - It cannot be termed as a case of cruelty. AIR 1994 SC 710 and (1975)2 SCC 326 - Ref. to.			(Paras 7 to 9)

heading: Divorce
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grant of - There is no provision under the Hindu Marriage Act to grant divorce on the ground that the marriage is irretrievably broken down.	(Para 11)

heading: Bride
HeadNote.description: Bride - Within meaning of S.5 - Would include not only a woman but also a transwoman - Words of statute must be interpreted in the light of legal system as it exists today. 	(Paras 10, 15)

heading: Illegitimate daughters
Right of
HeadNote.description: Illegitimate daughters - Right of - Any unmarried illegitimate daughter on date of coming into force of S.29-A of Hindu Succession Act does not have equal share as that of male coparceners by virtue of S.29-A read with S.16 of Hindu Marriage Act.	(Para 27)

heading: Customary divorce
Recognition of
HeadNote.description: Customary divorce - Recognition of - S.29(2) of HM Act saves customary rights - However, a person who relies upon such custom has to prove that such custom and usage had been continuously and uniformly observed for a long time and had obtained force of law amongst Hindus in their local area, tribe, community, group or family - And such custom was not unreasonable or opposed to public policy. 	(Para 67)

heading: Presumption of divorce
Property dispute
HeadNote.description: Presumption of divorce - Whether can be drawn - Property dispute - Contention that plaintiff having stayed with her second husband for a long period and three children begotten out of such relationship so presumption of a valid divorce between plaintiff and her first husband can be drawn - Held, divorce can be granted only u/S.13 of HM Act - On basis of long standing relationship even if legal presumption of marriage of plaintiff and her second husband is drawn - Presumption of divorce from first husband, cannot be drawn by any court of law. 	(Para 69)

headline:
(A) Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.13 – Divorce – Mental cruelty – Husband suffered adverse consequences in his life and career on account of allegations made by wife to various authorities – Legal consequences must follow – Those cannot be prevented only because, no Court has determined that allegations were false.			

(B) Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.13 – Divorce – Mental cruelty – Allegations/complaints levelled by highly educated spouse, wife against husband – Have propensity to irreparably damage the character and reputation of husband – Husband entitled to dissolution of his marriage.

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - Husband suffered adverse consequences in his life and career on account of allegations made by wife to various authorities - Legal consequences must follow - Those cannot be prevented only because, no Court has determined that allegations were false.			(Para 12)

headline:
(A) Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.13 – Divorce – Mental cruelty – Husband suffered adverse consequences in his life and career on account of allegations made by wife to various authorities – Legal consequences must follow – Those cannot be prevented only because, no Court has determined that allegations were false.			

(B) Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.13 – Divorce – Mental cruelty – Allegations/complaints levelled by highly educated spouse, wife against husband – Have propensity to irreparably damage the character and reputation of husband – Husband entitled to dissolution of his marriage.

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Mental cruelty - Allegations/complaints levelled by highly educated spouse, wife against husband - Have propensity to irreparably damage the character and reputation of husband - Reputation of husband sullied amongst his colleagues, his superiors and society at large - Plea by wife that she made said complaints in order to protect matrimonial ties, not tenable - It is definite case of cruelty inflicted by wife against husband - Husband thus entitled to dissolution of his marriage - Broken relationship between parties cannot be termed as normal wear and tear of middle class married life.			(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Permanent alimony
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Orally sought in divorce proceeding - Without making any separate application u/S.25 of Hindu Marriage Act - Maintainability - 'Application' as referred in S.25 implies any application either in writing or oral - Mode and form of application u/S.25, is immaterial - What is essential is material before court to decide same - Court cannot pass any order of permanent alimony and maintenance in vacuum - Court has to consider parameters guided in provision itself - Relief is incidental in nature and it is not substantive relief - Oral prayer for permanent alimony, maintainable. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18, 19, 22, 23)

heading: Divorce by mutual consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Procedure for passing of decree - Stated.

	The procedure for passing the decree of divorce by mutual consent by the trial court u/s 13B of the Act. Both parties have to move a joint petition before court stating therein that they are residing separately for a period of one year or more and they have not been able to reside together and they have mutually agreed that the marriage should be dissolved. The court registers the case and keep the matter pending for second motion by the parties after six month or more but not later than 18 months, if the case is not withdrawn in the meantime. After six months or more but not later than 18 months, on the motion of both the parties, the court shall, on being satisfied, after hearing the parties and after making such enquiries as it deems fit, that a marriage has been solemnized and that the averments in the petition are true, pass a decree of divorce by mutual consent.(Para 14)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description:
Permanent alimony - Factors to be considered while granting relief of - Stated. 

	In terms of section 25 of the Act, for granting the relief of permanent alimony, the court has to consider the respondent’s own income and other property, if any, the income and other property of the applicant, the conduct of the parties and other circumstances of the case, it may seem to the court to be just.	(Para 15)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Decree of judicial separation - Grant of, in proceedings for divorce by mutual consent - Challenge - While passing impugned order, Trial Court observed that period of parties staying together is so short that it is not possible that any serious dispute would have arisen between them - There need not be serious dispute between married couple for seeking divorce by mutual consent - If application is duly constituted and properly presented before Court, it is not for Court to search for ground or reason, which compelled parties to seek divorce by mutual consent - Parties presented application u/S.13B by appearing before Trial Court and thereafter on subsequent dates also appeared - Trial Court should have passed decree of divorce by mutual consent - Decree of judicial separation liable to be set aside. 			(Paras 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Decree of judicial separation
HeadNote.description: Decree of judicial separation - Grant of, in proceedings for divorce by mutual consent - Provisions contained in S.13A would attract only when Trial Court is satisfied "having regard to circumstances of case" that it considers so just to pass decree for judicial separation instead of mutual divorce - Unless such circumstances exist, Trial Court is not entitled to pass decree for judicial separation in mechanical manner. 		(Paras 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Husband went to fetch wife from house of ‘M’ who was treating her as his daughter - Quarrel between them, at that time found to be in nature of word against word - It can at the highest be said to arise out of ordinary wear and tear of marriage - Was not of such a level or gravity to say that same amounted wife inflicting cruelty on husband - Husband not entitled to divorce - Further, allegations made by wife in written statement as to second marriage by husband did not remain unsubstantiated - Thus, husband, held, not entitled for divorce on ground of cruelty. (Paras 13, 16)

heading: Divorce
Ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of cruelty - Fact that husband and his family members acquitted in criminal proceedings initiated by wife u/S. 498A IPC - Not sufficient to grant divorce - Moreso when husband failed to comply with the requirements of S.20(1) r.w. S.21 of HM Act to at least plead about initiation of said criminal proceedings by wife and its subsequent culmination in order of acquittal may be by amending the proceedings. 2020 ALL SCR 835 Foll. (Paras 23, 26, 27, 33)

heading: Divorce
Ground of desertion
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Ground of desertion - Wife specifically denied having deserted company of husband - Wife stated to be residing in her matrimonial home along with her husband and in-laws whenever she returned from Mumbai to Nagpur - Similarly husband used to reside with wife intermittently whenever he visited Mumbai and other places where the wife was pursuing her pilot training - He had no problem with service of wife nor did he have any objection to her further education or development - Wife admittedly attended last rites of his father - Husband failed to prove that wife left his company with view not to rejoin him in future and that it was without reasonable cause - Thus, no case of desertion made out by husband for grant of divorce. (Paras 31, 33)

heading: Appeal
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Limitation - Wife filed appeal within limitation - Prior thereto husband contracted second marriage - Said marriage would not be void but merely invalid. (Para 32)

heading: Divorce petition
HeadNote.description:
Divorce petition - Ground of mental cruelty - Allegation pertained to wife’s strange behaviour after she returned from maternal home after delivering a son - This covered period of only 4 days - Thereafter, wife sent to maternal home again - Alleged strange behaviour not supported by any evidence - Same was not even reflected in legal notice - For said behaviour of 4 days, divorce petition filed after 5 yrs. - Two other instances of cruelty also alleged but no evidence produced - No efforts made to fetch wife - Though she made repeated calls to take her back - In such a case, filing of maintenance claim by wife cannot be called as harassment - No case of mental cruelty made out - Petition dismissed.

AIR 2002 SC 2582, AIR 2002 SC 591, 2006 (3) SCC 778, 2007 (3) SCC 136 Ref. to. (Paras 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 14, 18)

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Mental cruelty - Prayer to produce additional evidence of mobile recordings - Said evidence pertained to subsequent conduct of wife behaving badly with mother and brother of her husband - Not a determinative factor in divorce petition - Discretion under O.41 R. 27(1)(b) not exercised. 

1992 Suppl. (2) SCC 623, (2004) 8 SCC 490 Ref. to. (Para 21)

heading: Matrimonial proceedings
Husband seeking divorce
HeadNote.description:
Matrimonial proceedings - Husband seeking divorce - Whereas wife seeking restitution - Husband alleging that wife does not take care of step daughters and ailing mother-in-law and frequently visits her parents’ home - Allegations are general and vague - No evidence produced in support - Not a case of mental cruelty but only a normal wear and tear of marital life - No notice served on wife before filing petition - No attempt made by husband to fetch wife even though she is ready to cohabit - This shows adamant approach of husband - Decree of divorce granted by court below set aside - Decree of restitution passed.

AIR 2002 SC 591, (2007) SCC 511 Rel. on. (Paras 15, 18, 22)

heading: Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Mental cruelty - Conduct of respondent to be looked into - Whether making it impossible for petitioner to co-habit - If it is case of accusations and allegations, regard must be had to context in which they were made.
	AIR 1994 SC 710 Rel. on. (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Judicial separation
Legality
HeadNote.description: Judicial separation - Denying decree of divorce - Legality - Several complaints and petitions filed by respondent wife against petitioner and his parents - One u/S.12 of DV Act was rejected on merits - Falsity of allegations established by material on record - Respondent filed no petition for restitution - Rather, she uploaded her profile on two matrimonial sites during pendency of petition - Evidence of husband show that respondent was not happy since beginning and wanted him to leave his secured job at Goa and move to Akola - Independent witness also deposed that respondent left house of petitioner in night despite humble requests made by petitioner - Conduct of respondent made life of petitioner miserable - He is entitled to decree of divorce for mental cruelty - Order of judicial separation liable to be set aside. (Paras 20 to 25)

heading: Divorce
Mental cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Mental cruelty - Allegation that wife is of suspicious nature, visiting husband’s office and creating scenes - Not denied specifically in w.s. - Not even countered in cross-examination - Deemed to be admitted as per O.8 R.5 of CPC - Whereas wife’s allegation of dowry demand belied by her own admission that there were no talks on dowry and marriage expenses were shared equally - House which husband had taken on loan, transferred in name of wife - Husband even left that house - Not a case of mere ‘ordinary wear and tear of married life’ - Husband cannot be reasonably expected to live with wife - Decree of divorce proper.
2012(1) ALL MR 267, 2003(3) ALL MR 777 (S.C.), 2016(3) ALL MR 901 (S.C.) Rel.on.(Paras 20, 22, 25, 27, 28, 30, 32, 35, 36)

heading: Maintenance
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.21 R.94 - Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (2005), S.20(6) - Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125 - Maintenance - Grant of - Enforcement of orders.

The order or decree of maintenance may be enforced like a decree of a civil court, through the provisions which are available for enforcing a money decree, including civil detention, attachment of property, etc. as provided by various provisions of the CPC, more particularly Sections 51, 55, 58, 60 read with Order XXI. (Para 101) 

Striking off the defence of the respondent is an order which ought to be passed in the last resort, if the Courts find default to be wilful and contumacious, particularly to a dependant unemployed wife, and minor children.

Contempt proceedings for wilful disobedience may be initiated before the appropriate Court. (Paras 102, 103)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of marital rape - Oral testimony of respondent, wife in regard to sexual perversity of husband, found trustworthy and unshaken during cross-examination - Evidence of wife clearly established that she was subjected to all sorts of sexual perversions against her will - Husband’s such licentious disposition disregarding autonomy of wife, amounts to marital rape - It falls in frame of physical and mental cruelty - Further, Imputation by husband, appellant as regards illicit relationship of wife, not substantiated - Husband’s failure in business attributable to wayward life led by him - His own father also made complaints against him and sought Police protection - Entire gold ornaments of wife taken away by appellant and sold to discharge his liability - Appellant never cared to provide love and care to respondent or his children and constantly harassing her by demanding money - It amounts to mental cruelty - Held, in view of facts wife entitled to divorce on clearly established ground of cruelty.	(Para 9, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description:
Divorce - Ground of marital rape - Fact that law does not recognise marital rape under penal law, does not inhibit court from recognizing the same as a form of cruelty to grant divorce - Therefore, marital rape is a good ground to claim divorce.
	In modern social jurisprudence, spouses in marriage are treated as equal partners and husband cannot claim any superior right over wife either with respect to her body or with reference to individual status. Treating wife’s body as something owing to husband and committing sexual act against her will is nothing but marital rape. Right to respect for his or her physical and mental integrity encompass bodily integrity, any disrespect or violation of bodily integrity is a violation of individual autonomy. Autonomy essentially refers to a state of feeling or condition one believes to possess having control over it. In matrimony, spouse possesses such privacy as invaluable right inherent in him or her as individual. Therefore, marital privacy is intimately and intrinsically connected to individual autonomy and any intrusion, physically or otherwise into such space would diminish privacy. This essentially would constitute cruelty. Merely for the reason that the law does not recognise marital rape under penal law, it does not inhibit the court from recognizing the same as a form of cruelty to grant divorce. We, therefore, are of the view that marital rape is a good ground to claim divorce.	(Para 13)

heading: Permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Permanent alimony - Grant of, in decree for divorce, within jurisdiction of Court, no specific application necessary - Decree for divorce granted in favour of appellant-husband on ground of cruelty and desertion - Respondent-wife was aged 35 years by time of petition in 1994 and couple had children through wedlock who were in custody of respondent - Taking into account liability of respondent to maintain and bring up children apart from maintaining herself, Trial Court, held, rightly made a reasonable provision in lumpsum of Rs.1,00,000/- towards permanent alimony - Order of trial Court not shown to be in any way unreasonable or disproportionate to means and assets of appellant - Impugned order confirmed. 1993(1) APLJ 113, 1994(1) ALT 713 (DB), 1995(3) ALD 195 (DB) - Rel. on.		(Paras 9-11) -

heading: Withdrawal of consent
HeadNote.description:
Divorce by mutual consent - Withdrawal of consent - Held, no spouse can unilaterally, wilfully be allowed to withdraw consent even on grounds such as fraud, undue force unless grounds are proved satisfactorily.

The Petitioner, by making representation that he was agreeable for divorce by mutual consent provided - respondent-wife withdraws her criminal complaint, returns his ornaments given to her in the marriage and takes care and custody of the minor child with limited access to him. The said representation made by the husband was accepted and acted upon by the respondent- wife to her prejudice. She withdrew criminal complaint filed against the husband and his family members. She returned ornaments received by her in the marriage.  She agreed to have a custody of the minor son and on the top of it waived present and future right to claim maintenance for herself as well as for minor son. Thus, it is clear like a day light that the respondent- wife acted to her prejudice by accepting terms of compromise favourable to the petitioner-husband. The husband is, thus, estopped from withdrawing his consent.  The Family Court cannot be helpless spectator and duplicity of the petitioner-husband to induce the hapless wife, the respondent to waive maintenance claim for not only herself and her son, also compelled her to withdraw the criminal complaint in the hope of starting her life afresh. The husband by his conduct has caused the wife huge disadvantage. No spouse can unilaterally, wilfully be allowed to withdraw consent even on the grounds; such as fraud, undue force, representation unless grounds are proved satisfactorily. In the present case, if the withdrawal of consent by the petitioner-husband is upheld, it will cause anamolous situation and serious prejudice to the respondent-wife, who is law abiding person. She will be left high and dry without recourse to any remedy and saddled with dead marriage. The respondent-husband has resorted to fraud and misrepresentation which cannot be permitted by the Courts of Law and equity.  The Family Court has rightly taken into account the wrong sought to be done by the husband and his attempt to cheat his wife depriving her an opportunity to work out and regulate the life of herself and her son in a fresh air. A pedantic interpretation of law might result in a situation resulting in gross miscarriage of justice in denying a woman with her abandoned son an opportunity to start their life afresh as stated.  AIR 1996 P and H 201 and (I) 1998 DNC 509 - Ref. to.	 [Para 33,35]

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Enhanced maintenance in changed circumstances - Application for, under Section 25(2) after having received Rs.30,000 in full and final settlement of her claim for maintenance - Maintainability - Held, grant of maintenance under Section 25(1), incidental to decree granting substantial relief under Act - Right of maintenance, a continuing right even after grant of decree under Act - Quantum of maintenance variable from time to time in light of changed circumstances of either party - Court, if satisfied that there is a change in circumstances of either party at any time after granting maintenance under Section 25(1), it may at instance of either party vary, modify or rescind such order passed under sub-section (1) - Appeal against dismissal of application, by Family Court, allowed. Family Courts Act (1984), S.19.

Section 25(1) of the Act provides for grant of a  gross sum or monthly or periodical sum towards maintenance on an application made by the wife or husband for a term not exceeding the life of the applicant taking into consideration the factors specified thereunder. Sub-section (1) of Section 25 makes it clear that such an order may be passed by the Court exercising the jurisdiction under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 at the time of passing any decree or at any time subsequent thereto. In other words, grant of maintenance under Section 25(1) is incidental to the decree granting substantial relief under the Act. Sub-section (2) of Section 25 provides that if the Court is satisfied that there is a change in the circumstances of either party at any time after granting maintenance under sub-section (1), the Court may at the instance of either party vary, modify or rescind such order passed under sub-section (1).   [Para 22]

The object of granting maintenance under Section 25 (1) is to enable the applicant, either the wife or the husband who has no independent income sufficient for her or his support, to maintain her/himself as per the status and economical condition of the other party. Sub-section (2) of Section 25 further empowers the Court to vary or revise the quantum of maintenance granted under sub-section (1) if there is any change in the circumstances of the parties. On a combined reading of sub-sections (1) & (2), it is clear that the right of maintenance is a continuing right even after a decree is granted under the Act and the quantum of maintenance is variable from time to time if there is change in the circumstances of either party.   [Para 23]

In the instant case permanent alimony as agreed between the parties was granted to wife while granting a decree of divorce and the same was complied with. The said order passed in I.A.No.540 of 2003, dated 6.10.2004, was admittedly made under sub-section (1) of Section 25 of the Act. If that be so, it is always open to the wife to seek enhancement of maintenance under Section 25(2) provided the changed circumstances are established to the satisfaction of the Court. Ex.P-2 settlement under which the wife agreed not to claim any further maintenance, does not preclude the Court to exercise the discretion conferred under sub-section (2) of Section 25 of the Act if the Court is satisfied as to change in the circumstances of the wife.  AIR 1969 AP 213 : 1969(1)An.WR 41 (DB) - Rel. on.   [Para 24]

heading: Stridhan
HeadNote.description:
Stridhan - Return of Stridhan on divorce or desertion - Word "Stridhan" includes gifts made to wife at time of marriage by her parents, brother, in-laws, husband, etc. - She is absolute owner of her stridhan property and she can deal with it in any manner she likes - Held, in the event of divorce or desertion, she is entitled for her stridhan and her claim in respect thereof, if proved, must be allowed and necessary directions to return the same must be issued by courts.

The word "Stridhan" includes gifts made to the wife at the time of marriage by her parents, brother, in-laws, husband etc. She is absolute owner of her Stridhan property and she can deal with it in any manner she likes. In the event of divorce or desertion, she is entitled for her Stridhan and her claim in respect thereof, if proved, must be allowed and necessary directions to return the same must be issued by the courts. In the present case, there is no dispute that the certain ornaments were gifted to the appellant by her parents in the marriage, as stated by her in her written statement and in her evidence. The respondent has also deposed that some ornaments were gifted by him at the time of marriage to the appellant. The appellant in her written statement and in her evidence, however, has made reference only to the ornaments/gifts made by her parents as Stridhan. There are six articles, mentioned in paragraph 11(O) of the written statement and in paragraph 23 of her deposition, as Stridhan. She has not claimed ornaments/gifts made by the respondent in the marriage as Stridhan. According to the respondent, all the ornaments were taken away by her while leaving the house. As against this, the appellant in her examination-in-chief has deposed that when she left the house the respondent and his relatives removed her all ornaments and refused to return them. This all happened when she last left the matrimonial home in June, 1996. Since then till the complaint under section 498-A was filed by her in October, 1997 and/or till she filed the written statement in the present case on 23.6.1998 she did not complain to the police about the alleged removal of her ornaments. The appellant, who had approached police on several occasions, would have definitely approached the police either immediately or atleast within a reasonable time and lodged complaint against the respondent and his family members for snatching her all ornaments. It has come in evidence that when she left the house, she left it with her father who was accompanied by his four friends, still no complaint regarding the alleged removal of ornaments was made and she kept quite for almost one and half year. Moreover, though the appellant has deposed that her ornaments were removed by the respondent and his family members, the father of the appellant who was also present with the appellant at that time, has not stated in his deposition about the alleged removal of ornaments. The appellant could have examined an independent witness, viz. one of the friends of her father who was present at the relevant time. The appellant has miserably failed to prove that she was not allowed to take away her Stridhan while leaving the house and it is still with the respondent and his family members. Learned counsel for the appellant took the Court through the relevant portion of the evidence in support of the appellant's claim regarding Stridhan. However, was satisfied that there is no evidence on record to hold that the appellant's stridhan was retained by the respondent when she left the matrimonial home last.  [Para 22]

heading: Constitution of India, Art.39
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Art.39 - Pension to two widows of Railway employee in equal shares - Validity.

Article 15 of the Constitution prohibits discrimination on the ground of sex, while Article 39 (a) provides for securing adequate means of livelihood for men and women equally. Article 39 (e) provides for ensuring health and strength for women. Keeping in mind the "Laxman Rekha" in the matter of interpretation of provisions of Personal Laws - qua the Constitution, the above constitutional provisions obligate the State for uplifting the women and secure descent living for them. Rule 75 provides for grant of pension even to the second wife/widow of a deceased railway servant along with first wife. This provision of Rule 75 made by the Indian Railways cannot be held to be in conflict or interdiction with Section 11 of the Hindu Marriage Act. On the contrary, for achieving the constitutional goal, as aforesaid, even for the unfortunate second wife/widow, Rule 75 provides for grant of pension to her for her survival in life. At any rate, it must be seen that by virtue of Rule 75, the payment of pension to the two widows is required to be made in equal share, which clearly shows that there is no burden on the treasury or the Indian Railways by inserting the said noble idea. There is no reason for us to hold that Rule 75 violates Section 11 of the Hindu Marriage Act, or that it is contrary to the Hindu Marriage Act, since it does not even remotely provides for any contradiction or interdiction therewith.    [Para 9]

heading: Lease finance agreement
HeadNote.description:
Lease finance agreement - Nature of.

Financial lease is a transaction current in the commercial world, the primary purpose whereof is the financing of the purchase by the financier. The purchase of assets or equipments or machinery is by the borrower. For all practical purposes, the borrower becomes the owner of the property inasmuch as it is the borrower who chooses the property to be purchased, takes delivery, enjoys the use and occupation of the property, bears the wear and tear, maintains and operates the machinery/equipment, undertakes indemnity and agrees to bear the risk of loss or damage, if any. He is the one who gets the property insured. He remains liable for payment of taxes and other charges and indemnity. He cannot recover from the lessor, any of the above mentioned expenses. The period of lease extends over and  covers the entire life of the property for which it may remain useful divided either into one term or divided into two terms with clause for renewal. In either case, the lease is non-cancellable.				 [Para 17]

HeadNote.act_name: Housing Board Haryana (Allotment Management and Sale of Tenements) Regulations (1972)
heading: Allotment of tenements
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Allotment of tenements - Demand of additional price from allottees - Validity - In view of bar contained in Cl.2(w) of Hire Purchase Tenancy Agreement, Board cannot demand additional price from allottees after 7 years of allotment of tenement irrespective of justification for such revision.

A conjoint reading of the allotment letter and clause 2 (w) of the Hire Purchase Tenancy Agreement, which every allottee is required to execute makes it clear that the price of the tenement specified in the allotment letter is tentative and the Board can revise the price after receiving final bills representing the cost of construction or if as a result of an order of the Court or an award made by the Arbitrator it is required to pay higher cost for the land used for construction of the tenements. In either case, the allottee is bound to pay the additional amount which would represent the final price of the tenement. If the cost of land is enhanced for any other similar reason then too the Board can revise the price and ask the allottees to pay additional price. In a given case, the Board may revise the tentative price more than once and the allottees are bound to share the burden of additional cost. However, the Board's power to revise the price of the tenements is hedged with the limitation of 7 years contained in clause 2(w) of the Hire Purchase Tenancy Agreement. That clause contained an express bar against the change in price after 7 years of the allotment of tenement. To put it differently, in view of the bar contained in clause 2(w) of the Hire Purchase Tenancy Agreement, the Board could not revise the price after 7 years of the allotment of tenement, irrespective of the justification for such revision. The Board's understanding of the prohibition contained in clause 2 (w) of the Hire Purchase Tenancy Agreement is evinced from Resolution dated 10.5.1989 wherein it was clearly mentioned that enhanced cost is not to be recovered from the allottees after 7 years from the date of allotment

While preparing the format of Hire Purchase Tenancy Agreement, the Board must have taken into consideration various factors which could lead to an increase in the cost of tenements and consciously incorporated a prohibition against change in the price after 7 years from the date of allotment of tenements. The rationale of this embargo was that once the allottee pays the total price, he may not be subjected to the burden of additional cost after a number of years. Surely, adjudication of the landowners' claim for higher compensation is not within the domain of the Board or the allottees but once the Board has, after due deliberations, incorporated a prohibition against change in the price after a period of 7 years from the allotment of tenements, there is no reason why it should not be asked to honour the commitment made to the allottees that they will not live under the fear of being asked to pay additional price after an indefinite period. The use of the expression 'or enhancement in cost of land on any account' after the expression 'the receipt of the final bill for the construction of tenements or as the result of land award or arbitration proceeding' shows that while framing the regulations, the Board had kept in view all the eventualities which could lead to an increase in the cost of land made available for construction of the tenements and yet it thought proper to put an embargo against the revision of price after 7 years. Therefore, the learned Single Judge and the Division Bench of the High Court were not right in deciding the writ petitions and the writ appeals on the premise that once the cost of land gets increased on account of payment of higher compensation to the landowners the Board is entitled to demand additional price from the allottees.  [Para 10,11,12]

heading: Guidelines by Govt.
Propriety
HeadNote.description:
Treatment of COVID-19 patients - Guidelines by Govt. - Advisory issued by Ministry of Ayush, dt.6-3-2020 - Observation by High Court - Propriety - Relevant Regulations clearly prohibits advertisement for solicitation of patients personally or advertisement in news papers by Homeopathic Practitioners - Therefore, they cannot advertise that they are competent to cure COVID-19 disease - Thus, observation by High Court that appropriate action be taken under provisions of Disaster Management Act 2005 against Homeopathic Medical practitioners who make any advertisement or prescribe any drugs or medicine as cure for COVID-19 disease - Cannot be approved.

When statutory regulations itself prohibit advertisement, there is no occasion for Homeopathic medical practitioners to advertise that they are competent to cure COVID-19 disease. When the Scientists of entire world are engaged in research to find out proper medicine/vaccine for COVID-19, the making of observation by High Court for taking appropriate action under provisions of Disaster Management Act 2005 against Homeopathic medical practitioners who make any advertisement or prescribes any drugs or medicine as cure for COVID-19 disease, cannot be approved. The Homeopathy does not cure the disease but it cures patients. (Paras 19, 20)

The guidelines issued by Govt. refer to Homeopathy medicines as medicines for prophylaxis, Amelioration and mitigation. The guidelines, however, specifically provides that “the prescription has to be given only by institutionally qualified practitioners”. The High Court in its impugned judgment has not fully comprehended the guidelines dated 06.03.2020 and taking a restricted view of the guidelines and have made observations for taking appropriate actions against the Homeopathic medical practitioners, which cannot be approved. The High Court, however, is right in its observation that no medical practitioner can claim that it can cure COVID-19. There is no such claim in other therapy including allopathy. The High Court is right in observing that no claim for cure can be made in Homeopathy. The Homeopathy is contemplated to be used in preventing and mitigating COVID-19 as is reflected by the advisory and guidelines issued by the Ministry of AYUSH. (Para 23)

heading: Succession Certificate
HeadNote.description:
Succession Certificate - In favour of widow of deceased - Widow not disqualified even if she remarries - As the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act, 1856 has been repealed, reliance placed on S.2 thereof is wholly misplaced.

It is true that section 2 of the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage Act 1856 inter alia stipulates that all rights and interests which any widow may have in her deceased husband's property by way of maintenance, or by inheritance or by virtue of any will or testamentary disposition conferring upon her, without express permission to re-marry only a limited interest in such property, with no power of alienating the same, shall upon her re-marriage cease and determine as if she had then died. This was obviously in a case where no express permission to re-marry was given. However, we find that the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act, 1856 was repealed by Parliament by enacting the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage (Repeal) Act, 1983. Therefore the reliance on section 2 of the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage Act, 1856 is wholly misplaced.

Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 inter alia stipulates that the property of a female Hindu is to be her absolute property. Section 14(1) categorically states that any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of the Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and not as a limited owner. The explanation to section 14(1) clarifies that property includes both movable and immovable property acquired by a female Hindu by inheritance or devise, or at a partition, or in lieu of maintenance or arrears of maintenance or by gift from any person, whether a relative or not, before, at or after her marriage, or by her own skill or exertion, or by purchase or by prescription, or in any other manner whatsoever etc. Provision in Hindu Succession Act, 1956 in pari materia with section 2 of the Hindu Widows' Re-Marriage Act, 1856. In other words, there is no provision that disqualifies a widow of a male Hindu from inheriting from her husband if she remarries, after his death.  [Para 5,8]

heading: Re-marriage of widowed mother
HeadNote.description: Re-marriage of widowed mother - Succession rights in son's property, whether lost - Re-marriage took place in 1952 - Son from first husband died intestate in 1972 - By virtue of S.8 of Hindu Succession Act, mother would inherit the property excluding other heirs (brothers herein) - She continues to be mother even after re-marriage - S.2 of Hindu Widow's Re-marriage Act, depriving mother of succession rights on re-marriage, shall not govern or regulate any future succession to which she may be entitled - Even assuming there is some inconsistency between S.8 of Succession Act and S.2 of Re-marriage Act, provisions of Hindu Succession Act would have overriding effect in view of its S.4 - Succession rights of mother, not lost. HeadNote.act_name: Hindu Women's Right to Property Act (1937)
heading: Entitlement of widow
HeadNote.description: Entitlement of widow - No partition between "V" and his son prior to death of "V" on 23-01-1934 - Though "V" died intestate he did not leave any separate property - It was only a coparcenery property in the hands of the son "C" after death of his father - Hence S.3 was not attracted so as to make widow of "V" entitled to even a limited interest in the property - Similarly after the death of 'C' in 1952, 'R' his mother and 'T' his sister had no right to succeed the estate left by "C". HeadNote.act_name: Hindu Women's Right to Property Act (1937)
heading: Partition suit
HeadNote.description:
Partition suit - Widow can file suit claiming share of husband in ancestral property of his joint family.

Section 3 (3) of Hindu Woman's Right to Property Act (1937) was enacted to give a right to a widow or a woman for demanding partition but the same was for a limited estate. However, with the advent of Act of 1956, which materially altered the Hindu Personal Law with regard to the succession, the widow has been placed as a Class I heir of her husband in the Schedule. In other words, by virtue of a widow being a Class I heir in the Schedule, under Act of 1956, she would be entitled to succeed to the entire share of her deceased husband in the joint property or ancestral property of the family with the same magnitude of estate, which her husband would have got had he been alive. In other words, her right to get an estate after the death of her husband like that of other coparceners in the family has been fully recognized and accepted by the Act of 1956. The concept of limited right or the concept of reversion after her death also stood abolished upon enactment of the Act of 1956 and as a result, she can deal with the property of her husband without any threat of reversion of her estate to the family of her husband. The right, that was given by Section 3 (3) of the Act of 1937, however, was of limited extent, in that, after her death, the property would revert back to the family of her husband. there is fallacy in the argument in that, Section 3 (3) provides for a right to file a suit for partition because there was no right at all in a widow even for her survival to get the property of her husband. In order that she must survive or must have some source of income for maintenance, Section 3 (3) was engrafted with a view to have her share but then in terms of the personal law of Hindus, a limited right was given to her. As against it, the Act of 1956 provides for a full right to a widow to the share of her deceased husband without any restriction of putting limited right or for dealing with share of her husband as per her choice.         [Para 17,24]

Sui juris means "one's own right." As discussed earlier, right to share has been given to a widow upon death of her husband as per the Act of 1956, which was as per Section 3 (3) of the Act of 1937 of limited nature. Hence, she can act sui juris.

2010(4) ALL MR 834 Held, per incuriam. 

AIR 1978 SC 1239 Disting.

(1992) 4 SCC 363, (1985) 2 SCC 321, (1991) 4 SCC 312, (1996) 8 SCC 525, (1994) 2 SCC 511, 1986 (2) SCC 511, (2002) 6 SCC 16, AIR 1962 SC 83, (2012) 3 SCC 495 Ref. to.         [Para 25,27]

HeadNote.act_name: Hindu Women's Right to Property Act (1937)
heading: Suit for partition by widow
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition by widow - Applicability of Hindu Women's Right to Property Act (1937) - Partition claimed relying on provisions of S.1(E) of Sangli Act - As per provisions of Sangli Act, upon death of husband of Hindu woman she becomes 'Sahabhagidar' in joint family property in place of her husband and entitled to claim partition - Provisions of Sangli Act would govern parties - Further, concept of limited estate contained in S.3(3) of Act 1937 does not find any reflection in provisions of Sangli Act - Provisions of Sangli Act would not be applicable to case of plaintiff-widow. 	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Homeopathic Practitioners (Professional Conduct Etiquette and Code of Ethics) Regulations (1982)
heading: Guidelines by Govt.
Propriety
HeadNote.description:
Treatment of COVID-19 patients - Guidelines by Govt. - Advisory issued by Ministry of Ayush, dt.6-3-2020 - Observation by High Court - Propriety - Relevant Regulations clearly prohibits advertisement for solicitation of patients personally or advertisement in news papers by Homeopathic Practitioners - Therefore, they cannot advertise that they are competent to cure COVID-19 disease - Thus, observation by High Court that appropriate action be taken under provisions of Disaster Management Act 2005 against Homeopathic Medical practitioners who make any advertisement or prescribe any drugs or medicine as cure for COVID-19 disease - Cannot be approved.

When statutory regulations itself prohibit advertisement, there is no occasion for Homeopathic medical practitioners to advertise that they are competent to cure COVID-19 disease. When the Scientists of entire world are engaged in research to find out proper medicine/vaccine for COVID-19, the making of observation by High Court for taking appropriate action under provisions of Disaster Management Act 2005 against Homeopathic medical practitioners who make any advertisement or prescribes any drugs or medicine as cure for COVID-19 disease, cannot be approved. The Homeopathy does not cure the disease but it cures patients. (Paras 19, 20)

The guidelines issued by Govt. refer to Homeopathy medicines as medicines for prophylaxis, Amelioration and mitigation. The guidelines, however, specifically provides that “the prescription has to be given only by institutionally qualified practitioners”. The High Court in its impugned judgment has not fully comprehended the guidelines dated 06.03.2020 and taking a restricted view of the guidelines and have made observations for taking appropriate actions against the Homeopathic medical practitioners, which cannot be approved. The High Court, however, is right in its observation that no medical practitioner can claim that it can cure COVID-19. There is no such claim in other therapy including allopathy. The High Court is right in observing that no claim for cure can be made in Homeopathy. The Homeopathy is contemplated to be used in preventing and mitigating COVID-19 as is reflected by the advisory and guidelines issued by the Ministry of AYUSH. (Para 23)

heading: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules (1955), Rr.58, 102
HeadNote.description:
Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules (1955), Rr.58, 102 - Property vesting in Govt. - Declaration under S.38E of Tenancy Act in favour of person - Has to be totally ignored - Property is unencumbered in hands of Govt.

In view of S.102A of Tenancy Act the land which is vested in the Government and which is held by the Government, has to be left out of consideration while applying the provisions of the Tenancy Act, 1950, to any land. In short, the provisions of the Tenancy Act are to be made applicable to the land held by the Government. It is not in dispute that the property in question, no doubt, stood vested in the Government, in pursuance of the provisions of the 1950 Act and, therefore, even if there happened to be a declaration under section 38E of the Tenancy Act in favour of the petitioner, that has to be totally ignored while applying the provisions of the 1950 Act and 1954 Act. Thus, even though a declaration is there in favour of the petitioner, that will have to be totally ignored for all practical purposes and the property will have to be held to be totally unencumbered into the hands either of the Custodian or the Settlement Commissioner under the provisions of 1950 Act or manager under the provisions of 1954 Act.					 [Para 13]

heading: Accident claim
HeadNote.description: Accident claim - Deceased aged 47 years died while riding as pillion rider on motorcycle due to accident between motorcycle and dumper - Income of deceased was taken as Rs.23,123/- p.m. - 30% added towards future prospects - Considering age of deceased, multiplier of 13 applied - After deducting 1/3rd towards personal expenses, loss of dependency comes to Rs.31,26,229.60/- - Claimants also awarded Rs.70,000/- towards conventional heads - Claimants held entitled to total compensation of Rs.31,96,230/- with interest at 9% p.a. subject to filing of affidavit that they have not received any amount towards financial assistance under Rules of 2006.
