heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Grounds of cruelty and adultery - Husband alleged that wife refused to do household work and even to share bed with him - That, she used to leave home without informing anybody and she also had illicit relations with another man - To prove illicit relation, hostel mate of wife (during studies) was examined - However, except stating about behaviour of respondent, witness provided no link about illicit relationship - In any case, matter of adultery cannot be considered without impleading alleged adulterer - As regards alleged behaviour of respondent, no cogent evidence produced - Mere aggressive behaviour or sadness of wife does not mean that she is spoiling matrimonial life - Nuptial knots cannot be broken on unfounded allegations - Petition dismissed. 2015 (2) R.C.R. (Civil) 871, 2007 ALL SCR 881 Ref.to.	(Paras 7, 14, 16, 17)

heading: Succession proceedings
Admission of plaintiff
HeadNote.description:
Succession proceedings - Admission of plaintiff - Admission opposed to law, would not come in the way of the plaintiff.

The question in respect of title or succession to the property is a matter which can be dealt with by the Civil Court and in view of provisions of Section 12 of the Act, decision of the Civil Court in respect of question of succession will prevail over the decision of Atiyat Court.  In the instant matter, in view of the law governing entitlement to the estate, it is to be noted that defendants, who are successors of deceased Noorbi who died during life time of Ajijabi, cannot claim any right or entitlement to the property left by deceased Ajijabi.  The question in respect of entitlement of the plaintiff or defendants by considering provisions of personal law governing the rights by way of succession is a domain of the Civil Court.  The Civil Court is, therefore, the only forum for rendering decision in that regard.  The alleged admission given in the succession proceedings is opposed to the law and as such, would not come in the way of the plaintiff.  [Para 17]

In this view of the matter, admission of deceased plaintiff recorded in succession proceedings would not be an impediment in her way in claiming her right, entitlement in respect of disputed property on the basis of succession as well as on the basis of personal law governing the parties. (1977)2 SCC 49 and (1977)3 SCC 540 - Ref. to.	 [Para 21]

heading: Suit filed under Tenancy Act claiming possession of lands from defendant tenant
HeadNote.description:
Suit filed under Tenancy Act claiming possession of lands from defendant tenant - On failure to obtain possession plaintiff filing suit under Act of 1952 - Defendant tenant is entitled to protection under Govt. circular.

The petitioners plaintiff instituted proceedings under the Hyderabad Tenancy Act. They claimed possession from defendant on the ground that the petitioners were landlords and defendant was the tenant. The possession was claimed on the ground of failure to pay rent. Having failed to secure possession, Petitioners filed the suit under Hyderabad Atiyat Inquiries Act, 1952. In the earlier proceedings, Petitioners did not plead non applicability of Hyderabad Tenancy Act. In the earlier proceedings, the petitioners did not claim that the lands were service Inam lands. In the earlier proceedings, Petitioners did not plead that defendant was not entitled to claim tenancy rights as the lands in question were service Inam lands. In the earlier proceedings defendant was admitted to be a tenant. Under the circumstances, it was not open to the Petitioners to plead that the lands in question were service Inam lands and, therefore, defendant was not entitled to the status of being a tenant. The Atiyat Deputy Collector erred, therefore, in coming to the conclusion that defendant was not a tenant.  [Para 6]

On scrutiny of the provisions of the Hyderabad Tenancy Act, the Hyderabad Abolition of Inam Act and Hyderabad Atiyat Inquiries Act, it is clear that there is no bar on creation of tenancy by the Inamdar under the three enactments. On the contrary, the Hyderabad Tenancy Act divides the tenants into protected tenants and ordinary tenants. Tenants falling under sections 34, 37 or 37-A are protected tenants while others are ordinary tenants. In the circumstances, the Circular dated 9/8/1955 seeks to protect the tenants who are cultivating Inam Lands. Hence, although the Circular does not confer status of tenant on a person, still, in cases where the cultivator is in possession for last several years, security of tenor is granted to such cultivator on his payment of rent. In the circumstances, it could not be contended by the Petitioners that the Circular overrides section 102A of the Hyderabad Tenancy Act. Defendant as an ordinary tenant, was certainly entitled to be protected from eviction. Hence, in such cases, the Circular is squarely applicable.  [Para 6]

heading: Service inam lands
HeadNote.description:
Service inam lands - Grant of lease after coming into force of Act is illegal - Lessee need not be heard before those lands are leased out by authorities.

Any person who has obtained lease from the Inamdar after coming into force of the Act cannot be called as lawfully inducted tenant on the land, because section 6 of the Act prohibits any such transfer. Section 5 of the Act makes a provision that opportunity be given to the holder of Atiyat grant before taking any steps under section 5 of the Act. A tenant inducted by the holder of the land, therefore, has no right to claim hearing under section 5 of the said Act.   [Para 10,14]

Therefore, the lessee cannot seek protection of Govt. circular dated 9-8-1955. The authorities are competent to lease the lands on yearly basis.  [Para 15]

heading: Decisions of Atiyat Collector and Deputy Collector
HeadNote.description: Decisions of Atiyat Collector and Deputy Collector - Appeal and revisions before Revenue Tribunal - Notification conferring jurisdiction issued and published in Official Gazette - Jurisdiction can be said to have been conferred legally - Amendment in Schedule to Code is not necessary - Appeal or revision could not be dismissed on ground of want of jurisdiction.	(Para 9, 11)

heading: Perpetual injunction
HeadNote.description: Perpetual injunction - To restrain defendants from interfering in possession of plaintiff - Plaintiff claiming possession on basis of lease/Batai Patra executed by one of defendants - Property was joint family property of defendants - As such when person is having an undivided share in any land he cannot create valid lease in favour of anybody so long as land is not divided by metes and bounds - One of defendants cannot transfer land to plaintiff - Plaintiff fails to prove his exclusive possession - Injunction cannot be granted. 		(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Jurisdiction of Civil Court
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Question relating to succession, legitimacy, divorce or other questions of personal law - Decision of Civil Court shall have a binding effect and will prevail over the decision of Atiyat Court.		(Para 14)

heading: Service inam land
HeadNote.description:
Service inam land - Property leased to tenant by Inamdar - Resignation tendered by Inamdar - Atiyat Deputy Collector directing resumption of land and appointment of Pujari - No notice given to tenant - Order is illegal. 

The Atiyat Court created under the Act is vested with powers to appoint a successor, whenever the succession opens and, therefore, the condition is that the succession will be regulated by the personal law applicable to the last holder. So, it is the duty of the Atiyat Deputy Collector to find out who was the successor as per the personal law applicable to last holder for appointment as Archak or Inamdar. That function cannot be delegated to the Tahsildar. On making such appointment as successor , the function of the Atiyat Court would have come to an end, which was started on the basis of resignation of last holder. At that time, at that stage, there was no reason for the Atiyat Deputy Collector to go into the question whether tenant was legally inducted as tenant and whether he should be dispossessed from the land in question. However, without any reason, the Atiyat Deputy Collector also passed the order that the land be taken into possession and it be leased out on yearly basis by auction.The State Government gets a right to resume the Atiyat grant by following the provisions of section 5 of the said Act. But, here, there was no enquiry under section 5 of the said Act and therefore there was no question of resuming the grant by the Government. The grant was not resumed. On the contrary, it was contemplated to appoint some another Archak or Pujari to render the services to the deity. So, when there was no resumption of the grant,the Government had no authority to take the land in possession or to dispossess Punjaba, the tenant of the land.  [Para 12]

Further, the bar created against lease of such land comes into force after 1952 Act and it does not apply to leases granted in 1948 i.e. prior to 1952.  [Para 14]

HeadNote.description:

In case there is any decision of the Civil Court, which takes a different view than the decision of the Atiyat Court, in that case only the decision of Civil Court shall have the binding effect and would prevail over division of Atiyat court. HeadNote.act_name: Haryana Urban (Control of Rent and Eviction) Act (1973)
heading: Distinction between
HeadNote.description:
Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act (1965), S.20 - Tamil Nadu Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act (1960), S.25 - Revisional jurisdiction and appellate jurisdiction - Distinction between - Revisional power is not and cannot be equated with power of reconsideration of all questions of facts as a Court of first appeal. 

Neither Haryana and Tamil Nadu nor Kerla Rent Control Acts entitles the High Court to interfere with the findings of fact recorded by the First Appellate Court/First Appellate Authority because on re-appreciation of the evidence, its view is different from the Court/Authority below. The consideration or examination of the evidence by the High Court in revisional jurisdiction under these Acts is confined to find out that finding of facts recorded by the Court/Authority below is according to law and does not suffer from any error of law. A finding of fact recorded by Court/Authority below, if perverse or has been arrived at without consideration of the material evidence or such finding is based on no evidence or misreading of the evidence or is grossly erroneous that, if allowed to stand, it would result in gross miscarriage of justice, is open to correction because it is not treated as a finding according to law. In that event, the High Court in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction under the above Rent Control Acts shall be entitled to set aside the impugned order as being not legal or proper. The High Court is entitled to satisfy itself the correctness or legality or propriety of any decision or order impugned before it as indicated above. However, to satisfy itself to the regularity, correctness, legality or propriety of the impugned decision or the order, the High Court shall not exercise its power as an appellate power to re-appreciate or re-assess the evidence for coming to a different finding on facts. Revisional power is not and cannot be equated with the power of reconsideration of all questions of fact as a court of first appeal. Where the High Court is required to be satisfied that the decision is according to law, it may examine whether the order impugned before it suffers from procedural illegality or irregularity.

(1993) 1 SCC 499 Approved.

1995 Supp (4) SCC 675 (1999) 5 SCC 645, (1999) 7 SCC 275 Rel. on.

(2000) 2 SCC 135 Explained.      [Para 45]

heading: University Grants Commission Act (1956), S.22
HeadNote.description:
University Grants Commission Act (1956), S.22 - Appellant after completion of professional course LCEH, i.e. Licentiate of the court of Examiners in Homeopathy took admission to LL.B. course conducted by university of Bombay - Appellant after surrendering LCEH certificate applied for getting herself enrolled as Advocate - Bar Council informed her that LCEH not being equivalent to gradation she cannot be recognized by Bar Council of India - Held, Bar Council of India rightly refused enrollment because pursuing law and practicing law are two different things - One can pursue law but for the purpose of obtaining license to practice, he or she must fulfill all the requirements and conditions prescribed by the Bar Council of India. 

(1994) 2 SCC 102 Ref. to.	(Para 31)

HeadNote.description: Power to appoint medical inspector - As per S.17 of Homeopathy Central Council Act (1973), said power is with Central Council of Homeopathy - Order of Division Bench of High Court holding that power to appoint medical inspectors is with Central Govt. as per Regn.3(5) of Regulations of 2013, improper - No such power conferred upon Central Govt. either under Regn.3(5) of 2013 Regulations or any other provisions of Act of 1973. 	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Refusal of permission
Validity
HeadNote.description: Increase in intake capacity in B.H.M.S. Course - Refusal of permission - Validity - Permission to increase intake capacity is refused due to non fulfilling criteria as per Homeopathy Central Council Regulation, 2013 - Implementation of said regulation was postponed and as per amnesty scheme, time was given to remove deficiencies - Opportunity for rectification of deficiencies ought to have been given before refusing permission - No such opportunity was given - Refusal of permission to increase admission capacity, not proper. (Paras 8, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Appointment
Approval
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Arts.226, 227, 14, 21A - Appointment - Approval - Petitioner running school for handicapped students - Petitioner appointed five staff members in view of GR dated 18.8.2004 to create new staff pattern - As against sanctioned strength of 40 students, only 26 students were there for whom 20 staff members were engaged by petitioner - Proposal for approval was sent first time in 2012 when first appointment was shown to be made in 2010 - Further, no post of cook was available even in new staffing pattern, appointment is given on such post when one cook was already working with petitioner - Petitioner was expected to first obtain sanction for post but had not done so - In one writ petition, directions given for absorption of surplus teacher first and after absorption of surplus staff, permission of Commissioner of Handicapped Welfare Office was required to be taken to appoint new staff - No such procedure was followed - Appointments made are in contravention of Arts.14 and 16 - By falsely showing strength of students and by misusing provisions of Rules and Code, petitioner-management has obtained public money - Case is glaring instance of misuse of process of law - Order rejecting approval to appointments, proper.  (2017) 14 SCC 1 Disting.  2008 ALL SCR 134, (2008) 5 SCC 241, (2011) 3 SCC 436, 2004(5) ALL MR 123 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 13, 14, 16, 17, 18, 19, 21)
